HEADLINE: OIL SURGE: CONSUMERS ALREADY TAKING A BEATING;
Mortgage Rates Up a Quarter-Point in Just a Few Days

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Home mortgage interest rates, which last week were hovering just above 10 percent, have increased quickly in recent days, following the yields on Treasury bonds onto higher ground.
A rapid series of increases in mortgage rates totaling more than a quarter of a percentage point in the last few days is a reminder of how the effect of higher oil prices spreads through the American economy. ''These rates are probably high enough to put a damper on activity in the housing market,'' said Thomas M. Holloway, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
An increase of one-quarter point on a 10 percent $100,000 mortgage would increase monthly payments by $18.53, to $896.10 a month. 
Since last Wednesday, before Iraq invaded Kuwait, oil prices have increased about $8 a barrel, causing economists and investors to expect a rise of half a percentage point or more in inflation over the next year. Expectations of higher inflation have caused interest rates on long-term Treaury bonds to rise almost half a percentage point, which has pulled up rates on home mortgages.
 
Two Increases in a Day
At Countrywide Credit Industries Inc. of Pasadena, Calif., the nation's largest independent mortgage lender, rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages were raised twice yesterday. The rate at the end of the day was 10.33 percent, up from 10.14 percent late Friday and about 10.08 percent last Wednesday.
Although other mortgage lenders' rates vary slightly, the upward trend has been the same.
''We take in about $20 million of mortgage applications a day and have to adjust our rates to reflect changes in the prices at which we can sell the mortgages,'' said Stan Kurland, chief financial officer at Countrywide. Mortgage banking firms, like banks, savings and loan associations and other lenders, package mortages into securities, which are then sold to pension funds and other investors as higher-yielding alternatives to Treasury bonds.
On days like yesterday, when rates are rising rapidly, Mr. Kurland said, the firm expects to receive a greater than normal volume of applications. ''A lot of mortgage brokers and real estate agents will see yields moving higher and decide to push through as many applications as they can, before rates move up more,'' Mr. Kurland said.
To avoid the risk of losing money when interest rates are rising, mortgage lenders frequently adjust rates charged to homebuyers. The lenders are vulnerable to a loss if, for example, a loan was made at 10 percent but sold to investors at a higher interest rate of 10.50 percent 75 days later -after the mortgage application has been processed and the loan placed with similar mortgages into a package of securities.
 
Housing Already Weak
The mortgage rate increases come at a time when activity in the housing market has already been depressed, with high vacancy rates in many parts of the country, a slowdown in economic growth that is threatening to become a recession and greater caution among bank lenders, many of whom have been hurt by defaults on loans to developers.
Commerce Department data show that housing starts fell for five consecutive months, to an annual rate in June of just 1.18 million units, the lowest level in nearly eight years. Sales of new homes have also been depressed, but they improved slightly in June, thanks to a decline in interest rates that began in April. ''But now we are moving back to nearly the same rates as April, so I expect a negative response by consumers,'' said Mr. Holloway, the economist.
Interest rates on 30-year conventional, fixed-rate mortgages, which are not backed by any Government guarantee or insurance, such as those quoted by Countrywide, remain lower than average rates charged earlier this year. According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a Congressionally chartered but privately owned agency that buys mortgages and sells mortgage-backed securities, the average interest rate in May was nearly 11 percent.
Treasury bond yields closed yesterday at 8.79 percent, up nearly half a percentage point since last Wednesday and the highest since May 10.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 93.31 points, or 3.3 percent, to 2,716.34, its biggest one-day decline since Oct. 13, 1989, when it fell 6.9 percent, or 190.58 points, to 2,569.26. Volume was 240 million shares, with declines exceeding advances by a ratio of roughly 6 to 1.
In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei average fell 916.23 points or 3.1 percent, to 28,599.53, yesterday. The average dropped quickly in the morning session again today but rebounded somewhat in the afternoon and closed down another 946.17 points or 3.31 percent, at 27,984.29. 
Yesterday's decline in New York followed a 55-point tumble in the Dow on Friday and an 88-point overall loss for last week.
The anxiety over inflation also caused a plunge in long-term Treasury prices. The yield of the benchmark 8.75 percent bond maturing in 2020 climbed to 8.79 percent, the highest in almost three months and nearly a quarter percentage point above Friday's close. As stock prices tumbled however, investors shifted funds to Treasury bills and other short-term investments, causing bill rates to fall to their lowest levels since 1988. [Page D14.] Oil stocks continued to move higher on the prospects of rising prices, while declining issues included transportation stocks, which are sensitive to oil prices, and utilities and banking issues, which are sensitive to higher interest rates.
Officials of the New York Stock Exchange held a briefing to calm concerns about how the exchange and its member firms withstood yesterday's sell-off.
Richard Torrenzano, an executive vice president of the Big Board, told reporters that all the computer systems for executing trades were operating without difficulty. He said that market ''circuit breakers,'' which delay or halt some trading in times of big declines, appeared to have steadied the market.
 
Confusion on Index Trading
Some traders asserted, however, that new rules made trading in stock index futures even more volatile than they otherwise would have been and left many traders confused because they were uncertain how markets would act after the rule went into effect. [Market Place, page D8.] At the opening of trading in New York, the stock market reacted swiftly to the sharply lower Asian and European markets. The beginning of trading in many stocks, including several of the 30 issues of the Dow Jones average, was delayed.
In the first few hours, the Dow average dropped more than 107 points, as rumors spread that Saudi Arabian troops were headed for the Kuwaiti border. The rumor was later denied by the Saudi Press Agency.
By noon, the market had recovered some earlier losses, but was still down more than 80 points on about 190 million shares traded. As volume slowed in the afternoon, the Dow lost only about 13 more points for the day.
Traders at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company noted that institutional investors, who normally trade in large blocks of stocks that require special handling, were active in the market but that there was no panic.
''There is scattered selling and the institutions are picking their spots to buy or sell,'' one trader said late in the day. ''The blocks are ordinary and there were none of any real size.''
Similarly, some brokerage firms reported that retail selling was busy, but not extraordinarily so. Declines were broad, with what are normally lower-volume stocks suffering as well as widely traded issues. On the American Stock Exchange, which includes many oil companies that rose in price because they are expected to benefit from higher oil prices, the index was off by only 1.83 percent, or 6.36 points, to 340.27. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.17 percent, or 17.42 points, to 400.04, its lowest level in more than a year. On March 20, 1989, it closed at 398.50.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 334.43, down 10.43 points, its lowest level since May 1, when it was 332.25.
The new ''circuit breaker'' rule on the Big Board, which was used for the first time on Friday, came into play again yesterday. When the Dow falls more than 50 points, the rule restricts traders who use computer programs to initiate sell orders. Such program traders are not permitted to sell stock on a downtick, which is when a stock's last sale is lower than the one before.
The rule is part of a package of measures the stock exchange approved earlier in the year to try to curb market volatility.
As a result of the those rules, there were far fewer program trades than normal yesterday. Program traders were in the market only twice, to buy and not to sell, said Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity.
The effect of both trades added 21.04 points to the Dow. The first program, from 10:25 A.M. to 10:30 A.M., added 18.07 points, and another from 1.59 P.M. to 2:03 P.M. added 2.97.
 
Top 10 Gainers
Among the top 10 gainers on the Big Board yesterday were ARCO, up 3 1/2 to 137 1/8; Great Northern Iron, up 3, to 56 1/4; Oryx Energy, up 2 5/8, to 54 5/8, and Phillips Petroleum, up 1, to 82.
Some of the top losers included UAL, down 12 1/2, to 110. An employee-led buyout of the airline company is still reported to have financing problems, but there is speculation that the company's board may agree to extend by a day or two the Aug. 9 deadline for a financing package.
Walt Disney was down 7 1/8, to 102 3/8, following a recommendation by a First Boston analyst to hold instead of buy the stock because of lower projected 1991 per-share earnings.
If the economy slips into recession, entertainment stocks are considered among the first to be affected. Time Warner, another entertainment concern, hit a new low during the day of 83 5/8, closing down 6 3/8, to 83 3/4.
Phelps Dodge, the big mining company, closed down 5 1/8, to 62 5/8, and Warner-Lambert, the pharmaceuticals and consumer products company, closed down 5, at 62 1/2.
 
Tokyo Stocks Drop
By Reuters
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 7 (Reuters) - Tokyo stocks regained in the afternoon some of the morning's sharp declines. Brokers said a flood of futures arbitrage-related index buying brought the Nikkei average of 225 stocks back up to 27,653.07, which was 946.46 points or 3.31 percent below Monday's close.
The average fell quickly after the opening, dropping 1,327.67 points at the midday recess over over fears that rising oil prices will cause serious problems for the oil-dependent Japanese economy.
Volume was a thin 150 million shares by midday, against 170 million on Monday morning. Volatility from light trading had already been exaggerating market declines in the two weeks before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday drove up oil prices sharply.

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Pfeiffer of Compaq;
The PC Surge In West Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The European Community's program to turn its 12 nations into a single market is creating a bonanza for makers of personal computers in general and for the Compaq Computer Corporation in particular. Analysts expect the Western European personal computer market to grow by as much as 25 percent this year - twice the pace of the more mature American market - as businesses try to improve their efficiency.
Compaq, which is based in Houston and is the second-largest personal computer company in Europe, behind only I.B.M., may do even better. Its European sales, which now account for about half of corporate sales, could total $1.8 billion or more this year, up at least 50 percent from last year's $1.17 billion. 
In a telephone interview from Boston, where he was talking to securities analysts, Eckhard Pfeiffer, the 48-year-old West German who is president of Compaq's Munich-based international operations, discussed his strategy for maintaining high growth in Europe.
Q. Compaq's European sales are growing two to three times as fast as the market. What is your secret?
A. We have been continually expanding our geographical marketing coverage and we're positioned in all the major growth product areas. We now have almost 1,500 dealers in Europe and they are in all countries in Western Europe. Although we have major accounts managers, we sell exclusively through our authorized dealers.
I.B.M. has a large dealer base but also sells directly, very much to the annoyance of dealers. So does Olivetti. It's an advantage for us and to their detriment. In most cases, an end user needs a whole range of hardware, software, service, training and supplies. No single hardware supplier can provide that.
Apple, which is now third in Europe, has tried to create a dealer network that handles Apple only. We believe very strongly that you have to provide a customer with more than one choice.
Q. How about your product line?
A. In PC's, we're in the high-performance segment, with our Deskpro machines based on Intel's 386 processor.
We're extremely well-positioned in laptops and have taken a strong position against Toshiba since 1988. Laptops, which account for 12 to 15 percent of the PC market in units, should be growing in the 70 percent range this year. And our Systempro computer, which has minicomputer capability and which is largely used for networks as file servers, is the highest-performing product on the market today.
Q. What kind of annual growth do you anticipate for the PC market in Western Europe?
A. We have a healthy economic climate in Western Europe, with the exception of the United Kingdom, and there's gigantic investment. We estimate the size of the market in 1990 will be six million units. It will continue to grow in the 20 percent range over the next three to four years, but that doesn't mean we have to slow to that level.
Q. How do you deal with the corporations that want a supplier who can service them on a pan-European basis?
A. If we're involved with a major account, we let the major account know which dealer is available to service it in the country required.
The dealer industry in Europe is very different from the industry in the United States, where almost 80 percent of distribution goes through chains. But Computerland is pretty well operational in all countries today. Businessland is trying. And we're beginning to see European channels made up of joint ventures - like the International Computer Group, a joint venture of British, French and German companies.
Q. How quickly do you see the PC market in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union developing?
A. We conservatively estimate that the industry may ship 250,000 to 300,000 units to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in 1990. It could be a 750,000 to one million market in 1991.
Given monetary union, East Germany will grow the fastest because it now has a hard currency to make investments and to create a free-market system. The second-largest opportunity is clearly Russia, although it obviously depends upon what happens politically and economically there.
Q. How are you trying to establish yourself in the East?
A. We now have about 18 dealers selling in East Germany. Robotron, the East Germany state computer company, is dissolving into many entities. We have been meeting with people in the parts that would be in the PC end but don't have final agreements at this time.
East Germany was firmly embedded as one of the major computer suppliers to the Comecon countries. That role has to be somewhat maintained. It is not going to happen with the old Robotron but with what is coming out of Robotron. We have already seen nice-sized orders coming in from East Germany that are going to be shipped out into other countries.
We recently announced our first dealer partners in Yugoslavia. We've started the dealer-selection process in Hungary. And we're beginning to establish contacts in Poland and Czechoslovakia.

HEADLINE: Commodity Chief Approved

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The Senate has approved the renomination of Wendy Lee Gramm as the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
By a voice vote on Saturday, the Senate confirmed Mrs. Gramm, who is 45 years old, as the top Federal regulator of the futures industry for a new five-year term. Mrs. Gramm became head of the agency under President Reagan in February 1988 and was renominated to the post by President Bush. She is an economist and the wife of Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas.
 
One of the issues confronting
Mrs. Gramm is final Congressional action on legislation to reauthorize the commodity agency. The bill, which would increase the agency's budget and regulatory power, has been held up in the Senate because of a turf battle between the agency and the Securities and Exchange Commission over the regulation of stock index futures.
Mrs. Gramm also faces the challenge of intense industry opposition to the agency's proposed rule to restrict the practice of dual trading, in which a floor broker makes simultaneous trades both for customer accounts and for his or her own account, creating potentially serious conflicts of interest.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Urged to Make Major Computer Effort

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The United States should undertake a major effort to develop superconducting computers that can operate a million times faster than today's fastest machines, a national panel recommends.
The recommendation is in a report now being completed by the National Commission on Superconductivity, a group of industry, academic and Government officials established by Congress in 1988 to advise it and the President on national strategies in superconductivity.
The full report, being sent to the President on Tuesday, has not been made public, but the executive summary has been released. 
The report said it should be possible, using superconductors, to develop a ''petaflop'' computer, capable of performing a million billion mathematical operations a second. The fastest supercomputers today now perform about a billion operations per second, which is known as a ''gigaflop.'' The term ''flop'' refers to a ''floating point operation,'' a type of arithmetic calculation.
Superconductors are materials that conduct electricity without losing energy through resistance. They could make possible extremely fast computers, super-efficient electricity generators and transmission systems and powerful electromagnets that could be used in such applications as trains that would float above their tracks magnetically and travel at high speeds. However, these applications will not be feasible for at least a decade, experts say.
Superconductivity could once be achieved only by freezing certain metal alloys to temperatures near absolute zero, about 460 degrees below zero Fahrenheit. New materials discovered several years ago are superconducting at temperatures as high as 235 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.
 
National Program Is Urged
The discovery of the ''high-temperature'' superconductors set off a flurry of work around the world and has led to numerous calls for a national program to help the United States stay competitive with the Japanese and Europeans.
The commission's report agrees in many ways with previous reports by a Presidential advisory panel known as the ''Wise Men'' and by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.
It states that the effort by American industry to exploit the new superconductors is ''insufficient, especially compared to Japan, where it is twice as large.'' High interest rates and unfavorable tax policy make it difficult for American companies to undertake projects that will only pay off in the distant future, if they pay off at all, the report says.
The report does not, however, recommend an increase in Federal financing, which it says is adequate. An increase in Federal money could not ''be spent sensibly at this point,'' David W. McCall, the commission chairman and head of the chemical research laboratory at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories, said in an interview.
Instead of more money, the commission is recommending that superconductor research efforts be focused on two particular goals.
One is the development of the petaflop computer, which the report said would have broad uses in areas like weather prediction and aircraft design, as well as military uses like target identification and cryptography. Such a goal might be controversial because some computer experts think computers using conventional silicon chips are gaining in speed so quickly that superconducting computers, which require special refrigeration, might never be economically feasible.
The other goal is to develop wires made out of the high-temperature superconductors that would be suitable for use in motors, magnets, generators and energy storage systems. One big obstacle in harnessing the new superconductors is that they have been difficult to make into wires that are malleable enough and that carry enough current for practical uses.

HEADLINE: Productivity Rise First in Six Quarters

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in six quarters, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department said today.
Analysts said they were encouraged by the gain in nonfarm productivity - defined as output per hour of work - especially in light of recent data showing rising unemployment and stagnant economic growth.
''It's one tiny bright spot in the midst of a lot of negatives,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. 
But economists said the 1.6 percent gain was still below the level needed to lift the standard of living of Americans sharply and improve the nation's ability to compete.
 
Jump in Hourly Labor Costs
They also were disturbed by the report's findings on hourly labor costs, an important measure of inflation for businesses. Those costs rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent in the second quarter of 1990, well above the 3 percent rise for all of 1989.
''The inflation numbers for the rest of the year look horrible, especially with the shock of the Middle East oil crisis,'' said Michael K. Evans, who heads a Washington economic forecasting firm.
The productivity rise in the second quarter was the first increase since productivity climbed five-tenths of a percent in the final quarter of 1988, the Labor Department said.
Although the report offered good news on the performance of American workers in the April-June period, the department said revised figures for last year showed productivity actually fell three-tenths of a percent rather than increased nine-tenths, as first reported.
 
Worst Since 1981-82 Recession
The poor 1989 showing was the worst since nonfarm productivity dropped nine-tenths of a percent in the 1981-82 recession, the Government said.
The report showed that from April to June, the number of hours Americans worked fell by a tenth of a percent, a likely sign that workers were being laid off in the face of slower economic growth and businesses were not hiring as many new workers, analysts said.
In revising numbers for the first quarter of 1990, the agency offered slightly better figures, saying productivity fell 1.9 percent rather than the 2.7 percent plunge first reported.
Today's report showed that unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 3.9 percent for the April-June period, compared with a 3.3 percent increase in all of 1989.

HEADLINE: Dollar Loses Draw as Safe Haven in Time of Crisis

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar, a longtime haven for investors in times of military and political crisis, has been all but shunned since Iraq invaded Kuwait.
Stock and bond markets around the world dropped sharply yesterday, and news reports indicated that Iraq had taken American hostages and may be building up forces along the Saudi Arabian border. But the dollar did not rise against the major European currencies; in New York it actually fell at one point below its lowest post-World War II close against the German mark of 1.57. [Page D16.] The dollar rose only against the Japanese yen. But the yen has been weaker than the dollar all year, and its fall yesterday was considered a flight from the yen, not a retreat to the dollar. 
''I don't think the dollar has any safe-haven attractiveness right now,'' said Claude Tygier, a foreign exchange specialist, partly because of the unattractiveness of the United States economy right now.
Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, added, ''If you call this a flight to quality, you have to call it a flight to the Deutsche mark.''
 
No Big Flight to Gold
Gold has also lost a little of its luster as a haven. It rose $7.30 an ounce yesterday, to $384.70 in New York, but that is still below the high of $386 it reached on the day of the invasion, when it jumped $12.
''If you are sitting here in the West, gold is not necessarily the safe haven,'' said Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse in New York. ''But still, for many countries in the third world, it is the only safe haven they've got.''
The fall of stock and bond markets yesterday, which was worldwide, was a response to rising oil prices, which were pushed even higher by the growing embargo on buying Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The higher oil prices, if they are maintained, will increase inflation and cause the rate of economic growth to slow as discretionary spending is reduced. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil rose $3.56 a barrel, to $28.05.
Long-term interest rates around the world are also rising sharply in anticipation of higher inflation, which is another blow for stock markets.
In Japan, which imports virtually all its oil, the Nikkei 225 index of the Tokyo stock exchange yesterday slid 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, to 28,599.53 and continued to fall today. At yesterday's close, the index, which was tumbling before the invasion, was down 13.5 percent since July 19 and just above its low for the year of 28,002.07, set April 2. But volume was thin, at 330 million shares, which some traders said indicated that the selling was not done in panic. Interest rates on Japan's benchmark 10-year bond rose 26 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.96 percent.
In Hong Kong, the decline was even steeper, with the Hang Seng Index down 248 points, or 7.42 percent. In Germany, the DAX index dropped 100.01 points, or 5.4 percent, hitting its low for the year of 1,740.93. The yield on Germany's 10-year bond rose 10 basis points, to 8.88 percent.
In France, the blue-chip index, known as the CAC-40, fell 5.12 percent, to its lowest close of the year at 1,773.79. The FTSE-100 index in London faired a little better, falling only 64 points, or 2.82 percent, while the yield on the 10-year gilt, its benchmark bond, rose 30 basis points, to 11.88 percent.
Even in Norway, where oil revenues account for about a quarter of the economic growth, the stock market fell 5.2 percent because of the fear of inflation rising worldwide and slowing economic growth, traders said.
One of the main reasons for the apparent change in attitude about the dollar as a haven is that the United States economic situation, especially with a sharp rise in oil prices, is all negative for the dollar.
Virtually all recent economic statistics suggest that a recession is now more likely, which would mean lower interest rates as the Federal Reserve seeks to avoid an even sharper economic decline. Lower rates and a recession both make dollar-denominated investments less attractive. Higher oil prices also mean rising inflation, another negative for the dollar. And with an energy tax increase a less likely alternative for reducing the Federal budget deficit, the nagging deficit issue looks much harder to resolve.
By contrast, the outlook in Germany is much healthier, even counting the rise in oil prices. The economy is growing and there is general confidence that the Bundesbank, the nation's central bank, will work to restrain the impact of inflation from the unification of the two Germanys and a lasting oil price increase. And because of higher oil prices, the Bundesbank is considered even more likely now to raise interest rates, which will make the mark even more attractive than it is now.
''It seems unlikely that the Germans will face any significant policy dilemma,'' said John Lipsky, director of international bond research for Salomon Brothers in London.
Mr. Tygier, foreign exchange specialist, said that another reason for the apparentchange in attitude toward the dollar is the relative ease and speed with which money can be moved around the world now because of deregulation of many markets.
Mr. Lipsky said that the United States still has the characteristics of a haven currency: a very large and open market and political stability. But he said that the markets in other countries, like West Germany and Switzerland, have grown and are beginning to make them alternative havens.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Slide On Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar lost more ground yesterday against all primary foreign currencies except the Japanese yen amid speculation that recent signs of economic weakness will lead to lower United States interest rates.
But the drop was tempered by uncertainties about Iraq's occupation of its neighbor in the Persian Gulf, Kuwait. Those worries made some traders reluctant to push the dollar lower. 
The dollar moved sharply lower as trading began in the United States. The currency fell toward its lowest level in more than two years against the West German mark, but later recovered somewhat as rumors swirled about what might happen overnight in the Gulf.
''This is all emotional trading,'' said Liliana Nealon, the first vice president in the New York office of the Union Bank of Switzerland.
She said the traders expected interest rates to fall in the United States in the wake of last week's unemployment report that indicated that the economy might be headed toward a recession, increasing chances that the Federal Reserve would encourage lower interest rates.
But Ms. Nealon said the traders also feared that an eruption of new military action in the Persian Gulf could drive the dollar higher because many investors viewed it as the safest to hold during international turmoil.
President Bush said on Sunday that he was ''ruling out nothing at all,'' including a military blockade, to choke off Iraqi trade, in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last Thursday.
The invasion has led to sharply higher oil prices around the world, and the dollar gained against the Japanese yen yesterday, largely because the Japanese economy is considered vulnerable to increases in oil prices. Japan depends almost entirely on imported oil.
By the end of trading yesterday in New York, the dollar had risen to 150.35 yen, up from 149.925 yen late Friday. Earlier, the dollar rose to close at 149.50 yen in Tokyo, from 149.35 yen on Friday. In London, the currency rose to 149.55 yen.
But the dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8725, from $1.85375 late Friday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8725, from $1.8570 late Friday.
The American currency also fell against the German mark, falling to 1.57875 marks, from 1.5935 marks late Friday. That approached the lowest level for the dollar since it reached an intraday low of 1.5615 marks on Jan. 4, 1988.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Friday, included: 1.3310 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505; 5.2890 French francs, down from 5.3415; 1,154.50 Italian lire, down from 1,166.00, and 1.14955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15125.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Fears of Escalating Inflation Spark a Rise in Gold Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices rose yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting continuing fears that the soaring price of crude oil -now at the highest level in more than four and a half years - will lead to higher inflation.
On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures rose, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
Gold futures settled $7.30 to $7.80 higher in New York with the contract for August delivery at $384.70 an ounce; silver ended 5 cents to 5.7 cents higher, with September at $4.92. 
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished $1 to $3.56 higher, with September at $28.05 a barrel, the highest settlement for a near-month crude oil contract since the latter half of 1985; heating oil futures settled 3 cents to 8.97 cents higher, with September at 75.55 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3 cents to 9.34 cents higher, with September at 81.52 cents a gallon.
Strength in petroleum and precious metals was enhanced yesterday by a fear that Iraq's occupation of Kuwait could draw the United States into a Middle East war.
Analysts said the gold market was thinly traded and seemed to have encountered strong resistance near a bid of $385 an ounce. They said the market's next move would probably depend on overnight developments in the Middle East.
Grain and soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by sharp gains in corn and soybeans as the crude oil and gold rises stoked inflation fears.
Crude's gains also sparked speculation that the Soviet Union, which exports oil to European countries, might soon have more money for grain imports, said Joel Karlin, a grain-market analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago.
After the close, the Agriculture Department released weekly crop-progress statistics, showing slight deterioration in the condition of the soybean crop and slight improvement in the corn crop's condition, although both crops remained in mostly good-to-excellent shape.
Crop development continued to lag far behind the normal pace, a function of the heavy spring rains that delayed planting in some areas.

HEADLINE: BUSH SENDS U.S. FORCE TO SAUDI ARABIA AS KINGDOM AGREES TO CONFRONT IRAQ; Seeks Joint Action

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 

 BODY:
Declaring that Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait posed an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia, the United States today ordered thousands of paratroopers, an armored brigade and jet fighters to the Middle Eastern kingdom, officials said.
 Declaring that Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait posed an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia, the United States today ordered thousands of paratroopers, an armored brigade and jet fighters to the Middle Eastern kingdom, officials said.
 An American military official said tonight that Egypt had agreed to join a multinational force with the United States, giving the operation an international Arab presence that Washington considers critical. The Bush Administration has also approached some of the gulf states, Morocco and Pakistan to seek their involvement, the official said. An Egyptian Defense Ministry official in Cairo denied that his country was sending troops to Saudi Arabia. 
 It was not clear tonight exactly how many American troops were moving to Saudi Arabia or whether this would be just the initial deployment of a larger force. The contingent, estimated at between 6,000 and 15,000, was assembled after King Fahd of Saudi Arabia gave his final permission to President Bush, officials said.


Saudis to Raise Oil Output
 In addition to the military movements, the Iraqi Government was confronted today by a Saudi decision to increase its daily pumping of oil by two million barrels, a figure that represents half the total production of Iraq and Kuwait. Other oil producers are also expected to follow suit, forcing down prices that have risen sharply since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Thursday.
 The military contingent is considered too small to conduct a full-scale war with the forces of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. It could not do much more than slow an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia.
 But it appeared sufficient to give the Saudi Government the military and political backing that King Fahd needed to resist pressures to support a fellow Arab leader. The King chose the side of Mr. Bush and the extraordinary coalition of Western nations, Japan and the Soviet Union.


Bush to Address Nation
 Administration officials said the President plans to address the nation in a televised speech Wednesday at 9 A.M., after the troops are in place.
 In making the riskiest move of his Presidency by sending American soldiers to a region that has proven a quagmire for other Presidents, Mr. Bush was taking the perilous gamble that Mr. Hussein would be frozen in his current position. But the clear danger was that the Iraqi leader's response would be military in nature.
 Mr. Hussein has staked his future on the military adventure in Kuwait, and to retreat from the occupied emirate now would mean forsaking his newly bolstered position in the Middle Eastern power balance, abandoning an attempt to grab control of the world oil market and jeopardizing his political existence at home in Baghdad.
 The military deployment drew quick support from Democratic and Republican lawmakers after Mr. Bush notified Congressional leaders this morning.
 The deployment was part of a two-pronged international assault on the occupation of Kuwait that escalated today with a steady tightening of economic sanctions. Turkey cut off the flow of oil from one of two Iraqi pipelines, and Bush Administration officials indicated that Saudi Arabia was expected to do the same with the other pipeline in addition to boosting its daily oil output to help offset any cuts in the world supply.
 These actions climaxed a diplomatic offensive by the United States that has included dozens of telephone calls by Mr. Bush to other world leaders. Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said he understood that the military aid to Saudi Arabia ''is going to be a big multinational force'' with ''a lot of contributors.''
 The deployment capped an apparently successful mission by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to Saudi Arabia and to Egypt, where he reportedly secured permission for an American aircraft carrier to sail through the Suez Canal.


Some U.S. Units Arrive
 But the exact sequence of events was unclear. The arrival of some American military units in Saudi Arabia today suggested that Mr. Bush may have already persuaded the Saudi King to join his military showdown with Mr. Hussein and that Mr. Cheney's mission had served only to make the arrangements final. Mr. Bush had spoken to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and to King Fahd in recent days.
 For his part, Mr. Hussein vowed today to resist the growing foreign pressure, which includes a worldwide trade ban imposed by the United Nations on Monday. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that in a ''very difficult and very negative'' two-hour meeting on Monday, Mr. Hussein told the highest-ranking American diplomat in Iraq, charge d'affaires Joseph Wilson, that ''he had no intention of leaving Kuwait and had every intention of staying and claiming it as his own.''
 By this evening, the White House was maintaining silence on troop movements to Saudi Arabia. After making daily appearances to discuss the Kuwait crisis in recent days, Mr. Bush remained out of the public view apart from two brief appearances in which he refused to take questions or make any statements.
 Mr. Fitzwater said the United States had information from Kuwait ''showing that the Iraqi forces are there in considerable quantity and they are in an offensive posture.'' He added, ''There is an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia from the way that they are positioned and located in Kuwait.''


Iraqi Troops Near Border
 Administration officials have said that there are between 100,000 and 120,000 Iraqi troops in Kuwait and that Iraq has been concentrating large portions of that force on the southern border with Saudi Arabia. Mr. Fitzwater declined to provide details on the Iraqi movements but said, ''There have been changes of a sort that cause us to believe there is a growing and continuous threat to Saudi Arabia.''
 Opening a Cabinet meeting today, Mr. Bush told his top advisers that the United States had made clear to Saudi Arabia that the threat posed to its security by the Iraqi troops on its border was also a threat to the national security of the United States, Mr. Fitzwater said.
 The United States intelligence information indicating an impending threat from Iraq, the assurance of American military backing and the participation of other nations appeared to be the final elements that secured Saudi Arabia's agreement to allow the stationing of foreign troops on its soil.
 If the reports of Egyptian and Moroccan involvement were true, that would have lent even more weight to the effort to persuade King Fahd to join in an American military operation.
 As air and land forces headed for Saudi Arabia, the Dwight D. Eisenhower, a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, was steaming toward the Suez Canal with its 12 escort ships. Administration officials said Egypt had agreed to allow the carrier to pass through the canal tonight, enabling it to join the carrier Independence and its accompanying vessels, which were taking up position in the northern Arabian Sea, where its jets would be within striking distance of Iraq.


Blockade of Oil Shipments
 Another carrier group, the Saratoga's, accompanied by 2,100 marines and the battleship Wisconsin, left Florida today on a 10-day voyage to the Mediterranean. Those ships would be used to blockade Iraqi oil shipments if such action was needed to enforce the United Nations sanctions, which ban all purchase of Iraqi commodities, including oil.
 France and Britain also have been bolstering their naval presence in the area as officials from both countries said they were prepared to join a blockade if necessary.
 Because of their fears about how Mr. Hussein might respond to military moves against him, the United States and other Western countries worked frantically today to speed the departure of their citizens from Iraq and Kuwait. The United States said 39 Americans who had been missing were safe in Iraq but were being held against their will in a Baghdad hotel while diplomats worked to secure their release.
 Reflecting the tension of the diplomatic contacts, Mr. Fitzwater took care not to characterize the Americans in Baghdad as ''hostages'' and refused to say what steps were being taken to gain their release.
 News reports from the region said an Iraqi Airways plane carrying Japanese citizens and other foreign nationals landed in Amman, Jordan, today. Meanwhile, Britain worked to open land routes from Baghdad to Turkey and Jordan so private citizens and non-essential diplomats could flee Iraq.
 Armed with the United Nations sanctions, the international community tightened its economic chokehold on Iraq. The Turkish Government agreed to seal off the flow of Iraqi oil at twin pipelines that terminate at the Turkish coast.
 Bush Administration officials also indicated that Saudi Arabia was expected to take similar action to shut down the other major pipeline out of Iraq, which crosses its territory.


Pipeline Flow Reduced
 The pipelines had been carrying about 1.6 million barrels of oil a day, more than half of Iraq's total exports of 3 million barrels a day, but the Iraqis began reducing the flow significantly on Monday, a move the United States attributed to a slash in demand that grew out of an international boycott of Iraqi oil.
 After a meeting between King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and Mr. Cheney, who presented American intelligence reports indicating that Iraq seemed on the verge of attacking Saudi Arabia, Administration officials said the Saudis also agreed to increase their oil production by two million barrels a day.
 That would offset some of the reduction in the world supply caused by the boycott and thus cut into one of Mr. Hussein's primary goals - taking control of oil production and driving up prices to replenish his country's treasury, which was drained by a decade-long war with Iran. It also would take some heat off the Bush Administration, which is under pressure from Congress to use strategic petroleum reserves to counter rising gasoline prices.
 The United States Justice Department has launched an investigation of those price increases to determine whether they were justified by rising prices for crude oil or violated antitrust laws.
 After his meeting with King Fahd, Mr. Cheney flew to Egypt, where he met with President Hosni Mubarak in hopes of securing his country's aid, including the passage of the Eisenhower through the Suez Canal. Mr. Cheney then flew to Morocco to continue his quick round of diplomatic contacts. #20 Calls to 12 Leaders In Washington, Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush's telephone contacts with world leaders had accelerated to one almost every hour. He said the President had made 20 telephone calls to 12 different leaders over three or four days, in addition to regular meetings with his top advisers and a luncheon today with William Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence.
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was to fly to Ankara, Turkey, today to meet with President Turgut Ozal. After that, he was to fly to Brussels for a meeting of the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
 On Capitol Hill, although there was no formal announcement of the military deployment by the White House, several Democratic lawmakers issued statements backing Mr. Bush's decision.
 ''I fully support the President's deployment of U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia,'' said Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. ''I hope the nation will rally behind him.''
 Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, called it ''the right move.''
 ''It's entirely appropriate for us to work with our allies around the world and nations in the region to isolate Iraq politically and economically and put military pressure on Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait,'' he said.
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, was in Georgia tonight and said he had no direct knowledge of the military moves. But he said he thought that a limited American military operation in Saudi Arabia would draw Congressional support if it was backed by Arab nations.
 ''My hope is that we'll continue to confine our role to protecting air bases'' and perhaps using American troops to mine highways from Kuwait on which Iraq might send tanks into Saudi Arabia, he said.


Predicting Iraqi Reaction
 He said Iraq would take Saudi Arabia's agreement to station foreign troops on its soil and raise oil production ''as a virtual declaration of war.''
 In the Middle East late tonight, Saudi Arabia and four other members of the Gulf Cooperation Council issued a call for Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait and refused to recognize what they called the ''puppet'' government installed by Baghdad in Kuwait.
 The move was politically important because it put an Arab stamp on the efforts against Iraq, in an attempt to prevent Mr. Hussein from casting them as the work of ''foreigners'' seeking to subjugate Arabs.
 Saudi Arabia, which had been notably quiet until today, also gave other indications of a stiffened resolve. Its tightly controlled press openly criticized the Iraqi invasion for the first time, and King Fahd was shown on television meeting with the exiled Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and other members of his ruling family.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
U.S. and the Soviets as Allies: It's the First Time Since 1945

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 7

 BODY:
In the five days since Iraq occupied Kuwait, the Soviet Union and the United States have begun testing a new working relationship that is without precedent since the outset of the cold war.
Their remarkable joint venture in foreign policy began last Friday when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze emerged from an airport meeting here to call for a worldwide arms embargo against Iraq.
By today, Bush Administration officials were indicating that the United States was prepared to invite the Soviet Union to join any international naval force assembled to enforce sanctions against Iraq. [Page A8.] More-Low Key Approach ''For the first time since World War II, we are virtually acting as allies,'' said Maksim A. Yusin, who has been covering the story for the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia. 
Moscow's approach to the crisis has been more low-key than Washington's.
While the United States has pressed for the most sweeping United Nations embargo in history against Iraq, the Soviet Union initially favored holding some sanctions in reserve.
 
Meetings With Iraqis
While the United States has flaunted its military potential, a Soviet spokesman cautioned today against ''muscle-flexing'' and played down the Soviet decision to dispatch a destroyer and an antisubmarine ship to the Persian Gulf to protect Soviet merchant ships.
While the White House has reportedly contemplated ways to unseat the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, Moscow has met regularly with Iraqi officials here and in Baghdad, in hopes of keeping a dialogue open with its erstwhile client.
But behind such tactical differences is a degree of coordination that is all the more significant because the Middle East has long been an arena of superpower rivalry.
Throughout the crisis, the two countries have kept in frequent contact in Washington, Moscow and New York.
 
Baker and Shevardnadze Talk
Yesterday Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze talked by phone for half an hour, discussing the plight of their citizens trapped in region and agreeing to support strict sanctions in the United Nations Security Council. Today Jack F. Matlock, the American Ambassador in Moscow, paid a call on the Foreign Ministry to discuss the gulf conflict.
Soviet officials have publicly ruled out joint Soviet-American military actions against Iraq, but they have suggested that they do not consider a blockade of the Persian Gulf to fall into the same category, and as a rule the Kremlin is a strong supporter of international peacekeeping efforts.
Mr. Yusin, the Izvestia correspondent, said he believed the Soviet Union would cooperate in an international naval blockade if such a strategy had United Nations approval.
 
A Contrast to the Past'
''If it is done under the flag of the United Nations, the Soviet Union might participate,'' Mr. Yusin said in an interview. ''But it is my personal feeling, based on some informal conversations, that they would do it only under the U.N. flag.''
At a news conference today, Yuri Gremitskikh, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said as far as he knew the Americans had not made a proposal to Moscow, and he declined to speculate on the possible response.
The relatively sanguine Kremlin attitude toward American military activity in the gulf is a startling contrast to the past, when Moscow regularly denounced American maneuvers as provocative.
 
Criticism Avoided
Soviet officials have deliberately avoided criticizing the United States for sending warships to the gulf. There has been no Soviet comment so far on the deployment of American forces to Saudi Arabia.
In a briefing for Soviet reporters yesterday, First Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksandr M. Belonogov suggested that the United States might intervene militarily if Iraq moved against Saudi Arabia or threatened American citizens.
Mr. Yusin, one of the correspondents present, said Mr. Belonogov declined to answer questions about how the Soviet Union might react, but ''we got the feeling that the Soviet Union would give moral support to such action.''
 
A Shift in Strategy
Moscow's approach to the Iraq-Kuwait conflict follows logically from its shifting strategy in the Middle East over the Past two years.
Where in the past the Kremlin sought to project its influence into the region largely through client states like Iraq and Libya, more recently it has courted pro-Western Arab countries, Iran, and even Israel.
The overriding Soviet interests now, officials there say, are stability in a region so close to their borders, and acceptance by the industrialized capitalist nations, with the attendant economic benefits.
''Countries like Iraq or Libya, extremist forces headed by dictators, play a destabilizing role in the region,'' said Mr. Yusin. ''Although we are still connected with these states by treaties of friendship and cooperation, we have less and less in common with them.''
 
Moscow Seeks Investments
Moreover, while Iraq is regarded increasingly here as an expensive deadbeat - its debts to Moscow for arms sales are estimated at $20 billion -Moscow has had high hopes that moderate, pro-Western Arab states, including Kuwait, would invest in the anemic Soviet economy.
Soviet commentators and Western diplomats cite several reasons why Moscow has been more low-key than the United States in its response to Iraq, aside from a general distaste in the current leadership - and the Soviet public - for military action.
One is the hope that the Soviet Union may yet be able to exert some influence or play a mediating role if it is not quick to sever its longstanding ties to Baghdad.
Soviet and Arab officials said Baghdad had so far flatly rejected Kremlin pressure, but Yuri Glukhov, the Middle East specialist for Pravda, wrote today that Moscow was ready ''to render any possible cooperation to the sides in the Iraq-Kuwait conflict.''
 
Soviet Citizens in Kuwait and Iraq
Soviet officials said their initial decision to suspend arms sales to Iraq and to join the United States in promoting sanctions was a difficult one, suggesting that it may have encountered some resistance within the leadership.
Moscow is also clearly nervous about the fate of nearly 900 Soviet citizens in Kuwait and about 8,000 in Iraq - including crews that maintain oil equipment and about 1,000 military advisers.
Another factor is that Moscow does not want to get too far ahead of Arab governments or to jeopardize its standing in the Islamic world, which depends to some extent on not seeming too eager to please the United States or its major ally in the region, Israel.
''For the Soviet Union, it would be a little premature to go against dominant opinion in the Arab countries and enter too direct an alliance with the United States,'' said Stanislav Kondrashev, the influential commentator for Izvestia, in an interview.
 
'Our Enlightened Interests
Despite the differences, Mr. Kondrashev said he believed Soviet-American cooperation had already helped speedily mobilize world opinion, brought some pressure on Arab countries to support sanctions and lent credibility to the Soviet efforts to forge a new relationship with the West.
''It underlines what is the most important thing for the Soviet Union is to have this kind of cooperation with Western countries,'' he said. ''It is a matter of our enlightened interests.''
''True, you cannot say that Soviet and American interests coincide in the Middle East,'' added Mr. Yusin. ''But I think we have passed a critical moment: now we cannot say that our interests and American interests there are opposed.''

HEADLINE: BUSH SENDS U.S. FORCE TO SAUDI ARABIA AS KINGDOM AGREES TO CONFRONT IRAQ;
Bush's Aim's: Deter Attack, Send a Signal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The American troops and planes being sent to Saudi Arabia tonight are intended to be part of a broad international force designed to deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi oilfields and to intimidate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
The first United States contingent is not large enough to take on the million-member Iraqi Army. More than 100,000 Iraqi troops are in Kuwait. But Pentagon officials said the force could be considerably augmented if the need should arise.
The move ordered by President Bush is plainly intended to demonstrate that any Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia would mean a direct confrontation with the United States, a confrontation that would bring the full weight of American military force against Iraq from bases around the world and aircraft carriers deployed in the region. 
Moreover, by deploying the American troops as part of what is intended to be an international force, Washington has sent a signal that such an attack would put Baghdad in conflict with Western nations other than the United States as well as some Arab states.
A military official said tonight that the United States had contacted Egypt, Morocco, Pakistan, and Persian Gulf states about participating in the international ground force. He said that Egypt has agreed to make forces available. An American miltiary official said that he had been told that the Egyptian contribution is said to be 2,000 to 3,000 men, but details about Egypt's role were sketchy. An Egyptian Defense Ministry official in Cairo earlier denied that his country was sending troops to Saudi Arabia.
 
A Light, Flexible Force
An Administration official described the initial complement of American forces as a light, flexible force.
It was unclear tonight precisely how many American ground troops were being rushed to Saudi Arabia by air as well as sea. Estimates ranged from 6,000 to 15,000.
Military officials said that the initial deployment involved a brigade from the 82d Airborne Division, to be sent by air from Fort Bragg, N.C; a brigade from the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division at Fort Stewart, Ga., including tanks and armored personnel carriers, to be sent by sea, and elements of the 101st Airborne Division of helicopter-borne troops, to be sent by air from Fort Campbell, Ky. An Army paratroop brigade consists of about 2,000 men.
Pentagon officials said the function of the paratroopers will be to protect the air bases.
The Air Force is sending two squadrons of F-15 fighter planes as well as AWACS radar surveillance planes. There are 24 planes in an Air Force squadron. One American official said some F-16 fighters would also be dispatched, but this could not be confirmed.
To shore up the defense of Saudi Arabia, the Navy is deploying a second aircraft carrier in the northern Arabian Sea within striking distance of Iraq. This will be done by sending the aircraft carrier Eisenhower from the Eastern Mediterranean through the Suez Canal this evening, a movement that was approved by the Egyptians as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney visited that country today.
The carrier Saratoga, which left Mayport, Fla., today, will take the Eisenhower's place in the Mediterranean. The Saratoga is accompanied by the battleship Wisconsin and ships carrying the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit based at Camp Lejeune, N.C.
Navy ships full of supplies stationed at Diego Garcia, an island in the Indian Ocean, are also steaming toward the gulf.
A headquarters for the Central Command, the successor for the Rapid Deployment Force created by President Carter, has been established in Saudi Arabia. #65,700 Saudi Troops The American troops are intended to be part of an international air, land and sea force, which officials hope will include a sizable Arab as well as Western European component. Mr. Cheney flew today from Saudi Arabia to Egypt and then Morocco, consulting with Arab leaders about an Arab role in the multinational force.
The American troops and whatever other foreign contingents are sent will join a Saudi force of about 65,700 troops, many of whom are mercenaries from Pakistan. The Saudis possess considerable technological strength in the air, with advanced AWACS radar-surveillance planes to monitor troop and air movements and squadrons of American-made F-15 warplanes manned by United States-trained pilots. Hawk surface-to-air missiles are the mainstay of the Saudis' air defense network.
A Bush Administration spokesman, reflecting the uncertainty over Iraq's reaction to the move as well as Washington's continuing quest for international partners, declined to say precisely how large the American troop presence in Saudi Arabia would be.
A senior Administration official said the purpose of the international troop deployment was to land a force ''sizable enough to give the Iraqis pause, but not enough to kick them out'' of Kuwait.
By deploying an initial ground force, supported by American warplanes and aircraft carrier groups, the official said the United States strategy was to ''show our commitment'' and gauge Mr. Hussein's reaction in the next day or two.
 
Saudis to Raise Production
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who chairs the House Armed Services Committee, said that the deployment ''discourages Iraq from doing the wrong thing militarily and encourages the Saudis to do the right thing economically.'' Saudi Arabia has agreed to increase oil production by 2 million barrels a day to compensate for the shortage caused by the sanctions against Iraq.
''A brigade of 3,000 men is not going to hold the line against the Iraqi Republican Guard force of seven divisions,'' Mr. Aspin added, referring to the American Army units dispatched today. ''But it establishes a presence across the line in Kuwait. If Iraq attacks across the line now, it is at war with the United States and that is a different story,'' Mr. Aspin added.
Thomas L. McNaugher, a military specialist at the Brookings Institution, added that the American deployment was intended to reassure Saudi Arabia that any attack would precipitate a war with the United States.
''It is the kind of force that you would want to move in initially but just the beginning of the kind of force that you would want to move in if you were encountering a full-scale Iraqi armored attack,'' said Mr. McNaugher.
 
For a War, More Force
He added that a full-scale war with Iraq would require more ''heavy'' American ground forces and more fighter planes. ''A force adequate to that task could involve two heavy divisions and 10 or 12 air wings,'' he said. An air wing includes 72 planes. In addition to its forces in Kuwait, Iraq is said to have moved several divisions normally deployed close to the border with Iran toward Kuwait and has ordered a mobilization of its reserves.
Iraqi aircraft have been deployed in airfields in southern Iraq. Iraq's air force possesses Exocet anti-ship missiles and Iraq may have acquired more of the weapons from Kuwaiti stockpiles, intelligence reports say.
According to classified intelligence reports, Iraq has been observed loading chemical bombs onto aircraft. American officials believe that the operations were performed in full view of American spy satellites to send a threatening message to the United States and Saudi Arabia.
 
U.S. Firepower Formidable
American analysts say an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia would probably involved two army corps. An army corps includes at least two divisions, and each division at least 10,000 men. One armored push would be made along the coast, while the other would be directed at the Saudi capital at Riyadh.
The American deployment, though relatively small, still leaves the United States with formidable firepower.
Pentagon officials said a group of F-111 fighter bombers, normally based in England, were in Turkey on Monday participating in a previously scheduled NATO exercise. That put the airplanes, which were once used to bomb targets in Libya, easily within striking distance of Iraq and Kuwait.
The movement of a second aircraft carrier to the northern Arabian Sea means that Navy attack planes are in a better position to defend Saudi territory and do not have to fly over other Arab states.
France and Britain are augmenting their small force in the region. The French have put an aircraft carrier based on Toulon, near Marseilles, on alert and a French destroyer is steaming toward the gulf to join two French ships already deployed there. The British are also deploying three ships in the region.

LENGTH: 1454 words

HEADLINE: BUSH SENDS U.S. FORCE TO SAUDI ARABIA AS KINGDOM AGREES TO CONFRONT IRAQ;
Saudis Make a Stand

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Aug. 7

 BODY:
By allowing American troops to land on its territory and increasing its oil production, Saudi Arabia tonight proclaimed what it has been reluctant to say openly for decades: that its interests lie with the West.
Until it agreed to lend open support to those willing to confront President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and challenge his buildup of troops on its borders, the Saudi Government had gone to great lengths to avoid accusations by more powerful and more militant Arab countries that it is an American client-state.
The action also represents a watershed for the rest of the Arab world. A number of other countries, like Morocco, Bahrain and Tunisia as well as the small Emirates of the Persian Gulf, may now be less bashful about flaunting their close but concealed strategic, military and political links with the United States.
The Saudis and their Arab gulf allies concluded that there was little room for compromise with Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait and the implications of doom it carried for other ruling families in the gulf region. 
''We are at the point where we have no choice but to stand up to Saddam,'' said a senior Saudi official, who asked not to be identified. ''If we were to allow the status quo to remain, there is little question we would be next on Iraq's list.''
Arab officials and oil industry experts in the region asserted that the realignment precipitated by the Iraqi invasion would produce other important changes in the politics and economies of the Middle East, affecting efforts to resolve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, oil prices and production levels and the future of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
The Saudi official said the concept of ''Arab solidarity'' often invoked by Arab leaders to keep Western powers out of the region was fading for Saudi Arabia and its gulf allies.
The Saudi stand solidified after the failure to forge an Arab League consensus on the crisis because of the explicit support given the Iraqi President by King Hussein of Jordan, Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the leaders of Yemen and Libya.
''There are many elements in the Arab world which want to see the demise of all Arab regimes in the gulf,'' the official added. ''We have to look elsewhere for support.''
Several other Arab gulf and Egyptian officials said in interviews over the last three days that the pro-Iraqi stand of King Hussein and Mr. Arafat was so offensive that neither would get ''a single dollar in aid'' in the future, in the words of a Arab gulf Cabinet minister.
''The governments of the gulf region have washed their hands of Saddam, Arafat and King Hussein,'' said the official, who asked not to be identified.
 
Where They Stand
After an initial period of hesitation after the invasion of Kuwait on Thursday morning, the Governments of Saudi Arabia and its gulf oil-producing allies as well as those of Egypt and Morocco are now unconditional in their condemnation of Iraq through their official newspapers and radio broadcasts, asserting that they will accept nothing less than a return to the situation as it stood before the invasion.
Saudis say that because they are certain Mr. Hussein will attack them as the economic strangulation of Iraq takes effect, they are anxious to give him as little pretext as possible until Western powers are in place to defend them.
For that reason, the Saudis said that while they are willing to increase their oil production slowly to ease the world's thirst for boycotted oil from Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, they are not in a hurry to shut down the pipeline, known as IPSA-2, that carries Iraqi oil to the Saudi port of Yanbu on the Red Sea.
''Any action by Saudi Arabia to interfere with the flow of oil via IPSA-2 will be regarded as an automatic casus belli by the Iraqis,'' the Middle East Economic Survey, an authoritative oil newsletter that has close contacts with the Saudis, noted on Monday in its weekly issue.
There were unconfirmed reports tonight that the Iraqis had in any case braked the flow of oil through the pipeline because of an abrupt decline in demand resulting from trade sanctions.
 
Fear of Chemical Weapons
Saudi military strategists believe their air force can delay and possibly cripple a land assault by Iraqi troops massed on the Saudi borders with Kuwait.
''A squadron of 60 Saudi jets is enough to wipe out any Iraqi land invasion in an open and very exposed desert territory,'' a Saudi official said.
But the Saudis fear that Iraqi may move to use chemical weapons and missiles, which could inflict heavy casualties before Iraq is suppressed by Western military powers certain to enter the fight the moment Iraq attacks Saudi Arabia.
Today Mr. Hussein said he had no plans to attack Saudi Arabia, but the State Department said Iraq was increasing its troop concentration on Saudi borders.
Saudi Arabian decision-makers are said to be convinced that Mr. Hussein has worked himself into an untenable situation, and their strategy aims at slowly cornering him without outright provocation.
''Saddam has already lost the game politically and economically,'' one Saudi said. ''If he expands it to the military area he will be finished. Our strategy should be to show him that the military option is open for us too by investing in it. We are moving troops and will probably give the Americans some logistical support in some areas of the kingdom.''
In the course of steadily confronting the Iraqi aggression, Saudi Arabia has been taking increasingly bolder steps.
On Sunday it allowed the exiled Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to relay a message on Saudi television to his subjects in occupied Kuwait. The speech was widely broadcast in supporting countries, including Egypt. The Saudis are also said to be supplying Kuwaiti refineries in Western Europe with oil to feed its retail gasoline operation, a network of 4,500 service stations in the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxemburg and Norway.
But oil experts say that the sudden removal of nearly four million barrels a day of oil from Kuwaiti and Iraqi exports will undoubtedly push oil prices much higher and produce logistical difficulties before other producers step in to make up the loss. Prices have gone from lows of $13 a barrel to as high as $24 for the Saudi benchmark variety.
''The more successful we are in effecting the oil boycott of Iraq and Kuwait, the greater the difficulty will be in finding oil elsewhere to replace those exports, even if Saudi Arabia and others with spare production capacity like Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates cooperated by pumping more oil,'' said John Lichtblau, president of the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Of the 13 members of OPEC, only three have the ability to significantly increase oil output. The Saudis are able to boost production by two million barrels a day; Venezuela can produce 700,000 extra barrels and the United Arab Emirates have 500,000 barrels' unused capacity.
The Middle East Economic Survey noted on Monday that regardless of what happens, the damage that the Iraqi-Kuwaiti crisis has already done to the cohesion of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries ''may prove beyond repair.''
Sadek Boussena, the OPEC conference president, announced today that he would make a statement on the oil situation Wednesday, probably to answer pressing requests for an emergency OPEC meeting by some of the group's members.
 
Quota Agreement 'Meaningless'
''At any rate the existing OPEC agreement on quotas and production is now meaningless,'' said Joseph Story, an independent oil consultant in Washington. Other OPEC experts noted that a number of the group's members, including Venezuela and Gabon, have wondered aloud whether there is any use in remaining members of an organization that has become largely dominated by Arab politics.
In describing the developments of the last three days, foreign diplomats stationed in the Middle East said the elements of an economic and political confrontation with Baghdad were coming together quickly.
''I think all the Arab gulf states are resigned to the fact that they are entering an unpredictable and very dangerous war with Iraq, but they seem confident of our support,'' said an envoy of one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.
Arab officials estimate that it may take the better part of two months before the economic sanctions bite, but there seems to be a growing feeling within the region that with the support of the West a decisive confrontation with Mr. Hussein will be won by the conservative regimes of the oil-producing countries of the region.

HEADLINE: Iraqi Crisis: Reverberations

 BODY:

IRAQI DEFIANCE President Saddam Hussein said Iraq would confront any ''imperialist or Zionist attempt'' to reverse its takeover of Kuwait. Experts said he was being backed into a corner from which his most likely options were to surrender or to lash out militarily. Pages A9 and A11.
BUSH'S GAMBLE By sending combat troops to Saudi Arabia, President Bush tied the United States' fortunes and his own to an explosive crisis with no clear outcome. Page A9.
TURKISH ACTION Turkey effectively ordered a shutdown of vital Iraqi oil pipelines. Page A10.
OIL PRICES Analysts said price rises might be stemmed by the Saudi pledge to produce two million more barrels daily, combined with expected production increases by other oil-exporting nations. The price of the benchmark American crude closed at $28.31, up 26 cents. Page D1.
FINANCIAL MARKETS The New York Stock Exchange steadied after a three-day slide prompted by the Iraqi invasion last week. The Dow was down 5.70, to 2,710.64. The Japanese stock market rose 3.10 percent, recovering some of yesterday's losses, and other major markets rose or declined slightly. Treasury securities continued to drop and interest rates climbed. Pages D1, D4 and D14.
RECESSION FEARS With the economy already weak, analysts said sharply higher energy costs were likely to slash corporate profits and could lead to a recession. Page D1.
BUDGET TALKS A reduction in the deficit is unlikely in view of the Iraqi crisis, Democratic and Republican lawmakers said. Doubts are growing about whether the economy can withstand $50 billion in belt-tightening while options like energy tax increases and deep military cuts now are unpalatable. Page A14.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A2-11
 
Troops were ordered to Saudi Arabia by the United States Government, which declared that Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait posed an imminent threat to the Middle Eastern kingdom. The U.S. is also sending an armored brigade and jet fighters, officials said. Page A1

HEADLINE: Colombia Swears In President, a Foe of Traffickers

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Amid tight security, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo was inaugurated today as President of Colombia.
A 43-year-old economist and Colombia's youngest President in this century, Mr. Gaviria has a four-year mandate to grapple with daunting problems: enduring left-wing guerrilla armies and violence by drug traffickers who made Colombia the source of 80 percent of the world's cocaine.
''Narco-terrorism is today the main menace to our democracy,'' Mr. Gaviria said in his inaugural speech. 
To guarantee security for representatives from 90 nations, including Vice President Dan Quayle, 22,000 soldiers and policemen patrolled the city, including a 24-block closed area around the inaugural site.
 
'Historic Responsibility'
With the public limited to watching televised coverage, the inauguration was an outgrowth of a presidential campaign that culminated in Mr. Gaviria's election on May 27. After three candidates were killed, the campaign was conducted largely on television. Mr. Gaviria, of the Liberal Party, was the candidate most opposed to the traffickers.
Today, echoing a historic cry of the Spanish-speaking world, Colombia's new President said that the nation's terrorists ''no pasaran'' - ''shall not pass.''
''My Government has the historic responsibility to pacify Colombian life,'' the President told dignitaries assembled in the high mountain air.
 
More Prisons and Protection
To fight ''narcoterrorismo,'' Mr. Gaviria promised to build high-security prisons and to provide protection and anonymity to judges and witnesses. Extradition of Colombian drug suspects to the United States for trial cannot be ''the principal tool of the war against drug trafficking,'' he said.
Mr. Gaviria drew some of the strongest applause when he said of the drug traffic, ''No success will be possible if there is not a substantial reduction in demand in the consuming countries.''
Drug-consuming countries should crack down on money laundering by traffickers, arms sales to traffickers and domestic distribution networks, said Mr. Gaviria.
The drug issue has gripped this country since last Aug. 17, when traffickers killed Mr. Gaviria's political mentor, Luis Carlos Galan.
Today, Virgilio Barco Vargas, Colombia's President since 1986, stepped down without seeing his nemesis, Pablo Escobar, brought to justice. Despite a $600,000 price on his head, Mr. Escobar, leader of the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel, has escaped arrest and has fought the state with a series of bombings and killings.
 
Ex-Guerrilla in Cabinet
To protect Mr. Barco from traffickers, Mr. Gaviria is expected to name him Ambassador to Britain. Last week, Mr. Barco named his chief of staff, German Montoya, Ambassador to Canada.
Turning to the left-wing guerrillas, a fixture on Colombia's political scene since the early 1960's, the new President has chosen Antonio Navarro Wolff, former presidential candidate of the M-19 Democratic Alliance, as his minister of health. Last March, the M-19 abandoned guerrilla warfare.
Mr. Gaviria held out to the nation's four remaining guerrilla groups the possibility of participating in November elections for delegates to a constitutional convention. He is Colombia's first president to give a cabinet post to a former guerrilla.
In recent weeks, peace talks started with three small armed groups. Two larger groups are still at war, fielding a total of about 7,000 guerrillas.
