HEADLINE: For U.S. Visa, Peruvians Try Lots of Ruses

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 4

 BODY:
A notebook kept behind the bulletproof glass where American consular officers talk to visa applicants is proof of the desperation created by Peru's deepening guerrilla violence and economic ruin.
It is filled with samples of fake employment letters, tax returns and bank statements that Peruvians have supplied in vain attempts to get visas to go to the United States.
Lima's street-wise entrepreneurs also manufacture visas themselves, stamping them into passports at prices ranging from $500 to $5,000.
''You get what you pay for,'' said Wayne G. Griffith, the United States consul general, referring to the quality of the fake visas. ''Some people believe they are buying real visas, so they think we are corrupt.'' 
 
How the Fakes Are Used
When the consulate came up with a counterfoil, a special sticker placed in the passport on which the visa is then stamped, counterfeiters began copying it as well. Mr. Griffith showed one fake so good that it could have gone undetected except for the fact that the counterfeiter carelessly used a Spanish-language date stamp.
Most fake visas are likely to be detected by immigration officers at United States entry points, so a more common use of them may be to help the passport holder get a visa for Guatemala or Mexico by showing the United States visa and saying he wants to stop over en route. Once in one of those countries, he may join a group crossing the Rio Grande by foot.
Over the last two years, applications from Peruvians seeking visas to go to the United States as tourists have nearly doubled, from 54,698 in fiscal 1988 to an estimated 104,500 this year. More than 40 percent are being refused because of suspicions that the applicants intend to stay and look for work. Two years ago, the refusal rate was just 22 percent.
The applicants line up by the hundreds each day, despite the fact that there is no sign or emblem declaring the building to be the United States Consulate.
 
'Critical Threat Post'
Lima, afflicted by leftist terrorism that has put a third of Peru under emergency military control, is considered a ''critical threat post'' for employees of the United States Government. A package bomb blew out the plate-glass front windows three years ago.
With legal immigration to the United States virtually closed to any but the immediate families of citizens, would-be Peruvian immigrants find the tourist visa their only option. But to obtain a tourist visa - what the law terms nonimmigrant visa - applicants must prove they have the means to pay for their trip and reason to return to Peru, like property, family ties or a good job.
That's where the creation of fake letters and documents comes in. The consulate has assigned one officer full time to work with the Peruvian police in detecting visa fraud. Since January, Mr. Griffith said, three counterfeit visa rings have been broken up.
Sometimes, however, the falsification involves something simple, like getting a friend who works for an established company to supply a piece of letterhead stationary on which to write an employment and salary report. #4 Do the Interviewing There are also cases of people who legitimately qualify for visas, then sell their passports and report them stolen. After obtaining a new passport, they return for another visa.
The four consular officers who interview the average of more than 500 daily applicants rely on their own admittedly subjective judgments and common sense in deciding whether the person is what he says he is and whether the documents are legitimate.
The interviewers, usually young Foreign Service officers on their first tour of duty abroad, run people through at intervals of one or two minutes each. There is no appeal from the interviewer's on-the-spot decision, unless the visa seeker wants to return with additional information.
''Do you have children here?'' an interviewer asks a gray-haired woman wanting to go to the United States to visit a child there. He wants to know whether she has a reason to return home.
A man is quickly told he cannot receive a visa because he neither owns his own home in Peru, nor has proof of ''solvency.''
A man who presents the last two years' tax forms raises suspicions because his income has supposedly jumped from the equivalent of about $5,000 to about $80,000. The consular officer thinks the stamp on the more recent form is fake.
''I am sorry, sir, but I can't give you a visa,'' he says, without hesitation or explanation.
 
Some Are Quickly Accepted
People whose passports show frequent United States entry stamps from previous trips get visas quickly because it is obvious they have reasons for regular travel and have not abused tourist visas in the past. Likewise, people who bring statements from banks in the United States showing they have substantial balances are likely to receive visas quickly.
A university student said she wanted to go to the United States for the reading of her father's will. He had died after living there 18 years. But the consular officer found that she had no close family ties to bring her back to Peru.
''It's unfortunate, but I cannot give you a visa,'' he said, adding that the estate could be handled by mail.
''Next,'' he said, motioning the next applicant forward.
''This is a lousy job,'' Mr. Griffith said as he watched.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
U.S. Is Ready to Ask Soviets to Help With Naval Blockade of Iraq

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials said today that Washington was prepared to invite the Soviet Union into any international naval force assembled to enforce sanctions against Iraq. They added that they had no doubt that Moscow would want to take part.
A senior Bush Administration official said the United States had not yet formally invited Moscow to take part in such a force, but had signaled to the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France that such a unit might be needed soon to enforce the worldwide economic boycott against Iraq ordered on Monday by the United Nations Security Council.
There have also been reports that an international ground force would be sent to Saudi Arabia, but there has been no indication yet that Soviet forces would take part. 
The Bush Administration's willingness to cooperate with Moscow in a naval force is in striking contrast to the American position of only three years ago.
In 1987, after a Kuwaiti appeal to permanent members of the Security Council, Kuwaiti oil tankers were registered under the flags of other nations to protect them from attack by Iran or Iraq, but the United States declined to let Moscow participate in the operation. American officials did not want to open an opportunity for a buildup of Soviet naval forces in the Persian Gulf.
 
'We Needed to Act Together'
But in the wake of the Soviet-American cooperation in the early stages of the current gulf crisis, senior Administration officials say they are prepared to invite Moscow into any a collective security force that might be assembled to deter Iraq or enforce sanctions.
''We think that they should be part of any multinational naval presence,'' said a senior Administration official. ''We will not try to exclude them.'' He added: ''It flows naturally from everything they have done up to now. I think we both understood that we were staring face to face at the major threat in the post-cold war world. We needed to act together in a way that will demonstrate that we will not just cope with this problem but also deter future situations like this from developing.''
Another senior official said: ''The more the Soviets do behave responsibly, the more it does increase our incentives to see them as possible partners in a military operation.''
''What the Soviets have done up to now should not be underestimated,'' the official added. ''It has had a major impression on the smaller countries who feel much more comfortable about sticking their heads out, knowing that the major powers are together on this thing. It also clearly played a role in getting the Chinese on board.''
 
Moscow's Caution
Asked if Washington was certain that Moscow would want to take part in such a naval force if it is assembled, the official said: ''There is no way that they would want to be left out. I can assure you of that. But what they are telling us now is let's move slowly, step-by-step. First let's see what happens with sanctions and then we will address the issue of a naval force.''
The official said that the statement today by the Soviet Foreign Ministry that a ''buildup in the military presence and naval muscle-flexing in such a very tense and very complex situation is not the best line of action'' reflected Moscow's concern that Washington not take any action on its own.
Nevertheless, Soviet behavior up to now has clearly given the Administration much more room to maneuver.
The present situation contrasts with 1979, when President Carter had to respond to the seizing of American hostages by Iran; he was repeatedly criticized for not taking firm military measures. President Bush thus far at least appears decisive, and one of the main differences between the two responses is the Soviet factor.
Michael Mandelbaum, director of East-West Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, said: ''Jimmy Carter could not attack Iran for fear of provoking the Soviets to intervene themselves or driving Iran into the Soviet orbit, which would have been a major geopolitical loss for the United States. Bush really doesn't have to worry about either.''
On Monday, John S. Wolf, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, summoned officials of several important American allies for a meeting about the safety of their nationals working in Kuwait and Iraq.
''It was the usual group,'' said a European official who attended, ''except for the fact that the Soviet representative, Oleg Derkovsky, was also there. So there we were, all sitting around this conferernce table - the Americans, the French, the Italians, the Germans, the Swiss, the Japanese, the Canadians, the British and - the Soviets. It was all very businesslike, everyone speaking together freely, looking at emergency contingency plans for evacuating foreigners. It was just like any other meeting of the allies. It was only afterwards that I thought about how odd it was.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Bush's Gamble in Sending Troops: Stakes Are Certain, Outcome Murky

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
By sending combat troops into Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved decisively today to defend fundamental American economic interests, but he also tied the United States and his own fortunes to a potentially explosive crisis with no clear outcome in sight.
 
The stakes behind the
President's decision were clear: control of oil supplies and prices. By grabbing Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was in a position to intimidate Saudi Arabia and dominate OPEC pricing. President Bush determined that this power - which touches every corner of the world economy - had to be retained by Saudi Arabia and the other members of OPEC, and the only way to insure that was by removing the Iraqi threat to the Saudis. 
The military force assembling in Saudi Arabia and nearby waters provides the reassurance that the Saudi leadership apparently needed to oppose Mr. Hussein.
 
Risks Are Also Clear
But the risks for Mr. Bush are equally clear: Washington is now face to face with a cornered enemy. Mr. Bush's political fate may be on the line, but Saddam Hussein has staked his Government on the success of his Kuwait adventure. He is a man who has demonstrated time and time again to his enemies at home and abroad that he knows no restraints, and Mr. Bush may now have to match him step by step.
Senior Bush Administration officials are worried over several possible Iraqi responses, including the possibility that the Iraqis will take Americans in Kuwait and Iraq hostage. The Jordanians may have been able to restrain Mr. Hussein until now, but that was before he had American troops on his doorstep. What will Washington do if he calls their bluff and engages American forces in a war of attrition that would engulf half of the world's crude oil reserves, send prices spiraling out of control and push the American economy into recession?
Tough questions, Bush aides admit, but, they add, what choice did they have?
 
Joining With Outsiders
No matter who prevails, the Iraqis or the Saudis, the Arab world and the American role in the Middle East are unlikely to be quite the same. The last time the United States or Britain intervened militarily in the region to prop up an Arab Government was in the 1950's, but those initiatives proved to be the curtain calls of a colonial era. In the 1960's, the Arab Nationalist tide loosed by President Gamel Abdel Nasser of Egypt swept the region. That enjoined every Arab leader to live by the maxim: never side with foreigners against Arabs - at least not in public.
As the Arab proverb puts it: ''Me and my brother against my cousin; me, my brother and my cousin against the outsider.'' Even President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who was reviled by the Arab world for aligning his country with the Americans, would never grant them bases.
Today, though, the Saudis joined hands in public with the outsider to confront the Iraqis, because the Iraqis changed the rules first when they invaded Kuwait. Arab leaders were not supposed to align themselves openly with foreigners, but they were also not supposed to devour one another's states. The closest precedent was the Syrian movement into Lebanon in 1976, but that was justified in its origins as part of a pan-Arab peacekeeping effort to end the civil war.
 
'A Line Has Been Crossed'
The Saudis decided that the risks of being accused of collaborating with the Americans were outweighed by the risks of being exposed to Mr. Hussein.
''A line has been crossed,'' said Fouad Ajami, a Lebanese-born Middle East expert at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''When Iraq shucked off the traditional limits of Arab politics the Saudis decided to shuck off their Arab nationalist scruples too. They understood that this time they could not bury their heads in the sand and wait for the storm to blow over. The idea of keeping the Americans just over the horizon just wouldn't do any longer. The fire was here.''
How will it be put out? There are four possibilities. The first is that Mr. Hussein will do nothing to provoke the American troops, but simply continue to consolidate his hold over Kuwait and launch a virulent rhetorical onslaught against the Saudi Government, hoping to rally the Arab world to his side. This could become extremely uncomfortable for the Saudi royal family.
 
Missiles and Poison Gas
A second possibility is that he will raise the ante by trying to grab a corner of Saudi Arabia or opening fire on American troops. He has missiles, poison gas, a million men under arms and a nation that became inured to war of attrition in the eight-year conflict with Iran.
A third possibility is that the sanctions will begin to choke Iraq and Mr. Hussein will signal a willingess to make a deal.
A fourth possibility, and the one most hoped for in Washington, is that someone in the Iraqi military will decide that Mr. Hussein has gone too far, and hatch a plot to oust him.
 
Removing the Threat
This last possibility is not only the most preferable to Washington but also the only one that would allow a quick resolution of the crisis and a quick withdrawal of American forces.
The mission of the American forces sent into Saudi Arabia today did not seem to be to liberate Kuwait. Their initial mission, at least, seemed to be to remove the immediate threat of an Iraqi attack against Saudi Arabia and the long-term threat of Iraqi intimidation.
But even if Mr. Hussein were to withdraw his forces from Kuwait tomorrow, he would remain a powerful force intimidating the Saudis and he would undoubtedly use his propaganda apparatus to stir up an anti-Saudi campaign throughout the Arab world. For this reason, it is difficult to imagine the Bush Administration's achieving its objectives and feeling free to pull out, without there being a change of government in Iraq.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Quick Action by Turkey On Sanctions a Startler

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7

 BODY:
By joining the worldwide sanctions against Iraq today Turkey moved more decisively than many cautious and even nervous people here had wished.
Some news commentators had insisted that given Turkey's geographic and economic exposure to Iraq, it should have been among the last to go along with the economic blockade ordered Monday by the United Nations Security Council.
Instead, the Government cast its lot fully with the American-led effort to cripple Iraq's economy.
In the most significant measure, Turkey effectively ordered a shutdown of vital Iraqi oil pipelines in its territory by banning ships from loading Iraqi crude at offshore terminals in the eastern Mediterranean. 
 
Shutdown Left to Iraq
Turkish officials said that Baghdad may still pump oil through the twin pipelines, which until the invasion of Kuwait last week had carried more than half of Iraq's total exports from its northern fields. But once storage installations are filled at the Mediterranean port of Yumurtalik, the officials said, Iraq will have no choice but to cut off the flow entirely, a process that they expected to take five or six days.
''This way, we leave it to the Iraqis to decide when to shut it down,'' said Mehmet Kececiler, the State Minister for Oil.
To a degree, events had already simplified this decision for the Turks. Feeling the pinch of an embargo led by the United States, Iraq had already closed one pipeline and slashed the flow in the other by nearly a third.
A pipeline that stretches across Saudi Arabia from Iraq to the port of Yanbu on the Red Sea is believed to be operating, but there were reports tonight that its flow had also slowed because of a steep decline in demand.
In Turkey, pipeline officials said that the effect of the Iraqi move was to reduce the oil flow to 44 percent of the 1.5 million barrels per day that used to be carried. ''If they cannot market, they cannot pump,'' said Oktay Vulal, director general of Botas, Turkey's state-run pipeline company.
 
Lone Tanker Turned Away
Forbidding any oil-loading at the Mediterranean end of the line was made somewhat easier by the fact that there are almost no ships around now. Mr. Kececiler said that only one tanker had shown up off Yumurtalik today, from Morocco, and it was turned away.
Losing Iraqi oil will be a big blow for Turks, because they had counted on it for 40 percent of this year's import requirements. Some speculated that Turkey may well be tempted to draw off some of this crude that is now fast accumulating in its reservoirs, taking it, in effect, as partial Iraqi repayment on its $750 million worth of outstanding debts here.
But siphoning off oil could be viewed abroad as an attempt to cheat on the embargo. and despite its caution, the Government has clearly chosen to show solidarity with the rest of the world against a neighbor that is feared but also widely despised.
''They're not going to be isolated,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''They're not going to desert the Western camp - no way. It's not an option.''
 
Iraqi Assets Frozen
Like other countries joining the economic blockade, Turkey ordered all trade stopped with Iraq and Iraqi-controlled Kuwait save food and medicine needed for humanitarian purposes. It also froze all Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets. A senior Government official said, however, that these were meager, amounting to only about $25 million.
Playing down the immediate threat to his country's oil supplies, Mr. Vulal of the pipeline company said that Iraq had already delivered nearly 75 percent of this year's anticipated supplies and that the rest would probably now be obtained with little trouble from Saudi Arabia and other sources.
Nevertheless, many Turks are concerned about the damage that the boycott will inflict on commerce valued at $3 billion a year. That figure includes pipeline fees that Iraq pays to Turkey, an enormous volume of truck traffic between the two countries and the considerable construction work performed by Turkish companies in Iraq.
Some here say that they also fear for the safety of an estimated 60,000 Turkish workers in Iraq, sent there on construction projects.
Others argued that a cautious foreign policy in the Middle East had always worked well for Turkey in the past and should still be maintained, especially given the threat presented by the unpredictable Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein. ''Turkey should be the last to join'' a United Nations blockade, a national newspaper, Hurriyet, said today. ''She has at least this right as a border country.''
 
Baker Due on Thursday
Turkish officials now expect to come under still more pressure with the scheduled arrival Thursday of Secretary of State James A. Baker, who is coming from what United States officials describe as ''broad overall consultations'' on the Persian Gulf crisis.
A senior Turkish official said he expected that Mr. Baker would seek Ankara's permission to use military bases here as staging areas, should there be a decision for military strikes against Iraq. The main site is an air base near the southern city of Adana, where it was disclosed today that the United States has 14 F-111 bombers similar to those used in the raid against Libya in 1986.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
EUROPE AND JAPAN SUPPORT EMBARGO

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
As if anxious to dispel memories of their past support for the Baghdad Government, Western Europe and Japan have moved quickly to carry out European Community and United Nations resolutions ordering trade and arms embargoes against Iraq.
But in throwing their weight behind the international campaign to isolate Iraq, Western Europe and Japan are also expecting to pay a stiff price for policies that in recent years have contributed enormously to strengthening President Saddam Hussein's position in the Middle East.
France, Italy, West Germany and Spain have sold weapons to Iraq; France and Japan have given generous credits to Baghdad, and Britain is among numerous industrialized countries to have encouraged their private companies to do business with Iraq.
The immediate impact of the crisis in these countries seems likely to be higher domestic oil prices, which could in turn slow economic growth. But Iraq also has huge outstanding debts to Japan and some European countries on which payments will now be indefinitely suspended. 
 
West Could Face Own Weapons
If the current trade embargo leads to a naval blockade of Iraq, Western nations may find themselves confronting sophisticated weapons, including supersonic aircraft and missiles, that they themselves have supplied.
In the hours and days that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week, Western Europe and Japan have nonetheless closed ranks with the United States, ordering freezes of Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, banning oil imports from the two countries and forbidding exports to Iraq.
One of the earliest signs of Western Europe's new determination to confront President Hussein has been its willingness to discuss the crisis at the headquarters of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels. In the past, France in particular has insisted that NATO has no authority to act in the Middle East.
''Usually in these cases you have the United States calling for action and the rest talking about diplomatic solutions,'' one NATO official said. ''Not this time. Everyone, including France, believes something should be done. And everyone, including France, agrees this is an issue of direct interest to NATO.''
France's position is specially complicated because it has long been Europe's main supplier of both armaments and credits to Iraq. For example, during Iraq's war with Iran between 1980 and 1988, France provided some $17 billion of armaments to Baghdad, including Mirage fighters and Exocet missiles.
 
Iraq Owes France Billions
Since the war ended, French construction and electronics companies have also signed important contracts with Iraq. Today, Iraq owes France around $4.5 billion, including $2.5 billion for weapons. Arms sales to Iraq were suspended in May only because Baghdad fell behind on its debt payments.
When the crisis erupted last Thursday, however, France apparently decided it could not be seen wavering. It quickly froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets and took the initiative of proposing that the 12-nation European Community boycott Iraqi oil and cut off arms sales to the country.
Some domestic critics have charged that the Government shares responsibility for Iraq's aggression. A cartoon in Le Monde today showed Western hostages being led away by a tank marked, ''Made in France.'' But this has only prompted the Government to take a firmer stance, including dispatching a frigate to join two warships already in the Gulf area.
Britain, in contrast, is not believed to have supplied weapons to Iraq, but British companies have also been vying for lucrative contracts in Iraq. And in recent months, opposition politicians in London have accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of overlooking assorted abuses of Iraqi power in the name of protecting British business interests.
Just this year, Iraq ignored British protests and hanged a London-based Iranian-born journalist on spying charges. Iraq was also accused of trying to smuggle American-made nuclear triggers through Heathrow Airport in London and of acquiring parts in Britain and elsewhere in Europe for a gigantic gun. Baghdad denied both charges.
But after the invasion of Kuwait, a former British protectorate with an estimated $28 billion worth of assets in Britain, Mrs. Thatcher immediately ordered a freeze of Kuwaiti holdings and, during a quick visit to the United States, showed herself anxious to coordinate the Western response with President Bush.
 
No Japanese Peacekeepers
Japan's stake in the crisis can be measured by the fact that it has not only been the main provider of foreign aid to Iraq, is a major exporter to Iraq and is owed some $4.7 billion by the Baghdad Government, but has also received about 12 percent of its oil during the first six months of this year from Iraq and Kuwait.
But despite some domestic claims that Tokyo hesitated in responding to the Kuwaiti invasion, waiting until Sunday to announce a full embargo of trade and aid, the Government has insisted that it moved quickly on sanctions, despite the considerable commercial losses involved.
Japan is nonetheless bracing for criticism for not offering to involve its armed forces. ''Our Constitution prohibits our military contribution, even to peacekeeping forces,'' Taizo Watanabe, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said. ''We have made it clear we will do what we can in a non-military way. But we don't know what kind of a contribution we can make.''
In Western Europe, apart from Britain and France, no other country has so far indicated willingness to participate in a naval blockade of Iraq, while Greece has announced that United States bases in Crete could not be used as a springboard for military action in the Middle East.
In Bonn, a spokesman said the question of West German involvement in a maritime blockade ''has not yet been raised'' and refused to comment further. The magazine Der Spiegel claimed this week that West German firms had helped Iraq develop ''military nuclear technology, construction of rockets and production of poison gases.''

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Democrats Urge Bush to Pressure Oil Companies on Price Increases

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats accused the oil industry today of engaging in price-gouging and exhorted President Bush to stop it.
''Someone is making a killing,'' Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said at one of three hastily arranged public hearings on sharp increases in American fuel prices following Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
Charles J. Di Bona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, vehemently denied the accusation. Critics of the oil industry are taking ''a naive, one-sided view of how markets work,'' he said. 
American oil companies had no choice but to pass on to consumers the higher cost of oil on the world market, Mr. Di Bona maintained, saying prices would drop if world prices fall.
 
A Call for Pressure
But angry members of Congress said Mr. Bush should pressure industry leaders for price relief, in much the same way President John F. Kennedy pressured the steel industry in the early 1960's.
Mr. Bush also was urged to tap the Government's crude oil reserve. The aim would be to cushion American consumers against further economic repercussions from hostilities in the Middle East.
Oil companies have raised gasoline prices by as much as 25 cents a gallon since President Saddam Hussein sent his Iraqi forces into neighboring Kuwait last week. Company executives said their prices are the result of increases in crude oil costs, from $16 a barrel in July to $27 after the invasion.
The American Automobile Association reported today that prices for self-service unleaded gas went up an average of 1.5 cents per gallon overnight and have averaged 12.6 cents higher than they were Aug. 1. The average is now $1.20 per gallon, the highest since 1985, said the A.A.A., which checked 1,400 service stations nationwide.
 
Eager to Show Anger
Today's spate of hearings was an unusual occurrence during a Congressional recess. But lawmakers were anxious to vent their constitutents' anger over price increases. They were joined in this high-profile public interrogation by officials of state and local governments and consumer groups.
Despite oil industry denials of price-gouging, several witnesses maintained, the evidence was otherwise. They complained that oil companies are quick to pass on price increases but slow to pass along any savings.
''The American public is angry,'' said Senator Richard Bryan, Democrat of Nevada. ''They have a sense they are being held hostage to you, the oil companies.''
The industry executives were summoned a day after the Justice Department pledged that it would look into the soaring fuel prices. Anti-competitive pricing activities will be aggressively prosecuted, it said.
 
'On a Massive Scale'
But that did not satisfy angry congressmen.
''In the last week, American consumers have been ripped off on a massive scale,'' Senator Joseph Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, complained to witnesses appearing before a Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee.
Representative Phil Sharp, Democrat of Indiana, said president Saddam ''may not be the only greedy person in this picture.''
Mr. Bryan cited a nationwide survey by the American Automobile Association showing gas prices up at least 11 cents - and as high as 19 cents - since last week's invasion. The prices have soared despite evidence showing supplies are still plentiful.
''One is left with the inescapable conclusion that profiteering is occurring at the expense of the American consumer,'' Mr. Bryan said.
But Glenn Tilton, president of Texaco Refining and Marketing Inc., said his company was a hostage to supply and demand - and thus had to raise its prices along with everyone else.
Mr. Lieberman said Mr. Bush should summon executives of the big oil companies and tell them to exercise price restraint.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
FEW CHOICES SEEN FOR IRAQI LEADER

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, unexpectedly faced with a rapid and menacing global response to his invasion of Kuwait, increasingly is being backed into a corner from which his most likely options are to surrender or to lash out militarily, private and Government experts on the Middle East said today.
Those experts said that in the next several days he may well decide whether to choose war, striking at Saudi Arabia in an attempt to capture or destroy oilfields on which the Western economies rely, or withdraw his forces into Iraq, perhaps through a face-saving negotiated agreement.
President Hussein also could choose to remain entrenched in Kuwait and hope that an international ban on trade with Iraq, imposed on Monday by the United Nations, will crumble. But Saudi Arabia's decision to increase oil production, offsetting some of the shortage of 4 million barrels a day created by the United Nations embargo, makes that option increasingly unattractive. 
If President Hussein backs down or is defeated, the experts say, he probably cannot long retain his grip on power.
 
Choice of 'the Big Gamble'
''The next 24 to 48 hours are going to tell the story,'' a Government official who is kept informed of developments in the gulf crisis said today. ''What he's going to do is really difficult to predict.''
In the opinion of that official and others, any military action by Iraqi forces is likely to occur relatively soon, before American aircraft and troop deployments and naval forces of several nations move within easy striking range.
A speedy march into Saudi Arabia would give President Hussein's forces a chance to reach Saudi oilfields and pipelines, making it much more difficult for Western forces to evict them without destroying centers that supply nearly a quarter of the world's oil.
''If he's boxed in, I don't think anyone should be sanguine about what he'd do next,'' Thomas McNaugher, a Brookings Institution expert on Iraqi military and political matters, said in an interview today. ''He's shown a clear willingness to take the big gamble and use his military options.''
 
A Squandered Opportunity
But Mr. McNaugher and others agreed that President Hussein already appears to have squandered one option: a swift withdrawal of most of his troops from Kuwait and installing a pliable civilian government that could win Arab acceptance.
That would not have been difficult. The exiled Emir of Kuwait is not beloved among Arab heads of state, in part because of Kuwait's persistent violation of OPEC agreements to limit oil production.
Had President Hussein taken that approach before the United States and United Nations acted this week, they said, the Saudis and others would have been more reluctant to support the United Nations embargo or an American military presence.
Even an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait still would have delivered President Hussein's message that Iraq was the dominant Arab nation and the controlling force in oil production and pricing, Mr. McNaugher said.
''An ability to impact Saudi oil production levels would have crushed the embargo if he could have carried it off,'' a Government official said. But with the Saudis now aligned against it, Iraq has lost its leverage among Arab Governments and the political payoff from a withdrawl.
 
Chance for Negotiated Solution
Helmut Sonnenfeldt, a State Department counselor in the Nixon and Ford Administrations and a national-security expert, said President Hussein still could seek a negotiated solution to the crisis along the lines suggested by his allies in the Palestine Liberation Organization and by King Hussein of Jordan. That peace plan calls for Iraqi withdrawal, an election to choose a new Kuwaiti Government, and some form of subsidization of the Iraqi economy.
With Iraq already under an international order to leave Kuwait and permit the Emir's return, that course ''is not much of an option, either,'' he said. ''But he may think the coalition against him will begin to crack if something reasonable is put forward.''
And to concede defeat now would wreck President Hussein's dream of leadership in the Arab world. ''If you believe this guy wants a bigger position in the world, a position with the have-nots of the Arab world cheering him on, then he's not going to back down,'' a Government expert said.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Jordan Talks of Balance But Some See Iraqi Tilt

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 7

 BODY:
As the crisis surrounding Kuwait expands, King Hussein of Jordan is struggling to balance his old friendships with his recent enthusiasm for Iraq and its strongman, Saddam Hussein.
Though he is a longtime ally of the United States, the King has refused to join in the condemnation of Iraq. Though he is a hereditary ruler from the Hashemite Kingdom, he has remained silent about the forced exile of the Kuwaiti royal family in the face of invading Iraqi troops.
The King is trying to avoid taking sides, his aides say, in the hope that he can continue talking with the Iraqi President and serve as a bridge between him and other Arab leaders to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. 
 
'Wanted to Keep the Doors Open'
Jordan's Prime Minister, Mudar Badran, said that joining with a majority of Arab League members to protest the invasion of Kuwait ''would have closed the door against any possibility of going to Iraq to resolve the situation.''
''We wanted to keep the doors open between us and our brothers in Iraq,'' he said.
Western diplomats who watched an NBC News interview with the King broadcast by Jordan's state-run station over the weekend said that at one point he appeared to have crossed the center of the road in favor of the Iraqi leader.
''I believe he is a person to be trusted and be dealt with,'' King Hussein said of the Iraqi President in the interview. ''He is an Arab patriot in the eyes of many.''
Workers as well as members of the Jordan's political elite said in interviews today that they deeply admired Saddam Hussein for having held off Iran in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war.
They said they had little sympathy for Kuwait, which they said had shared much less of its oil riches with Jordan than their country deserved as a buffer state with Israel.
 
No Recognition, or Criticism
Jordan has so far withheld recognition of the newly installed Government of Kuwait, though it is among the handful of Arab states that have refrained from criticizing the invasion and calling for an immediate withdrawal.
As aid from the United States and the Gulf states has diminished and Jordan's economy has suffered, King Hussein has drawn closer to the Iraqi leader. Diplomats say the two leaders appear genuinely to enjoy each other's company.
For Jordan, with its 360 miles of open border with Israel, the good will of the most powerful country in the Arab world is regarded as vital.
''Iraq's power is our shield,'' said Mahmoud el-Sherif, the editor of Jordan's oldest daily newspaper, Ad Dustour. ''We look to Iraq, a big country, a powerful country, as a political shield against Israeli expansionism.''
There has been little public debate about King Hussein's responsibility toward the Kuwaiti royal family. ''If we had taken a strong position on the royal family of Kuwait we would have lost our leverage with the Iraq leadership,'' said a Jordanian close to the Government. ''That leverage is our priority. We are still expecting movement.'' Caught in the Middle Strong criticism from Washington has led to worry that widespread fighting could develop, with a possible military reaction from Israel. Caught between Israel and Iraq, ''We would become hamburger,'' said Kamel Abu Jaber, a former university professor who now directs the Jordanian Center for Middle Eastern Studies.
The Jordanian Government and many private Jordanians argue that negotiations among Arabs are likely to be most successful in resolving the crisis. They say they do not believe the Iraqi President has designs on Saudi Arabia. But they said economic sanctions or a military strike could provoke an emotional reaction from him.
Many Jordanians say that the invasion of Kuwait does not suggest to them that their small country of 2.8 million people might also be in jeopardy from Iraq at some point.
Instead, they say that Kuwait was a special case, and that in many ways Iraq was justified in invading. Like the Iraqis, the Jordanians believe that Kuwait did not sufficiently contribute to Iraq's costs in the war with Iran.
Not only were Kuwait and Iraq feuding about Iraqi claims that Kuwait had been pilfering millions of dollars worth of oil from border oil fields, but Iraq has also claimed ownership of the territory from the time of Kuwait's emergence as a state in 1961.
''This is a long-term historical dispute,'' one Goverment official said. ''The new element was that with Iraq out of the war and burdened with debts, it considered Kuwait owed a debt and it wanted to be paid. This is an internal dispute between Arab states. It is not like your invasions of Grenada or Panama.''
Jordan has also been disappointed that it has not been able to obtain more financial support and more sophisticated weaponry from the United States.
 
Strong Current of Resentment
The resentment here toward Kuwait runs deep. ''The Kuwait people deserve what happened,'' said Mona Elyamani, a 26-year-old psychology student at the University of Jordan. ''They are very rich and they spend their money playing poker and going to discos. A lot of poor people are starving in the Arab world and they do not look after them.''
Many Jordanians said they felt Arab leaders had been humiliated in relations with Israel and the United States. Though they worried about an eruption of violence, they said they felt inspired by Mr. Hussein's frequent harsh responses to his critics and his quick strike to end the bickering with Kuwait.
''Deep in my heart I am happy,'' said a pharmacist in her mid-30's, who spoke only on the condition that she not be identified. ''We really want someone to give us a sense of worth. We Arabs have been suffering so long.''

LENGTH: 1155 words

HEADLINE: Faltering Hopes for Accord on Deficit Are Dimmed Further by Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Democratic and Republican lawmakers said today that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is a serious setback for already troubled budget talks between Congress and the White House and that it will probably scuttle any deficit reduction for the coming year.
While the negotiators stressed that they had not given up on a budget agreement, the tone of their comments made plain how pessimistic many of them had become. The situation in the Persian Gulf, they said, created new difficulties, political and substantive, in reaching agreement on a package of spending cuts and tax increases to trim $50 billion from the deficit for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
In policy terms, there are growing doubts about whether an economy that is showing signs of weakness can withstand $50 billion in belt-tightening, while political options like energy tax increases and deep cuts in the Pentagon budget now become more difficult to sell to the rest of Congress. 
''The bottom line is that those who have been looking for an excuse to avoid making tough decisions on the budget may have found in the Persian Gulf their salvation,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. ''The outcome of the budget negotiations this fall will be determined by the events in the Persian Gulf over the next few weeks.''
 
Session in Secluded Setting
After two months of talks that have yielded only partisan bickering, the negotiators are planning to meet in a secluded setting outside Washington in the first week of September to push for an agreement. Lawmakers in both parties have repeatedly said that what the budget debate needed was a sense of crisis about the deficit to overcome political resistance.
''We now certainly have a sense of crisis; the only problem is that it is the wrong crisis,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee. ''The one we have simply feeds into a basic resistance on deficit reduction.''
But even before the situation in the gulf arose, negotiators had become concerned that a $50 billion deficit package could tip a fragile economy into recession and were wondering if a smaller package might make more sense. With the price of oil already up by $5 a barrel, and further increases possible if tensions remain high, the recession fear has become more pronounced and the likelihood of a smaller package is now discussed openly.
''If the oil price stays at that level, it slows the economy more by contributing to inflation,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee. ''It would be like pulling $60 billion out of the economy before you even get to budget cuts.''
Mr. Bentsen, like other budget negotiators, said those involved in the talks would want to re-examine the economy and the situation in the gulf in September before making a decision about scaling back the deficit package. ''The dilemma we face on the other side is what happens to the financial markets if don't do enough on the deficit,'' he said, adding that actions by the Federal Reserve Board on interest rates will also have a major effect on what the negotiators decide.
 
Less Room to Maneuver
The talks so far are based on the premise that cutting a sizable chunk from the deficit would produce a favorable reaction from financial markets and permit the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. But with higher oil prices adding to inflation, budget negotiators worry that the board may have less maneuvering room.
The higher oil prices also mean that increases in energy taxes, which had seemed a likely possibility for the tax portion of the deficit package, are now a much less attractive option.
''There's no question that things like energy taxes become more difficult if you're in the middle of an embargo or blockade,'' the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said Monday. ''It makes the acceptance of energy taxes more politically difficult, though not necessarily less desirable.''
On the spending side, cuts in the military budget and in large Government benefit programs like Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security become more politically difficult. Moreover, attempting to cut the benefit programs may be futile because they include provisions for automatic increases when inflation goes up or the economy goes into recession.
''I'm pessimistic,'' said Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee. ''When you combine a slower economy with Iraq and the hastening date of the November elections, it seems to me the momentum has turned the other way. Whenever there is turmoil and confusion, you can always expect Congress to do as little as possible.''
 
Pessimistic View Is Unchanged
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, has long predicted that even if the budget negotiators could agree on the ingredients for a deficit reduction plan, they would be unable to sell it to the rest of Congress before the November elections. Mr. Packwood said today that nothing had happened to change his view.
''I don't know what the impact of the Persian Gulf is; I haven't been able to figure it out yet,'' he said. ''But if the argument has been that the deficit is our most important problem and we need to agree on cutting it, I don't see that the situation in the Persian Gulf has changed that problem.''
Negotiators have been deeply divided over how the spending cuts should be divided between military and domestic spending, and the Persian Gulf flare-up will do little to resolve those differences. While lawmakers say events in the gulf should theoretically have little to do with cutting the elements of the military budget that involved countering a Soviet threat, they agreed that the psychological effect of gulf tension could weigh against Pentagon cuts.
''If there is an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, all bets are off on defense cuts,'' Mr. Packwood said.
 
Escape Clauses in Budget Law
In fact, all bets may be off in any event, due to some provisions in the balanced-budget law. The automatic spending cuts that are due to take effect under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law on Oct. 1 if agreement is not reached on cutting the deficit can be waived by the President with the consent of Congress, if there is a recession or if economic projections predict two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.
The automatic cuts would also be immediately suspended if Congress declared war.
But lawmakers in both parties said it was hard to imagine that anyone at the White House was paying a great deal of attention to the fine points of the budget law right now. As a senior Congressional budget aide said, ''For the time being, I have taken my budget charts and graphs off the wall and replaced them with a map of the Persian Gulf.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''We now certainly have a sense of crisis; the only problem is that it is the wrong crisis,'' said Leon E. Panetta, left, House Budget Committee chairman. Pete V. Domenici, Republican on Senate Budget Committee, said ''The outcome of the budget negotiations this fall will be determined by the events in the Persian Gulf over the next few weeks.'' (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Emergency's Here: Use the Oil

 BODY:
American consumers are being ''ripped off on a massive scale,'' Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut said yesterday, voicing anger felt around the country. The anger is directed at gas stations and oil companies that jacked up prices even though the gasoline they were selling was imported long before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Is that price-gouging? Yes, but trying to do something about it would punish consumers worse. If regulators tried to roll back prices, they would create severe shortages reminiscent of the tortuous gas lines of the 1970's. Nevertheless, Congressional Democrats exhort President Bush to stop the price-gouging. 
They ought to focus instead on something useful that Mr. Bush can do: Open the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, 600 million barrels of oil stored in underground salt domes along the Gulf Coast. Prudent use of the oil reserve can calm jittery markets and minimize the impact of Saddam Hussein's aggression.
As demonstrated anew by yesterday's dramatic announcement that troops will be sent to Saudi Arabia, the President has so far skillfully orchestrated the military and diplomatic counterattack. But by refusing to tap the reserve, he is fumbling the economic response.
The United Nations embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait will, if enforced, cut off 8 percent of the world's oil supply. That's no small hit. And traders, fearing the worst, have begun to hoard every barrel in sight, thereby adding to the disruption. The combination of interrupted supply and panicky demand has driven crude oil prices $10 a barrel above last month's level.
That has surely produced windfall profits for wholesalers and retailers who bought oil at pre-invasion prices. Such profits are infuriating but they are not easily eliminated. If Congress were to try, by temporarily rolling back retail gas prices, the outcome would be calamitous. Speculators would hoard low-price gas until the price controls were lifted. That's a recipe for severe shortage. And meanwhile, the artificially low prices would send precisely the wrong signal to consumers, who ought to be conserving petroleum.
Denouncing gas station owners won't help consumers. What would help them is extra supply. That could come from Saudi Arabia, which has now promised to pump an extra two million barrels a day. And it could come from the Strategic Reserve, which was created after the 1973-74 oil crisis as a defense against temporary supply interruptions. In combination with similar buffer stocks in Japan and Europe, the reserve is large enough to offset the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil for up to a year. All that's necessary is a declaration by President Bush that an emergency exists.
The Administration balks because selling oil from the reserve smacks of price control. That misses the point. The purpose of tapping the reserve is not to put a permanent lid on prices. It's to mitigate a temporary supply crunch created by the President's decision, unquestionably correct, to organize a worldwide embargo. The crunch has been made worse by hoarding, which would ease as soon as the President announced the opening of the Strategic Reserve.
If Saudi Arabia pumps extra oil as promised, that solves half the problem. The strategic reserve can handle the rest of the imbalance. The U.S. spent billions to create the reserve as a buffer against temporary disruptions. This crisis is the time to reap the benefit of that investment.
The choice is not, as the Administration implies, between competitive markets and price controls. It is between economic damage and minor irritation. This is an emergency; that's what lifeboats are for.

HEADLINE: In South Africa: The Nightmare Ebbs

 BODY:
The world is too absorbed by the Persian Gulf to be wholly attentive, but there's stunning news from South Africa:
An ''armed struggle'' that began 29 years ago has been suspended by Nelson Mandela's African National Congress as part of a landmark bargain with President F. W. de Klerk. And for his part, South Africa's reforming President has agreed to the phased release of some 1,500 political prisoners and to the return of more than 20,000 anti-Government exiles.
This gives substance to hopes for peace, and removes a stubborn obstacle to full-scale talks on a non-racist constitution for South Africa. 
The suspension of the armed struggle finally gives President de Klerk something to show to his own supporters. If he has gone only partway in meeting Mr. Mandela's demand for immediate release of all prisoners, at least a deadline has been set and the principle accepted. It is a compromise that surely augurs well for wider talks on South Africa's future.
Now both leaders will need all their resourcefulness to bridge deeper divergences. They are pledged to redouble efforts to curb violence in Natal, where fighting between rival black movements has cost 1,200 lives this year.
Also ahead is the daunting task of reconciling different visions in a society that is haunted by ethnic hatreds, political rivalry and a gaping inequality of income.
Mr. Mandela firmly demands a one-person-one-vote system that would empower blacks. Mr. de Klerk agrees that suffrage should be multiracial, but seeks entrenched constitutional guarantees to protect minority rights. This circle could be squared with a system of checks and balances, incorporating a bill of rights and enforced by an independent judiciary.
The African National Congress is pledged to nationalize industry and radically redistribute wealth. For his part, Mr. de Klerk says his insistence on a free market economy is non-negotiable. But Socialist economies have failed in Africa as well as in Europe.
It would make more sense for Mr. Mandela to press for more jobs, better pay and opportunity in a country where 88 percent of the wealth is controlled by only 5 percent of the people, nearly all of them white.
South Africans will decide these arguments but Americans can help promote their peaceful resolution. When full-scale negotiations begin, Congress can prudently review U.S. sanctions as conditions for easing them are met.
Against all the odds, leaders of decency and sense are moving forward, and the long nightmare appears to be moving steadily away from apocalypse and toward peace. Even in crisis elsewhere, that is news worth celebration.

HEADLINE: For Congress, One Month Left

 BODY:
Finding nothing so urgent that can't wait till September, Congress broke for its summer vacation right on schedule. The budget deficit? Manana. Curbs on campaign contributions? Clean air? Child care? Some other day. New taxes? Horrors. 
This 101st Congress returns after Labor Day, and breaks again on Oct. 5 to campaign. If it wants to be known for more than procrastination, that will be a busy month.
Nothing marks this Congress's non-accomplishment so vividly as its failure to frame a budget. Even its few accomplishments will be limited by the widening gap between spending and revenue. The admirable AIDS treatment bill offers an example. It authorizes nearly $900 million a year to deal with the epidemic as a natural disaster, with urgently needed help for places like New York City. But in the end, there's no way of knowing how much will actually be appropriated.
Budget negotiations with the White House have been under way for three months. They have gotten absolutely nowhere - and the deficit has gotten bigger. The crisis in the Middle East will only make agreement more difficult, reinforcing the case for more defense spending. And that's on top of rising costs for the savings and loan bailout, and sagging revenues from the slowdown in the nation's economic activity.
The budget negotiators now promise to get serious next month. But after five years of fudging, such promises aren't worth much. Time alone will tell. And meanwhile the House and Senate have been fattening this year's money bills with extras as if there were no problem. The House and Senate farm bills are prime examples. President Bush properly threatens a veto if the final bill is not trimmed.
On some issues that don't require Federal funds, Congress has scored impressively this year. Both the House and Senate passed civil rights legislation to undo Supreme Court decisions that have eroded job discrimination laws - but a veto is threatened. Both houses voted unanimously to require double hulls on oil tankers. But a House-Senate conference on the clean air bill has made almost no headway in resolving wide disparities in their two versions.
On issues closer to home - members' behavior and campaign financing - the record is still murky. The Senate took the rare step of denouncing a fellow member, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, for improper financial dealings. But his egregious misconduct also warrants stripping him of seniority; his G.O.P. colleagues won't even convene a meeting to consider the question.
Meanwhile, not a word from the Senate Ethics Committee on the ''Keating Five'' Senators who pressured savings and loan regulators on behalf of a large contributor, or on Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York, who is under investigation for questionable fund-raising and favoritism.
As for the larger question of campaign finance, there's no law yet, but the Senate has passed a strong bill and the House has at least passed some bill. That gives reason to hope that a post-vacation conference can produce meaningful reform.
There's plenty of work to do, and there won't be much time to do it.

HEADLINE: Don't Pin Housing Drop on Savings and Loans

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It came as a small surprise to see the country's housing leaders cite the savings and loan crisis as a primary reason for a looming economic recession and a continuing drop in new housing starts (front page, July 19).
The savings and loan industry is the favorite whipping boy on Capitol Hill. If there are too many unsold homes on the market, if interest rates go up, if the Federal deficit balloons, blame the savings and loans. 
It is time to stop sticking pins in the savings and loan industry. Other mortgage lenders, such as commercial banks, have cut their mortgage lending activity. Mortgage bankers have also pared their lending activity. Both have escaped unfavorable treatment in the news media.
Declining housing starts are removed from the savings and loan crisis. The slowdown in housing starts, as well as in resales, results from the public's refusal, and inability, to pay the prices. In the 1980's, Mr. and Mrs. Average American wanted to take advantage of the equity in their homes and trade up to the home of their dreams. The real estate market was quickly glutted with trade-up houses, and the price tags were too high for most people.
Instead of blaming the savings and loans for the slump in real estate, economists should look at the reasons for the high cost of housing. To a large extent, this country has gone through unprecedented prosperity coupled with runaway inflation. People were working, incomes were rising, and money was to be made in almost every market. The cost of housing, like everything else, took off.
Financial institutions did not set the prices on new housing starts. Builder-developers sent prices skyrocketing with each new development. Prospective buyers were encouraged to buy before a price increase took effect. Houses that came on the market at $200,000 quickly advanced to $250,000.
Savings and loans had nothing to do with the exorbitant price tags. Congress should direct the bulk of its criticism for the housing slump at the builders. Sooner or later, builders had to realize that the real estate bubble would burst, and the party would be over.
 
BARRY J. ZADWORNY
Senior Vice President
Roma Savings Bank
 Trenton, July 24, 1990

HEADLINE: The Catskills Trade In a Little Glitz for Much More Substance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Talk of Sullivan County'' (news article, July 13) depicts several issues as the burning issues of the moment in Sullivan County, New York.
While the tourist economy has indeed changed dramatically, I would hardly describe the county as a depressed, withered, crumbling community ''where crack houses co-exist with Catskill resorts.'' That our bungalows have declined and the resorts have lost prominence is not the travesty you imply, but merely evidence of a changing, adapting - yes, even vital - economy that has diversified and evolved beyond the traditions of the past. 
The county's tourist economy, different though it may be, still thrives with more than one million tourists enjoying our county annually. We have also become a major second-home area in the last decade - an industry that contributes far more stability to our economy than did the tourism of the past. Our economy has also evolved into a much more diverse and productive one; roughly 4,000 new jobs were added in the last five years, despite a net loss of hotel employment, with average weekly earnings rising 40 percent during this time, ranking us third in the state.
We have our problems, but they are those of success, not failure. As the third fastest growing county in the state in population as well as wage gain, we face the problem of fast-paced growth and development, not of a withering economy. Visual quality, a focal point in your article, is just one of many more important issues the county has begun to address through various measures. A recently appointed task force is working on a master plan for the county that we hope will make greater headway into many of these issues.
Your focus on the declining segments of traditional tourism is understandable, given the historical reputation of Sullivan County for its world-class resorts - a reputation that has lost some of its luster. However, this focus fails to acknowledge what Sullivan County has become - a livable, diverse community that is still a haven for many city dwellers seeking rural relief while attracting a growing number of permanent residents who are enchanted with our bucolic countryside, saner pace of life and more affordable housing. If we have traded a little of the glitz for much more substance, perhaps the trade-off will serve us better in the long term.
 
DAVID KAUFMAN
Chairman, Board of Supervisors
Sullivan County
 Monticello, N.Y., July 20, 1990

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Someone Has to Pay

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
My plan was to wax wroth today about gasoline prices being raised at Biff's Exxon before Iraq's Wehrmacht had moved more than 10 yards into money-rich Kuwait. Luckily, while I was searching for the wax my gaze fell on a New York Times story that took the steam out of me.
This was one of those fuller-explanation stories that make The Times indispensable to people who would rather know what's going on than foam at the mouth. Being of the foamer species, I studied it with deepening gloom. 
If I read it right, it would be childish to throw a fit about Biff or accuse oil tycoons of putting razor to the motorist's throat. The only villains, it seems, are (1) psychology and (2) computers.
Precisely how these two did the dirty deed at Biff's is something I'm not ready to be examined on. Accounts of how the marketplace works its miracles have tended to numb my brain ever since I dropped out of Economics 101 on the pretext of having to attend my mother-in-law's funeral, and ended up failing Logic 102 after the professor pointed out that since I was not yet married a dead mother-in-law was a logical absurdity.
In short, I may have a finer point or two about the oil market wrong. Still, the twin messages of the Times story seemed clear enough: (1) Iraq's move created an instant psychological need for gasoline-price rises. (2) The existence of computers transmitted this psychological hunger across the country faster than a clutch of program traders can wipe out the stock market by electronically switching all their business to the $100 window at Pimlico.
The result: Biff had his ladder up against his sign before you could say, ''Saddam Hussein and King Hussein are not related.''
Naturally I figured Biff being up the ladder meant the price of gasoline was finally dropping a couple of cents per gallon in response to the excess stocks of crude oil burdening the market. I had been reading all summer about that excess crude oil and wondered when it would lead to a price drop at Biff's.
Oh sure, I knew about the refinery in Louisiana that's always out of order whenever crude-oil stocks become excessive, and I knew that this breakdown always keeps gasoline prices unnaturally high long after they would otherwise decline.
So I said to Biff up the ladder: ''Finally posting a drop in prices, I see, Biff. Guess that means they fixed that refinery down in Louisiana.''
Biff said, no, he didn't expect they'd get that refinery fixed in his lifetime, or even his grandchildren's, and he was going up to post a price increase, not a cut. ''Say it's not so, Biff.'' ''Saddam Hussein marched into Kuwait two minutes ago,'' he replied.
Not wanting Biff to think me an ignorant provincial, I rushed to the library to read up on Saddam Hussein, so didn't ask Biff why he had jacked up prices faster than instantly. Now of course I know. It was because psychology was moving faster than the speed of Superman.
I suppose Biff was sitting by his cash register in a light doze, dreaming of the bad old days when he not only had to pump gas for his customers but also had to give them road maps free instead of charging $2.50. With his mind idling like this, it would have been highly receptive to psychological transmissions from oil headquarters, where computers of course were humming furiously.
Biff has no computer, but a mere second on the hot line to Exxon Interplanetary would have sufficed for him to get a recorded message: ''Saddam Hussein has invaded Kuwait.''
Biff must have murmured, ''By George, I feel an irresistible psychological need to boost prices,'' and gone to it.
Understanding this, thanks to The Times's fuller explanation, I cannot pour bile on good old Biff or even on psychology-and-computer-driven oil tycoons without suffering the guilt that follows a bout of unfair journalism.
But surely someone must be made to pay. Fuming against Saddam Hussein would be worse than useless, for Saddam Hussein is an Arab, and few things improve the Arab day more than evidence that an Arab has made an American fume.
It's just as useless to denounce the evils of psychology and computers. I have tried it before. The only result is a flood of letters from smug know-it-alls sneering at either your ignorance of electronics or your patently childish sexual inhibitions.
Let us rage then against Henry Ford the Founder for enslaving us to these doom machines. Without them, Saddam Hussein would be just another Hussein not related to the King.

HEADLINE: Tobacco Companies Find Harlem Wary

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
For years Harlem Week - a celebration of black culture and achievement -has relied on companies like Philip Morris and Heublein Inc. to underwrite its concerts, athletic competitions and receptions.
But this year, amid protests over the heavy advertising of tobacco and alcohol in black and Hispanic communities and some threats to disrupt the festival, the organizers of Harlem Week, which began on Monday, have decided to give some of these companies a lower profile.
When promotional posters and banners go up, the names of sponsors will still be on them, but without words like ''rum,'' ''vodka'' or ''beer.'' The festival has banned for several years the advertising of cigarette brands, though it lets the parent companies like Philip Morris use their corporate names.
''We believe there's an excess proliferation of tobacco and liquor promotion in our community,'' said Lloyd Williams, president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce, which organizes Harlem Week. 
Throughout the nation, black and Hispanic organizations, including newspapers and professional associations, that have relied on money from alcohol and tobacco companies are wrestling with an issue that pits their financial viability against what protesters say is the health of the communities they serve.
As recipients of corporate money, minorities straddle a particularly uncomfortable line. Blacks, for instance, smoke and suffer smoking-related diseases at a higher rate than whites. At the same time, tobacco companies are praised for being among the first businesses to recognize the value of supporting black organizations and events.
Some publishers of newspapers and magazines aimed at minority readers said that tobacco and alcohol companies took out advertisements when no one else would.
''I had a beer distributor that gave me advertising for six months and kept me alive,'' said Tino Duran, publisher of two Spanish-language weeklies in Texas and president of the National Association of Hispanic Publications. ''If it hadn't been for that kind of advertising, I wouldn't be in business today.''
 
A Bill in Congress
But several minority organizations have re-examined their policies, influenced by a general concern about health, work by the anti-smoking lobby, the marketing practices of some of the companies and the efforts of the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, who is black and has made the health of minorities a priority.
The concern about marketing has also resulted from well-publicized crusades by community leaders like the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d in Harlem and the Rev. Michael Pfleger in Chicago. At the same time, minority health-related organizations have rallied behind a bill pending in Congress that would severely restrict cigarette advertising. According to Matthew Myers, director of the Coalition on Smoking or Health, a group of 40 national organizations that endorse the bill, minority health professionals are increasingly speaking out about the costs of cigarette smoking.
''It's a frustration among those of us in the health community,'' Mr. Myers said. ''In our society today tobacco takes its greatest toll in the minority communities, and yet until recently very few members of the minority community spoke up loudly.''
Critics charge that tobacco companies have aggressively gone after black and Hispanic customers as their overall market shrinks. A major concern is the use of billboards, which these critics see as an indiscriminate medium that reaches minors.
 
Fighting With Paint
It is not the first time that such advertising has been criticized, but tobacco and alcohol companies said this was the first time the attacks had come from black and Hispanic groups.
Thirty-four percent of black adults smoke, compared with 28 percent of white adults and 27 percent of Hispanic adults, according to a 1989 study by the Simmons Market Research Bureau. Sixty-four percent of white people drink alcohol, compared with 63 percent of Hispanic people and 60 percent of black people, the bureau reported.
In a highly publicized campaign that has spread to other cities, Mr. Butts, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, and members of his congregation have been taking to the streets with long-handled rollers and white paint to cover billboards that advertise cigarettes and liquor in Harlem.
''You don't see that in the white community,'' he said. ''They don't do it anywhere else like that. It's criminal.''
But leaders like Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, have accused critics of implying that blacks are not capable of making their own choices.
The executive vice president of the National Urban League, Frank Lomax 3d, said his organization would continue accepting money from tobacco and alcohol companies because ''all corporations in America have a responsibility to help address some of the problems facing urban communities.''
 
Saturating Black Neighborhoods
Advertisers deny that they aim their messages at black and Hispanic people disproportionately, and they say the protests are isolated.
''Our experience has been that the protesters are very few in number and represent extreme elements of anti-smoking groups and are not representative of the general population that attend our events or receive advertising from us,'' said John R. Nelson, a spokesman for Philip Morris U.S.A., maker of Marlboro cigarettes and Miller beer.
But the issue has not been lost among some organizations with sponsorship ties to the companies. The National Association of Black Journalists did not have Philip Morris as a sponsor when its annual conference met in Los Angeles last week, for the first time in at least 10 years. A deeply divided board of directors decided to forgo $40,000 that it had expected to receive from the tobacco maker.
 
The Uptown Uproar
The organization's president, Thomas Morgan, a reporter for The New York Times, said the board's vote was prompted by reports earlier this year that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company planned to test market Uptown, a menthol cigarette specifically aimed at black smokers. The news caused an uproar, and the company canceled the product.
The National Coalition of Hispanic Health and Human Services Organizations severed its financial ties with alcohol companies three years ago and since then has encouraged other Hispanic groups to take a similar stand.
The organizers of Harlem Week, which runs through Aug. 19, have adopted a compromise. They have continued accepting sponsorships from tobacco companies in the name of the parent company, not the cigarette brand. This year they told a dozen alcohol companies that are also sponsors that they could use the company or brand name on promotional materials but without naming the alcoholic beverage and in smaller type than ''Harlem Week,'' Mr. Williams said. For example, Mr. Williams said, ''Hennessey cognac'' could be used in the past in promotional materials, but this year only the importer's name, Schieffelin & Somerset Company, can be used.
Mr. Duran and other publishers said those who criticize alcohol and cigarette advertising should also consider economic impact.
''We're concerned about the criticism. Is this forcing us to cut back or be less likely to support minority groups? The answer is no,'' said a Heublein spokesman, John A. Shea. ''We have a longstanding commitment to the minority community.''
Companies are also responding to some of the concerns. In New York, some billboard companies like Sale Point Posters put up public service announcements to replace the alchohol and tobacco advertisements. Metropolitan Outdoor Advertising moved the advertisements away from churches, schools and playgrounds. Some advertisers announced that they would no longer advertise on billboards in any low-income neighborhood.
But Mr. Butts is not satisfied. He wants a nationwide halt of all alcohol and cigarette billboard advertising, and he is stating his case with periodic demonstrations in front of Philip Morris headquarters in Manhattan. He said he knows of sympathizers who have also vowed to monitor Harlem Week events and tear down any such open advertising if they run into it.
''The community is really upset,'' he said. ''They want it to stop.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lloyd Williams, president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce, which organized Harlem Week. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)
