HEADLINE: Crime, Police And Politics;
A Game of Numbers With a Long History

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to hire 1,058 more police officers is the latest in a long string of similar pledges by recent mayors and would-be mayors of New York City, maneuvers in a numbers game that has as much to do with political appearances as with fighting crime.
Last week, the City Council proposed hiring about half that number of officers by cutting the current budget, and Mr. Dinkins said he was not sure that the city could afford to do so. On Monday, he said it not only could do so, but must.
Why? The short answer, the Mayor's own aides acknowledge, is that four children have been shot and killed by bullets intended for others in recent weeks. New Yorkers, still testing their new mayor and impatient in the face of record-high crime, demanded a visceral response. Police hiring was the lethal weapon at hand. 
''It's been the red meat of local politics for the last 10 or 12 years,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed primarily by businesses.
 
Promises by Koch
Police officials say they will be glad to have the new recruits, but they are also among the first to warn that more officers alone will not solve the crime problem or protect sleeping children from stray bullets.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch made the same sorts of promises on hiring, a good number of which did not come true on time, or ended up barely keeping pace with retirements in what is by far the nation's largest police force. The principal difference is that he seemed to seize the initiative with such brio that it took the mayoral campaign last year for his opponents to make much of a fuss about why all the hiring had not occurred.
So what will happen now? Not much, since the first of the officers will not become recruits at the Police Academy until October and because of the time needed for training will not be on the streets until next spring, or available for regular assignments in patrol cars until the fall of 1991.
Of course, if Mr. Dinkins had not moved to hire more officers now, the city would be that much further behind in its elusive goal of restoring the 26,000-member Police Department to its pre-fiscal crisis strength of about 31,000 officers. And Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown's strategy of ''community policing'' - with its heavy emphasis on foot patrols - requires a lot of staffing.
The city loses more than 2,000 officers a year through attrition, so it must pedal hard just to stand still. Together with the previously scheduled hiring of 3,000 that was to have produced a net gain of 1,000 officers by next summer, the new hiring is intended to make a total gain of about 2,000 in the three departments - transit, housing and the main force.
Even that would mean a relative handful of extra officers on duty in a typical precinct at any time. But when some precincts have only one or two patrol cars available on the midnight shift as they do now, every little bit helps. #2 Percent Rise in Crime Even if all the officers are hired, correlations between the number of police officers and crime are extremely tenuous. In the early 1980's, as the size of the New York force increased markedly, crime declined, but it began climbing again in late 1985, even as the force was still growing.
In the first three months of the year, the most recent period for which final statistics are available, there were 61,356 reported crimes in January, 53,355 in February and 57,453 in March. Police officials say preliminary figures for the months since then show little change, though crime has risen by about 2 percent compared with last year and murders are expected to reach an all-time high of 2,000 or more by December.
But beyond these broad trends, what forced the Mayor's hand on the hiring was alarming individual crimes and headlines that quoted Mr. Dinkins as insisting that ''this is not Dodge City'' (although he was merely answering a television reporter who had asked, ''Is this Dodge City?'').
In the face of complaints that he never did enough advance planning, Mr. Koch vowed in 1984 to have 30,600 officers by 1988, and he repeated unequivocally in April 1987 that he would meet that goal. But in February 1988 he said fiscal uncertainty meant the goal would have to be postponed, and he in fact delayed a number of police classes to save money.
 
Looking for Money
On his third day in office last January, Mr. Dinkins delayed hiring more than 1,800 rookies because of unexpected revenue shortfalls. He vowed on Monday to do everything possible to hire the 1,058 officers. It could be politically disastrous for him to renege on that pledge after having been so publicly pressured into it.
Still, it remains unclear how the new officers will be paid for, and whether they can all be hired. Mr. Dinkins will finance the cost of the officers - and increases for prosecutors, jails, legal aid and community anti-crime groups - through about $26 million in cuts from other services.
But in the fiscal year that starts next July, the cost of the officers, including their employment benefits, will rise to about $66 million while the cuts made now will translate into only about $31 million on an annual basis. The difference will have to be made up through new revenue - probably higher taxes - or further cuts.
In the meantime, there is little prospect of improvement in the local economy, and the State Financial Control Board recently warned that tax revenues in the next fiscal year are likely to be about $1 billion short of what the city will need to pay the planned cost of all its programs - and that was before the new hiring was announced.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Trade Schools: Defaults And Broken Promises

SERIES: Students in Default: A Troubled Agency - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
Bonnie Rodgers says the trade school recruiters knocked on her door, left leaflets in her courtyard and even approached her outside the city welfare office, serenading her with phrases like ''financial aid'' and ''job placement.''
When she enrolled in a $2,800 course to become a nurse's assistant, she thought she was on her way out of poverty.
She wasn't. Although she made the trade school's honor roll, she still lency test, and she says her course certificate is worthless on the job market. Still on welfare, she is struggling to repay a $2,500 Federal student loan for a course that, she discovered, a public program offers free. 
 
'Bill Over My Head'
''It didn't do anything for me,'' she said. ''I've got a bill over my head and I still need an education.''
Critics of the nation's 4,000 private trade schools say experiences like Ms. Rodgers's are common. They say that many schools are more interested in harvesting financial aid dollars than in helping students, and that the schools often use dishonest recruiting techniques, admit unqualified students and provide them with inadequate teachers and equipment.
The schools are paid up front, often through Federal loans and grants signed over by low-income students. But with low-paying jobs, or no jobs at all, many students default, leaving taxpayers with the bill. Federal officials say defaults will top $2.4 billion this year, and although trade school students account for only 22 percent of the loans, they produce 44 percent of the defaults.
Defaults at trade schools, also called proprietary schools, have helped lead the nation's largest student-loan guarantor, the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, to the brink of collapse. The foundation is a nonprofit corporation that guarantees more than $9 billion in student loans, more than a third of them to proprietary school students.
The Government, which must repay 80 percent of defaulted loans to banks if the corporation collapses, is now trying to arrange a bailout.
 
Senate Hears Testimony
In February, Senate hearings produced testimony critical of virtually every aspect of the trade school industry, ranging from recruiters who promise too much to banks that do too little to collect on government-backed loans.
Texas officials have described a graduate of a truck driving institute who borrowed more than $5,000 only to learn that she could not get a state license - she had only one foot. Last year, state officials suspended a Houston trade school from the student loan program after it sent recruiting buses to other cities, signed up students at homeless shelters and helped them apply for aid.
The number of defaults, ''taken together with the scandals that have gone on in some of these trade schools, has sent out a clarion call for tighter regulations and stricter laws,'' said Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana, who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Post-Secondary Education.
No one knows the number of trade schools engaged in abuses. ''It's a minority,'' he said, ''but it's such a large minority that it's creating an educational crisis in this country.''
Defenders of the schools say abuses are limited. ''What you have is a handful of schools that badly abuse the program,'' said Stephen J. Blair, president of the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools. But even he estimated that about 15 percent of proprietary schools were engaging in objectionable practices.
 
Industry Cites Success
Mr. Blair said that on the whole the industry recruits qualified students and provides them with marketable skills. He said 61 percent of trade school students completed the programs, as against 43 percent of students at community colleges. He said 81 percent of graduates found jobs in their fields.
Citing studies by the trade school industry, Mr. Blair said it trains 74 percent of the nation's surgical technicians, 52 percent of its computer programmers and 33 percent of its secretaries.
About one-third of the trade school students default on loans, as against 7 percent at four-year universities. While critics say the figures reflect the inadequate programs and graduates' inability to get jobs, the schools say they are simply dealing with students from poorer backgrounds.
Last year, Lauro F. Cavazos, the Secretary of Education, called student-aid abuses ''rampant,'' a charge Mr. Blair disputes.
Complaints about abuses may rise with new welfare rules that will take effect this fall. Under the requirements of the 1988 Family Support Act, increased numbers of welfare recipients will be required to join work or training programs. That is expected to raise proprietary school enrollment, now about 1.8 million.
 
Diligence and Good Grades
Many trade school students become disillusioned and drop out, but not Ms. Rodgers. She has preserved a mound of notes, grades and honor roll certificates that showcase her diligence. A report card from one 13-week period shows her with a 96 average.
Ms. Rodgers, a 35-year-old single mother with five children, said she had been on welfare for about eight years when she decided to enroll in late 1986. Recruited by many schools, she settled on the Americo Technical Careers Institute.
The school's promise of financial aid sounded good, she said, but the words ''job placement'' sounded even better. Although the school manual stated that ''placement assistance is not to guarantee employment,'' Ms. Rodgers said that distinction was lost on her. ''When they said 'job placement,' I expected to be placed on a job,'' she said.
Ms. Rodgers, a 10th grade dropout, had to take an entrance exam, but she does not recall it's being difficult. ''I assume they accept everyone,'' she said. ''I knew people in there that couldn't do much reading.''
To pay for the $2,800 course, she said, she got $4,600 in Federal aid - a $2,100 grant and a $2,500 guaranteed loan; the aid not used for tuition was for living expenses. #66.1 Percent Default Government figures show that in the 1988 fiscal year, 66.1 percent of the loans to Americo's students were in default -1,739 loans worth almost $2.5 million.
Ms. Rodgers says many students enrolled just to get the living expenses. But her diligence is seen in pages of medical terms, like polydipsia and the integumentary system, carefully copied from a textbook. Now she says she did ''more memorizing and not as much understanding.'' Her view of her educational shortcomings seems borne out by her failure, even after a subsequent 16-week course, to pass a test for a general equivalency diploma.
But her biggest disappointment came when she wanted to turn her high-90's grades into a high-paying job. She says the school referred her to a job placement agency where she would be required to pay a fee. Unwilling to pay more money, she said she began putting in applications on her own, but found no interest.
 
Still on Welfare
Six months later, still on welfare, her first loan repayments came due, and she soon became another account number on a long list of defaults by Americo's students.
Marvin Copes, national director of education for American Educators, the company that owns Americo, said Ms. Rodgers's subsequent inability to pass a GED test does not indicate she was unprepared for the course. He said the Americo course tends to test more practical skills than does the GED test.
He said ''it is not normal'' for Americo students to be asked to pay a job placement fee, He said more than 85 percent of the school's graduates find jobs in a related field and offered to provide Ms. Rodgers with a free refresher course. ''I think the school is very sincere in its objectives,'' he said.
He would not speculate on reasons for the high default rate, but said repayment was the students' responsibility, not the school's.
Ms. Rodgers now works part time in a recreation program at a public housing project. Along with public assistance, the work brings her monthly income to about $350, she said. Out of that, she said, she has made four $50 payments on the loan, hoping to whittle it down so that someday she can re-enroll, this time in a public university.
Ms. Rodgers says her phone still rings with two types of callers, credit agencies pushing for faster loan repayment, and trade school recruiters. ''I told them I have been into that and I don't want to be involved with these schools no more,'' she said.

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Is the Killer Jacket Losing Its Grip?

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
MEN'S fashions were center stage in New York last week as leading designers showed their spring 1991 lines. The dominant message was hang loose. The antidote to the french-cuffed, pin-collared, my-suit-wants-to-eat-you-for-breakfast 1980's seems to be a roomier, slouchier, less uptight Mr. Dude.
Men's fashions don't change all that much, but they are constantly evolving. As proof, just look at yourself in a photograph from the mid-70's. (Then again, maybe you'd better not.) The current direction, with its easier, less restrictive silhouettes, recalls the boxy sack suits of the early 1960's and follows in the steps of recent women's collections. (Remember: men's wear became more feminine in the 1960's, too.) Among the feminizing touches: softer, unconstructed jackets; ''couturified'' sportswear items, like ponchos in silk and T-shirts in pure linen or spandex; all-white ensembles, and lots of pale, exotic colors like pistachio, mauve, ''mist linen'' and ''aqua mustard.'' (''Hey, Bob, throw me my pistachio jacket, will you?'') In some collections, shoulder padding has been removed, paralleling a similar reduction in women's clothing. But in others, like Bill Robinson's, suit shoulders retain an exaggerated sweep. Double-breasted jackets, once seen only in embassies, banks and speak-easies, are an accepted part of contemporary men's fashion. And there were a lot of them last week, from Isaac Mizrahi's white terry-cloth blazer to Joseph Abboud's creamy ivory tuxedo. 
Mr. Mizrahi bubbles with ideas, and his first complete collection for men was irrepressible, from its elegant hayseed looks, like seersucker overalls, to cabana sets in graphic patterns, which you may have been subjected to as a child in Miami.
Allow him to free associate: the classic men's rep tie, transformed into colorful banded rep trousers; slickers in red, yellow and white, lined in gingham check; overalls in floral paisley - to heck with the feed store. Mr. Mizrahi also showed several rajah, or Nehru, jackets, like the kind he wears himself.
These are clothes to bring out the man within the man. The timing may be right. People tend to wear more colorful clothes in times of recession, as a relief from the prevailing grayness in the economy.
Ronaldus Shamask is a designer's designer. Among those in the audience at Roseland last week for his fashion show were Geoffrey Beene, Mary McFadden, Randolph Duke and Jeffrey Banks.
Down the runway lumbered big, hunky guys with their jackets hanging loose, a couple days' stubble on their faces and Birkenstock sandals on their feet. Their trousers were held up by belts of rope. Could this be fashion? Check the prices. Brother, can you spare around $1,200?
Looking a bit like broke money managers roused from a park bench, the men wore long, loose ''JFK'' jackets, although they recalled Bobby more than Jack, with thin lapels and various button stances, usually very high, showing just a peak of necktie. Completing the look were high-waisted pleated trousers, often cropped.
Clearly, not a look to wear to the office, unless you follow the financial ticker from your beach house. But Mr. Shamask isn't really dressing men for work so much as for play. And his sportswear is crisply imaginative, from the plaid linen cardigan jackets to the crocheted vests and reversible mackintoshes.
Another designer from the slouch school is Bill Robinson. For his fashion show at Laura Belle, a discotheque on West 43d Street, Mr. Robinson sent the models out with shirts untucked, unconstructed jackets hanging loose, and either chukka boots or Converse All-Star high-top sneakers on their feet.
Among the hits were chenille sport jackets in khaki and blue, all-white beach clothes and big parkas in suede and canvas. Mr. Robinson is a terrific outerwear designer. When it comes to tailored clothing, he favors an extended shoulder that slopes and looks a little bunchy. This footballer look, especially in bold regatta-striped blazers, can be a bit theatrical.
For all the new ideas, the average man might ask, when will designers come up with a truly practical advance? A proper business suit, say, for 90-degree weather?
Alexander Julian has devoted himself to precisely that task. Mr. Julian, who works within traditional men's wear shapes but pushes the edge of the envelope when it comes to fabrics, has come up with hopsack-weave linen that is effectively half air. Whipped up into a three-button suit, the fabric is light as a feather and cool to wear. (The suit will be available next spring at about $900.) Another piece Mr. Julian takes particular pride in is a shirt of yarn-dyed Jacquard linen. The fabric, developed by the designer in Italy, is in the permanent collection of the Smithsonian Institution.
Joseph Abboud, who was declared the best men's wear designer of 1989 by the Council of Fashion Designers, appears to be all washed up. That is to say, stone-washed, sand-washed and river-washed, to name a few of the beatings his clothes go through.
Whether it's stone-washed khaki or linen trousers, a washed canvas jacket or sand-washed silk shirts, Mr. Abboud prefers clothing that has a patina of wear. He also makes excellent folk art sweaters and an extensive collection of ties, many with pale backgrounds. His look combines Mediterranean and Southwestern influences, Italian tailoring with ''broken pottery'' colors. It is handsome without being too adventurous.

THE OIL JOLT
 
The rise in oil prices on world markets slowed, and the reported Saudi pledge to produce an additional two million barrels a day, combined with production increases expected from other nations, may stem further price rises, analysts said. [Page D1.]
 
For corporate America and the U.S. economy, the sudden rise in oil prices could not have come at a worse time. With the economy already weak, the added drag of sharply higher energy costs is likely to slash corporate profits, economists say. [D1.] 
 
Natural gas is getting new consideration. Huge volumes of natural gas, long regarded by oil producers as the crab grass of fossil fuels, have been left in the ground because of the expense of bringing it to market. That may change. [D1.]
 
Oil companies are preparing to redeploy tanker fleets to pick up oil from alternative producers, and they are already paying a price for Mideast instability in higher insurance rates. [D5.]

HEADLINE: And There's Always Natural Gas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Natural gas, long regarded by oil producers as the crab grass of fossil fuels, is getting new consideration because of the crisis in the Middle East.
Finding gas has always been a disappointment to drillers looking for oil; bringing natural gas to market requires expensive pipelines or other equipment, while oil can be loaded on tankers and sold anywhere on earth. As a result, huge volumes of gas have been found but left in the ground, especially in the third world.
''This is really a new business,'' said Robinson West, president of the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington. ''There is an enormous amount of gas, and gas reserves are located in different areas than oil reserves. Many importing countries have substantial gas reserves.'' 
Global oil reserves amount to about one trillion barrels, and gas reserves to the equivalent of about 665 billion. But the world uses five times as much oil as gas. That could change markedly if world governments believe that Saddam Hussein has created a long-term increase in the price of oil.
At C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., a brokerage firm, Charles T. Maxwell, the vice chairman and energy strategist, pointed out that oil now meets about 37 percent of the world's energy needs, and 15 percent is from OPEC members. ''Now one guy is coming along, saying, 'I'm going to raise the price on that 15 percent.' '' he said. ''The other 85 percent isn't going to stand for it.'' Natural gas and coal producers will try to seize some of the oil market, he said.
The experience of the 1970's and 1980's was that a stiff increase in oil prices led to fuel-shifting and efficiency improvements that cut oil demand so sharply that a price war broke out among producers. This leads Mr. Maxwell and other analysts to doubt whether the current high oil prices can be sustained.
Another important feature of natural gas is that its reserves are dispersed compared with oil's. While OPEC members lay claim to about two-thirds of the world's oil reserves, they hold only about one-third of its gas.
But some oil-exporting countries, including OPEC members, are using more natural gas themselves, as are many oil-importing nations. But unlike importers, who want less dependence on oil, the exporters want gas to displace oil in their own economies and increase the volume of more valuable oil that they can export, say Mr. West and others.
Still, some natural gas exports come from OPEC members. Thomas R. Robinson, associate director for natural gas at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., pointed out that Japan, the destination for most of the gas that is liquefied for transport, imports from Indonesia, which is an OPEC member. ''But it's not an OPEC question per se,'' he said.
Shell, Elf Aquitaine and Agit are considering a liquefied natural gas export project in Nigeria, and Exxon and Shell are considering a similar project in Venezuela, Mr. West said. Both countries are OPEC members and both are looking for more revenue.
 
Indigenous Use
A major market for natural gas may be indigenous use in the third world. The World Bank has been trying for several years to encourage third-world oil importers to use their gas reserves.
Petter Nore, a gas specialist at the bank's Natural Gas Development Unit, said that gas is usually priced in contracts that tie it to both oil and coal, so that even in a sharp run-up in oil prices, as is now occurring, the gas price is mitigated by that of the other fuel, increasing its price advantage over oil.
In addition, he said natural gas is perceived to have a greater security of supply than oil products. Part of this grows from the inflexibility of the supply: if it arrives by pipeline, it cannot be easily diverted. 75% Cost Reduction A study by the World Bank found eight oil-importing countries in which natural gas could be delivered to population centers for less than $1 per thousand cubic feet, less than a quarter of the cost for the same quantity of energy in the form of oil when oil is $28 a barrel.
Mr. Nore added, however, that the current crisis would have to persist to have an effect on many governments. ''You don't see a response in the gas situation just because Hussein does something for two months,'' he said. ''This would have to be something that you perceive to be a permanent shift.''
In the United States, natural gas has been priced in recent months at about 85 percent of the cost of oil, said Dr. Marion B. Stewart, an economist with National Economic Research Associates in White Plains. With the recent surge in oil prices, he said, ''my sense is that we have enough of a supply response on the part of gas producers that we will not see gas move up in lockstep; it will move up a good deal less.'' 500,000 Barrels a Day Consumption was declining this year because of weak economic activity, he said, and the oil price increase will add to gas's use. He expects that gas may be substituted for the use of about 500,000 barrels of oil a day. United States oil demand has lately been around 17 million barrels a day.
Some experts say the market for transportation fuel, where about 60 percent of United States oil use takes place, is particularly appropriate for natural gas. Theodore Eck, an economist at the Amoco Corporation, a large gas producer as well as an oil producer, said the consumption of 500,000 barrels of oil a day could be shifted to gas in a few years by conversion of fleet vehicles and trucks to natural gas.

HEADLINE: Five Years Needed to Clean Up Savings Fraud, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that it would take the Government two to three years to secure indictments against most of the individuals it suspects of savings and loan fraud and five years to clean up most of the cases.
The Attorney General's remarks, made at a luncheon with reporters, outlined a timetable for criminal actions in savings and loan cases that roughly coincides with estimates of how long the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout, will need to seize and dispose of all the insolvent institutions and to sell their assets.
Later in the afternoon, the Justice Department announced two indictments among its top 100 cases, against former officers and borrowers of the Lamar Savings Association of Austin, Tex., and against the former chairman of the defunct Trinity Valley Savings and Loan Association of Beaumont, Tex. In the Lamar case, the Government said Stanley E. Adams Jr., the former chairman and principal stockholder, and other officers looted the institution of more than $121 million by setting up sham real estate transactions. 
In the Trinity Valley case, the former chairman, Alan Ross Rothery, a California Lawyer, was accused of embezzling $4 million from the institution from September 1985 to April 1987. Officials say he took deposits collected in the Beaumont area and lent them to real estate ventures he controlled in Los Alamitos, Calif., and then illegally diverted funds from those loans to his own use, as well as improperly receiving broker's commissions.
At the luncheon, Mr. Thornburgh said that the department had just begun addressing the 100 most significant fraud cases arising from the savings and loan debacle and that he did not expect to be able to ''redeploy some of the resources'' now devoted to savings and loan enforcement to other areas of criminal prosecution until 1995.
His comments were in line with an effort by the Bush Administration to orchestrate a low-key campaign to get out the message that one year after it began, the savings and loan bailout is working. Under Searing Criticism The Administration has come under searing criticism by Democrats for a slow start and bureaucratic squabbling that has delayed enforcement of the legislation signed by President Bush last Aug. 9.
Polls indicate that the public considers the savings and loan debacle one of the most important domestic issues as the fall elections approach and that it blames Republicans more than Democrats.
Mr. Thornburgh's remarks will be followed on Wednesday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's address to the National Press Club on the bailout and on Thursday by a talk by Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, to the Citizens for a Sound Economy, a Washington research group.Last week, Deputy Secretary John Robson briefed several groups on the matter.
Mr. Thornburgh, outlining results of the prosecutions so far, said the Government had brought 328 indictments and won 231 convictions so far, with prison terms in 78 percent of the cases. He said only five people had been acquitted. 234 F.B.I. Inquiries He added that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was currently examining 234 failed institutions.
''We are going to follow the evidence wherever it leads us,'' he said. The Attorney General also sought to answer some of his Congressional critics, who have contended that the department is investigating only a fraction of the 21,000 criminal referrals that regulators and others have made concerning fraud at savings and loans, banks and other financial institutions.
He said that 83 percent of those cases involved allegations of fraud totaling less than $25,000, cases that are not a top priority, and that the department received 600 referrals from one failure.
''When you get down to it, you end up with a finite universe of about 100 major S.& L. fraud cases,'' he said. ''The major focus is on these.''

HEADLINE: June Level Of Borrowing Rose Slightly

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board said today that consumers repaid car loans much faster than they took out new ones in June, a fresh sign of shrinking economic activity that slowed credit expansion.
Total installment debts increased by $463 million in June, barely an annual growth rate of eight-tenths of a percent, after climbing by a revised $3.65 billion, or at a 6.1 percent annual rate in May.
Loans for new cars posted the greatest change, with the total value of outstanding loans falling by $1.58 billion in June, after declining $5 million in May. 
 
Economic Slowdown Feared
Since consumers account for about two-thirds of the spending on goods and services that make up the gross national product, such a clear sign of spending caution in a critical category like cars implies a coming slowdown in total economic activity.
Similarly, the total of revolving, or credit-card, credit slowed to a gain of $1.3 billion in June, compared with May growth of $3.2 billion.
The Fed had said that total May consumer credit had grown by $3.91 billion, but revised that down to $3.65 billion.
Other categories of credit, including bank loans, grew by $827 million in June, after increasing by $353 million in May.
In its second-quarter G.N.P. report, which showed that the economy slowed to a weak 1.2 percent annual growth rate between April and June, from 1.7 percent in the first three months of 1990, the Government said consumer spending had slackened significantly.
 
Factory Orders Down
Factory orders also weakened, and the National Association of Purchasing Management said the manufacturing economy fell sharply in July after three months of growth.
The July employment report and the results of the purchasers' survey, plus weak orders for durable and non-durable goods, ''point to an economy that is caving into a full-fledged recession,'' said Allen Sinai, the chief economist for Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc.
With the additional complication from rising oil prices because of the Middle East crisis, Mr. Sinai predicted that the G.N.P. would shrink by five-tenths of a percent to 1 percent in the second half of the year.
Consumers remained heavily in debt despite slower credit growth in June. Before seasonal adjustment, total outstanding consumer installment debts swelled in June to $723 billion, from $720 billion in May and from $696 billion in June of last year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene

BYLINE: By James Sterngold;
Japan in Dilemma On Inflation Policy

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
While the powerful Japanese economy appears to be in a position to ride out the storm of higher oil prices and disrupted supplies relatively well, the country's weak link in an otherwise solid economic chain may be in the financial markets, economists and analysts say.
Their basic concern is not the strength of the Japanese economy, but the weakness of America's. Any large increases in Japanese inflation and interest rates caused by rising oil prices could force United States rates to jump to maintain the appeal of dollar investments to the Japanese. Some fear that such a jolt could help push the already staggering American economy toward recession. 
The concern over America's straitened condition has thus given Japan far less room for maneuvering, a fact that in these troubled times has added a decidedly more nervous edge to the markets here, which still like to think of the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, and the Ministry of Finance as steady and in control, with lots of policy options.
''Japan,'' said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here with Deutsche Bank, ''is caught in a policy conundrum. Given this nervous environment, the markets cannot tolerate any policy slips.''
In the first two trading days of this week, Japan's stock and bond markets have sagged since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but they have not broken. As in New York, share prices have been hit hard, falling 6.3 percent in the first two sessions. But there has not been panicked selling or serious disruptions in trading, and stocks rose 3.10 percent today as bargain hunters moved in.
Meanwhile, interest rates on the Government's benchmark 10-year bond have jumped to 8.1 percent, from 7.7 percent on Friday, a very substantial increase considered the most worrisome sign.
The Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, sought to soothe rattled nerves yesterday by saying Japan had ample stocks of oil to withstand a temporary cutback of supplies.
Since the oil shocks of the 1970's, the Japanese economy has diversified its energy sources, grown less dependent on imported oil and sharply increased industrial efficiency; the Japanese economy gets nearly three times as much output from a barrel of oil as it did in 1973. Economists agree that although Japan imports virtually all of its needed energy, in many ways it is in a far better condition to ride out a short-term sharp cut in oil supplies than other industrial countries.
Mr. Hashimoto's most important remarks concerned inflation. He sought to head off concerns that higher oil prices would accelerate inflation and prompt an increase in interest rates.
''We're not in a position where we need to change monetary policy,'' Mr. Hashimoto said. Nonetheless, the inflationary worries are at the heart of a dilemma for Japan. Inflationary pressures were growing even before oil prices shot up. The economy is in its 44th month of expansion, Japan's second-longest period of growth in postwar history, with 5 percent growth expected this year. Factories are at capacity, there is a labor shortage, the money supply is growing at a rate of more than 10 percent a year and inventories are at rock bottom - classic signs of overheating.
The fear is that the pressure on prices is growing just as policy makers are finding their means for dealing with them shrinking because of the global economic turmoil. If the Government raises interest rates to nip inflation in the bud, investors would be drawn to yen-denominated securities. Such a move could cause the dollar to drop, perhaps sharply. America would then be under pressure to raise rates to attract a continued flow of Japanese capital to cover the budget deficits. That could push the American economy toward recession.
On the other hand, should the Japanese Government hesitate too long and permit inflation to build, the yen could drop - it has tumbled sharply already this week - and prompt an outflow of capital, wrecking the shaky markets. A delicate balance must be struck.
On the positive side, the nearly 30 percent slide in the stock market in March and April, which was caused largely by higher interest rates, traders said, has already taken some of the froth out of share prices and left investors a little more sober. And institutions have been less eager to sell quickly, analysts said, because they are still sitting on mounds of cash. Given these factors, Mr. Taylor said, ''this is not a scenario for a prolonged crash.'' That is scant comfort. ''It's not a big danger signal, it's just uncertainty,'' said a senior trader at a Japanese securities house. ''In this country, we worry less about specifically what the Government is doing sometimes than whether they are moving confidently.''

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Post a Gain; Others Mixed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Japanese stock market made up some of yesterday's losses today, as bargain-hunters pushed the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key Nikkei index up 3.10 percent. The world's other major stock markets rose or declined slightly.
Analysts said the increases were, in part, just a natural steadying after the steep drops on Monday in response to the rise in oil prices. Several analysts said they expected world stock markets to remain volatile until there appears to be a resolution of the Middle East crisis. 
They also agreed that it would not take much to get the markets tumbling again. European and Asian markets were closed when Administration officials said that the United States was sending troops to Saudi Arabia and that the Saudis had indicated they would start pumping an additional 2 million barrels a day, partly offsetting the decline in supply resulting from the boycott of Iraq and Kuwait.
 
Oil Stocks Could Rally
One analyst, Steven H. Nagourney, chief international strategist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, suggested that the stock markets had not yet fully reflected the rise in oil prices, which means that markets over all will decline more while oil stocks could still rally.
''Right now, something fundamental has changed,'' said Sander Cseh, senior vice president at Provident Capital Management International. Referring to the sharp market declines in 1987 and 1989, he added, ''Every other time we have had a major drop in the market, there was not a major change in the economic fundamentals.''
But with the sharp rise in the price of oil, he said, ''this time there will be a change in the rate of inflation, a change in consumer spending and a change in interest rates.'' Mr. Cseh said he did not assume that the situation would be resolved quickly or that the price of oil would soon drop.
''You are going to have uncertainty for at least a month or so,'' he said.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 index fell yesterday by 946.46 points, or 3.31 percent, to 27,653.07, its lowest level since Oct. 26, 1988. That brought the Nikkei's loss since the invasion of Kuwait last week to 10.4 percent. But today, the Nikkei gained 856.07 points, to 28,509.14.
Japan, which imports virtually all of its oil, has had the most negative response to the invasion and subsequent rise in oil prices, although it has lessened its dependence on oil and diversified its sources since the last oil crisis. What impact there will be has been intensified by the Government's decision on Monday to join in the international embargo against Iraq and Kuwait.
But on Wall Street, the stock market stabilized after a volatile day. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 93.31 points on Monday, was down only 5.70 points. And in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index fell more than 6 percent in early trading and then rebounded to close down only three-tenths of one percent.
In Europe stock markets rallied, helped in part, dealers said, by reports that foreigners would be allowed to leave Iraq and Kuwait. In West Germany, the Frankfurt bourse's DAX index rose 29.37 points, or 1.69 percent, to 1,770.30 after falling 5.4 percent on Monday and hitting its low for the year. In Britain, which had a milder decline of 2.82 percent on Monday because its North Sea oil reserves make it less vulnerable to an oil shock, the Financial Times 100 index rose 15.6, or seven-tenths of one percent, to 2,235.80.
In both London and Frankfurt, the yields on 10-year bonds, which had risen sharply on Monday, declined a little. The yield on the German Bund was down 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 8.80 percent, while the yield on the British gilt slipped 2 basis points, to 11.86 percent.
In France, the blue-chip index, called the CAC-40, was up 2.14 percent, to 1,811.84, after dropping more than 5 percent on Monday. In Norway, the Oslo market rose 1.69 percent after a 5.2 percent fall on Monday.
Mr. Nagourney said he sees several more potential jolts for the markets. The most extreme is the possibility of a war that could turn the oil fields of Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia into a ''burning heap.''

HEADLINE: Tankers Scramble for New Supplies

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
With oil from Iraq and Kuwait under embargo and the threat of war hanging over the Middle East, oil companies are preparing to redeploy their tanker fleets to pick up oil from alternative producers. And they are already paying a price for the region's instability in the form of higher insurance rates for ships and cargo.
The major oil companies operate large fleets of tankers, and the invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent embargo have left some ships idle at sea or in ports, waiting for orders based on where oil is available for purchase.
The Chevron Feluy, a tanker owned by the San Francisco-based oil company, was heading into the Persian Gulf on Thursday when it received word that it would not be able to pick up its scheduled cargo of Iraqi crude. Ever since, the ship has been sitting outside the gulf, waiting as Chevron scrambles to find other suppliers. 
 
'A Lot of Dislocation'
''This type of situation causes a lot of dislocation,'' said Douglas C. Wolcott, the president of Chevron's shipping division. ''Some tankers are in the right place at the wrong time.''
Mr. Wolcott said that Chevron had organized internal task forces that are working on replacing Iraq and Kuwait as suppliers, and that the Chevron Feluy and other tankers would be given new orders as the company buys more oil from other countries. Together, Iraq and Kuwait exported more than four million barrels of oil a day before the embargo.
Saudi Arabia reportedly said yesterday that it would add two million barrels a day to its output.
Industry executives said that if the embargo holds and other nations, like the United Arab Emirates or Venezuela, do not join in increasing production, there would be an oversupply of tanker capacity and the cost of transporting oil would probably fall. But they said transportation costs make up only a small fraction of oil's market price and that a tanker glut would be of minimal help in keeping prices down.
The embargo ''is a major event in the oil markets, causing the oil industry to adapt as quickly as possible to find other sources as economically as possible,'' said John Lord, a spokesman for the Mobil Corporation, which has 40 tankers carrying oil around the world. ''Our tankers go where the game is. We are doing everything we can to keep our system supplied.''
The oil companies are also facing sharp increases in insurance premiums on both their tankers and their cargoes of crude. On Monday, marine underwriters at Lloyd's of London increased insurance rates for cargo on ships traveling in the Persian Gulf. The standing rate had been 0.0275 percent of the value of the cargo.
But Lloyd's is now imposing an additional premium of one-tenth of a percent of the cargo's value for ships calling at Saudi Arabian ports and five-hundredths of a percent for ships calling at other Persian Gulf nations. Rates for ships calling at Iraqi and Kuwaiti ports are being determined by negotiation, Lloyd's executives said.
Lloyd's increased premiums last week for rates on insurance for the ships themselves. Rates would undoubtedly rise dramatically in the event of an all-out war.
 
Bidding Up the Price
Chevron and other oil companies own tankers that are now on route to the United States and other destinations with oil purchased from Iraq or Kuwait before the imposition of the embargo on Thursday. That oil, which is not subject to the embargo, has risen sharply in value since the embargo because of the general tightening of oil supplies and because some refineries, which turn crude into products like gasoline, are configured to run only the grades of crude exported by Iraq and Kuwait. Most of the largest oil companies can reconfigure their refineries to process different grades.
The oil companies that need Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil for their refineries are bidding the price up sharply, creating a potential windfall for the companies transporting it.
''You can be sure that all the major oil companies are trying to sell out the crude that has the highest price and buy the lowest-priced crude for their own refineries,'' said Frederick Leuffer, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices of Cattle Increase; Pork and Grains Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cattle futures prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting some apparent easing of economic worries linked to the Middle East crisis and strength in the cash cattle markets.
On other commodity markets, pork futures ended mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed.
News from the Middle East remained a major influence in many commodity markets but signs during trading that hostilities were cooling allowed traders to focus on other factors as well. 
Live cattle futures settled .28 cent to 1.15 cents higher in Chicago, with the contract for delivery in August at 77.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .55 cent to 1.12 cents higher, with August at 89.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .95 cent lower to .05 cent higher, with August at 58.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent lower to .52 cent higher, with August at 51.07 cents a pound.
Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers, said the inflation and recession fears caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait had had a depressing effect on cattle prices recently because consumers would tend to bypass beef in favor of cheaper meats if the economy took a downturn.
''When you start comparing beef with chicken at the meat counters, you know which is going to get the nod,'' he said.
But cattle prices bounced back strongly yesterday as the stock and crude-oil markets steadied amid indications early in the day the Iraqi Government had assumed a less aggressive posture.
Further support stemmed from stronger packer demand for live cattle and stronger demand for feeder cattle by feedlot operators.
Paul Hare, livestock analyst with Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago, said the live cattle market was oversold and due for a correction after falling for four straight days.
Grain and soybean futures ended narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Traders also began evening up their positions ahead of tomorrow's Agriculture Department crop report, analysts said. The report, scheduled for release after tomorrow's close, will contain the Government's first official estimates of 1990 United States corn and soybean production.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Prices for Gold Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday against all leading currencies except the German mark, as traders kept a close watch on the Persian Gulf crisis and its effect on interest rates.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $384.50 an ounce, down 20 cents from Monday. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for gold at $385.50 an ounce, up $1.50. 
Ronald H. Holzer, chief currency dealer at Harris Trust & Company in Chicago, attributed the dollar's rise largely to technical factors. But he said traders were also buying dollars in the belief that United States interest rates would remain stable for the short term. ''Short-term rates have not moved lower,'' he said.
In fact, interest rates in the bond markets have risen sharply in recent days on inflation fears, which stemmed from the rapid rise in oil prices after Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait last week.
When interest rates decline, the value of a currency tends to follow suit as dollar-denominated investments become less attractive.
The dollar had fallen sharply on Monday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen, on worries that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates lower to prevent the country from falling into a recession.
In New York yesterday, the dollar again rose against the Japanese currency, to 150.90 yen, from 150.35 on Monday. Earlier, in Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar closed up at 150.60 Japanese yen, compared with 149.50 yen on Monday. It traded at 149.90 yen in London.
Against the German currency, the dollar slipped in New York to 1.5875 marks, from 1.5788.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. The pound bought $1.8765 in London, up from $1.8725, and $1.8715 in New York, down from $1.8725.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.3370 Swiss francs, up from 1.3310; 5.3230 French francs, up from 5.2890; 1,162.25 Italian lire, up from 1,154.50, and 1.15125 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14955.
Gold rose in London to $383.25 an ounce from $382.50 late Monday. In Zurich, it rose to $383.15 an ounce from $382.50.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose by $4.94, to $383.52 an ounce.
Silver prices declined. On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.857 an ounce, down from $4.892 on Monday. Silver fell in London to $4.89 an ounce, from $4.91.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Editor of Financial Times To Resign at End of Year

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Sir Geoffrey Owen, the editor of The Financial Times for the last decade, will step down at the end of this year, when he will be succeeded by the newspaper's deputy editor, Richard P. Lambert.
In April, Sir Geoffrey, who is 56 years old, will become the director of the business policy program at the London School of Economics, where he plans to focus on the competitiveness of British industry. The position ''will be mainly concerned with research into British industrial performance in the postwar period and relating it to developments in other European countries,'' Sir Geoffrey said in an interview. 
During Sir Geoffrey's tenure, the newspaper's circulation increased to 291,531, from 199,233. In the last couple of years, much of the growth has come from the United States, where circulation is now 18,816, and continental Europe, with about 60,800. In June, the paper began printing an edition in Japan, where it now sells about 4,500 copies.
Mr. Lambert, who is 45, joined The Financial Times in 1966 as a reporter and initially covered company news and wrote about personal finance. He became financial editor in 1979, was appointed New York correspondent in 1982 and was promoted to his current job in 1983.
The European circulation of The Wall Street Journal, a primary competitor of The Financial Times in Europe, is relatively small - only 11,043 in Britain and 35,221 on the continent. But Mr. Lambert said he does not take the paper lightly, especially in several countries on the continent.
While The Journal ''hasn't made a huge impact in the United Kingdom, it gives us some benchmarks,'' he said, adding that it was ''no coincidence'' that The Financial Times had increased its coverage of capital markets.
In the United States, he said, his paper's circulaton is ''very strongly biased towards the southern tip of Manhattan, and we have a high profile among a small range of readers.''
Replacing Mr. Lambert as deputy editor will be Ian Hargreaves, an alumnus of the paper who is now director of news and current affairs at the British Broadcasting Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Some More Bad News For Outdoor

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
The outdoor advertising industry has taken a battering lately from special-interest groups and Federal lawmakers who want to impose tough new restrictions. Now there is more bad news: Advertising revenues for the outdoor industry in the first quarter dropped 15 percent from the period last year, according to the LNA/Arbitron Multi-Media Service.
Industry executives say the prime reasons for this downturn are the country's sluggish economy and growing fears of recession. Automobile advertising, for example, which had been one of the strongest categories, fell 30.6 percent in the quarter. Spending in the top 10 categories, which account for more than half of outdoor revenues, fell 20 percent, to $128 million, from $161 million in the period the previous year. 
''It has been a tough year so far,'' said Mark Van Fossan, the chief operating officer at the Patrick Media Group, a leading outdoor company. But Mr. Van Fossan said he was confident that the situation would improve in the fall, when he expected important advertisers like auto makers to step up spending.
Analysts said that like the magazine industry, outdoor advertising had been hurt by the surprising strength of network television. During the advance sale of network prime-time advertising in June, advertisers spent a record $4.3 billion.
''Very often, out-of-home is a discretionary buy,'' said Pete Riordan, a manager at BBDO for out-of-home advertising, which uses public places like the sides of buildings, bus shelters and shopping malls. ''With television spending high and budgets tighter, outdoor advertising is bound to suffer.''
Analysts predict that the trend is likely to continue, which would probably mean a shakeout among outdoor companies, some of them already deeply in debt.
Some analysts said the industry has also been hurt, in part, by growing protests from special-interest groups that want to ban billboards for tobacco and alcohol. In New York, Chicago and Dallas, religious and community leaders have been whitewashing billboards that display ads for cigarettes, wine, beer and liquor. The protesters assert that by concentrating advertising for tobacco and alcohol in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods, these advertisers are unfairly targeting minority consumers.
Bowing to pressure, cigarette and alcohol advertisers have agreed not to use billboards that are near schools or churches, where children can more readily see them.
More important, the protests have accelerated cutbacks in cigarette advertising, which had been already declining. During the last 10 years, the percentage of total outdoor advertising revenues from cigarettes dropped to just 13 percent, down from more than 40 percent in 1979. For the first quarter of this year, tobacco advertising fell 27.4 percent.
In addition, the alcohol industry has become wary, and advertising in the category dropped 1.3 percent in the first quarter.
Analysts said the traditional outdoor advertising industry was also facing stiff competition from the growing popularity of new out-of-home media like video display terminals in subway stations, shopping malls and supermarkets.
To remain competitive, the outdoor industry has been steadily improving the quality of billboards. In the past, most billboards were handpainted and the results varied widely depending on the artist's skill. Now, many billboards are produced using computer technology that produces artwork that looks as good as print ads in magazines, industry executives said. As a result, more billboards are sporting ads for cosmetics, food and fashion - categories that had not used outdoor much in the past because of the poor visual quality.
Billboards are also looking better because some agency executives, particularly in California, see them as a highly visible way to flex their creative muscles. Billboards for Nike athletic shoes, for example, have won many creative awards.
''Billboards aren't as creatively limited as they used to be,'' said Russell Booth, a group media director at Grey Advertising. ''There is a lot of dramatic work being done.''
To spark greater interest at agency creative departments, the Gannett Outdoor Group has started a creative-challenge program. At agencies in New York and Chicago, Gannett executives have offered prizes like free trips to Europe to the creators of outstanding new billboards for clients that had never used the medium.
''We want them to think of outdoor as an important part of an overall advertising strategy,'' said John Hope, a senior vice president at Gannett. ''The more good billboards creative people see, the more billboards they'll want to create.''

PUB-DATE: August 9, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1044 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
OIL MARKETS EASE; STOCK PRICES RISE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Oil prices fell and the stock markets in the New York and Tokyo steadied yesterday after the United States decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and reports that the oil-rich kingdom would increase its production.
But the easing in oil markets and a leveling off in share prices seemed tentative, with the economic outlook hinging on the uncertain prospect of developments in the Middle East.
Despite a decline in the price of oil of more than $2 a barrel yesterday, to just under $26, the price remains about 50 percent higher than it was in July, with much of that increase coming after Iraq invaded Kuwait last week. The oil-price run-up has been quickly - and controversially - translated into higher fuel costs for businesses and higher gasoline prices for motorists. Higher energy prices have made it seem more likely that an already-weak economy will slip into recession. 
In the stock markets yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.26 points in New York, to 2,734.90, after falling day after day since the Iraqi invasion last week. Similarly, the Tokyo market rallied yesterday, before declining in today's trading session. In Europe, the performance was mixed, with both the Frankfurt and Paris markets falling and the London market inching ahead.
In his televised address yesterday, President Bush called on the oil industry to avoid taking advantage of political turmoil in the Persian Gulf to maximize profits.
''I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share,'' the President said in a broadcast to the nation yesterday morning. ''They should show restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices.''
Mr. Bush also said, ''I will explore whether we and our allies should draw down our strategic petroleum reserves.''
 
ARCO's Commitment
In response to President Bush's urging to restrain oil and gasoline price increases, the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's largest trade association, pledged its ''complete cooperation'' and ARCO, a big marketer in five Western states, said it would freeze wholesale prices for one week.
No other companies, however, gave any immediate indication that they would follow the lead of ARCO, whose foregone profits for the week were thought likely to amount to tens of millions of dollars.
''We hope the market will stabilize during this time,'' George Babikian, head of the Los Angeles-based company's refining and marketing division, said in a statement, ''but if at the end of the week our position is out of line with world market prices, we will have to recognize that fact.''
 
Telegram to Bush From Mobil
A spokesman for the Mobil Corporation said he could not comment on any pending price moves but supplied a copy of a telegram that the company's chairman, Allen E. Murray, sent to the White House after the President's plea.
''I can assure you that we will continue to show restraint in the face of escalating prices for crude oil,'' Mr. Murray stated. ''While we have raised prices, to date we have recovered only a fraction of the higher costs incurred. Please be assured that in this time of crisis Mobil will do its fair share.''
But with retail gasoline prices having already climbed by an average of more than 12 cents a gallon since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait - and twice as much in some cases - the industry was once again smarting from a public-image black eye.
 
Threat by Senator Dole
No less a friend than the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, whose state ranks among the top 10 oil producers, complained of ''irresponsible and arbitrary'' price increases and said these invited Government action.
''Sometimes the oil companies never learn,'' Senator Dole declared. ''They're just asking for some kind of excess-profits or windfall-profits tax.''
Congressional Democrats, meanwhile, kept up their barrage of criticism of the oil industry, with the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, insisting that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh conduct an investigation of possible conspiratorial pricing.
The episode recalled the 1962 confrontation between President John F. Kennedy and the steel industry, whose effort to raise prices an average of $6 a ton was held by the President to be ''a wholly unjustifiable and irresponsible defiance of the public interest.''
The industry capitulated and withdrew the increase within four days of Mr. Kennedy's direct, public challenge in which he spoke of ''this serious hour in our nation's history when we are confronted with grave crises in Berlin and Southeast Asia, when we are devoting our energies to economic recovery and stability, when we are asking reservists to leave their homes and families months on end and servicemen to risk their lives.''
John H. Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff, convened a meeting of Government policy makers yesterday afternoon to discuss oil prices, but no industry officials were invited, an official said. Nor did President Bush, a former oilman himself, make any private telephone calls to urge price restraint.
The President did, however, phone ARCO to express pleasure at the company's price freeze.
Another development welcomed by the Administration was a decision by Mexico to raise output by 100,000 barrels a day, a modest amount but an addition that had not been formally requested or expected. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady called the increase a gesture of good will.
The outlook for oil remains uncertain, but most analysts said prices were unlikely to fall much further soon because the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait has been effective so far.
''Right now the embargo appears to be working well,'' said Theodore R. Eck, chief economist for the Amoco Corporation. ''They are having trouble selling oil because they have lost their traditional customers. But that may not be true a month from now.''
Mr. Eck said the pipeline through Turkey appeared to be closed down, but that Saudi Arabia had been silent on the pipeline that passes through its territory to the Red Sea port of Yanbu. In addition, the Iraqi port of Basra on the Persian Gulf remained open for exports if Iraq can find buyers.
And some feel those buyers will materialize if the embargo drags on and oil supplies tighten.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although oil and financial markets began to level off yesterday, the economic outlook still hinges on developments in the Middle East. Murphy, left, former Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times) (pg. A19)

PUB-DATE: August 9, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1808 words

HEADLINE: Around U.S., a Cautious Chorus of Support

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

 BODY:
If President Bush had been listening, he might have been reassured by the talk the last couple of mornings around the tables at Bert & Ernie's Restaurant in Plattsburg, a town of 2,100 people in western Missouri farm country, where patrons begin filtering in at the first daylight.
''I think he's got to draw a line somewhere,'' said Bruce Wilkinson, a farmer, summing up what seemed to be a consensus about the President and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, ''and it looks like the line has got to be at the Saudi border.''
A few lingered around the table yesterday morning and sat rapt during Mr. Bush's television address. When it was over, they continued in the same vein of support for him, though one strong voice for caution was that of the Rev. Ed McCurley.
''You people keep saying the Iraqis don't value human life,'' said Mr. McCurley of the First Christian Church. ''Well, what about us? Here we are talking about going to war over money. I say, 'Whoa.' I say it's an Arab problem. Let's leave it to the Arabs.'' 
 
A Cautious Chorus
In conversations with more than 200 people across the American continent, mostly conducted after it became known that United States troops were headed for Saudi Arabia, the voices formed a cautious chorus of support for the President. But it was a chorus whose tones were tempered by worry that the American action would damage an already fragile economy and raise energy prices sharply - and possibly cause American blood to be spilled.
In a dentist's office in Miami, a Ford plant in Georgia, an amusement park in Missouri, a gas station in Los Angeles, in deepest West Texas ranch country, the events seemed to be understood only sketchily by some people, many of whom did not seem quite sure where Kuwait is or who had invaded whom. But there was nothing vague about the unease over the American embargo of Iraqi oil and resentment at an oil industry they see as taking advantage of the turmoil to extract unfair price increases for gasoline and diesel fuel.
Standing in the parking lot at Six Flags Over Mid-America just outside St. Louis, Howard Hart of San Jose, Calif., who like thousands of other Americans is in the middle of a vacation on the road, said gasoline prices had risen 10 to 15 cents in a week.
''It's the American way,'' Mr. Hart said. ''But I'm surprised at how blatant they're being about it.''
 
'We Can't Sit By'
While the President's firm but measured response won general approval, the concern about its effects on the health of the economy came through loud and clear. And probably nowhere was this dichotomy more apparent than at the Ford Motor Company's plant in the Atlanta suburb of Hapeville, which is the final assembly plant for the Taurus and Mercury Sable models.
One worker, Gary Meadows, said he supported United States military action not just because of the Iraqi invasion but also because he thought Americans in Kuwait were threatened. ''We've sat back long enough and been humiliated,'' he said. ''We can't sit by and let them take our citizens captive.''
But the automobile workers were also keenly aware that their industry teeters on recession, and that the rising oil prices that a boycott of Iraqi oil may bring could push it over the edge. ''It's going to drive up the price of gasoline, and that's going to adversely affect us - all of the automobile industry,'' said Oliver Terrell, who has been on the job just three months. Joe Harris, on his first day in a new supervisor's job, said he supported the President's decision because ''we don't want to let the situation get out of control.'' But he, too, was worried about gasoline prices. ''I noticed they were up again today when I got gas this morning,'' he said. ''We need to have some stability.''
 
Talk of Recession
Again and again the word ''recession'' was used. ''We're already on the edge of a recession,'' said E. W. Dixon, a grain and hog grower in Plattsburg, Mo.
Thirteen hundred miles away, in Miami, Dr. Stephen J. Parr has set up a small television in his office so he can follow events when he is not drilling teeth. He backed the President's position. ''You got to be ready for the worst; otherwise the worst can happen,'' he said.
But there were skeptics, too. J. Brian King, a photo illustrator in Miami, felt that the United States should keep out of such foreign entanglements. ''I don't like it,'' he said. ''I think they should take care of their own problems. I can understand ships standing by. But troops, that I don't agree with. We should have laissez-faire. Let them work out their own problems. We have enough oil in this country to last us a while.''
At the Jewish Home for the Aged in Miami, some residents, like many other Americans, seemed caught between hatred for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and fear of United States entanglement.
''There have been so many wars, so many have been killed,'' said Katie Safier, an 81-year-old retired real estate agent from New York. ''Hussein is a dictator like Hitler. He wants to take over all the oilfields. But why should we be involved? We could get oil from Mexico.''
But for everyone who feared a prolonged bloody entanglement, there were one or two others who urged President Bush to press ahead. A few even seemed impatient at his pace.
''Harry Truman wouldn't have put up with this for a minute,'' said Maurice Shoemaker, a farmer in northwestern Missouri.
Bruce Kennedy, a turf grower, agreed. ''Sooner or later you have to do something,'' he said. ''I'd wait just long enough to get the bombs loaded. Look what happened to Qaddafi. You don't hear so much out of him now.''
 
Recalling His Own War
In Atlanta, Jesse Taylor, a Ford automobile worker, was unequivocal. ''I think they ought to go in there and level Iraq as flat as that concrete floor,'' he said. ''You're dealing with a madman.''
Possibly few have followed the events more closely than Avi Nathan, a new American citizen and immigrant from Israel who served as an artilleryman in Israel's six-day war against Egypt in 1967. He has spent the last three days in his home on the West Side of Los Angeles, glued to his television following events in the Persian Gulf and railing against the Iraqi ''pirates.''
''I'm glad what President Bush did - he had to do it,'' Mr. Nathan said, even though, as the operator of a limousine service that carries Hollywood celebrities to television appearances, he fears for what it would do to oil prices. He spends $2,000 a month on gasoline.
But nearby, Mike J. Fadlallah, the Lebanese owner of the Unocal gas station in Redondo Beach, offered sympathy for Mr. Hussein. ''He's got a country to take care of,'' he said. ''They fought with Iran for a year to protect their oil, and now with Kuwait dumping oil on the market and calling in Iraq's debt he had to act.''$ 
Resentment in Detroit
Resentment against the President's action was particularly strong among Arab Americans in the Detroit area, which has the largest concentration of Arab Americans in the United States. They number about 150,000, mostly from Lebanon, Jordan and Yemen, and the community includes many Chaldeans from Iraq, Christians who generally consider themselves Arab Americans.
''The West is just meddling,'' said Charles K. Alawan, an American-born construction worker of Lebanese descent. ''American officials don't care which Moslem kills which, as long as they kill each other. Most Americans just care if they have gas for their cars.''
Samih Kasr, a restaurateur born in Jordan, had sympathy for the Iraqi cause. ''The Kuwati people have been abusing their wealth, not cooperating with the Arab movement and their cause,'' he said, adding that the West maintained a double standard. ''We didn't hear anything about world condemnation when the U.S. invaded Grenada or Panama,'' he said.
 
No Unity in Brooklyn
But in Arab Brooklyn, there was anything but unity. At the Rashid Sales Company, which sells Arabic tapes, books, magazines and newspapers on Atlantic Avenue, customers were devouring daily newspapers from Egypt, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia. The owner, Stanley Rashid, whose father came from Lebanon, said his patrons were taking opposite sides on the conflict. ''People from the Gulf are generally supporting Iraq, while people from Egypt are against Iraq,'' he said. ''I guess it's historically been that way.''
Up the street, the Damascus Bakery did a brisk business selling pita bread, meat and spinach pies and baklava amid political debate. Outside, Abdul Sala, an immigrant from Yemen, said he thought it was a ''family problem'' that the American Government should stay out of. Mosad Muthana said he thought American involvement might have the unintended effect of pushing Arab youth into President Hussein's camp because of American support for Israel.
 
By a River Divided
Just across the East River on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, American Jews had a very different view of it all at Ratner's Deli. They invoked Nazi analogies. ''Saddam Hussein is like a Hitler, a crazy man,'' said Ahron Yohananoff, a 78-year-old retiree from Kew Gardens in Queens. His companion for tea and bagels, was Moshe Katz, a cantor. ''You have to do something and do it very fast,'' Mr. Katz said. ''If not, we'll be in trouble.''
At the next table was Benjamin Grable, a 68-year veteran of World War II, working on his lox and cream cheese on onion roll. ''I hate war with a passion,'' he said. ''But by the same token, when something becomes necessary, it becomes necessary. I would put everything in place to stop Hussein immediately.''
Two thousand miles and a cultural universe away in the small ranching and oil town of Rankin (population, 1,250) in West Texas, the subject was also Iraq at the M & N Restaurant. But there it all seemed more remote, less emotional, except insofar as the events affected oil prices. At the cash register was the owner, Linda Nicholson, who was worried about her son-in-law in the Navy. She feared he would have to serve in the Persian Gulf.
 
'Far Away and Complicated'
But otherwise, she said they had not kept abreast of developments. ''It's far away and complicated,'' she said. ''There isn't a lot of talk of it around here. Oil right now is the conversation, how high it will go and whether it will be good for business. But not about what the President should do or anything. We don't know anything about that.''
One of her customers was Dan Brown, the sheriff of Upton County, waiting for his chicken fajitas. ''I really hadn't thought about it that much,'' he said. ''I know something's happening; it's on the news. I believe you have to protect American lives and American interests.''
How about Kuwaiti and Saudi lives and interests, he was asked.
''Kuwait?'' he replied. ''I thought this was happening in Iraq.''
