PUB-DATE: August 9, 1990
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1793 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: U.S. MAY SEND SAUDIS A FORCE OF 50,000; IRAQ PROCLAIMS KUWAIT'S ANNEXATION;
BUSH DRAWS 'LINE'

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Thousands of elite United States troops, the vanguard of a force that senior defense officials said may reach 50,000, took up positions in Saudi Arabia today as President Bush vowed to defend the Middle Eastern kingdom and its oil reserves, the richest in the world.
The President ruled out an immediate invasion of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait and said economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations would be given time to do their work of economic strangulation, forcing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw. But Mr. Bush and his aides made it plain that American land, sea and air forces had been committed to the Persian Gulf area for the long term.
''A line has been drawn in the sand'' against any Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, Mr. Bush said.
 
'A Criminal Force'
With a lengthy war of nerves seemingly in prospect, President Hussein, refusing to back down, announced the annexation of Kuwait and pledged to fight what he called ''a criminal force'' assembling in the region under American leadership. 
President Bush emphasized that ''we're not at war,'' and he described the mission of American troops as defensive. But that description really applies only in a tactical sense. In strategic terms, the American troops in Saudi Arabia, backed by aircraft carriers, missiles, fighters, bombers, tanks and other weapons, together with the embargo and a de facto naval blockade of Iraqi commerce, are intended to help force President Hussein to pull back.
Disappointing the Bush Administration, Egypt and Morocco decided not to provide troops, at least for the moment, to stand alongside the Americans and give the multinational force an Arab element. Britain agreed to join the force, but France did not. Italy and Spain agreed to provide crucial access to bases on their soil for United States planes involved in the buildup.
 
Egypt Arranges Arab Talks
Senior European diplomats said the Administration still hoped that military operations in the region could be put under the United Nations flag, but that, they said, would take time and require persuasion of the Soviets and the Chinese. Either could veto any such move in the Security Council.
An emergency meeting of the Council tonight to consider the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait was adjourned until Thursday because the Moscow and Beijing representatives said they had not received instructions from their Governments on how to vote.
But both countries said they expect to support a draft resolution, submitted by the Kuwaiti Government-in-exile, that declares the annexation null and void.
Led by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, the Arab nations arranged another summit conference for Thursday evening in Cairo, in a final attempt to find some peaceful solution. Representative Steven J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat who spent an hour with Mr. Mubarak today, said the Egyptian leader hoped to put together an Arab deterrent force to which Egypt and several other Arab nations would contribute soldiers.
But some political leaders said they feared that Mr. Hussein might attack Saudi Arabia sooner rather than later. Backing Mr. Bush's action, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, the Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, issued a warning that ''there is a danger of a hot war, and the greatest danger comes in the very next few days.''
 
'An Aggressive Dictator'
''Saddam Hussein sees us coming,'' Mr. Aspin said. ''He knows more troops will be there tomorrow and still more next week. He could try to seize the oilfields before we have enough men there to stop them and then hold those oilfields hostage. That is the greatest and most immediate threat.''
Mr. Bush's tone, in only the third televised address to the nation of his Presidency, was that of a leader preparing his country for war.
He described President Hussein as ''an aggressive dictator threatening his neighbors'' and compared him with Hitler. He used emotionally charged words from the late 1930's like blitzkrieg and appeasement. And he asked that ''in the churches around the country, prayers be said.''
''Standing up for our principles is an American tradition,'' Mr. Bush said in his speech from the Oval Office this morning. ''As it has so many times before, it may take time and tremendous effort, but most of all, it will take unity of purpose. As I have witnessed throughout my life in both war and peace, America has never wavered when her purpose is driven by principle.''
 
Bush's Economic Concerns
The dispatch of American paratroopers and other forces was a historic breakthrough for United States diplomacy, in that Saudi Arabia had finally dropped its insistence on keeping American military aid concealed, and it may lead other Arab states to do the same.
In addition, analysts contended that it was first time since World War II that the United States had intervened militarily out of mainly economic concerns.
Had Syria been the target, a prominent international banker said, ''we wouldn't have sent in the troops, because they don't have all that oil.''
The President emphasized economic concern by saying he hoped other oil producers would ease the pain the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil imposed on oil consumers by increasing their own production, thus forcing elevated prices down. The Administration expects Venezuela and Saudi Arabia, among others, to do so. Mr. Bush also called on United States oil companies to avoid gouging, which they have already been accused of doing.
 
British Contribute Forces
Congressional opinion swung solidly behind the President's action.
But a number of senators and representatives, Democrats and Republicans alike, expressed anxety about the failure of most other countries to promise troops so far for the joint military effort. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republcian majority leader, said, ''The Arab countries have got to come to the party too.''
''I hope we won't be the Lone Ranger the way we were in Vietnam,'' said Senator Alan Cranston of California, the second-ranking Senate Democrat.
The financial markets reacted to the latest developments in the crisis by sending stocks up and oil prices down - the reverse of the last few days.
British contributions to the multinational force, officials in London said, would include Tornado aircraft and several ships, but probably not any infantry units.
 
Blocking Oil From Iraq
''The multinational effort is designed to deter Hussein,'' said Douglas Hurd, the Foreign Secretary. ''If Iraq compounds this with a fresh act of aggression, it will be extremely expensive, damaging and destructive to Iraq,'' he continued - seeming to indicate that Britain was prepared to join the United States not only in deterrence but also in counterattack if needed.
Perhaps with the thought that he would need the fullest possible Congressional backing if a shooting war developed along those lines, Mr. Bush sent Congress formal notification of his action under the War Powers Act, a piece of legislation born in the aftermath of Watergate that Republican Presidents have often ignored.
American military strength in the region already includes carrier task forces in the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean, with a third steaming toward the Mediterranean.
When all are on station, they will be able to block Iraqi oil shipments that might reach the Saudi port of Yanbu, that might come down the Persian Gulf and through the Gulf of Oman and that might reach Turkish ports. So far, the market for Iraqi oil appears largely to have dried up.
 
Fear of Poison Gas
Among the elements being added by United States military planners are a brigade of the 82d Airborne Division, from Fort Bragg, N.C.; a brigade of the 101st Airborne Division, equipped with helicopters, from Fort Campbell, Ky., and a brigade of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, equipped with tanks and armored personnel carriers, from Fort McPherson, Ga.
Arab and European diplomats said that eventually all of the 82d and the 101st would be sent, as well as antiaircraft and antitank missiles and some intelligence equipment. Such a deployment could involve up to 50,000 men.
One of the major fears in official Washington about the course of action on which President Bush has embarked is the Iraqi capacity for using poison gas. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a briefing at the Pentagon that Soviet-made Scud surface-to-surface missiles, now in position to hit the Saudi capital of Riyadh or the country's main oilfields, consituted ''one of the principal threats directed against Saudi Arabia.'' They can be fitted with chemical warheads, and American intelligence has indicated that some of them have been so armed.
 
Fate of Detained Americans
American forces have not faced chemical weapons in the field since the trench warfare of 1918.
In total, the Iraqis are believed by American officials to have massed as many as 100,000 troops in Kuwait. They appear to be digging in and maneuvering into positions from which a ground attack could be launched, supported by tanks and missiles.
Another problem is the fate of Americans in Kuwait and Iraq. They have not been harmed yet. But there is a largely unspoken fear here that some are being held as hostages.
 
Looting by Iraqis Reported
Iraq permitted United States officials to visit 38 Americans in a Baghdad hotel today and released an American child, which some took as a mildly conciliatory signal. But the 38 were held against their will under armed guard, and there was no sign that the 3,000 or more other United States citizens trapped in the two countries would be allowed to leave.
In addition, concern for the Americans' safety was heightened by reports of widespread looting and raping of Kuwaitis by Iraqi soldiers, brought out by Europeans who have managed to reach Saudi Arabia.
A third worry is the question of what Mr. Bush will do, having pledged as publicly and as forcefully as a President can do that he would not permit the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait to survive, if he fails in his attempt to make it impossible for Mr. Hussein to hang on to the little sheikdom.
No one in the Administration was willing to say for quotation that the President had held another option in reserve, that he could still convert the American force in Saudi Arabia into an assault force and send United States bombers to hammer Baghdad. But many officials made it clear that that possibility was in the background.
''George Bush promised that this guy wouldn't end up with Kuwait,'' one of them said. '' He hasn't staked his life on that, but he may well have staked his political future on it. So in the end - six months, a year, who knows? - he may try anything.''

HEADLINE: Racketeering Is Still Found at Fulton Fish Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Two years after being appointed to help drive racketeers out of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, long investigated as a Mafia stronghold, a Federal administrator said yesterday that an ''atmosphere of lawlessness'' and brutality still prevailed there.
The administrator, Frank H. Wohl, said the market was in the clutches of a small number of people who dictated how fish and seafood could be unloaded from delivery trucks and who charged ''extortionate'' fees for their services.
Mr. Wohl also asserted that the strong-arm tactics of some companies at the market discouraged suppliers from sending fish to New York, driving up retail prices for consumers in the city.
''The result is a frontier atmosphere, in which the prevailing attitude is that the Fulton Fish Market is a sovereign entity where the laws of economic power and physical force, not the laws of New York City, prevail,'' Mr. Wohl said in a report filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. 
Mr. Wohl declined to estimate how much more consumers had to pay for fish as a result of the corrupt practices. He and other experts said it was impossible to compare the price of fish in New York with prices in other cities because of such factors as market conditions, labor costs, local taxes and consumer tastes.
Mr. Wohl contended that city officials had contributed to the problem by abdicating their responsibility to regulate and police the market. He said he would soon impose rules aimed at helping suppliers and businesses to operate without intimidation. About 90 million pounds of fish and shellfish, with a retail value of about $2 billion, are sold each year at the market, the largest wholesale fish market in the country.
City officials sharply dismissed Mr. Wohl's assertions, arguing that the administrator was placing blame to disguise his failure to achieve his own court-appointed goal.
Mr. Wohl was named by a Federal judge in 1988 to monitor conditions at the market with the power to ban people from working or doing business there and to set some rules on how fish was delivered to wholesalers and sold to retailers. His appointment was considered part of a fresh strategy to drive out organized-crime factions by using civil-court procedures rather than criminal indictments.
His report was the latest statement pointing to continued racketeering at the market, with its center on South Street and the East River in lower Manhattan. Over the last 60 years, it has frequently been investigated as a bastion of organized crime.
The report said brutality was so commonplace that drivers who violated unwritten parking rules on streets near the market were beaten. Mr. Wohl, in the report, said city officials had told him that they feared for the safety of city employees and also feared attempts to corrupt police officers if the city enforced regulations more strictly.
 
'Unwritten Customs'
''The city's abdication of its management responsibilities in the market has led to the assumption of that responsibility by others, who have organized the market through unwritten customs and practices designed for their own benefit,'' Mr. Wohl said.
Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said much of the report was ''old news.''
''The place has been a mess for 60 years, and in the last year and a half we have tried to straighten out the most glaring problems and get cooperation from merchants and develop rapport with them,'' Ms. Nathan said in an interview. She maintained that the city had improved sanitation, parking and traffic conditions and had increased police patrols.
Asked about Mr. Wohl's assertions that the market was dominated by racketeers, Ms. Nathan said, ''The report reflects Mr. Wohl's inability to correct the problem and he has a $1 million-a-year budget.''
Mr. Wohl said Federal courts authorized payments of about $750,000 last year for the salaries of about a dozen investigators and researchers and other expenses.
 
'Ample Authority'
Mr. Wohl, in an interview, said he had issued the report because he was at the midpoint of his four-year appointment and wanted to see ''regulatory controls'' in place before his tenure ended. He said that the city had ''ample authority'' to regulate the market and that if it failed to accept his proposals, his office would then enforce them.
In his report, Mr. Wohl said six companies or ''crews'' that he did not identify controlled the unloading of fish and seafood brought to the market by trucks.
Although the city has the authority to license and regulate the unloading, when truckers arrive at the market they are ''assigned by some unknown authority to unload their trucks,'' the report said. The truckers have no say in how their cargo is unloaded, nor do the wholesalers who receive the supplies.
Under this system, the report said, it costs just as much to transport a pound of fish 50 feet at the market as it does to transport it hundreds of miles from New England or the Gulf Coast to New York City. The unloaders charge the wholesalers $1.35 per 100-pound box and 65 cents per 60-pound box - about the same cost as delivery from Maine or Louisiana, Mr. Wohl said.
 
Physical Abuse
Truckers and wholesalers would be ''subject to physical abuse'' and ''their future activities'' in the market would be ''imperiled'' if they unloaded the supplies themselves, the report said.
The unloaders also have the power to allow fish to spoil by the order in which they deliver supplies, the report said, and drivers are extorted for extra fees to have their cargoes unloaded promptly.
Mr. Wohl said in his report that he would promulgate rules to control the unloading and the licensing of the unloaders. Trucks, he said, would be unloaded in their order of arrival at the market and a ceiling would be set on charges.
Evidence that some wholesalers defrauded fish companies for about $6 million in the last years has been turned over to local prosecutors, the report said.
Mr. Wohl said the city had no records of who was leasing municipal space at the market and whether rents were being paid.
 
Parking and Traffic
The report also accused city officials of making no attempt to control parking and traffic through the congested market on South Street, between John Street on the south and Dover Street on the north. Activity in the market, next to the South Street Seaport, is at its peak in the early morning.
Several drivers who parked their cars in the area or had driven near the market have been severely beaten and their vehicles smashed with metal hooks and pipes, the report said.
Although the report referred to racketeering activities at the market, Mr. Wohl did not specify whether any of the improper activities were controlled by Mafia families. He said organized-crime influence at the fish market would be addressed in another report.

HEADLINE: Praslin Journal;
Where the Tortoises Play, Tourists Are Limited

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRASLIN, Seychelles, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Mountainous granite islands poking out of turquoise water and slivers of coral atolls that barely peep above the horizon make up this tiny nation that hopes to impress the world with its sensitivity about the environment.
Scientists say there is much to preserve on the Seychelles' 115 islands flung over hundreds of miles of the Indian Ocean off the coast of Africa: turtles, birds, an exotic coconut tree known as coco de mer, reefs, shells, and even the fine white sand.
The Government, which practices a hybrid of socialist economics and politics, agrees. Seychelles receives more than half of its foreign exchange earnings from well-to-do tourists who jet in from Europe. Thus, keeping unsullied, palm-fringed beaches, abundant fishing and rare birdlife has become critical to the economic well-being of the 67,000 local people, known as Seychellois. 
''We've got very little else other than natural beauty,'' said Lindsay Chong Seng, a British-trained biologist who is the director of the country's tourism support services. ''If we lose it, that's it.''
 
Management Plan Drawn Up
Preserving the Seychelles will take more money and more expertise than the country can afford. Thus, with the help of the United Nations and the World Bank, the Government has drawn up a $600 million environmental management plan which it hopes donor countries will finance.
The World Bank and the United Nations are organizing a conference on behalf of the Seychelles in Paris next February where donors will be asked to make pledges.
So far, environmentalists say the Seychelles has done quite well, studiously avoiding turning what it advertises as paradise into another Hawaii, or even a facsimile of the Caribbean.
The new environmental management plan states that over 40 percent of the land area on the scattered islands is national parks and reserves. While some environmentalists believe this figure is exaggerated, they say the Seychelles compares favorably to Botswana and Tanzania, two African countries with large amounts of protected land. Recently, the Government more than doubled the cost of sand used for building as a way of discouraging further erosion of some beaches.
 
Numbers to Be Limited
''They do have a pretty good conservation record and they are quite serious about it,'' said Jim Thorsell, the senior adviser on natural heritage for the International Union for Conservation of Nature in Switzerland.
Perhaps most striking is a recently announced limitation on the number of tourists. Last year, nearly 90,000 visitors relaxed in the perpetual sunshine, a vast increase over the early 1980's when a coup attempt set tourism back.
The Government has said it will allow no more than 100,000 tourists a year, and plans to enforce this limit by allowing only 4,000 hotel beds. ''A maximum ceiling of 4,000 beds with an average length of stay of 9 to 11 days and with a 75 percent occupancy rate works out at 100,000 tourists a year,'' Mr. Chong Seng said.
New hotels cannot be built on new sites. Instead, additional hotel rooms must be built as extensions to existing hotels or on land where an old hotel has been torn down. It is an unwritten rule, only obviously violated once - at the Sheraton Hotel - that no building can be higher than a coconut tree.
 
Tortoises in Danger
But some environmental problems remain unaddressed. The Seychelles is home to four species of sea turtles, two of which are of special interest. The first is the green turtle, which was once plentiful on the northern islands of the Seychelles but whose last large wild refuge is on Aldabra, a totally protected and remote atoll 500 miles south of the main island of Mahe. The second is the hawksbill turtle, whose carapace is used for tortoise-shell boxes, trays, bangles and the like.
A study of Seychelles turtles five years ago by an American zoologist, Jeanne A. Mortimer, for the World Wildlife Fund concluded that the hawksbill turtle, which takes 25 years to mature, was ''dwindling as an exploitable resource.'' Her report suggested that the best protection for the turtle would be a complete ban on possession, purchase and sale of all hawksbill products.
But tables crammed with tortoise-shell curios at the open-air market in the center of Victoria, the Seychelles capital, are the best evidence that the capture of the hawksbill turtle continues unabated. International trade in tortoise-shell products was banned in 1977 by the Conference on the International Trade in Endangered Species, to which the Seychelles is a signatory. The ban makes it illegal for tourists to take tortoise shell home but it is a ban easily flouted because the objects are so small they can easily be hidden in luggage.
 
Law Cannot Be Enforced
Seychelles law forbids the killing of the female hawksbill, which is vital to the continuation of the species, but Mr. Chong Seng points out that the country has no means to enforce the law.
Already, some of the environmentally conscious tourists who come here are calling up Mr. Chong Seng to complain about the sale of tortoise shell here.
But the biologist's biggest worry is about the meeting in Paris next February. The turtle question, he concedes, is the big ''sore point'' in the new environmental management plan. When the Seychelles asks the holders of the purse strings for money, Mr. Chong Seng envisions them retorting, ''But what about the turtles?''

HEADLINE: Son of Former Military Ruler Goes Into Politics in Pakistan

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 7

 BODY:
A son of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, convinced that the time is right to revive the name of Pakistan's late military ruler, has set aside a career in banking and plunged into politics in anticipation of elections on Oct. 24.
In the Indian subcontinent, where political dynasties have shaped the modern history of almost every nation, 38-year-old Ijaz ul-Haq sees a certain inevitability in this. He says that after two tumultous years of Benazir Bhutto, whose Government was dismissed on Monday by the President of Pakistan, people are taking a new look at the past and a kinder view of the Zia years.
''In the subcontinent, until the literacy rate has gone above 50 percent, politics is going to revolve around personalities,'' he said in an interview on Friday, just three days before the ouster of Ms. Bhutto, in the house in Rawalpindi that his family has borrowed from friends while a new one is under construction. ''In Pakistan, the only political forces seen today are the Bhuttos, represented by the Pakistan People's Party, and the anti-Peoples'-Party force, which is represented by the Zia ul-Haq constituency,'' he said. 
 
In General Zia's Name
''If somebody is going to come forward in the next elections in the name of General Zia ul-Haq, it is going to be his son and nobody else,'' Mr. Ijaz said.
Ms. Bhutto is the daughter of the Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown by General Zia in 1977 and hanged in 1979. Ms. Bhutto, who had wide public sympathy when she won the elections of November 1988, was at first preoccupied with avenging the death of her father. But many Pakistanis have mixed memories of Mr. Bhutto, a populist and an autocratic leader. Ms. Bhutto, despite her Western education, soon revived some fears of this personalized style of administration, while failing to deliver on election promises to improve social and economic conditions.
The Zia name, in contrast, still holds political weight. For common people, his was no reign of terror. Portraits of General Zia are still sold in the bazaars, and his visage adorns long-haul trucks. ''My father always used to say he had the silent majority of Pakistanis with him,'' Mr. Ijaz said.
On Aug. 17, the second anniversary of General Zia's death in a mysterious plane crash that also killed the United States Ambassador, Arnold Raphel, Mr. Ijaz plans to test the potential for his own political future when he speaks at a ceremony at General Zia's tomb in Islamabad, assuming that the event is allowed under emergency rules imposed this week.
 
Bank Executive Based in Bahrain
Mr. Ijaz, who until a few months ago was a Citibank vice president for Persian Gulf nations, based in Bahrain, is touring Pakistan to rally support for the Aug. 17 commemoration. He is also organizing the party machinery for the Muslim League, which dominates the conservative opposition Islamic Democratic Alliance, Ms. Bhuto's rival for power.
Mr. Ijaz said that his new Zia ul-Haq Foundation was computerizing the electoral history of all parliamentary constituencies. In each, a committee to screen and monitor candidates will be formed. If Mr. Ijaz, who has a master's degree in business administration from Southern Illinois University, is able to succeed, he will have created the first modern political organization in Pakistan, where nominations go more often than not to powerful families or their relatives, friends or retainers.
Electoral success, however, is still a long way off. Mr. Ijaz could prove an embarrassment to the Muslim League, which already has several other potential opposition leaders in the ranks. So far, Mr. Ijaz speaks only of securing a parliamentary seat, not a ministerial job.
Another unknown factor in Mr. Ijaz's future is the military, to which the league has been closely allied. Mr. Ijaz, who was never interested in following his father into a military career, says he has not spoken with the chief of the army, Gen. Mirza Alam Beg, since the army backed Ms. Bhutto's accession to power in 1988. The army also backed her ouster on Monday.
 
Bitterness Against Government
Mr. Ijaz has accused the Bhutto Government of harrasing his mother, whose presidential pension and other privileges were withdrawn. She and a mentally handicapped 17-year-old daughter live on an army pension, plus rent from a house General Zia owned and the help of another son, a physician, who lives with them. Two other sisters live abroad, one in the United States and one in Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Ijaz is bitter about the failure of the United States and Pakistan to resolve the mystery of his father's death, saying he believes there was a conspiracy to suppress investigations beyond the initial technical report. The United States Embassy has repeatedly denied the charge. ''The cover-up of the crash started immediately after it happened,'' Mr. Ijaz said. ''The Americans, the army and the President of Pakistan are all involved.''
Mr. Ijaz, who has been collecting evidence independently, said that he suspects the involvement of the Al-Zulfikar guerrilla organization, based in Syria and headed by Ms. Bhutto's brother, Mir Murtaza. In his political campaign, Mr. Ijaz says he will dwell on a deterioration of law and order, condemn weakening support for the Afghan resistance and expose what he called the corruption of Ms. Bhutto's husband and father-in-law, comparing their record with that of his father.
''People see that this man, General Zia ul-Haq, was uncorruptible,'' his son said. ''He was a very humble man who rose from nowhere to the top ranks of the army but never brought his family into public life. When he died, people did not even know how many children he had.''

HEADLINE: Quayle Presses Peru to Take U.S. Military Aid

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the United States does not intend to send American soldiers to Peru to fight drug traffickers.
But he pressed the new President of Peru to accept a $36 million military aid package that could result in the use of American military trainers in this country.
''We have no plans for military operations in the war on drugs - period,'' Mr. Quayle said at a news conference after a meeting here with the Peruvian President, Alberto Fujimori. 
Mr. Quayle, the highest-ranking American official to visit Peru in more than 30 years, vigorously denied recent news reports that the United States planned to send troops to the Andes to stem coca production.
Peru is the world's largest producer of coca leaf, the raw product for cocaine.
 
'Totally False' Reports
''I've also read these false reports that somehow there are going to be military operations in the Andes and Peru,'' Mr. Quayle said. ''Totally false. I would like to eradicate, if I may, the idea of militarization of the war on drugs.''
The Vice President insisted, however, that it was important that Mr. Fujimori accept the American military aid package, which is intended to help the Peruvian Government wrest control of coca-growing areas from leftist guerrillas.
President Fujimori, who has been in office less than a month, has been non-committal about accepting American military assistance. He has instead called for additional economic aid that could be used to wean Peruvian coca leaf growers from producing the illicit crop.
Of the meeting today, Mr. Quayle said, ''We did discuss this, and I do believe it is in his interest to accept this aid.''
Although he described the session with Mr. Fujimori as ''very productive,'' the Vice President declined to characterize Mr. Fujimori's response to suggestions that Peru accept the military aid. ''He will be making an announcement on this subject, not I,'' Mr. Quayle said.
The offer of military aid has drawn criticism from lawmakers in both Peru and the United States, who question whether the use of American military advisers in Peru could lead to the introduction of American troops in this nation's war against the Shining Path, the Maoist guerrilla group that controls drug-producing areas.
The drug war has been pushed to the sidelines of public debate in Peru in President Fujimori's first weeks in office, as the Peruvian leader struggles to prevent the collapse of the nation's economy.
There have been shortages of food and oil this week in Lima, the capital, as shoppers hoard staples in anticipation of Mr. Fujimori's economic recovery plan.
The plan is expected to eliminate price controls on some food and consumer goods. That, in turn, is expected to lead to widespread price increases.
 
Economic Chaos and Violence
The value of the Peruvian currency, the inti, has been in a free fall, and inflation in Peru is now running at nearly 20 percent a day.
Newspaper headlines in Lima this morning, describe the economic situation as ''Fujishock,'' and the President himself has described the economic situation as ''the most profound crisis in the nation's republican history.''
The economy chaos has led to violence. On Tuesday, several people were wounded, one critically, when bombs went off during demonstrations in Lima by workers protesting wage levels and the threat of Government-sanctioned price increases.
The loss of the coca crop could well be another severe economic blow to the Peruvian economy, since coca cultivation contributes an estimated $1 billion a year to the nation's economy, and farmers cannot readily convert to another crop.

LENGTH: 1203 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf; Strategy: Embargo;
U.S. Bets Its Troops Will Deter Iraq While Sanctions Do the Real Fighting

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
By sending American troops to Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved to deter an Iraqi invasion and committed the United States to a long stay in the Middle East kingdom, gambling that a steady tightening of economic pressure will force President Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Bush, they said, is confident that economic sanctions approved by the United Nations, the prospect of a multinational naval blockade and the constant threat of warfare with the United States and other nations will make Mr. Hussein's position in Kuwait untenable.
The Administration calculates that the economic embargo will cut off Mr. Hussein's supplies of military spare parts and ammunition, making it impossible to sustain his long supply lines and perhaps eroding his political stature at home, officials said. The United States is gambling that in time the Iraqi leader will be forced to retreat from Kuwait. 
''The embargo is the key,'' a senior official said. But he and other officials said it will take months for such an admittedly risky strategy to play out, and they said other, more long-range questions face Mr. Bush.
 
Action Now, Answers Later
Even if Mr. Hussein retreats from Kuwait, Middle Eastern politics has fundamentally been changed. How will the United States respond? How does the presence of a significant American military force in an Arab country, a major oil supplier to the United States, change the political and military equation? How will the new divisions created by the Kuwait invasion within an already tenuous Arab unity play out over the long run?
Administration officials said the White House is still groping for answers to these questions while, for now, Mr. Bush and his senior advisers are focused on the most immediate military and political issues.
The President asserted today that his current thinking is ''not beyond'' the sending of troops to Saudi Arabia in hopes of deterring an Iraqi attack on that country, the development American planners now fear most.
 
A Waiting Game
But Administration officials acknowledged that it is not enough for the United States simply to stall Mr. Hussein in Kuwait, because Mr. Bush has vowed to drive the Iraqi leader from the emirate.
Mr. Bush referred repeatedly in his news conference and televised address today to Mr. Hussein's reputation for ruthlessness. And, although they were not willing to say so explicitly, Mr. Bush, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made it clear that they were prepared to expand American military activity beyond the current ''defensive positions'' in Saudi Arabia.
Public comments today by Mr. Bush, Mr. Cheney and Mr. Powell, as well as interviews with other officials, made it clear that the United States is betting heavily on the effectiveness of the sanctions imposed on Iraq. But Administration officials acknowledged that this ''waiting game'' they are playing with Mr. Hussein is full of risk, since they have no reliable way of judging his intentions.
 
Assuming U.S. Threat Is Enough
The current American strategy is based on a series of assumptions and calculations about Iraqi capabilities and intentions.
Perhaps most important, Administration officials said they believed the presence of American troops in Saudi Arabia would be enough to keep Mr. Hussein from attacking. ''He would be bound to sustain incredible losses and we think it would be obvious that he would lose,'' one official said.
That calculation could underestimate the Iraqi's taste for battle. Mr. Hussein did not hesitate to attack Iran and then fight that nation for nine years despite the huge economic and human cost of the war.
But in explaining the American reasoning, an official said: ''Iran wasn't a nuclear power with airplanes and ships and highly trained forces. All Iran had was a lot of people and it basically sustained itself by throwing bodies at him. The United States presents a much different kind of foe for him and he surely recognizes that.''
 
All Hopes on Embargo
With the assumption that the threat of an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia is mitigated by sending paratroopers and fighters to Saudi Arabia, the American strategy then boils down to the embargo.
''Hussein can't maintain himself in this position for too long,'' an official said. ''If the embargo is effective, it means the loss of all his funds, it means the loss of parts for his warplanes, since the two sources were France and the Soviet Union, and they cut him off. Now he has to look for someplace else to buy parts and we'll do our best to cut off all sources.''
The official added: ''He has a food and distribution problem, although he does own Kuwait and presumably there is some capacity within the country. Further, he's not getting any of the wealth he needed so badly and you've got to figure he needed wealth badly to undertake this action in the first place. That situation should be growing worse because the oil sales are cut off.''
It is something of a political departure that Mr. Bush is relying so heavily on an embargo, since he and other Republicans have often held that embargoes cannot bend the will of nations. But Administration officials defended the strategy.
 
Why an Embargo Would Work
''The belief is that the world has changed considerably,'' one official said. ''We don't have the cold war situation, where it was difficult to enforce sanctions because of ideological competition and huge divisions in the world. This time, we've got the Soviet Union on board and virtually everyone else as well.''
The official said geography is on the American side. ''You can shut off the gulf and you've got them locked in on the Mediterranean side,'' he said. ''We've got one pipeline shut down, and we're working on the other.''
Finally, Administration officials argued that economic sanctions have failed when they were applied against relatively healthy economies, like that of South Africa. ''This time,'' the official said, ''we're dealing with a single-source economy based on oil sales that is on its knees because of the war and can be hurt very easily.''
Beyond the military issues, Administration officials are facing a complex political situation with which they have not completely come to grips.
For one thing, they are still struggling with Arab resistance, notably in Egypt, to American military involvement. Mr. Bush has to find ways to repair his once friendly relations with King Hussein of Jordan, who has supported the Iraqis in the current conflict.
Beyond that, President Hussein of Iraq has been trying to drive a wedge between the region's ordinary citizen and the oligarchies, like those in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, which have thrived on oil profits for decades and enjoyed American support.
Administration officials said they have considered this tactic, but play down its ability to change the political map of the Middle East. ''It's the old monarchy versus the new dictatorship, and Hussein hardly has clean hands,'' a senior official said. ''This is a guy who has run his country with cruelty and if this is populism, it's a populism of blood.''

LENGTH: 837 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From Bush's Statement on U.S. Defense of Saudis

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's address from the Oval Office yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
In the life of a nation, we're called upon to define who we are and what we believe. Sometimes the choices are not easy. As today's President, I ask for your support in the decision I've made to stand up for what's right and condemn what's wrong all in the cause of peace.
At my direction, elements of the 82d Airborne Division as well as key units of the United States Air Force are arriving today to take up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia. I took this action to assist the Saudi Arabian Government in the defense of its homeland. No one commits America's armed forces to a dangerous mission lightly. But after perhaps unparalleled international consultation and exhausting every alternative, it became necessary to take this action. 
Let me tell you why. Less than a week ago in the early morning hours of Aug. 2, Iraqi armed forces, without provocation or warning, invaded a peaceful Kuwait. Facing negligible resistance from its much smaller neighbor, Iraq's tanks stormed in blitzkrieg fashion through Kuwait in a few short hours.
With more than 100,000 troops along with tanks, artillery and surface-to-surface missiles, Iraq now occupies Kuwait.
 
Principles of U.S. Policy
This aggression came just hours after Saddam Hussein specifically assured numerous countries in the area that there would be no invasion. There is no justification whatsoever for this outrageous and brutal act of aggression.
A puppet regime imposed from the outside is unacceptable. The acquisition of territory by force is unacceptable. No one, friend or foe, should doubt our desire for peace and no one should underestimate our determination to confront aggression. Four simple principles guide our policy. First, we seek the immediate unconditional and complete withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Second, Kuwait's legitimate Government must be restored to replace the puppet regime. And third, my Administration, as has been the case with every President from President Roosevelt to President Reagan, is committed to the security and stability of the Persian Gulf. And fourth, I am determined to protect the lives of American citizens abroad.
Immediately after the Iraqi invasion, I ordered an embargo of all trade with Iraq, and together with many other nations announced sanctions that both froze all Iraqi assets in this country and protected Kuwait's assets.
 
Appeasement's Limits
The stakes are high. Iraq is already a rich and powerful country. It possesses the world's second-largest reserves of oil and over a million men under arms. It's the fourth-largest military in the world.
Our country now imports nearly half the oil it consumes and could face a major threat to its economic independence. Much of the world is even more dependent upon imported oil and is even more vulnerable to Iraqi threats. We succeeded in the struggle for freedom in Europe because we and our allies remained stalwart. Keeping the peace in the Middle East will require no less.
But we must recognize that Iraq may not stop using force to advance its ambitions. Iraq has massed an enormous war machine on the Saudi border capable of initiating hostilities with little or no additional preparations. Given the Iraqi Government's history of aggression against its own citizens as well as its neighbors, to assume Iraq will not attack again would be unwise and unrealistic. And therefore, after consulting with King Fahd, I sent Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney to discuss cooperative measures we could take.
 
Enforcing the Sanctions
Following those meetings, the Saudi Government requested our help. And I responded to that request by ordering U.S. air and ground forces to deploy to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
Let me be clear, the sovereign independence of Saudi Arabia is of vital interest to the United States. This decision, which I shared with the Congressional leadership, grows out of the longstanding friendship and security relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia.
U.S. forces will work together with those of Saudi Arabia and other nations to preserve the integrity of Saudi Arabia and to deter further Iraqi aggression. Through their presence, as as well through training and exercises, these multinational forces will enhance the overall capability of Saudi armed forces to defend the kingdom.
I want to be clear about what we are doing and why.
America does not seek conflict. Nor do we seek to chart the destiny of other nations. But America will stand by her friends. The mission of our troops is wholly defensive. Hopefully, they'll not be needed long. They will not initiate hostilities but they will defend themselves, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and other friends in the Persian Gulf.
And one more thing, I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share. They should exercise restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices.

PUB-DATE: August 9, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1645 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on the Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today on the Iraq crisis:
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. How long will you keep American forces in Saudi Arabia, and why not use them to drive the Iraqi troops out of Kuwait?
A. Well, as you know from what I said, they're there in a defensive mode right now. And therefore, that is not the mission, to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. We have economic sanctions that I hope will be effective to that end, and I don't know how long they'll be there. They just got there - are just getting there. 
Q. Is this an open-ended commitment? I mean, could this drag on for years?
A. Nothing is open ended. But I'm not worrying about that there at all. I'm worrying about getting them there and doing what I indicated in our speech in there is necessary -the defense of the Saudis and the trying, through concerted international means, to reverse out this aggression.
 
War With Iraq
Q. Mr. President, are we in a war? And what other nations have agreed to join our forces in defending Saudi Arabia? And I take it you also have included other gulf nations in that umbrella.
A. We're not in a war. We have sent forces to defend Saudi Arabia. Other nations - I will leave announcements about what other nations will be participating to the Saudis. But I believe Margaret Thatcher, after talking to King Fahd, has announced that forces will be going in, and then I think you'll see other such actions. But I'd much prefer to leave that to Saudi Arabia, who - indeed, it's their country.
 
Cheney's Mission
Q. But was Cheney's mission successful in rallying support with Egypt and Morocco?
A. Well, I - I, having talked to Mubarak a couple of times myself, feel that we are in very close agreement with him. Who was your other country you asked about?
Q. Morocco, Yemen.
A. Morocco - very, very supportive of the Saudis and of our overall position on the Mideast. So, they're - I was very pleased with the Cheney mission in that regard.
 
Americans in Baghdad
Q. Mr. President, there are several dozen Americans in Baghdad apparently not able to leave [inaudible] and perhaps hundreds more in Kuwait, and perhaps elsewhere in Iraq as well. In view of the extreme political sensitivity of Americans toward this whole question of hostages, why should not Saddam Hussein feel that he holds very high cards now in dealing with the United States?
A. Well, I've been encouraged that there had been - have been actually announcements, I believe, saying people were free to leave. So I'm not going to speculate or hypothecate beyond that. I want to see them out of there, obviously. But what he does, that's a bit unpredictable.
 
Iraq's Chemical Arms
Q. Mr. President, the question of chemical weapons. There are reports that the Iraqis were seen loading airplanes with chemical weapons. How concerned are you that he would use these over our troops that are there?
A. Well, I think any time you deal with somebody who has used chemical weapons on the battlefield, you are concerned about it. And I would think that he'd know that, given the way the world views the use of chemical weapons, that it would be intolerable and that it would be dealt with very, very severely. So I would hope that there would be no use of chemical weapons.
 
Shutting a Pipeline
Q. Do you know if the Saudis are going to follow the Turks' lead in shutting off an Iraqi pipeline? . . . Have you had any promises from the Saudis or any other oil-producing countries that they will increase production to make up for this shortfall?
A. Well, I'm convinced - I believe that the Venezuelans have announced a significant increase. And I expect you'd find others to follow. And what was the first part, John?
Q. Are the Saudis cutting off the pipeline to - [inaudible]?
A. That matter will be discussed, I'm sure, and I know that the Saudis are fully in accord with the action taken by the United Nations in terms of Chapter 7 sanctions. And so I - but we have no deal with them in that regard.
 
The Press and Troops
Q. Sir, it's difficult for us to get information from Saudi Arabia, one reason being the American news media were not permitted to accompany American troops into Saudi Arabia. Was that your decision or King Fahd's?
A. That decision didn't come to me. But there's plenty of reporters in Saudi Arabia right now.
Q. Well, do you think there should be a Pentagon pool, as there was for example in Panama?
A. Well, I'd have to discuss that with the Secretary of Defense. I'm glad that the matter - that that many forces could be moved with not too much advance warning, and with not too much, therefore, risk to Saudi Arabia or to these troops. Yeah?
 
How Bush Decided
Q. Mr. President, was there any one single thing that tipped your hand into deciding to send U.S. troops and aircraft into Saudi Arabia? And secondly, how supportive have the Soviets been about your decision?
A. There was no one single thing that I can think of. But when King Fahd requested such support we were prompt to respond. But I can't think of an individual specific thing. If there was one, it would perhaps be the Saudis moving south when they said they were withdrawing.
Q. You mean the Iraqis, sir?
A. I mean, the Iraqis - thank you very much, it's been a long night - moving - the Iraqis moving down to the Kuwait-Saudi border when indeed they had given their word that they were withdrawing. That heightened our concern.
 
Support From Moscow
Q. How supportive have the Soviets been to your decision, sir?
A. The Soviets have been very responsible, in my view. They have joined the United Nations on that resolution, and Jim Baker, as recently as yesterday afternoon or evening, was in touch with Shevardnadze again. And you know, I can't ask for a more favorable response than he received. Yes, Jerry.
 
Economic Pressure
Q. Mr. President, is it your intention to let economic pressure alone provide the force that drives Iraq out of Kuwait? Are you prepared to wait several months, which is how long it might take for the economic sanctions to really bite?
A. Well, we've taken this first significant step to defend Saudi Arabia. The economic sanctions should begin to bite pretty soon. There will be further steps taken to insure that they are fully effective, and then we'll wait and see where we go from there.
 
Trust and Hussein
Q. Mr. President, you've told us several times of Saddam Hussein's lies in his dealings with other leaders and with the United States on his intentions. Why do you now believe the Iraqi Government's statements that they will let Americans go if there are no - if there is no evidence of an American being let go?
A. I'm not sure I totally believe them. I hope they're telling the truth.
 
Tactics Against Iraq
Q. Mr. President, you said in your speech this morning that the puppet regime in Kuwait was unacceptable, and so was the acquisition of territory. At the same time, though, you said that the - that the deployments are wholly defensive. The question is, how do you actually expect to force Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait?
A. Economic sanctions in this instance, if fully enforced, can be very, very effective. It is a rich country in terms of oil resources. They're a poor country, in a sense, because he squandered much of the resource on military might, and there are some indications that he's already beginning to feel the pinch. And nobody can stand up forever to total economic deprivation.
 
Overtures and Intentions
Q. Mr. President, can you tell us what U.S. and Saudi forces will be up against? You mentioned surface-to-surface missiles, you've spoken previously of the chemical-warfare capability. . . . The second part of the question is, did we misread Saddam Hussein? A couple of months ago, your people were up on the - the Administration was up on the Hill deflecting a move to put sanctions on - on - on --
A. Let me - let me ask you - I'm not going to take the question on the exact military problem there because we're going to have a thorough briefing at the Pentagon - I think they're much better equipped to handle that kind of detail. On Saddam Hussein, look, we have tried very hard to see if there wasn't a way to have somewhat improved relations. There's no question about that. But - and I have no regret about having tried to have discussions that might have led to a better relationship.
But that had to stop the minute you have this - this kind of aggression. But I don't think having - having tried tentatively to have a little better relationship with a person over the last couple of years - we've still been very, very wary all along of his - of his intentions.
 
Intelligence Lapse?
Q. But did our intelligence let us down or -or did you know that what has happened -when did you get an indication of - [inaudible] - as far as moving into Kuwait and that sort of thing?
A. No, I don't - I don't feel let down by the intelligence at all. When you plan a blitzkrieg-like attack that's launched at 2 in the morning, it's pretty hard to stop, particularly when you have just been given the word of the people involved that there wouldn't be any such attack.
 
Chances of Recession
Q. Do you think the spike in oil prices which has occurred significantly at home as a result of the Persian Gulf problem could edge the economy into a recession?
A. I have not been advised of that. I hope that is not the case, and what I hope to do is see a reduction in oil prices once a - once it becomes clear that there will not be shortage. There's an overhang now of oil in the marketplace, thank God. We have a Strategic Petroleum Reserve that we can draw from. Other countries have the same - a couple of other countries have S.P.R.'s themselves.

LENGTH: 1760 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From News Conference by Cheney and Powell at the Pentagon

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference at the Pentagon today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription agency:
 
OPENING STATEMENTS
CHENEY. I thought I would open with a brief statement about my trip this past weekend.
We arrived in Saudi Arabia on Monday; met with King Fahd Monday evening, as well as the Crown Prince and other officials. At that time, we discussed in general the intelligence that was available to us on the situation in the gulf, reviewed with them the diplomatic developments and all of the work that had been under way by the President with respect to efforts to impose economic and political sanctions on Iraq in regard to its invasion of Kuwait. We then discussed with them in some detail the military situation on the ground in the Persian Gulf region, and we also presented to the King a rundown on our military capabilities. 
Subsequent to those discussions, the King made the request for the deployment of U.S. forces to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. I conveyed that request by telephone to the President. The President authorized me to deploy those forces, and I subsequently then gave instructions for those deployments to the chairman by telephone back here in Washington, and of course, to General Schwarzkopf who was with me in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.
Subsequent to that, I had a meeting the next morning with Prince Sultan, who is the Saudi Defense Minister. We discussed in greater detail the deployments that are now under way. When I left Saudi Arabia at the direction of the President I stopped and visited, as I think's been announced, President Mubarak in Alexandria, Egypt. And then last evening, King Hassan in Rabat, Morocco.
POWELL. After the Secretary called back, orders were issued for the deployment on Monday evening, and the first element lifted off the ground - early advance party elements lifted off the ground at 7:35 yesterday morning, and the flow has continued with the major part of the flow beginning last night with the departure of the F-15's from Langley Air Force Base.
At the moment, the following forces are in the area of operations or are soon to arrive within the area of operations. Let me begin with the Persian Gulf. As you know, for a long time we have had a presence in the Persian Gulf, and that's the Joint Task Force Middle East, currently consisting of seven ships -Antietam, England, Vandergrift, Ray, Rentz, Barbey, and then the flagship, La Salle, and the Bradley is also part of the force right now. They have been there for some time and were pre-positioned and are not part of the new deployments.
Coming to the southeast, we had the arrival of the aircraft carrier Independence and its group on Monday, and it was prepared for operations on Tuesday. And you see additional forces with the Independence group -some of those are combatants and some of those are resupply ships. With respect to additional naval forces moved into the region as part of the direction given to us by the President and the Secretary, the Eisenhower battle group has now passed through the Suez Canal and has taken up a position generally where you see it in the Red Sea along with the Scott and the Ticonderoga.
As you also know and have seen on television, the Saratoga battle group as well as the battleship Wisconsin, departed East Coast ports for a normal deployment - not part of this operation, just a normal deployment. But obviously, as these ships arrive in the Mediterranean and operate in the Mediterranean, they will increase our overall naval presence in the region.
With respect to the deployment of air forces, as I mentioned F-15 model C's and D's left Langley Air Force Base last evening -during the course of the evening. They are continuing today. And the first planes havelanded in Saudi Arabia and are taking up positions at various locations within Saudi Arabia.
And finally, with respect to ground force deployments so far, the Division Ready Brigade, D.R.B. - that brigade that is always kept in the highest state of readiness in the 82d Airborne Division - left beginning at 3 this morning for duty in Saudi Arabia and will be arriving in Saudi Arabia in the course of the afternoon and evening.
That is all I'm going to say now with respect to those deployments that are under way or units that have already arrived in country. Thank you.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. General, could you at least say how many men are in the Division Ready Brigade?
POWELL. No. I'm not going to give specific numbers with respect to the size of our forces in country or in the Division Ready Brigade at this time.
 
Troop Vulnerability
Q. General Powell, how vulnerable are these troops during this transition period when you're putting troops and equipment into place?
A. We thought of that, and I think they are pretty secure. Even though these aircraft and ground troops are just arriving, the Independence is in a position to provide support now, as is the Eisenhower battle group. So we have the ability to cover these movements. And, of course, the Saudi armed forces are quite capable. They have Awacs aircraft. They also have top-of-the-line fighters. So I'm reasonably sure that we can get in in good order without presenting any vulnerabilities. I think I also failed to mention the five Awacs that are also arriving just about now in Saudi Arabia.
 
Chemical Warfare
Q. What is the threat of chemical warfare on behalf of the Iraqis? Have they moved any chemical weapons down to within range of Saudi Arabia?
A. The Iraqi armed forces do have chemical weapons, artillery-delivered as well as delivered by other means. They have used them in the past. It's a threat that we're concerned with. And I treat it as a capability that is there and could be used. I am not - I don't want to heighten any concern with respect to that because the intelligence is somewhat ambiguous. But it is a capability that they have demonstrated in the past that they will use, and we understand that and we have -are preparing our forces accordingly. But I don't want to heighten tension any more over that issue.
 
Troop Training
Q. General, can you give us an estimate of how trained and ready your troops are to fight a force of a million men that's already been through an eight-year war with Iran?
A. . . . Even though there may be one million people in the Iraqi Army, it is not an army that is currently postured to come storming across any border with one million people. I am confident of our ability, when we have finished our deployments, to be able to accomplish the mission the President gave us.
 
Gas Protection
Q. Could you tell us if these troops that have already been deployed to Saudi Arabia - are they equipped with specialized gear to deal with gas warfare?
A. Yes.
Q. Could you get into some detail of exactly what kind of equipment that entails?
A. We have protective masks, we have overgarments that will protect the body from chemical contamination, and we have necessary medicines that will serve as antidotes to chemical agents.
 
Iraqi Forces
Q. General, would you give us your assessment, please, of the quality of the Iraqi forces that invaded Kuwait and their readiness, based upon their current positions, to go further into Saudi Arabia should that be the military decision?
A. Well, they conducted the Kuwaiti operation in a very professional manner. It's an army that is capable. They have had eight years of experience in war. They have the capability to invade Saudi Arabia with forces in contact and they have the ability to reinforce those forces. That's what's caused this problem that we now have. So, we treat them and view them as a capable military force. But they are not invincible and they're not 10 feet tall and we have capabilities that we are now bringing to bear, to insure that we, in concert with the armed forces of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, can deal with that threat.
 
Missile Capability
Q. On the points the President raised in his speech about the surface-to-surface missiles, could you explain the concern --
A. They have that capability.
Q. -- that the President had in mind, particular - in terms of particular weapons systems and what those are?
A. Well, those weapons systems, as we have seen demonstrated, have quite a range. And the Iraqis have shown a great deal of creativity in taking Soviet equipment they had been provided and modifying that equipment to give it even greater range. And if you look at the range arcs, that is one of the principal threats directed against Saudi Arabia. And that's why, I'm sure, the President highlighted it.
 
Deal With Saudis
Q. What was the breakthrough that King Fahd saw in your argument? . . .
CHENEY. Well, the discussion with King Fahd obviously was - I - a significant moment. He - the conversation went on for about two hours roughly, and it was, as I say - consisted initially of my presentation and that of General Schwarzkopf as we briefed on the situation in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and Iraq and also briefed on our military capabilities.
My impression is - although obviously the King would want to speak for himself - but that it had become abundantly clear that the Iraqis had, in fact, committed an act of infamy, if you will, in their aggression against Kuwait; that, having told the Saudis and others in the region that they had no intention to invade, they did in fact invade; that the conduct of Saddam Hussein represented a qualitative shift, if you will, in sort of the rules of behavior in that part of the world.
The King indicated to me that he felt his first priority had to be the safety and security of the people of Saudi Arabia, and that based upon that, based upon the historic relationship of the United States and the Government of Saudi Arabia - specifically, he cited the meeting between his father, King Abdul Aziz, and President Roosevelt on the U.S.S. Quincy in 1945, and based upon their fundamental trust of the United States, they were prepared to ask for our assistance. And I think it was that culmination of events of the last few days - the naked aggression by Iraq as well as the historic relationship of the United States and President Bush's extensive consultations with him and commitment to provide significant forces for the defense of the kingdom, that combination of things - that led to King Fahd's decision to ask for our help.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1014 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
To Baghdad, Poison Gas Is 'Poor Man's A-Bomb'

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Poison gas, a weapon no United States serviceman has had to confront since 1918, could make the Arabian desert virtually impassable for American ground troops in a no holds-barred war with Iraq.
Iraqi chemical weapons could cause enormous casualties among ground troops, experts agree, and could leave so much contamination on the ground that passage would be unsafe long afterward. Poison gas is known among arms makers as ''the poor man's atomic bomb.''
American troops are issued protective clothing and other gear to cope with gas attacks, and the Army's tanks and other armored vehicles have air-filtering systems. But these pose logistic and other problems, particularly in the hot climate of the Persian Gulf in summer, that could severely hamper troops in combat. 
Even in the face of inevitable American reprisals, analysts speculate, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq might be tempted to use every weapon at his disposal in the hope of quickly wounding the United States badly enough to discourage further involvement.
 
An Early Advantage
If Iraq and the United States were to go to war in the next few days, Iraqi chemical weapons, combined with a small but modern arsenal of battlefield missiles and a large armored force that includes 5,500 tanks - of which at least 500 are advanced Soviet T-72's, could give Iraq a potent edge in the opening phase. Iraq is much weaker than the United States in tactical air power and reconnaissance, but the build-up of American ground forces in the area will take time, and a quick strike by Iraq could overwhelm a large area.
Besides softening up American resistance, poison gas might be used to disrupt or disable military depots, oil pipeline stations, ports and population centers. Some forms of mustard and nerve gas are highly persistent, and contaminated soil can remain hazardous or lethal for years. Facing imminent defeat, Iraq might even use poison gas to destroy as much of the Middle East's oil-pumping capacity as possible with the object of causing economic havoc in the West until petroleum production facilities could be repaired.
Although some United States Army troops have been trained to survive the unique hardships of desert warfare, and all American soldiers have had at least superficial instruction in chemical warfare defenses, Iraq's veteran forces are far more experienced in these vital skills.
 
An Ample Stock on Hand
Col. Andrew Duncan of the British Army, a spokesman for the International Institute for Strategic Studies based in London, said in an interview that Iraq is presumed to have ample stocks of chemical weapons. Iraq manufactures both mustard gas - a major killer during World War I - and the nerve gas tabun, which was invented during the 1940's by Nazi Germany. In its recent war with Iran and fighting against Kurdish dissidents in Iraq, Baghdad mounted repeated chemical attacks, principally using canisters dropped from aircraft. Residual poison gas is still causing casualties in these areas , experts say.
The nerve gases stocked in military arsenals are colorless, volatile liquids that can be sprayed as aerosol mists, or dispersed by explosions.
Both mustard and nerve gas can attack through the skin. A droplet of liquid nerve gas the size of a pinhead can kill a person.
 
Outfitted Like an Astronaut
This means that battlefield survival in a nerve-gas environment depends on complete isolation from the lethal chemical. Fitted with full protective gear, an American soldier looks like a lunar astronaut. His face is covered by a hermetically-sealed M40 or M43 mask fitted with a communications microphone and head phones, and provided with air filtered by various absorbent chemicals.
His body is enveloped in a double-layered synthetic-fiber suit containing gas-absorbing charcoal. A gas-resistant shroud covers his head and shoulders, underneath a heavy Kevlar helmet, and he wears butyl rubber gloves and boots.
A soldier wearing this cumbersome, stifling garb must also carry a weapon, ammunition, a water canteen, a first-aid pack, and whatever other field equipment he is assigned. When he walks or runs he quickly overheats, as recent experiments at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland demonstrated.
In the Arabian desert, where midday temperatures hover around 120 degrees, sustained infantry combat in a nerve-gas environment without frequent air-conditioned rest periods is out of the question.
To cope with the problem, the Army relies on its M20 ''Collective Protection Equipment'' - a gas-tight plastic liner for a room or tent fitted with pumps that supply untainted, cool air to occupants.
 
Iraqis Experienced
Iraqi troops would face the same dangers and problems as Americans in a chemical war, but they have had years of practice in conducting chemical warfare and in fighting in a hot climate and know what to expect.
 
Nature Is an Enemy
Tanks and some other combat vehicles can be sealed against poison gas, but all protective systems are based on filtering systems that chemically remove lethal substances from the air pumped inside. The filtering chemicals used in these systems, and in gas masks, become exhausted with use, especially if the contamination is heavy, and must be changed every few hours or days, requiring reliable supplies or replacements.
Desert warfare is conducted over vast areas where nature is often as potent an adversary as a human enemy. World War II tank battles in the deserts of Egypt, Libya and Tunisia demonstrated the critical importance of supply lines covering vast distances. Allied air power was decisive in interdicting Axis supplies to North Africa from across the Mediterranean, and American air supremacy over the Arabian desert in the present confrontation could similarly hamstring Iraq's mechanized forces by stopping supplies of fuel, ammunition and food.
But it may take time for an American air umbrella to dominate the desert, and meanwhile, Iraq's powerful armored divisions, backed by the threat or use of chemical weapons, could take a heavy toll.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A cylinder impounded by a Greek customs official last April from a British truck in Patras was believed to be a part ordered for an Iraqi artillery system from a British company. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
NATO, Bereft of a Military Role, Redefines Itself as the West's Political Galvanizer

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The United States briefed its NATO allies today on its decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and encouraged them to participate in an international force being formed in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, NATO officials said.
Although NATO is constrained by its charter from playing a military role in a conflict outside Europe or North America unless a member state - in this case Turkey - is attacked, the United States has sought to involve the alliance to underline the West's determination to confront Baghdad.
On Monday, President Bush received NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, at the White House. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will fly here on Friday to address NATO foreign ministers after paying a quick visit to Turkey on Thursday. ''We think NATO's political role is crucial,'' an American official said. 
Several hours before President Bush delivered his televised address announcing the troop buildup in Saudi Arabia, the United States Ambassador to NATO, William H. Taft 4th, informed the North Atlantic Council of Washington's plans and emphasized the importance of a multinational military response to the Iraqi challenge.
 
Unusual Unanimity
''We hope for as much support as possible for the force,'' an American official at NATO's headquarters here said. ''And there's more unanimity on this point than I can remember before in this house. Now we have to see who is willing to participate.''
Britain, which is already moving to reinforce its naval presence in the gulf, said today it would join the multinational force protecting Saudi Arabia. France, which has also dispatched a frigate to join two warships in the gulf, indicated that it was not yet ready to do so. Other countries had yet to respond, although Italy joined a multinational force that patrolled the gulf in 1987.
Because NATO itself is not directly involved, member countries are not required to allow American naval and air bases on their territory to be used for refueling, for massing troops or as staging posts in any gulf conflict.
Spain and Italy nonetheless said today that they had authorized the United States to make use of American bases there. Greece said last weekend it would not permit American bases in Crete to be used for staging any military action in the Middle East.
American officials said that while the multinational force would not be coordinated by the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, NATO is serving as a forum for exchanging information and developing contingency plans for a possible expansion in the crisis or for a potential disruption in international oil supplies.
 
Sending a Signal
The North Atlantic Council, the organization's senior policy-making body, has already met twice, and many other committees have been meeting daily. ''Even if the United States is acting unilaterally, you should not underestimate NATO's role as an expression of political solidarity,'' the American official said.
In an example of the action behind the scenes here, the little-known NATO Wartime Oil Organization met today with the organization's Economic, Political and Senior Civil Emergency Planning Committees to analyze the political impact of an oil shortage on NATO countries and its strategic effect on the alliance itself.
A delegate from the United States Department of Energy, Romulo Diaz, urged NATO members at the meeting to work together to conserve oil, American officials said. He also briefed them on specific proposals related to strategic oil reserves that Washington will present on Thursday at a meeting of the 21-nation International Energy Agency in Paris.
Along with mobilizing agencies to handle food relief, evacuation and other potential needs in a war situation, the Senior Civil Emergency Planning Committee was preparing to mobilize civilian resources like merchant vessels, which would be used if it were necessary to move large numbers of American troops to Europe.
 
NATO Broadens Its Interests
NATO officials pointed out that while the organization was founded in 1949 to counter the Soviet threat, it has in recent months broadened its interpretation of the alliance's security interests to include regional conflicts.
Although NATO cannot yet act ''out of area,'' meaning outside Europe and North America, the officials noted that the organization had embarked on a major strategic review since the virtual collapse of the Warsaw Pact in Eastern Europe.
''The Iraq crisis is a concrete example of what we have been talking about when we refer to 'new challenges,' '' an American official said. ''That's why Washington is giving NATO a high profile in this case. It's anxious that NATO be seen to be relevant.''
