SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 741 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A New Kind of Crisis

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
For the first time in many years, an American President has discussed a grave international crisis and the serious actions it requires of him without issuing a call to arms against Communism or raising the old, familiar cold war fears.
Perhaps as a partial result, the U.N. Security Council was able to take strong and unusual action -mandatory sanctions against Iraq, in response to its conquest of Kuwait, with the Soviet Union, China and the United States standing together in the unanimous vote.
The lack of cold war overtones also may have been partly responsible for Mr. Bush's diplomatic success in pulling Moscow, Beijing, Japan, the European Community and even some of the Middle Eastern nations into alignment with the U.S. against Iraq and its dictator, Saddam Hussein.
That it was against indisputable ''Iraqi aggression,'' not some hazy ''Red threat,'' that Mr. Bush acted also helps explain what appears to be the unusual unity of the American public and of Congress in his support. Mr. Hussein, moreover, has refused foolishly to make good his promise to pull out of Kuwait - which would have made it much harder to mobilize opposition to him. 
Even so, the President probably could not have achieved such international unity, even in the absence of divisive cold war pressures, had not the Mideast crisis concerned oil -the energy source not just for tanks and planes but for modern economies around the world.
Any threat to oil supplies and prices invokes the common and vital interest of many nations. That may have been the factor that encouraged Mr. Bush to risk his call for the ''immediate, unconditional and complete withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait'' and the restoration of the emirate. Such a call could only be a gamble on bringing about the downfall, not just the defeat, of Saddam Hussein.
Mr. Bush described the independence of Saudi Arabia as a ''vital interest'' of this country. Sending American forces to protect that interest can leave Mr. Hussein in no doubt that an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia would mean war with the United States. At least by Western standards of reasoning - which may not apply - the Iraqi dictator seems unlikely to take up this deliberate challenge.
By the same standards, however, he seems equally unlikely to meet Mr. Bush's requirements that he pull out of Kuwait and restore its former Government to office. If, as appears likely, he invaded that country to repair an Iraqi economy badly damaged by his long war against Iran and to divert his populace from his harsh dictatorship, he might well not survive the abject surrender that Mr. Bush demands.
Some Middle Eastern nations will support the President's determination to protect Saudi Arabia, in order to stop Mr. Hussein's power grab. But even those nations may not join in his demand for a restoration of the status quo ante in Kuwait. The former Kuwaiti emirate was not well regarded among other oil-producing nations, owing to its violations of OPEC decisions; and it would be easy for endangered nations in the region to concede the conquest of Kuwait in return for Mr. Hussein's promises to leave everybody else alone.
Thus, the odds seem fairly good that Mr. Bush's dispatch of U.S. forces will deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia, if one ever was contemplated. But the President might well lose his gamble that Mr. Hussein will back down on Kuwait.
The forces going into Saudi Arabia, Mr. Bush insisted, are ''wholly defensive'' and have no mission ''to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait.'' Thus, the President was careful not to threaten military action against Mr. Hussein - only to make it clear that military action by him against Saudi Arabia will be resisted. In the effort to reverse the invasion of Kuwait, Mr. Bush insisted at his news conference, his reliance was on ''economic sanctions.''
Perhaps the international need to thwart Mr. Hussein's reach for effective control of Mideast oil can make those sanctions as effective as Mr. Bush hopes. But what if they don't force an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait, to which Mr. Bush is pledged, or bring about the downfall of Saddam Hussein, for which he obviously aims?
The President was careful at his news conference neither to rule out nor to threaten ''pre-emptive strikes'' against Iraq itself (presumbly air strikes). The inference surely must be taken, however, that if sanctions don't produce the desired results, military action is next.

HEADLINE: More Babies Are Dying

 BODY:
Born in the U.S.A.: it should be a matter of pride. But for too many children, being born here constitutes bad luck. That's the substance of a sidetracked report by the White House Task Force on Infant Mortality. 
A quarter of the 40,000 infant deaths that occur in this country every year are easily preventable; so are a lot of the handicaps that afflict 100,000 newborns. The problems are primarily attributable to their mothers' lack of prenatal care.
Some officials involved in the study told a Times reporter that it was on hold because the conclusions were an inconvenient reminder of unkept Bush campaign promises. Another official says it just needs further work. Never mind. The report won't be news to health care professionals.
They've known for years that poverty and accompanying ignorance, combined with cuts in Federal programs, have slowed America's steady progress in lowering the infant mortality rate. Today, instead of going down it is being pushed up by crack, venereal disease and AIDS. By this measure, the United States ranks 20th among industrialized countries in preventing infant deaths.
America already knows how to make the rate drop again. Two years ago the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality recommended expanded Medicaid coverage and incentives to doctors to take Medicaid patients. The White House Task Force makes similar recommendations, and suggests an increase in Federal spending on prenatal care. Both panels say employers might also contribute.
The Task Force estimates that the steps it recommends would cost $480 million a year. Compare that with the lifetime medical costs for low-birthweight babies; each can run $400,000. Such costs of children now being born to crack-addicted mothers are beyond reckoning.
America can't afford not to spent more on prenatal care, not on economic grounds and not on the grounds of humanity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Black Congressional Hope in Connecticut

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: OXFORD, Conn., Aug. 7

 BODY:
Here in the Naugatuck Valley, long a bastion of the white working class, Gary Franks is an unlikely candidate for a seat in Congress. He is a black Republican.
But Mr. Franks won his party's nomination here last month after a seven-hour, nine-ballot, five-candidate convention, and he is now pitted against Toby Moffett, a liberal Democrat, in the race for the Fifth Congressional District, which is represented by John G. Rowland, the Republican gubernatorial candidate.
The contest is expected to be one of the most watched Congressional battles in the nation, and it could make Mr. Franks, a popular three-term alderman from Waterbury, Connecticut's first black Congressman. If elected, he would also become the first black Republican since 1935 to sit as a voting member in the House of Representatives. 
''The Democrats expected some small-town suburban Republican to win the nomination,'' said Mr. Franks's director of communications, Stephen R. Beaujon. ''I think Toby went to the nearest bar when he heard Gary Franks won.''
But Mr. Moffett, 46 years old, is unfazed, at least publicly, by Mr. Franks's nomination, saying that each of the Republicans vying for the nomination had different strengths and weaknesses.
After his victory, Mr. Franks, 37, received pledges of support and financing from national, local and state Republican leaders.
''One of my arguments at the convention,'' he said, ''was 'Who would do better against Toby Moffett?' ''
Mr. Moffett, a former representative, is frequently criticized for his recent move to Newtown, in the Fifth Congressional District, after living for three years in Branford, in the Third Congressional District. In his years in the House, from 1974 to 1982, he lived in Litchfield in the Sixth Congressional District. There is no residency requirement for Congressional candidates.
''Moffett is a carpetbagger,'' said Liz Hamel, a spokeswoman for the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee in Washington.
Until last fall, he worked as a television news anchor in New Britain after failing to win a Senate seat in 1982 and the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1986.
 
A Call for Self-Sufficiency
Mr. Franks, a fiscal conservative, has assailed Mr. Moffett as a liberal remnant of the Jimmy Carter era, which he said was partly responsible for economic policies that led to double-digit inflation and interest rates of more than 20 percent.
''The key to the American way is making people self-sufficient,'' he said. ''The worst myth out there is that you can do this through policies that tax and spend, tax and spend, tax and spend.'' Mr. Franks supports a capital gains tax cut and opposes raising Federal income-tax rates. He favors a constitutional amendment to prohibit burning the American flag and supports the death penalty for so-called drug kingpins. He supports abortion rights, and he criticizes abuses in some Federal programs like welfare, that lead to a ''spiral of government dependency.''
''He's an excellent choice to run against Toby Moffett,'' said Jack R. Goldberg, Mr. Rowland's press secretary.
 
All-State Basketball Player
The other Republicans who vied for the spot were Steve Watson of Danbury, State Senator Jamie McLaughlin of Brookfield, State Representative Alan Schlesinger of Derby and former State Representative Warren Sarasin of Beacon Falls.
Mr. Franks grew up in Waterbury, where he was senior class president and an all-state basketball player at Sacred Heart High School. His father was a mill worker who never finished the sixth grade, but all six Franks children graduated from college, and three have earned doctorates.
''I'm the only one with just one degree,'' said Mr. Franks, who graduated from Yale in 1975.
After college, Mr. Franks spent several years working for corporations in Fairfield County as an industrial and labor relations executive before starting his own real-estate firm.
As a Waterbury alderman, Mr. Franks has won praise from both Democrats and Republicans.
 
'He's His Own Man'
''He's held in high regard by all people,'' said John A. Sarlo, a Democrat and minority leader on the Board of Aldermen. ''He is going to run well.''
''He is his own man,'' Mr. Sarlo continued. ''He was for the city requiring more public notice for zoning and development, and that went against the grain of some of his party.''
Mr. Franks, expects to do well in Waterbury, which has about 15 percent of the district's registered voters and more than a third of its Democrats.
He also believes his Republican voter base in the rest of the district is strong because of its intense antipathy toward Mr. Moffett.
Moreover, Mr. Rowland's coattails are likely to help Mr. Franks, who lost a race for state comptroller in 1986 but received more votes than any other Republican on the ticket, carrying the Fifth District by 20,000 more votes than the party's gubernatorial candidate, Julie D. Belaga of Westport.
 
'It's a Targeted Race'
Some Republicans believe Mr. Franks would have faced a more difficult campaign against another Democrat, Michael Pacowta, the Mayor of Shelton, who has deep roots in the working class and conservative Naugatuck Valley. He decided not to engage in a primary against Mr. Moffett.
They note that Mr. Moffett did not carry the Fifth Congressional District in 1982 in his losing challenge for the Senate seat held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Mr. Moffett's campaign manager, Jay H. Marlin, is weary of the carpetbagger label and attacks on Mr. Moffett's record. ''It's a targeted race,'' Mr. Marlin said. ''No matter who was running they're going to be teeing off on Toby Moffett.''
''Now they are saying Gary Franks is the greatest thing since sliced bread,'' Mr. Marlin said, ''but it did take them seven hours and nine ballots to determine they want him as their nominee.''
 
Raising Campaign Money
The Fifth District is 1 of 29 open seats this fall. The district meanders across the middle of the western half of the state from Meriden west to Danbury. It includes such wealthy towns as Weston and Wilton, as well as Waterbury and the old blue-collar mill towns along the Naugatuck River.
Mr. Franks, who has raised about $150,000 so far, expects to raise $500,000 to $600,000 for the campaign, and the figure, according to some Democrats, may run as high as $1 million. Mr. Moffett has raised $300,000 so far and also expects to raise $500,000 to $600,000.
Neither campaign believes that Mr. Franks's race will be a significant issue. But neither can Mr. Franks rely on a large turnout of black support to carry him into Congress. Blacks make up only about 4 percent of the voters in the district, which is almost evenly divided among Democrats, Republicans and unaffiliated voters.
Currently, there are only two other black Republicans running for Congress: Former Cincinnati Mayor Ken Blackwell in Ohio, and a businessman, Al Brown, in Louisville, Ky. There are no black Republicans who are mayors of major cities, nor are there any black Republican governors. The last black Republican in the Senate was Edward Brooke of Massachusetts who left his seat in 1978.
But Mr. Franks noted that black Republicans were common, and, in some areas, before the 1932 Presidential election, outnumbered black Democrats.
''The pendulum can swing both ways,'' he said, citing recent polls that have given President Bush a moderate favorability rating among black voters. ''Right now, it's way over, but it's starting to go back.''

HEADLINE: Burmese Rebel Recalls Days of Violence

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
Every Saturday for the last month, denying himself food or drink, Min Sun Min dons one of his two suits, knots his one red polyester tie and rides the subway to the Upper East Side for an act of revolutionary defiance.
The slight, 110-pound Mr. Min Sun Min stands silently all day across the street from the Burmese Consulate holding a carefully lettered poster that reads: ''Hand over the power to the voters'' and ''Release all political prisoners.''
''I come and protest here as a representative of all Burmese people's sufferings,'' he said.
The solitary vigil by the 34-year-old dissident is as quixotic in its hope as it is in its audacity. The Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, does not have a history of tolerating dissent either at home or abroad, scholars say. The nation's military rulers violently crushed a nationwide pro-democracy uprising that began two years ago yesterday, and despite their overwhelming defeat in recent elections, they have so far refused to hand over power. 
 
'I Wear My Best Clothes'
''The Government puts pressure on the relatives of dissidents in Burma,'' said Josef Silverstein, a professor of political science at Rutgers University, ''taking away their jobs, arresting them or brutalizing them in some way, to keep those abroad quiet.''
To groggy Upper East Side residents, who pass the silent protester on Saturday mornings on their way to Central Park or down the street to buy croissants, Mr. Min Sun Min barely warrants recognition. Even a spokesman for the consulate said he had no idea who Mr. Min Sun Min was or what he wanted.
''On this day I wear my best clothes,'' he said, standing across the street from the white, four-story consulate at 10 East 77th Street, ''because I believe that my work here is very noble, like when you go to church.''
Hanging from his neck is a sign that says, ''Peace Burma.'' Like many Burmese dissidents, Mr. Min Sun Min refuses to use the Government's new name for his homeland.
Despite his obscurity in this country, Mr. Min Sun Min was a leading opposition figure before he fled his homeland.
''He was not a nationally known figure, but he played an important role in his city,'' said Thant Myint-U, a fellow at the International Center for Development Policy who specializes in Myanmar. ''The life of both Sun Min and Yuzana Khin, another student leader, have been very difficult since they arrived here. They came to the United States with the hope that they could study about American democracy, but they haven't been able to get any financial support.''
Min Sun Min, meaning king of the sun, is a pseudonym; he has used it to protect relatives since he became a public figure.
During the Aug. 8, 1988, democratic uprising, he led protests in Bassein and ran the city's dissident newspaper, The Gong. The uprising ended in a crackdown by the police and soldiers on Sept. 18 and 19 that left an estimated 3,000 people dead.
Since his arrival, which was arranged with the help of Representatives Dana Rohrabacher; Republican of California, Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, and Steven Schiff, Republican of New Mexico, interest in the plight of political dissidents in Myanmar has waned.
 
A Tiny Basement Room
On Mr. Min Sun Min's first day in New York last January, he stepped off a bus in Times Square carrying two vinyl bags and was promptly robbed of all the money he had - $20. Life has been a lonely struggle ever since.
He has handed out fliers for Chinese restaurants, and he spent a few nights in Central Park last March scavenging for bags of bread that are left for the homeless. He now lives in a tiny basement room he shares with five Chinese immigrants in Brooklyn.
The few hundred Burmese in New York, 400 of whom are still Burmese citizens according to the consulate, shy away from Mr. Min Sun Min's protests.
''I know the other Burmese cannot join me,'' he said. ''They have too much to lose.''
 
Taught English Classes
Mr. Min Sun Min, who worked as a high school teacher, fled Myanmar after General Saw Maung's military junta took control in September 1988. The swift retribution by the military made it impossible for him to say good-bye to his wife and son, now 7 years old.
Mr. Min Sun Min made his way with other students to the remote Three Pagodas Pass, one of 12 student camps along the border with Thailand affiliated with the Democratic Alliance of Burma, a group consisting of 23 ethnic groups opposed to the junta. He was elected to represent the 500 students at the camp and he taught English.
But Mr. Min Sun Min's nine-month experience in the guerrilla war soured him on the armed struggle.
''After battles we would pick up the dead bodies of the soldiers, taking their guns and their bags,'' he said. ''I saw that the soldiers were very young, like our students, and then I saw the letters from their parents and the photographs. I felt very sad. I could not believe these young boys were my enemy. Their officers were my enemy, but not these boys. I decided that the military way was not the right way.''
 
A Series of Odd Jobs
Mr. Min Sun Min, suffering from malaria, and Ms. Yuzana Khin, were admitted to the United States by the Immigration and Naturalization Service a year ago under a special two-year humanitarian-parole program. Ms. Yuzana Khin, who lives in Washington, said she has similiar economic difficulties and trouble organizing more than two-dozen Burmese for protests outside the embassy.
Since his arrival Mr. Min Sun Min has met with student groups and is studying English at Hunter College with a scholarship from the human rights group Asia Watch. He has taken a series of odd jobs, including washing dishes and delivering food. He currently works at a Manhattan photocopying store.
When the Burmese Government refused to release jailed opposition leaders this year, as it had promised, Mr. Min Sun decided to begin his lone protest. Yesterday, the second anniversary of the uprising, he and five other Burmese along with six Americans protested for two hours outside the consulate.
Mr. Min Sun Min lives on the corner of Church Avenue and East Seventh Street near Prospect Park in Brooklyn. There are no sheets on his worn mattress. Copies of newspapers and news magazines are stacked on the floor along with a few books on nonviolent struggle and a typewriter. Mr. Min Sun Min, who published 11 short stories back home, keeps copious notes and a diary about his life in America. Over his bed is a Burmese flag.
He hopes the Burmese political situation improves soon so that he can return home.
''It's hardest at night,'' he said. ''When I go to bed I always remember the custom of saying good night to my son. And then when I close my eyes I remember his face the last day I took him to the market. He wanted me to buy him a toy, but I had no money. He looked at me so piteously and I felt so sad. I wanted so much to buy my son a toy. It is this face that I see when I close my eyes and think of home.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Min Sun Min, a Burmese dissident, protesting last Saturday at the Burmese consulate, he said, ''as a representative of all Burmese people's sufferings.'' (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Council Questions Brown on Efforts to Fight Crime

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The New York City Council aggressively questioned top Dinkins administration officials yesterday about their efforts to fight crime, with one committee chairman saying New Yorkers now know ''how the average Roman felt while Rome burned and Nero fiddled.''
The remark was made by Sheldon S. Leffler of Queens, the Public Safety Committee chairman, at a hearing in City Hall as he and his colleagues questioned Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown and Milton Mollen, the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, about Mayor David N. Dinkins's plan to hire 1,058 more police officers by next spring.
 
'Colorful Language'
Several Council members said the city was not doing enough to fight crime, while others questioned how it could pay for the officers and whether they would really be hired. Mr. Leffler said he was considering proposing a law to require that a certain number of officers be hired each year. 
When asked later about Mr. Leffler's comment, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I suppose that's colorful language that perhaps he thinks is useful.'' But the Mayor added, ''It is not accurate to suggest that we've not been doing anything.''
Earlier, in a luncheon speech to Harlem business and political leaders, the Mayor elaborated on something he had suggested last week, that the city might have hired more police officers during its economic expansion in the early 1980's, when Edward I. Koch was in office.
''We had a boom period over the last 10 years, and yet there are some things that today we do not have that we might have had, had we expended resources at that time,'' Mr. Dinkins said in the speech. ''And now that we recognize that we don't have those things, and we want those things - like more cops - we're going to produce them in an hour and a half in a climate of an economic downturn?''
Under Mr. Koch, the city increased its police force from 22,000 in 1980 to 28,000 in 1988, when the growth stopped because of fiscal restraints. The force now stands at about 26,000.
 
To Counter Fears
At the hearing, Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens said that the city had to do more to counter fears about crime that he said threaten to drive people out of many neighborhoods and that City Hall must simply find a way to get more police officers on the streets. ''For too long in this town, the bookkeeper's ink has been thicker than the public's blood,'' he said.
Mr. Brown and Mr. Mollen faced the criticism calmly, elaborating not only on their plans for hiring but also on efforts to redeploy deskbound officers to street duties, and they pledged to do even more.
Mr. McCaffrey asked why officers guarding diplomatic buildings could not be reassigned to regular patrols and whether the state police could not assign more officers to highway duty in the city to free local highway officers.
Mr. Brown replied that the 47 officers assigned to diplomatic duty were paid for by the Federal Government and that if they were reassigned, the city would have to bear the cost. Mr. Mollen said discussions were under way with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo about how state troopers might help.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Modern Cassandra With a Message That Angers but Still Wins Support

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
A basic tenet of Washington politics is that bad news doesn't sell. Jimmy Carter found that out in his now-infamous ''malaise'' speech, when he painted a picture of a country entering a moral and economic decline, a speech that many analysts say was the beginning of his political demise.
But L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator and overseer of the savings and loan bailout, seems to have mastered the art of making bad news work for him.
Consider last week. On Monday, he shocked the House Banking Committee by announcing that the savings and loan bailout would need $100 billion in the coming fiscal year, far more than previously expected. 
The next day, he told the Senate Banking Committee that falling real estate values would cause so many bank failures that the pool of reserves at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, would suffer a $2 billion drain this year.
 
Bearer of Gloomy News
He repeated his gloomy message later that night on the ''MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour'' and ''Nightline.'' And then he returned to the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday to assert that fraud had played a part in almost half of all savings and loan failures.
It was a blitzkrieg of the news media, Capitol Hill and public opinion for Mr. Seidman (pronounced SEED-man), who is chairman of the F.D.I.C., which insures deposits at commercial banks. That position automatically made him chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created last year by Congress to manage the bailout of savings and loan companies.
Members of Congress praised him for his frankness, bankers winced at the prospect that his statements might cause an erosion of public confidence in the banking system, and members of the Bush Administration fumed about this prickly, intensely independent regulator they have not been able to control.
''Seidman, the Cassandra,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, referring to the mythological figure with the gift of prophecy, whose prophecies of misfortune were ignored. ''I think there are a lot of people, me included, who hope he is reading the tea leaves wrong and is overly pessimistic. If he isn't, we're all in trouble.''
 
Mixed Reception in Capital
The week demonstrated the skills of this regulator, who has been warmly received by Democratic and Republican lawmakers but given the big chill in the White House.
In fact, for the last three months leading members of the Administration - particulary the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady - have been intensely jockeying to push him out of his job before he wants to go.
In private, White House officials complain that Mr. Seidman is not a team player, that he cannot be trusted. But his supporters say that what really disturbs the Treasury and the White House is his independence and candor. Mr. Seidman responds with a mixture of bafflement and bluntness to the not-very-subtle efforts to replace him.
''I haven't found anybody yet that thinks the Administration gained from leaking that they tried to push me out,'' he said at his summer home on Nantucket Island last week. ''The only one I truly know who has applauded that effort is Charles Keating.'' Mr. Keating is the former head of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, now defunct, who arranged for large campaign contributions to five Senators and then got them to intervene for him with regulators.
''I am not a lame duck, because I have not answered the question of when I am going to leave,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''I have worked very hard not to let that happen. Otherwise, I would not be able to get things done.''
 
Independence Resented
The pressure on Mr. Seidman to leave stems not from any charge of incompetence. It's just that from the start of the Bush Administration, the F.D.I.C. chairman has fought intensely to preserve the independence of the agency from control by the White House. He openly opposed the White House and the Treasury in their attempts to give the President power to dismiss the chairman before his term expires.
Beyond this - and perhaps most important - the White House has found Mr. Seidman's style especially grating. His penchant for acerbic one-liners has offended Adminstration officials. And he has repeatedly demonstrated his skill at circumventing the White House, enlisting the aid of Republicans and Democrats and shrewdly using the press to his advantage.
Privately, Administration officials say it was White House distrust that led to the one event that has personally most hurt Mr. Seidman, who considers himself a loyal Republican and friend of the President.
In early May, White House officials, stung by criticism that the savings and loan bailout was going slowly, began telling reporters that the Administration wanted to replace Mr. Seidman, that they needed their own person at the F.D.I.C., and that they would not be sorry if Mr. Seidman, a Reagan appointee, decided to leave with about a year remaining in his six-year term.
Within days, the President, saying he was not trying to push Mr. Seidman out of his position, named his successor - the Federal Reserve Board's chief banking regulator, William Taylor - placing the F.D.I.C. chairman in an odd lame-duck status.
 
Support From Republicans
Reaction was intense, overwhelmingly in Mr. Seidman's favor. Dozens of Republicans in Congress urged the President to reverse his position, arguing that Mr. Seidman's continued presence and the credibility he lent to the bailout would help their party in the fall elections.
Encouraged, Mr. Seidman was not to be pushed and has not operated as a lame duck. ''I'm fed up with these leaks from John Sununu,'' he said recently after a speech. ''I told him, 'For every leak from you, I'm going to stay another month.' ''
While at first he at first made noises that he might leave in July, Mr. Seidman has put that off for several months and is vague about his plans, again keeping the Administration off guard.
He adds that his insistence on staying until he gets the Resolution Trust Corporation ''up and running'' would not have precluded an earlier exit and says that despite the push by the White House, ''it has not been bad for me; it just made me feel that it could have been handled a little more gracefully.''
''Frankly, I did not want to leave when the R.T.C. was perceived to be a failure because of a slow start and bureaucratic infighting,'' he said. ''Also, I would add that I was not pleased with the appreciation shown my past efforts by certain members of the Administration.''
Although he professes to be puzzled by what he views as the Administration's hostility to him, his aides and even his critics acknowledge that his popularity and credibility actually soared once he became a target of the Administration.
''Bill Seidman is the Jane Pauley for American Government,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, referring to the former host of NBC's ''Today,'' whose popularity soared after she was pushed off the program.
 
Issue of Bush's Son
Compounding Mr. Seidman's high-visibility profile is a problem that few regulators before him have faced. Mr. Seidman holds the fate of a Presidential offspring in his hands.
The F.D.I.C. is preparing a $200 million negligence lawsuit against the President's son, Neil, and other former officials of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Not only has the President instructed his staff to keep hands off the case, but he has also promised not to intervene, which Mr. Seidman says for the most part precludes any communication between the President and the F.D.I.C. until the case is filed.
Mr. Seidman does not readily accept the analysis that he is succeeding by being the bearer of bad news. Rather he says his appeal is the product of being accurate, and that Jimmy Carter fell flat with his malaise speech because ''it wasn't true and the American people didn't think it was true either.''
''I have always felt that if you fool yourself on the facts, you'll never get to the right answer,'' he said. ''If you want to see a glorious example of that, look at the S.& L. problems.''
Mr. Seidman says he is accustomed to friendly fire. During World War II, when he was an officer on a destroyer in the Pacific, American warships mistook his vessel for a Japanese boat and opened fire. A companion destroyer was sunk, and Mr. Seidman's vessel escaped unharmed. He attributes his relaxed attitudes under pressure to this and other war experiences.
He acknowledges that these are strange and heady days for a 69-year-old former accountant, a top economic adviser in the Ford White House, a vice chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation and dean of the Arizona State University Business school.
 
Brush With Death at Ranch
The pressures in recent months were compounded by an accident that briefly disabled him and almost left him crippled. One morning in late June, as he mounted his horse at his ranch in Wagon Mound, N.M., the steed bolted. When the banking regulator tried to jump off, his foot caught in the stirrup and he was dragged; his pelvis was separated and he lost almost half his blood.
But despite that incident and the pressures of the bailout, Mr. Seidman says he is unfazed and still thinking about his future.
He has talked about retiring to his ranch to develop his prized herd of Corriente cattle, which are used in rodeo events and bring three times the price of meat cattle. He has also talked about growing raspberries, reading more of his favorite writer, the Western novelist Louis L'Amour, and even putting in more time carving and making mobiles, an art taught him by Alexander Calder.
One thing he will not lack for is funds. Already a millionaire, he says job offers have been piling up and agencies that specialize in arranging speaking engagements have guaranteed him almost unlimited work.
''They said that they could arrange as many speeches for me as I wanted at $20,000 a pop,'' he said as he looked out over Nantucket Harbor.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Housing Costs Keep 32% Poor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Nearly one-third of Americans are ''shelter poor,'' spending so much of their income on housing that they cannot afford other necessities, a study released today said.
The study, by the Economic Policy Institute, an economic research organization, said 27 million households were ''unable to meet their nonshelter needs at even a minimum level of adequacy'' because of high housing costs. Those households comprise 78 million people, or 32 percent of the population, the organization said.
The study said 42 percent of those who rent their homes and 22 percent of homeowners were shelter poor in 1987, the last year of the study.
The number of households in that category increased from 18.7 million in 1970 to 26.5 million in 1987, an increase of 42 percent, the study said.
The study's author, Michael E. Stone, professor of community planning at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, used an index that assumes a family pays its rent or mortgage first, then uses what income is left to pay for basic needs like food, clothing, transportation and medical care.

HEADLINE: Congress, in Switch, Plans to Give Census Workers Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Two months after voting to deny unemployment benefits to thousands of temporary census workers, Congress has decided to reverse itself.
With an amendment to a bill now awaiting President Bush's signature, both houses have voted to repeal an administrative provision, passed in May, that directed that census work performed after April 20 would not count toward eligibility for unemployment compensation.
The provision, adopted at a time when the Census Bureau needed additional financing from Congress to finish the 1990 count, was intended to save at least $70 million that the bureau had set aside for unemployment claims.
But the cost-cutting move, aimed at more than 250,000 enumerators hired in April to count Americans who had not returned their census forms, brought an uproar among census workers and criticism by some lawmakers, who noted that the provision had been inserted into an unrelated appropriations bill and had not been subject to committee hearings. 
 
A Retaliation in Kind
In a retaliation in kind, the repeal measure was tacked onto an unrelated trade bill that was approved by the House and the Senate last week. The Bush Administration has expressed opposition to some elements of the overall trade legislation, but whether the President will veto the measure is not yet clear.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, proposed the repeal measure in conference committee negotiations, with the backing of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Downey, acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said the cutoff of unemployment benefits had particularly galled him because it had sprung from appropriations committees, whose job, he said, is to ''appropriate, not legislate.''
But he said he also had a more personal objection: in 1960, when he was 11 years old, he tagged along with his mother as she went door to door as a census taker, and ''it seemed to me to be tough work, and hazardous.''
 
Census Cutback Uncertain
Mr. Downey added: ''You just don't deny benefits to workers because one Federal agency is short of money. These workers were singled out for discriminatory action.''
It is not yet known whether census programs will be cut back if the bureau now has to find money to reimburse states for unemployment claims. The provision to rescind the unemployment benefits had originated in the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, State the Judiciary and Related Agencies, headed by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina.
A spokesman for Senator Hollings said he was traveling and was unavailable for comment.
Warren Kane, the subcommittee's staff director, said, ''Our members will address this matter in September, and I don't know what the response will be.'' But he added, ''We have a fixed allocation, and nobody has given us any relief in that allocation.''
 
Complaints From Census Workers
In the last month census workers swamped lawmakers with telephone calls and letters complaining about the cutoff. Several lawmakers, including Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who said he got about 100 angry calls and letters from his state, introduced bills to repeal the provision.
Mr. Leahy and five other Senators wrote a letter to Mr. Hollings agreeing with the workers that ''their good faith employment agreements with the Census Bureau were violated.''
One major complaint was that the bureau did not notify regional offices about the change until more than a month later, and many of the temporary workers did not find out about it until they filed a claim with their local unemployment office and were told they were not eligible.
In 1980, work by temporary census employees counted toward unemployment benefits. But at that time it was the Department of Labor, not individual Federal agencies, that reimbursed states for such claims.

HEADLINE: On Tapping Oil Reserve

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Key members of Congress, as well as many energy economists, are dismayed by the Bush Administration's reluctance to counter the last week's run-up in oil prices by selling stocks from the Government-owned Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
 
Although President
Bush said yesterday that he would ''explore whether and when we and our allies should draw down reserves,'' the Administration wants to keep the Government out of the business of managing energy prices. It prefers to use the Federal stockpile only to meet specific physical shortages, if and when they appear.
Partisan politics are apparently playing a role in the policy debate over the use of reserves, which was discussed in two Congressional committees this week. So, too, are differences of opinion on whether America should dip into its reserve without guarantees from Europe and Japan to match the effort. But there seems to be a more fundamental disagreement over how the reserve should be used and when. 
The Administration's critics contend that a hands-off policy during a crisis is itself a form of management, and that the real value of the reserve is to curb panic during the initial period of uncertainty over future prices. Jack Riggs, the staff director of the House Energy Subcommittee, argues that ''the Administration's position amounts to an invitation to the markets to increase prices.''
The Strategic Petroleum Reserve was created in 1975 in the wake of the Arab oil embargo and the subsequent explosion in oil prices. The reserve, kept in underground caverns leached from salt formations in Louisiana and Texas, now totals about 600 million barrels of crude oil. If the system worked as intended - it has never been tested under crisis conditions -a network of pumps, pipelines and coastal tankers would allow the Government to deliver up to 3.5 million barrels a day to refineries - enough to cover about 20 percent of current consumption and replace about 40 percent of current imports for about six months.
 
Motives Questioned
But the policy governing the use of reserve oil has largely been left to Presidential discretion. And in testimony before two Congressional committees this week, Energy Department officials have questioned the political motives of those seeking an early release of oil and refused to pin down the circumstances in which the reserves would be committed.
Some Congressional Democrats may indeed be eager to fix the responsibility on the White House for the 10- to 15-cent increase in gasoline prices in the last few days. And some Administration officials may indeed be maneuvering to defuse grassroots anger over higher prices, while taking credit with their friends in the oil belt. But there is some policy substance to the debate.
Administration officials are jockeying with Europe and Japan over how much of the burden of any shortfall in oil supplies will be borne by Americans. And they do not want to commit the White House before meetings with other consuming nations, scheduled for today. Frank Zarb, the chief executive of Smith Barney and a principal architect of energy policy in the Ford Administration, is sympathetic. ''You don't drain America first,'' he said.
 
Concern About Price Controls
But the core explanation for the Administration's caution seems to be a deep reluctance to tamper with private markets. Convinced that the energy price controls of the 1970's were a costly mistake and alarmed by Congressional calls to investigate oil price-gouging, Administration officials apparently fear that attempts to buffer energy inflation by selling oil would lead to ever greater involvement in setting prices. This explains why Energy Department officials testified that only physical shortages - an inability to buy oil at any price - would lead to releases from the reserve.
That position strikes Phil Sharpe, chairman of the House Energy Subcomittee, as ironic. ''We are asking the Government of Turkey to cut the Iraqi pipeline,'' he said. ''And we are asking the Governments of Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to increase production. But the Administration says our Government should not interfere with oil prices.''
If Western governments did choose to intervene, they seem well-armed for the task. Publicly held reserves represent only about three weeks of world consumption. But with privately held stocks of oil near records, Philip Verleger, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, notes, the big oil-consuming nations are in a position to get by without any imports for about five months. In fact, only about one-third of total imports would be affected by even the loss of all the oil from the Persian Gulf.
 
Need to Prevent Panic Seen
But most energy economists believe that the real value of a strategic reserve is to prevent panic, not to nurse reeling economies through a protracted oil shortage. And if history repeats itself, that would be enough.
The oil shocks of 1974-75 and 1980 were essentially inventory crises, Mr. Verleger points out. The explosions in prices and spot shortages were caused by the uncertainty over future prices and future availability of fuel, not the physical shortages. Panicky users tried to fill every tank in sight, dramatically increasing short-run demand.
Thus hesitation in drawing down Government stockpiles when the crisis looms and consumers grow edgy could sharply reduce the market bang from a reserve barrel. Daniel Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, argues that early use of the reserve weapon would allow small sales to have a relatively large impact. ''Even a few hundred thousand barrels a day,'' he concludes, ''would be a great show of credibility.''
Mr. Verleger agrees: ''The great lesson from intervention in financial markets,'' he said, ''is to act quickly.''
Most energy analysts (including some within the Administration) thought the battle to make early use the official policy had already been won. An inter-agency report last winter, commissioned as part of the Congressional debate over how much oil to buy for the stockpile, concluded that the best use of the oil was to prevent speculative spikes in energy prices. But something apparently happened on the way from the forum.

HEADLINE: Japan's Oil Safety Net Faces a Test: Will It Hold?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 8

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Room 325 has been a backwater of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry: two cluttered rows of battered gray desks where bureaucrats watched over oil stockpiles while others fought trade wars or built new industries in electronics or aerospace.
But starting last weekend, Room 325 - the ''3'' has long since fallen off the door and the words ''International Energy Policy Division'' are stenciled on a piece of paper at the entrance - became the command center of a scramble to keep the world's second-largest economy going in the absence of an eighth of its oil supply.
So far, that effort appears to be working. Though the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil in recent days is more than twice as severe as the cutbacks that struck this totally import-dependent nation in the oil shocks of the 1970's, no one is panicking.
Whether it is bravado or true confidence, officials here point to Japan's 142-day stockpile of petroleum, greater than that of any other nation. And they contend that Japan's biggest security rests in its remarkable successes in increasing energy efficiency: though the Japanese economy is more than twice as large as it was during the last oil shock, its oil demands have barely grown. 
Even some outward signs of nervousness are missing. Gasoline prices at the pump may be soaring in the United States, but the Government here made it clear early on that it would not tolerate a repeat of the organized price gouging that accompanied the past oil shocks. This time, prices have barely budged.
It is not immediately clear why retail prices should rise in the United States and not in Japan. Japanese oil companies, unlike their American counterparts, say the pump price reflects the cost of crude purchased several months ago and thus it will be a while before current price jumps are felt by consumers. Also, gasoline is already roughly three times as expensive in Japan as in the United States, and is heavily taxed.
In the meantime, several major Japanese oil companies, quietly working the phones, have come up with extra supplies to help offset the losses resulting from the embargo of shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. There are reports that Japan is paying top dollar for oil on world markets, pushing the price higher.
''The Japanese bureaucracy had to move very, very quickly, and it did,'' Midori Tani, the division's deputy director and one of the few women in senior jobs at the ministry, said today as she quickly ate a sandwich at her desk between meetings. ''People are worried, but they think we can manage it, at least for a while.''
 
A Question of Time
The question is for how long. Though they differ on specifics, most economists here seem to agree that if the oil cutoff is limited to Iraq and Kuwait, the Japanese economy will probably feel only a ripple. But the possibility that keeps Japan awake at night is that fighting will spill over to Saudi Arabia. Once, 14 years ago, the Saudis provided a third of Japan's oil. Now they provide 17 percent, and the biggest Japanese-owned oilfield sits right on the edge of the Saudi-Kuwait border.
''Saudi Arabia is the one that it would be very, very hard to live without,'' said Toru Tachibana, the senior economist at the Japanese Institution of Middle Eastern Economies. ''In the longer run, the situation could be quite pessimistic.''
But Japan's support for Saudi Arabia is tempered, severely, by its fear of alienating its other suppliers in the Middle East. That was evident today, when the Government's chief spokesman, Misoji Sakamoto, refused to endorse President Bush's decision to send troops into Saudi Arabia as a deterrent to an Iraqi attack. ''The United States has made an independent decision, and Japan cannot comment on that,'' Mr. Sakamoto said.
 
Fear of Western Backlash
Such wavering support worries many Japanese officials, who fear a backlash from the West because of Japan's failure to join in the international military face-off against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Japanese officials say they are limited by their Constitution, written by the United States during the post-war occupation, which bans the creation or use of offensive military forces. ''We sense what is coming,'' one senior foreign ministry official said today. ''I am sure that some people will accuse us of letting someone else defend our access to oil.''
To deflect the criticism, Government officials have been scurrying to find non-military means of contributing to the effort. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to go ahead with a long-scheduled Mideast trip next week, visiting Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Turkey and Egypt. But so far, beyond joining the embargo on Iraqi oil and trade, suspending foreign aid to Iraq and freezing Kuwait's huge assets here, Japanese officials say they have few ideas about how they can help.
''There is a lot of frustration about this situation,'' said Mr. Tachibana, who said he personally favored a much more active Japanese role in military operations in the Middle East, given Japan's enormous stake in the region. ''But my opinion,'' he added, ''is definitely in the minority in this country.''
 
A Decade of Preparation
Perhaps because Japan learned in the 1970's that it was nearly helpless to guide events in the Persian Gulf, it has spent the past decade in a concerted, if little seen, effort to try to insulate itself. In many ways, the Japanese have been preparing for the Iraq crisis - or one like it - for more than a decade.
By imposing strict goals on car makers and industry, Japan has been far more successful in producing energy-efficent cars and making steel and even textiles more efficiently than anyone imagined possible in the late 1970's. Moreover, the move to more information-intensive industries has allowed Japan to speed its transition to nuclear power, natural gas and even coal. In the last year, however, Japanese oil consumption has begun to rise again, suggesting that the message was not lasting.
Japan's biggest push toward insulating itself came from a Government-owned company with headquarters only two blocks from the trade ministry. With money from the Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, it has built 10 national oil stockpiles around the country. While some are still under construction, the Iraq crisis hit when Japan's stockpile was near its all-time high.
 
Finding New Supplies
The Government corporation's other mission has been to find alternative sources of oil for Japan, mostly closer to home in Asia. So far it has enjoyed only mixed success. With oil prices so low in recent years, many exploration efforts have been passed over as unprofitable. ''We must hope the price goes up enough to facilitate exploration,'' said Kazuhiko Itano, an executive of the corporation.
Clearly, however, Japan's efforts to diversify have begun to pay off. China has become a major supplier, accounting for 7 percent of Japan's oil. So have Mexico and Malaysia. The result is that the Middle East now accounts for roughly 72 percent of Japan's oil imports; during the previous oil shocks, it was more than 80 percent.
It was that knowledge that led the Agency for Natural Resources and Energy, a sleepy operation little heard from in Japan, to advise Mr. Kaifu over the weekend that Japan could agree to the oil embargo without immediately threatening its economic future. ''It was a bit tense, though,'' said Ms. Tani, a slight woman in her mid-30's who has held several other posts in the agency, including one that put together an ill-fated petrochemical plant for Iran.
 
Looking to the Middle East
Now the search is on for additional oil, and most of it, Japan says, will have to be purchased in the Middle East. Before the embargo, the Energy Department in Washington said there was excess world capacity of four million barrels a day. Ms. Tani and her colleages are looking for it.
Some efforts to direct it to Japan have already begun. The biggest Japanese producer, the Arabian Oil Company, which has a giant complex near the former ''neutral zone'' between Kuwait and Saudi Arabi, said today that it would raise its pumping speed to 300,000 barrels a day, up from 250,000. That is still short of the plant's capacity, which is 400,000 barrels a day.
''We would like to raise it more,'' said a company official, ''but we do not want to put the Saudis in the position of exceeding their quota.'' The fear is that such increases would give Mr. Hussein a pretext for attack.

HEADLINE: Oil Drops More Than $2 a Barrel

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of oil dropped more than $2 a barrel yesterday, and the price of gasoline fell more than 6 cents a gallon, following reports that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would increase their production to mitigate a feared oil shortage.
And even though President Bush's decision to send American troops to Saudi Arabia could lead to a military conflict with Iraq, traders said the decision helped lower oil prices because the American forces would give Saudi Arabia the protection it needed to pump more oil to help ease the shortage.
But no analysts were ready to say that yesterday's decline in oil and gasoline prices was the start of a new trend. Given the confrontation with Iraq, the next news bulletin from the Middle East could send prices back up again. And there is still uncertainty about whether oil production is really being increased, especially because OPEC members are leery of saying what they are doing for fear of annoying Iraq and other members. 
 
Reports of Frenzied Buying
''What I am concerned about is all these people drawing lines in the sand,'' said Theodore Eck, the chief economist for the Amoco Corporaton, referring to the strong speech by President Bush yesterday and official comments by a spokesman for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
In Europe, insurance rates on oil and tankers soared, and there were reports of frenzied buying of Iranian oil because of fears that war would break out in the Persian Gulf. [D18.] In addition, there has still been no public confirmation by the Saudis that they will increase production. One Saudi official said his country did not plan to either confirm or deny the reports by American officials that it would increase production as much as two million barrels a day, which would reduce the expected oil shortage from an embargo of Iraq and Kuwait by about 40 percent.
In trading yesterday, the price of West Texas Intermediate crude for delivery in September dropped $2.35, to $25.96 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On Monday and Tuesday, the crude oil price jumped almost $4, to more than $28 a barrel, or nearly 75 percent higher than in mid-June.
Despite the decline yesterday, some oil traders said they did not expect the price of oil to fall back to the $20-a-barrel level, where West Texas Intermediate crude was trading before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, as long as the situation in the Middle East was unresolved.
 
Much Higher Base Price
Referring to the increased production expected from Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, Peter C. Beutel, a trader at Merrill Lynch Futures, said, ''It may help shore up the supply situation, but we will still be at a much higher base'' for the price of oil.
But he said that he believed these countries would increase production and that the movement of American troops into Saudi Arabia would appear to reduce the chance of an Iraqi attack.
The wholesale price of unleaded gasoline also fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, dropping 6.18 cents, to 76.21 cents a gallon. Taxes and the dealer markup are added on to this price at the pump.
There were no immediate indications that the drop in gasoline futures prices, however, would be passed on at the gas pump. Consumers have been angered by the sharp rise in gasoline prices since the Iraqi invasion, and many politicians are calling for investigations of the increases. #14 Cents a Gallon Some gasoline prices went up as much as 14 cents a gallon. But oil company officials say wholesale prices for gasoline have gone up as much as 20 cents a gallon since the invasion last week, so the full price has not yet been passed on.
ARCO announced yesterday that it was freezing its wholesale prices of gasoline, diesel fuel and jet fuel for a week in response to President Bush's call for restraint on price increases. A spokesman for Amoco, Mike Thompson, said he could not say what his company's response would be. But he added that any decision would have to wait until there was a definite downward trend in prices. Amoco, he said, has raised its gasoline 10 cents a gallon since the invasion.
The indication by President Bush that oil from the country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve might be used to ease the shortage from the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil also helped send prices down yesterday, some traders said. But they also said the reserve was unlikely to be used unless the situation in the Middle East deteriorated further. #586 Million Barrels The International Energy Agency, which has the authority to get the United States and its allies to share oil in the event of a sudden shortage, is to meet in Paris today to discuss the oil shortage and the use of government oil reserves. The American reserve has 586 million barrels of oil in it. The two other big reserves are in West Germany, with about 53 million barrels, and Japan, with about 200 million barrels.
The price of oil generally moved down throughout the day in New York yesterday despite some possibly negative news. The president of OPEC, Sadek Boussena of Algeria, said in a statement that he was opposed to indivdual OPEC members deciding on their own to raise their producton levels, partly because such moves would undermine the power of OPEC to affect the oil market.
At the same time, President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela said that his country could raise production by 400,000 barrels to 500,000 barrels a day but that he did not want to act unilaterally without OPEC.
 
Market's General Belief
Some traders still doubt that the Saudis will raise production, although the drop in the oil prices yesterday reflected a general belief that output would be increased. There were also indications that captains of some oil tankers were leery of going into the Persian Gulf to pick up Saudi oil for fear that a war might leave them trapped there.
A Saudi official, who commented only on the condition that he not be identified, said his country's production level would rise slowly. And several oil analysts said they expected production levels to rise but that OPEC countries would prefer to avoid any formal announcements.
''I would think that any OPEC member would be careful about what they do and what they say they are doing,'' said Robert A. Hermes, president of Purvin & Gertz, a Houston consulting firm.

HEADLINE: Fed Report Says Economy Slowed Before Mideast Crisis

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
A Federal Reserve survey released today shows the economy was slumping even before the onset of the Middle East crisis that has heightened the possibility the nation will be thrown into a recession for the first time in nearly eight years.
The survey, known as the Beige Book, is a compilation of reports by the Fed's 12 regional banks of economic conditions in their parts of the country. It is released every six weeks.
''Business and banking contacts in the reserve districts generally report continued economic growth, though most noted that the pace was slow or had slackened recently,'' the regional Fed bank in Atlanta said of the survey, completed before July 27. 
 
Effect of Oil Prices
Since then, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has sent world energy markets soaring on worries of supply disruptions, and the higher prices are expected to heat up inflation. That, in turn, could choke off growth in the economy, which has expanded steadily since November 1982.
In their report, the Fed banks did not reach a consensus on the direction of prices, but several of the regional banks reported widespread increases. They also found wages rising at a fairly brisk pace of 3 percent to 5 percent annually.
Meanwhile, manufacturing activity was found to be flat in most industries. Some banks were finding good demand from abroad, however, such as strong commercial aircraft orders from overseas for the Boeing Company in the Northwest.
 
Benefits for Steel
In addition, United States carmakers stepped up production to prepare for a possible strike, so steelmakers have benefited, the report showed.
Still, the banks reported that ''with the exception of steel and commercial aircraft, backlogs and lead times were said to be working down.''
Consumers were also pulling back in many regions. Retail sales were ''soft to a little higher than a year ago,'' the banks said.
''Retailers in New York City are less optimistic about the outlook given the continuing layoffs at banks and brokerage firms, while those in St. Louis expressed similar views in light of anticipated defense cutbacks,'' the survey said.
Military contractors, including two of the largest, the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, both based in St. Louis, are laying off thousands because of shrinking defense budgets.
Problems were reported obtaining bank credit for construction in many areas, the Fed report said. But the reasons for the tightness varied.
 
Need for Lower Rates
Some economists said the survey confirmed that interest rates needed to be lowered to stimulate the economy even before violence erupted in the Persian Gulf. Now, with the slowing effect that higher oil prices may have, there is more evidence that lower rates are needed, they said.
Normally, to avoid recession, the Fed would lower rates to spur the economy. But that option has been complicated because providing the stimulus of lower rates at a time of rising energy prices could overheat the economy, feeding inflation.
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has made it clear he considers fighting inflation to be the central bank's top priority.
 
A Bleak Picture
Before the survey was released, the chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce, Richard Rahn, painted a bleak picture of the direction of the economy.
''We anticipate that the economy will grind to a virtual standstill during the third quarter of this year and actually contract by 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter,'' he said at a news conference, adding that it was probably too late to avoid recession, particularly with higher oil prices.
Mr. Rahn predicted ''a mild recession'' beginning at the end of this year and running into 1991. A recession is defined as two successive quarters of shrinking economic activity.

HEADLINE: Brady Wants Rate Cut, But Sees No Recession

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that oil price shocks need not topple the economy into a recession, and he called on the Federal Reserve to stimulate growth with lower interest rates.
''We are not contemplating recession,'' Mr. Brady said, replying to a question after a luncheon speech to the National Press Club here.
''Certainly the events of last week, where the price of oil has gone up, are going to impose additional hardships on the country,'' he said. ''But I don't think we should come to judgment quickly.'' 
He said both he and President Bush wanted the Federal Reserve to give an impetus to economic growth by lowering interest rates. He said strong growth was particularly important now, as the United States responds to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
''Everybody wants lower interest rates,'' he said. ''At this point in time in the United States, economic growth is very important.''
Mr. Brady expressed confidence that Federal Reserve policy makers, who are to meet on Aug. 21, would lower rates in response to sluggish growth. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at an anemic 1.5 percent annual rate in the first half of 1990.
''The fact that the country is faced with slower growth will almost certainly produce lower interest rates,'' he said.
On other topics, Mr. Brady said:
* He did not know if oil companies were taking advantage of consumers by raising gasoline prices so quickly after the invasion of Kuwait, but said, ''If people are gouging, those that are doing the gouging will hear from the President.''
* Budget-deficit negotiations with Congress may produce a different number than the $50 billion reduction goal, but reducing the deficit is more important now that the United States is trying to exert its influence in the Persian Gulf.
* The staggering cost of the savings and loan bailout ''frightens politicians into finger-pointing and blame-avoiding.''
Supporting Mr. Brady's view that economic conditions warrant a loosening of credit was a Federal Reserve report released today that showed economic growth was slackening even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. A July 27 survey of the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks said that ''most noted that the pace was slow or had slackened recently.''

HEADLINE: United Air Group's Bid Extended

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 8

 BODY:
United Airlines' parent company, UAL Inc., tonight gave an employee buyout group an extra two months to arrange financing for its $4.38 billion bid.
UAL's stock price rose sharply today amid widespread expectations that the board would extend the deadline. The stock rose $13.50 a share, to $114.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Many people said the directors had little to gain by enforcing the previously set deadline, which gave the buyout group until the close of business Thursday to come up with financing.
UAL's board said it was willing to extend the deadline because of the crisis in the Middle East.
 
New Deadline Is Oct. 9
The company said, however, that if financing was not arranged by the new deadline, Oct. 9, UAL would terminate the buyout agreement.
The directors indicated that they had doubts about the effort's chances of success.
''UAL emphasized that - especially in light of events in the Middle East, state of the financial markets and softening economy - there can be no assurance that a transaction can be completed,'' the statement said.
Enforcing the deadline could have embittered UAL employees, who have been trying to buy the airline since spring.
 
Offer of $201 a Share
The buyout group is not believed to have its financing lined up, and enforcing the deadline would also have had the effect of canceling the offer. The group has offered to pay $201 a share in cash and securities for all of UAL's common shares outstanding.
Should the offer collapse, the company's stock might well slide sharply, further alienating stockholders, who have seen the value of their shares decline sharply in recent weeks. Within the last 12 months, UAL's share price has been as high as $294.
In recent weeks three of the five banks that had originally agreed to back the deal have pulled out. These banks - Chase Manhattan, Chemical and Citibank -have indicated that they will not provide loans unless the buyout group comes up with equity, or essentially its own money, that it can put into the deal.
 
Outside Sources of Equity Money
The buyout group has been casting about for outside sources of equity money. Reports have been published, which the buyout group has declined to comment on, that it has approached suppliers like the Boeing Company and the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney division, as well as the General Electric Credit Corporation and the GPA Group, the Irish company that owns Guinness Peat Aviation, the largest aircraft-leasing company.
Gerald Greenwald, a former vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, who is leading the employee group's efforts, was expected to report to the UAL board today on the status of those negotiations.
Even if Mr. Greenwald can convince the board that talks to obtain outside equity money are progressing, he must then convince them that the banks will come forward with loans. With United Airlines' having been in turmoil ever since the pilots made a bid for it by themselves in 1987, the directors are understood to be in no mood to hear about an offer with equity that might still collapse because of a lack of bank support.
''Greenwald will have to present the board with an outline that is very doable,'' said Sharon Kalin, president of Athene Coronado Management Inc., a big New York money-management firm that has a significant stake in UAL.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
4 Younger Executives Move Up at Chemical

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
The Chemical Banking Corporation announced a reorganization of its top management yesterday, drawing from its own cadre of executives to name a new president and to create an office of the chairman with four younger executives.
The appointments shed little light on who will succeed Chemical's chairman, Walter V. Shipley, who is 54 years old and has no plans for early retirement. He described the new office of the chairman, which replaces a 12-member senior management committee, as a way of ''insuring management continuity by drawing upon a new generation to help provide senior leadership.'' 
Chemical's management was disrupted nine months ago when its president at the time, Thomas S. Johnson, left to accept a job as president and designated successor to the chairman at a rival, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
The seventh-largest banking company in the nation, Chemical concentrated on its domestic business in recent years by purchasing banks in Texas and New Jersey and by expanding its business with consumer and middle-size corporations in the New York City area. International activities have been cut back sharply.
Members of the new office of the chairman are:
William H. Turner, 50, with responsiblity for Chemical's regional banking activities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. His previous job of managing the banking businesses with middle-market corporations, an activity where Chemical is the leader in the New York area, was expanded to include consumer banking, real estate lending and private banking with wealthy individuals.
Marc J. Shapiro, 43, who will continue as president and chief executrive of the Texas Commerce Bancshares unit. After enduring years of hardship in the mid- and late-1980's when the weakening of the Texas economy led to greater-than-expected losses, Texas Commerce began earning a profit this year. Its position as the leading lender to businesses in Texas is expected to lift earnings - and Mr. Shapiro's stature in the Chemical organization - as the local economy continues to improve.
Edward A. O'Neal Jr., 46, the bank's most experienced executive in computer applications, who was put in charge of all technologically oriented businesses, like credit cards, and financial services like cash-management products for businesses. As head of the Chemical's consumer banking business for the last three years, Mr. O'Neal was credited with improving profitability and market share, while consolidating the branch system.
William B. Harrison Jr., 47, who will continue handling institutional banking activities worldwide. The job includes managing the company's funding and securities trading, and developing securities backed by bank loans.
Robert J. Callander, 59, the bank's former vice chairman, who was named president, the No. 2 position under Mr. Shipley. Mr. Callander will handle Chemical's outstanding loans with less-developed countries, and oversee executives in charge of managing risk and setting credit standards.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mixed Feelings On Bank Stocks

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
FOR contrarian investors in bank stocks, willing to fight the downward trend in prices and steady flow of bad news, the problem in recent months has been to know just which hour is the darkest one that precedes the dawn.
Bank stocks have been in a tailspin for 10 months, and investors who thought the lows of late 1989 were attractive now find an abundance of such bargains. The Tisch family, for example, spent more than $94 million to buy a 6.6 percent Bank of Boston stake late last year at $20 a share on average. Last week, the family spent $10 million more to raise its investment to 8.9 percent, buying shares at $9.875 and $10. 
The problems of banks are industrywide and not confined to the New England area. A growing roster of delinquent real estate loans, slack loan demand as the economy weakens and a structure of heavy costs have depressed earnings this year. And if the economy slips into a recession - a growing fear among many investors - history shows that banks will suffer a substantial rise in delinquent payments and defaults on loans of all kinds.
For many of the country's best-known banks, stock prices are down nearly 50 percent from 10 months ago, despite modest gains in the last two days. Citicorp closed yesterday at $19.375, up 62.5 cents, compared with a high of $35.50 in early October 1989, while Chase Manhattan rose 62.5 cents, to $18.50, down from a 1989 high of $44.875.
Many regional banking companies that were the industry's best performers during the 1980's have also been hard hit. The stock of Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, closed at $28.625 yesterday, up $1.25, but well below its 1989 high of $37. NCNB of Charlotte, N.C., fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $33.875, down from $55. In the West Coast banking group, Wells Fargo closed at $63.875, up $2, compared with $87.375, and BankAmerica rose 87.5 cents, to $22.75, from a 1989 high of $36.375.
In the last few days bank stocks have fallen less than the market ''as investors recognized the defensive characteristics of banks, such as their dividend yield,'' said Thomas Hanley, managing director at Salomon Brothers.
Among companies whose dividends are widely regarded as safe from cuts, Citicorp's $1.78 dividend equals a yield of 9.2 percent while the First Chicago Corporation's $2 dividend yields 8 percent.
If the threat of recession from higher oil prices causes the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term interest rates, as many economists expect, Mr. Hanley said, ''we could have a trading rally in the bank group over the short term.'' But over the next several quarters, Mr. Hanley said, the risk of loss from bad loans is great enough to remain cautious on the outlook for bank stocks.
W. Anthony Hitchler, chief investment officer at Brandywine Asset Management in Wilmington, Del., said bank stocks were so low that ''a couple of years from now you could look back at this as an incredible opportunity.''
''But for now,'' he said, ''the psychology for bank stocks is as bad for an industry as I have ever seen.''
With the downward trend in prices so well established, and ample warnings from bankers that losses on real estate loans might worsen, Mr. Hitchler said, ''the risk of client displeasure is just too great'' to begin buying. ''I want to diversify out of the mid-Atlantic and Southern regions,'' he added, ''but first I want to see some stability.''
Richard Bove, banking analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the disruption of the oil market from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait could bode well for companies like the Chemical Banking Corporation, which have major operations in oil-producing states.
As bank stock prices tumbled in recent weeks, bankers and Wall Street analysts began attributing much of the decline to speculative selling by ''hedge funds.'' These privately owned funds try to protect their speculative trading positions by ''hedging'' in the futures or options markets or in stocks of companies in the same industry.
But operators of hedge funds say that blaming them for the weakness in bank stocks is a facile explanation. ''If bank managers are looking outside their companies for explanations of why their stock is down, they should take a second look,'' said Joseph L. Feshbach, general partner at Feshbach Brothers, a hedge fund operator based in Palo Alto, Calif. ''Their stocks are down for lots of good reasons, starting with the fact that their financial performance has been nothing short of disastrous.''
Mr. Feshbach said he has been an active seller of bank stocks, but asserted that ''the financial resources of hedge funds are too small relative to the market value of banks' stocks'' to explain the steep drop in bank stock prices.
Donald J. Hardy, an analyst at the Frank Russell Company, estimated that hedge funds have total assets of $20 billion or more, spread among a myriad of trading techniques and many industries. The market value of 35 large banking companies monitored by Salomon Brothers fell to as low as $74.4 billion early this week.
