HEADLINE: Dow Rises 24.26 Points as Oil Prices Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks advanced strongly in active trading yesterday, as oil prices turned downward following President Bush's morning address to the nation explaining the dispatch of United States troops to Saudi Arabia.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 24.26 points, at 2,734.90, off from the day's high of 2,748.02, when it was up 37.38 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, meanwhile, rose 3.52 points, to 338.35.
Volume remained on the heavy pace of the past few days, ending the day at 190.4 million shares traded. 
The American Stock Exchange index closed at 340.03, virtually unchanged, while the Nasdaq index of the over-the-counter market closed up 5.65 points, at 407.73.
 
Market Stability
The President's strong stand seemed to bring stability to the market, traders noted, and that brought investors back in droves to hunt for bargain prices. Analysts said, however, that investors were still nervous, and that buying could quickly turn to selling as developments in the Middle East unfold.
Oil stocks, which had benefited from the rise in oil prices over the past few days, dropped yesterday as supply fears eased. September contracts of West Texas Intermediate crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange were down $2.35 a barrel, to $25.96.
Among the big losers were the Chevron Corporation, down 1 3/4, to close at 76 7/8; the Exxon Corporation, down 1 5/8, to close at 51 3/4; the Amoco Corporation, down 1 3/8, to 56 1/4, and Texaco Inc., down 1 7/8, to close at 62 3/4.
 
Eyes on the Treasury Refunding
Market participants also had their eyes on the Treasury's quarterly refunding taking place this week. Less-than-statisfactory results could mean higher interest rates, which would not bode well for the stock market.
A stock rally in the afternoon was interrupted following a sudden decline in bond prices, which were reacting to the poor results of the Treasury's 10-year note auction, part of the quarterly refunding. But the bonds quickly bounced back, and so did the stock market. Advances led declines by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1.
''Confidence is a big factor in the stock market,'' said Peter G. Grennan, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''It gives the market resiliency, which was evident today. So far the President's firm handling of the situation has been good for the market.''
 
Few Program Trades
There were few program trades in yesterday's market, according to Birinyi Associates Inc., which tracks such activity. Program trades, which are almost exclusively practiced by large institutional traders, can create rapid market fluctuations. In all there were three sell programs, one in the morning and two in the afternoon, which were related to reports of a poor Treasury auction. They occurred between 2:25 and 2:38, and during that time the Dow fell 12.62 points. The only buy program came between 3:06 and 3:11, at about the same time bond prices began coming back. At that point the Dow rose 6.18 points.
Other active stocks yesterday included Honeywell Inc., which announced its intention sell its Federal Systems Inc. unit to Bull HN Information Systems Inc., a unit of Compagnie des Machines Bull of France for an undisclosed price. Honeywell rose 1 3/4, to 98 3/8. The Eastman Kodak Company's stock rose 1 1/8, to 41 1/8, on a recommendation by Alex Henderson, a Prudential-Bache analyst, who said the stock was well insulated from swings in oil prices.
Drug stocks, a traditional institutional favorite because they are not as susceptible to market swings as other stocks, also rallied. Merck & Company rose 2 1/4, to close at 85 1/8; Eli Lilly & Company, was up 2 5/8, to close at 78 3/8; Johnson & Johonson, was up 1 7/8, to 67 1/8, and Bristol-Myers Squibb, was up 1 3/8, to 61 1/2 UAL's stock rose 13 1/2, to close at 114 1/2, on expectations that the company's board might grant the employee group seeking to buy the company a 30- to 90-day extension to help arrange its financing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher On Fears Over Middle East

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday against all major currencies except the yen and the Canadian dollar, bolstered by the tensions in the Middle East.
Currency dealers said the dollar started out sharply higher, then fell back. President Bush's announcement that warplanes and combat troops backed by Navy ships were taking up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia seemed to calm the financial markets.
Nonetheless, the possibility of a conflict with Iraq pushed the dollar higher, dealers said. Those concerns, they said, outweighed any fundamental worries about economic weakness that could drive interest rates lower and make the dollar less appealing to foreign investors.
''On fears of the Middle East, the dollar was way up,'' said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York.
 
Debate Over Safety
Some dealers in Europe, though, debated whether the dollar was the safest currency to hold right now. In fact, after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait last week, which touched off the Middle East tensions, currency dealers flocked to the German mark. The dollar had declined on worries that a rapid rise in oil prices eventually would push interest rates lower.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to close at 150 Japanese yen, from 150.60 yen Tuesday. It traded at 150.15 yen in London, and at 149.90 yen in New York, down from 150.90.
The dollar was stronger against the pound compared with Tuesday. The pound traded at $1.8660 in London, down from $1.8765, and at $1.86885 in New York, down from $1.8715.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5920 German marks, up from 1.5875; 1.3380 Swiss francs, up from 1.3370; 5.3365 French francs, up from 5.3230; 1,165.00 Italian lire, up from 1,162.25, and 1.14785 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15125.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Slips and Copper Rises As Oil Prices Turn Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures fell yesterday and copper futures climbed as a downturn in oil prices prompted an abrupt change in speculation about the economy.
On other commodity markets, pork futures fell sharply and cattle extended their gains.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1.20 to $1.50 lower, with the contract for delivery in August at $383.20 an ounce, down $1.30. Silver futures finished 1.5 cents to 1.8 cents lower, with August at $4.843 an ounce. 
Copper futures ended 2 cents to 3.65 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange, with August at $1.31 a pound.
The moves reflected a shift away from the inflation and recession fears that began building late last week, when Iraq invaded Kuwait and touched off a run-up in oil prices and a plunge in stock prices worldwide.
The gold market responds quickly to inflation fears because the metal is perceived as an investment hedge against inflation. Copper is used heavily throughout the construction and manufacturing industries, so its price is especially sensitive to signs of economic expansion or recession.
 
Stocks Rally
Economic jitters eased somewhat yesterday as the price of crude oil fell and the United States stock market rebounded, partly in reaction to the movement of United States forces into Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraqi threats to oil-producing nations beyond Kuwait.
Analysts said reports that Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other major oil-producing nations would increase their output also worked to suppress crude prices.
While West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 83 cents to $2.35 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the September contract at $25.96 a barrel, heating oil was 2.46 cents to 5.01 cents lower, with September at 70.13 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 2.13 cents to 3.8 cents lower, with September at 76.21 cents a gallon.
Pork futures plummeted on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting seasonal factors and a bulge in hog production.
''We've had a year of good profitability in the hog market, and we're beginning to see the results in increased slaughter,'' said Thomas Morgan, president of the Sterling Research Corporation in Arlington Heights, Ill.
Most hog contracts and some belly contracts fell their permitted daily limits of 1.5 cents and 2 cents, respectively.
Live hogs finished 1.22 to 1.5 cents lower, with August at 56.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.32 cent to 2 cents lower, with August at 50.75 cents a pound.
Cattle futures rose moderately, extending strong gains posted Tuesday that were linked to a better economic outlook and strong cash markets.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Fall Sharply On Worries About Mideast

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Japanese stock prices fell sharply today, wiping out all of the Tokyo market's gains from yesterday.
Japanese traders said they were still very nervous about the crisis in the Middle East.
In Tokyo today, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks dropped 893.41 points, or 3.13 percent, to close at 27,615.73, its low of the day. Much of the loss came in the late afternoon. 
The Tokyo stock market had rebound strongly yesterday after losing more than 10 percent of its value in the four previous trading days since Iraq invaded Kuwait. But today's severe drop offset yesterday's gain of 856.07 points in the Nikkei average.
 
Mixed Reactions
In other financial markets yesterday, there were mixed reactions to President Bush's announcement that American forces would go to Saudi Arabia and to rumors that the United States had bombed Iraq's capital, Baghdad.
Stocks rose yesterday on Wall Street. But in some markets, like those in West Germany and France, share prices were down sharply. The stock market in London was basically unchanged.
In New York yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.26 points, or 0.89 percent, to 2,734.90.
In West Germany, the Frankfurt bourse's blue chip index, the DAX, fell 46.67 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1723.63. The market, traders said, was whipped by rumors and closed before Presdent Bush made his televised speech in the United States.
The Frankfurt market, which fell 5.4 percent on Monday and rebounded 1.7 percent on Tuesday, is also troubled by the impact of the cost of the unification of the two Germanys. Many fear that this union will lead to both higher inflation and higher interest rates.
The Paris stock market also fell sharply. The blue-chip index, the CAC-40, fell 54.75 or 3.02 percent, to 1,757.09. the market is now down 10.36 percent since the invasion. Brokers were not encouraged by either Mr. Bush's speech or the early rise on Wall Street in New York.
The London stock market's leading indicator, the Financial Times 100-stock index, rose only 1.7 points, to 2,237.5.
In Norway, which is an oil producer and an expected beneficiary of higher oil prices, the stock market fell again, dropping 7.92 points, or 1.25 percent, to 623.20. Brokers said they were concerned that higher oil prices would bring a worldwide recession.

HEADLINE: Food Supply Is Vital in Embargo

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Embargos on trade with Iraq and Kuwait have focused on oil exports, but the effect on Iraq's food imports may also prove critical.
Iraq depends on imports for 70 percent to 80 percent of its nutritional needs, and food stockpiles were unusually low even before the invasion of Kuwait last Thursday, John P. Parker, an Agriculture Department economist who studies Middle Eastern agriculture, said yesterday.
As of last Saturday, Iraq's Government stockpiles held enough wheat for two months of normal consumption, enough rice for three months, enough beans and barley for a month and less than two weeks' worth of corn, he said.
''The more I look at it, the worse it looks,'' Mr. Parker said. 
 
September Corn Harvest
Iraq has already harvested its wheat and beans this year, while its corn crop, due for harvest in September, will provide enough for another month and a half of normal consumption, or longer with rationing. Bakeries and other businesses have tiny food supplies because for years the Government has closely controlled food production and distribution, Mr. Parker said.
A drought last year in Iraq and the American Government's decision a year ago to halve guarantees on Iraqi food purchases, to $500 million, have severely hurt the country because it has been unable to buy enough additional food elsewhere, he added.
By contrast, the embargos are unlikely to hurt American farmers or businesses severely.
''I don't think there's a significant impact'' on American agriculture, said Bernard Steinweg, a senior vice president of the Continental Grain Company, an international agribusiness company based in New York. ''It's not as if we had an embargo on the Soviet Union or one of the other major customers.''
Grain markets have been quiet this week, he said, adding that a lasting increase in oil prices could push up farmers' costs and eventually raise food prices.
 
Kuwait's Food Outlook
Kuwait has enough canned goods stored to feed its population for several months, Mr. Parker said. But these will probably be needed soon, since the country imports 96 percent of its food and is subject to the embargos, he said.
Kuwait has only a ninth of Iraq's population, so its supplies of canned goods would not feed the Iraqi population for long. In 1986, Iraq had 16.1 million people, while Kuwait's population totaled 1.87 million in 1987.
Neither embargo is total. The United Nations action allows food shipments to Iraq only under ''special humanitarian circumstances,'' while the American embargo permits food shipments only if they are ''donations of articles to relieve human suffering.''
The presence of many foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait, including several thousand Americans, may make it difficult to impose a total and prolonged food embargo.
 
Canada May Ban Shipments
According to the State Department, Brazil, Australia, the 12-member European Community and the United States have banned food shipments to Iraq, and Canada may do so soon. Argentina, China, Saudi Arabia and Thailand have not made a decision on food shipments, while Turkey is continuing them on the humanitarian grounds specified by the United Nations. Together, these countries account for three-quarters of Iraqi food imports.
Saudi Arabia spent heavily in the 1970's to improve its agriculture after American discussions in 1973 of halting grain exports to the Mideast, but Iraq did not follow suit.
If the embargos prove prolonged, American farmers and car makers are likely to be among the first exporters affected, other Government and industry experts said. But shipments to Iraq and Kuwait represent a small fraction of American agricultural and motor vehicle production, so that with few exceptions, the embargos' effects are unlikely to be severe, they added. 10th-Biggest Customer Iraq was the 10th-largest foreign customer for American agricultural products last year, accounting for about $1 billion of the United States' $37.2 billion in agricultural exports, said Sally A. Klusaritz, an Agriculture Department spokeswoman. The primary purchases were of wheat, rice and feed grains, she said.
American rice growers are particularly dependent upon the Iraqi market, which accounted for nearly a fifth of the industry's $1 billion in exports last year, said James W. Willis, the vice president for foreign market development at the USA Rice Council, a Houston trade group.
But American agricultural exports to Iraq have almost stopped in recent months even without the embargo, pending Federal investigations into an Agriculture Department program that guarantees bank loans used to finance food sales to Iraq, Ms. Klusaritz said. The Iraqi Government owes $2 billion to the United States under the program, she said.
 
Car Purchases at $250 Million
Kuwait bought about $250 million in cars, trucks and vehicle parts from the United States last year, according to Commerce Department figures. The General Motors Corporation accounted for most of the sales, shipping about 10,000 cars and trucks a year, most of them Cadillacs, Buicks and GMC Suburban vans, the company said yesterday.
But with $127 billion in sales last year, G.M. is unlikely to be hurt, said Thomas F. O'Grady, the president of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc., a consulting company in Wayne, Pa. ''Really it's a drop in the bucket, although no one likes to lose $200 million a year in sales,'' he said.
Kuwait also bought about $47 million worth of used American cars and $43 million in American cigarettes last year, the Commerce Department said. The United States also exports to Kuwait and Iraq other products in much smaller quantities. According to the department, American exports to Iraq last year totaled $1.15 billion and $855 million to Kuwait.

SECTION: Section D; Page 20, Column 1; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
The Man Wearing the Knickers

BYLINE: By Ira Berkow

 BODY:
Anyone who follows golf knows that Payne Stewart wears old-fashioned knickers, his trademark. His golf shoes, though, are less prominent. That's because they are the standard variety, with laces and cleats. They are his shoes, and it is obvious he finds no reason to put himself into anyone else's shoes.
As reported in Wednesday's Times, Stewart blasted the news media for making too much of what turned out to be incendiary remarks by Hall Thompson, the founder of the Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala. 
Stewart is the defending champion of the P.G.A. Championship, which begins play today for this year's title. ''I think the whole thing's been blown way out of proportion,'' said Stewart. ''That's something you guys are pretty good at, blowing things out of proportion.''
Thompson had said that there were no black members at Shoal Creek, and his club wouldn't be ''pressured'' into having any. It turned out he was wrong. When harsh focus was put on Thompson and the club, and local boycotts were threatened, and advertising television sponsors of the event withdrew, a widely respected black businessman in Birmingham was indeed hastily corraled as an honorary member.
It alleviated for the moment the rawness of the situation, and forced the PGA Tour, the Professional Golfers' Association of America, which conducts the P.G.A. Championship, and the United States Golf Association to announce that in the future the membership policies of private clubs would be a major consideration in where these guys hold their golf games.
Now, there are times when the news media blows things out of proportion, something Marla Maples and her boyfriend, for example, have come to learn. But this golf story is not one of those inflations.
Stewart added that the players were not deeply concerned by the issues brought up by the controversy. ''The players have probably made more jokes about it than anything else,'' he said.
Jack Nicklaus didn't. ''I don't think that's a joking issue,'' he said.
And Calvin Peete didn't. Earlier, he had been dismayed at the lack of support for blacks by other Tour golfers. The best black golfer on the Tour said that if some of his white colleagues were black they wouldn't be saying this. Their understanding, he said, would be deeper.
Stewart, from Springfield, Mo., has been on the Tour, in knickers and cleats, for 11 years, or since he was 22 years old. And like too many professional golfers, he has a life that obviously extends no farther than from tee to green. He has, like some other Tour players recently, said that he was a golfer and not a politician. Which means, then, that they are not citizens? ''I'm a barber,'' said the barber, ''not a politican.'' ''I'm a bank president,'' she said, ''not a politician.''
Nonsense. If you don't take a side, then you are taking a side. Edmund Burke put it tidily 200 years ago: ''The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.''
A black man in Birmingham, Richard A. Peters, writes in a letter about discriminatory country clubs, and how their ''racist acts'' contribute to some whites' continuing to classify blacks as second-class citizens. ''And these clubs,'' he said, ''are where our dominant male society socializes. These are the people behind the people who set policy and set the tone for our communities.'' It is all of a piece. Once, Gary Player, a decent man, tried, like Stewart, to divorce sports from politics. ''I love all people,'' Player had said, ''regardless of race or religion.'' But two decades ago, he was being held up as a symbol of apartheid, the official policy of his government, even though he made numerous positive gestures, including wanting to play an exhibition with the handful of prominent black Tour players, and give the proceeds to a fund for blacks.
In the 1969 P.G.A. Championship, someone threw a soft-drink cup with ice in his face. At the United States Open, stones were hurled at him. I remember covering the 1970 Masters in Augusta, Ga., and seeing Player, whose life had been threatened, move about the course and the clubhouse circled by 10 security guards.
The closest Player came to possible racism was when someone asked his caddie where he got those nice new white golf shoes. ''They're Mr. Player's,'' said the black man. ''I'm breakin' 'em in for him.'' If that could be taken as racist in some elements of society, it was taken as de rigueur in golf.
Recently, Player, who supports the decision to investigate membership policies for future Tour events, said that one has to put himself in other ''people's shoes.''
As that black caddie did with his shoes. As he has apparently done. As Payne Stewart has not.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Reading Saddam's Mind

BYLINE: By William Safire; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
A great leader, a new Saladin, is known for the enemies he makes. I now have the enemies I need.
First, I have every rich Arab in the world hating and fearing me. They thought they could buy me off by financing my war against the Persians. I spit on their demands for repayment. Today, Kuwait is mine; tomorrow, the Arab world. 
I do not have to fight the Arab nation; I have only to lead it. Arabs in the streets are sick of weakness and cry out for a conqueror to wreak vengeance on the sheiks, the West, the Jews.
Arab leaders? Mubarak lives in terror of Sadat's fate. Hassan knows he is the last King of Morocco. Syria has 4,000 tanks, but I show my contempt for Hafez al-Assad by moving my troops from the Syrian border toward the Saudis.
Arafat and my little Hashemite toady in Jordan have come running to me because they have more respect for military muscle than money. Fahd knows I will hang him and confiscate his wealth, so he has run to the Americans.
Ah, my new enemy, the Americans. We will see how they like sitting in the 110-degree tents in their poison-gas gear. I hold 30 times as many American hostages as the Ayatollah ever did. If America besieges us, we will see how world opinion changes when I show starving Iraqi babies on television, when I let their maddened mothers harass our 3,500 American guests.
America lost an eight-year war against an enemy a tenth of its size; Iraq won an eight-year war against an enemy triple our size. We'll see who is better prepared to bear the pain of oil blockade. If America cannot win a war in a week, it begins negotiating with itself.
I know the Americans. I have listened to the supplications of Senator Specter; I heard the silence of the White House after my gassing of the Kurds and hanging of the English reporter. I have broadcast the meeting with Senator Dole's delegation telling me how he opposed the Israeli bombing of my reactor in 1981, assuring me that the Voice of America fired the writer who insulted my secret police. Weaklings all. A month ago Bush expected me to thank him for the money, the grain, the technology. Now he is terrified at my using the Dow chemicals - financed by his Export-Import Bank -in poison gas canisters aimed at his troops occupying precious Arab soil.
I fooled the Americans and Saudis by taking Kuwait; they fooled me by agreeing to base troops near the oilfields; now it's my turn again. Let them dig in and sweat; I have the opportunity to launch the first surprise non-attack.
My Jordanian messenger has warned other Arab ''leaders'' that my followers will bring down any government that joins the Yankee force. I want the American mercenaries there alone. I want them and the Saudi royalty to get sick of each other.
Meanwhile, I can turn my attention to my most useful, unifying enemy, the Israelis. If they had not stopped my nuclear weapons plant nine years ago, I would have been able to incinerate Teheran. The same order that gassed only 5,000 Kurds at Halabja would have killed three million Persians at one blow.
How do I change this from a war between rich Arabs and poor Arabs to a glorious war of Arabs against the Zionists and their American allies? How do I force Hafez and Hosni, the disunited Arab republic, to fight by my side?
One way would be to send a tank column not against the Americans, but into my willing neighbor, Jordan, at the invitation of the little fellow I still permit to be King. That would surely bring the Israelis into my war.
Israel could no longer claim my crusade to be a war between Arabs. By moving into Jordan, which offers my tanks and artillery a straight corridor to the Israeli border, I offer the Jews no choice but to strike. Then it would be Saddam against Shamir -and Fahd would have to throw out the Americans and world opinion would swing to my side. End of sanctions.
Only one drawback with that plan: When the Israelis hit, they will hit with everything they have. If I use gas to slaughter civilians, they'll go nuclear. I don't mind taking the casualties, but they'll go after every one of the centrifuges I scattered to make enriched uranium.
Maybe the wisest move now is no move at all. My population can take starvation, and I, who began as an assassin, know how to guard against any von Stauffenberg solution. Atrocities in Kuwait will terrorize the Saudis and emirates, and Abul Abbas and threats to hostages will terrorize the West. After inflation and recession, Bush will want to bring the boys home by Election Day.
If waiting doesn't work, I can play the Israeli card.

PUB-DATE: August 10, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 593 words

HEADLINE: The Siege of Iraq

 BODY:
President Bush has skillfully orchestrated a two-pronged response to Iraq's occupation of tiny Kuwait. He has dispatched American military forces to prevent the Iraqi divisions from pushing on to occupy Saudi Arabia's oilfields. And he has led the worldwide economic effort to choke off Saddam Hussein's oil exports and force him to withdraw from Kuwait. 
The American troops have, from the moment of their arrival, provided a sound way to deter Iraq's military threat to Saudi Arabia. And though trade sanctions rarely work, in Iraq's case they promise ultimately to squeeze hard enough to force withdrawal from Kuwait.
Even so, that could take months. President Bush has so far won a unified commitment from Iraq's trading partners to punish its treachery. But for the siege of Iraq to succeed, they will have to remain patient, and that will require extraordinary leadership.
Iraq depends on oil exports to pay for almost everything, including over 70 percent of its food. Yet Iraq has buffer stocks that, in the case of food, could last until winter.
Given enough time, countries find ways to undermine economic sanctions. The resolve of encircling nations to maintain a siege is often no match for the resolve of the besieged. All President Hussein would need is an ally, or foreign merchants willing to violate international sanctions and their country's law. Rhodesia survived United Nations trade sanctions by turning to South Africa.
Besides, Iraq has some anti-siege weapons. For one thing, it has plenty of cheap oil. If that could be sold at deep enough discounts, there might well be shippers willing to sneak the oil onto international markets, even at the risk of seizure by governments complying with the U.N. embargo.
Another potential weapon is that Iraq might be able to manipulate the Arab world's animus toward the U.S. and Israel as well as the wealthy Kuwaitis. Playing to these entrenched emotions, Iraq will try to peel one or more of its neighbors away from the U.N. sanctions.
Finally, Saddam Hussein remains ruthless. During the grueling eight-year war with Iran, he subjected his country to endless suffering. Yet he remained firmly in control. He is not a ruler who will surrender merely to spare his countrymen unnecessary pain.
All that said, Iraq will be fighting tremendous forces. It relies solely on oil, which is very hard to slip out through the siege lines. Oil is shipped in large, expensive tankers whose movements are easily monitored. As long as oil-importing nations remain unified, shippers won't find any place to unload Iraqi oil.
Adding to Iraq's woes is the fact that, at present, its oil can be exported only through a few limited outlets, principally Saudi Arabia, Turkey and the Persian Gulf. Saudi Arabia and Turkey are committed to the embargo. And the Persian Gulf is easily blockaded.
Finally, few shippers will deal with Iraq on credit in any case; it is already drowning in debt.
Choking Iraq into submission will raise humanitarian issues. Would President Hussein hold out to the point of starving innocent Iraqis? Would the world squeeze that tight? But those questions lie far down the road. The siege of Iraq could succeed well short of such extremes.
Time will be needed to make the trade embargo work. But time will also undermine the resolve of the nations now joined to make it work. They know how to act on their outrage at Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression, and are doing so. What's unclear is whether they are angry enough and unified enough to stick to their siege guns.

HEADLINE: Ms. Messinger's Obstructionism

 BODY:
Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger's veto of a Columbia University plan to build on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom could hasten the decline of a deteriorating community and leave those who want to honor Malcolm X, murdered in the ballroom 25 years ago, with nothing but a building in ruins.
It also sends an irresponsible message to a frustrated business community just when New York most needs sound economic development.
Columbia has long planned to put a new biomedical research center on the Audubon site. It would be the first phase of a four-block research park in the Washington Heights neighborhood. That plan, which included a memorial to Malcolm X, drew objections from a coalition of preservationists, civil rights groups and black militants who want to save more of the ballroom and the building's terra cotta facade. 
Their opposition led the Dinkins administration to fashion a compromise that would preserve 40 percent of the ballroom and some of the facade. The local community board and several elected officials embrace that plan, and Columbia has endorsed it -as long as the university doesn't have to pay the additional $9 million.
Ms. Messinger, though, wants to save more of the building. She is entitled to her opinion. But the forum for discussing projects with citywide implications is the Board of Estimate, which was scheduled to consider the plan next Thursday. Thanks to Ms. Messinger, it may never get there. Ignoring the political process, she took advantage of an obscure state law that let her veto $8.1 million in Port Authority funds for the project. The veto effectively dooms it before any other elected official has a chance to consider it.
Worse: To make her case, Ms. Messinger misinterprets the proposed deal, and cloaks her objections in sanctimony. She argues that the city's plan is not fiscally responsible, while denying that her approach would be even more costly. Even as she complains about the cost of the compromise plan, she notes that she has up to $4 million in discretionary capital funds - but would make it available only for her version of the project.
The Dinkins plan is not perfect. City Hall still cannot say where some of the $34 million needed would come from. The proposal does, though, represent a responsible compromise.
If the Borough President's veto is actually a lobbying tactic, how does she expect a fiscally strapped city to comply with her demands? The additional cost is only one issue; planning and environmental requirements could delay the eight-year-old project by at least another year. In that case, Columbia says it will walk away.
Thus Ms. Messinger's obstructionism could well kill the project, leaving Manhattan and New York with nothing but unkept promises and an unfortunate lesson in the high cost of inflexible politicians.

LENGTH: 573 words

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Vietnam Again, for the First Time

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
Fifteen years after North Vietnamese tanks smashed into Saigon's Presidential Palace, there are still two Vietnams. The Republic of (South) Vietnam, that artificial creation of French colonialism and cold war politics, is no more. But commercial capitalism, the American presence and the Viet Cong-led insurrection pressed a distinctive subculture onto the South. The political ramifications endure. 
No American is a total stranger in Ho Chi Minh City, as Saigon is now officially known. English is widely spoken. Ordinary Vietnamese greet Americans with surprising warmth. And even for those who weren't there ''before 1975,'' as the local euphemism puts it, locales made familiar by war movies and the nightly television news are everywhere.
The first glance of my room at the old Majestic Hotel brought back memories of the opening scenes of ''Apocalypse Now,'' when Captain Willard lies in a similar hotel room contemplating his assigned mission up the Mekong River. Just a few blocks away, the former U.S. Embassy, its rooftop helipad intact, is occupied by a state petrochemical company. Nearby is the old Presidential Palace, now offering guided tours.
Two other museums present the official history of the war from the Communist side, displaying captured American aircraft, tanks and high-tech artillery pieces and recounting the atrocities committed by the U.S.-backed Southern regime.
But many old-time residents of Saigon have different memories from the pre-1975 years. There is little evident bitterness over a costly and futile war. Instead there is a kind of nostalgia for what, from today's vantage point, seem happier, more prosperous times. Those rosy recollections indict the economic failures of Communist rule. The Communist leadership itself acknowledges those failures and for four years has been encouraging market-oriented economic reform.
That has not only unleashed the strong commercial instincts of the South but has also begun to spread private economic activity northward to Hanoi, for 35 years a bastion of Marxist-Leninist orthodoxy. In a reversal of the pattern of the 1960's, today's infiltration routes run from south to north.
The irony would be more delicious if economic reform had not been coupled with a nasty political backlash. Vietnam's Communist rulers are prepared to tolerate capitalist economics. But, frightened by the example of Eastern Europe, they fear any accompanying decentralization of political power.
A wave of arrests earlier this year has chilled political discussion. A disproportionate number of those arrested appear to be Southerners, including many who were closely associated with the Communist movement before 1975.
Vietnam was isolated from the outside world for more than a decade after the war, thanks to an American-sponsored economic embargo and hostile international reaction when Hanoi invaded and occupied Cambodia. Now Vietnamese troops are back home. Western trade and investment are on the rise. Deals with Visa and MasterCard have recently been signed, although Americans are still prohibited by United States law from using such credit cards or doing business in Vietnam, or even placing phone calls to that country.
Those policies, large and small, are overripe for review, especially since the United States is now beginning a dialogue with Vietnam. The psyches of America and Vietnam are tied too closely together for lasting estrangement.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1622 words

HEADLINE: CORPORATE RESPONSE TO SHOAL CREEK;
More Caution by Sponsors After Shoal Creek Furor

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
The scandal over a country club's racially exclusionary membership policy will make corporations more cautious about paying to associate their names with athletic events, a $2 billion industry that until now has been growing explosively.
Marketing experts said that over the last six years large corporations have come to rely increasingly on sports to sell their products. Sports, in turn, have become so dependent on corporate sponsorship to stage major tournaments and events that their very survival sometimes depends on it.
The relationship between sports and corporate sponsors is far more intimate than that between conventional advertisers and television programs. Corporations frequently play host to clients at sports events, and have their names attached to tournaments, games and scoreboards. Because their relationship is so much more public, marketing and sports analysts said, both sides are open to greater pressure than ever before from groups agitating for social change. 
 
Visible Targets
''Sponsorship is more visible than traditional advertising; that's why sponsors are becoming the targets of protests,'' said Lesa Ukman, the editor of Special Events Report, a Chicago newsletter that tracks the field. ''Shoal Creek has shown that when you're dealing with sports or cultural events or music, the sponsors have real responsibility. And if they're not willing to take it, there will be problems.''
The exclusionary policy of the Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., where the Professional Golfers' Association Championship began yesterday, touched off the current furor.
''I think the sensitivity level raised here will carry over into any activities we look at in the future,'' said Bill O'Neill, the public relations director for the Cadillac division of General Motors.
Corporations will spend $2 billion this year to have their names associated with athletic events, Ukman said, and perhaps three times that amount advertising and promoting their involvement. By contrast, musical and cultural events will garner $500 million in sponsorships.
In 1984, some $350 million was spent on sports and culture sponsorships. But the success of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles - the first Olympics opened widely to corporate sponsors - spurred a burst of spending. In 1985, for example, corporations spent $850 million sponsoring athletic and cultural events.
 
Golf and Stock Cars Lead the Way
Golf and stock-car racing have led the pack, with the P.G.A. and PGA Tour, and the stock-car circuit each drawing some $85 million this year from marketers eager to have their names attached to tournaments and their logos near stadiums.
Even before Shoal Creek, sports executives recognized the potential economic harm they could suffer from the effect of adverse publicity on advertisers and sponsors. The National Basketball Association moved quickly to address the problem of drug use by its players because it recognized that the issue was damaging to its image and marketability, said Stephen A. Greyser, a professor of consumer marketing at the Harvard Business School who has been a consultant to the N.B.A.
Sponsors often buy one-quarter to one-third of the advertising time on the telecasts of the sports events to which they attach their names. So without sponsors, television networks will be less likely to pay for the broadcast rights.
''I think corporate sponsors will not eagerly embrace problem properties,'' said one network executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''And the rights holder who doesn't have a corporate underwriter to insure a TV broadcast's economic viability will have a harder time getting on the air.''
More than the money from broadcast rights is at stake. Increasingly, corporate sponsorship determines whether an event lives or dies. After Sunkist Growers bought its way into the name of the Fiesta Bowl in 1985, eight other corporate sponsors discovered college football, said Ukman, creating such gridiron classics as the Mobil Cotton Bowl and the John Hancock Bowl. These sponsors also pumped money into the purses, sometimes attracting better college teams and more television coverage. Sunkist, for example, increased the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl's payment to the teams from a total of $1 million in 1985 to $4 million in 1988.
Similarly, corporations contribute most of the $50 million in prize money given out at various PGA Tour, Senior PGA Tour and Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour events.
Unable to find corporate sponsors with deep pockets, some sports events have met their demise, among them the Bluebonnet Bowl, a college football game that was played in Texas for 29 years before it was canceled in 1988.
 
Tennis Controversy
There have been other controversies over sports marketing. Earlier this year, for example, Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, criticised the sponsorship of women's professional tennis by Virginia Slims cigarettes, made by the Philip Morris Companies. George Washington University, a site for a Virginia Slims tournament, subsequently pressed Philip Morris to name the tournament for one of its nontobacco brands. Instead, Philip Morris announced in June that it would move the tournament from the school to another site in Washington.
Threats against conventional advertisers, especially those by religious groups and conservative organizations objecting to sexual content in programs, remain a powerful force in television. But their success has been limited, mainly because it is hard to dissuade a mass audience from watching a program or buying products advertised on it.
A niche audience, which may be as large as the blue-collar men who attend and watch auto racing or as narrow as a company's own sales force, can be a much more cost-effective target for marketers. A brewer can attach its name to a stock-car race and also set up a hospitality tent at the track to entertain liquor store managers. Or it can offer the supply of free tickets it gets for sponsoring or advertising on an event to people who purchase two six-packs, driving up short-term sales in a given area.
But the intricacy and intimacy of the relationship between sponsors and sports renders corporate sponsorship easier to disrupt than the relatively passive relationship between a conventional television advertiser and the viewer, said Greyser of Harvard. Sponsors who are boycotted at the site of an event can be embarassed in front of their clients, and those boycotts can be the subject of vivid news coverage, damaging the company's image with the broader public.
Golf, especially, because of its affluent image and the opportunities it provides for hosting clients and sales people, is particularly attractive to corporations. And until Shoal Creek, the game was nearly free from the controversy, including the drug problems and salary disputes, that had engulfed baseball, basketball and football.
''People pay a premium for golf because it delivers a highly targeted audience,'' said Chip Campbell, a former sports-marketing executive at RJR Nabisco and now the president of Sports Marketing International, a subsidiary of the Burson-Marsteller public relations agency. ''Customer relations is also very important, especially at that end of the scale where you're dealing with decision-makers who spend a lot of money.''
James C. Reilly, the general manager of domestic marketing and services at I.B.M., said the decision to sponsor an event was complex.
''There are a number of gates we go through in deciding to sponsor an event,'' he said. ''Along with the obvious media considerations, will it provide a customer-hosting opportunity for our sales force? Will the event help us demonstrate I.B.M.'s technology? On the next level, will it provide dealer incentive opportunities? And are there possibilities for us to demonstrate I.B.M.'s corporate citizenship?''
The current controversy began in late June, when Hall Thompson, the founder of Shoal Creek, said his club would not be pressured into admitting black members. His comment, for which he later apologized, incited local and national civil rights organizations to plan protests at the club during the nationally televised broadcast of the P.G.A. Championship.
 
Pulling Out
The championship's major advertisers, including I.B.M., the American Honda Motor Company, Spalding Sports Worldwide and the Toyota Motor Corporation, subsequently pulled their commercials from ABC and ESPN. Delta Air Lines, which pays the P.G.A. a fee to be designated the championship's official airline, asked the organization to remove banners identifying its association from the Shoal Creek grounds, said William D. Beery, a Delta spokesman.
The Eastman Kodak Company, which pays the P.G.A. a fee to set up booths for professional photographers at many events, canceled its plans for Shoal Creek after Thompson revealed the club's policy. But when Shoal Creek reversed its rules, so did Kodak.
The P.G.A. moved quickly to redress the damage, affirming that country club membership policies would now be a factor in tournament site selection. As a result, none of the 25 corporations that paid to have hospitality tents at Shoal Creek withdrew, said Joe Steranka, a P.G.A. communications director.
Reilly said I.B.M.'s decision to move its advertising to other time slots on ABC was not difficult to make once Shoal Creek's membership policy became public. There was no pressure from groups or individuals inside or outside the company, and no corporate conclaves were convened.
''The clarity of our policy came face to face with the emerging public controversy,'' Reilly said. ''The decision was obvious.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
No Oil Emergency Yet, Energy Officials Assert

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
With oil markets still jittery today, the industrial world's senior energy officials sought to reassure the industry and investors that there were sufficient oil supplies worldwide.
Still, they emphasized the importance of becoming more prepared for emergency measures in case the situation in the Middle East deteriorated.
At a meeting of the International Energy Agency in Paris, energy officials from the United States, Japan and Europe decided that despite their embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the time had not yet come to take such urgent measures as tapping emergency oil reserves or beginning special conservation programs.
 
An Uncertain Future
Nevertheless, the officials noted that the future was very uncertain and agreed to prepare to begin using their emergency oil reserves, if necessary. 
''There is a risk that the situation could evolve into a shortfall,'' said Ulrich Engelmann, chairman of the International Energy Agency.
For now, however, the ministers said petroleum supplies remained adequate, citing the supplies of oil at sea, the high level of company- and government-controlled oil stocks and the possibility of higher oil production by several countries.
''We're not in a crisis situation,'' said John Easton, the United States Assistant Secretary of Energy.
After rising sharply following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week, oil prices have declined in recent days on the expectation that Saudi Arabia would increase its current production of 5.4 million barrels a day by about two million barrels. That would help cushion the effects of the embargo on oil from Iraq and Kuwait, which the I.E.A. says export 4.4 million barrels a day. #50 Percent Rise in a Month West Texas Intermediate crude oil dropped 29 cents today to close at $25.67 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, about 50 percent higher than it was a month ago. In London, North Sea Brent crude oil closed at $25.05 a barrel, up 7 cents on the day.
At today's meeting in Paris, energy officials from 21 nations seemed especially concerned about calming the oil markets and preventing prices from soaring. They characterized the price increases as a response to uncertainty rather than to shortages.
''The price development is the typical speculative reaction to a political negative event,'' Mr. Engelmann said.
The International Energy Agency was formed by oil-importing nations in 1974 after Arab nations embargoed oil shipments to the United States. It helps coordinate a response to any oil-supply emergency and seeks to foster a balance in energy supply and demand, encourage conservation and promote other energy sources.
 
'Excellent Stock Situation'
In their communique, the energy officials called on oil companies to ''take advantage of their generally excellent stock situation'' and ''avoid abnormal spot market purchases.''
Several officials said the West's oil supplies could be insured and prices stabilized, at least for a time, if companies drew down some of their reserves.
''There is a common interest among the oil industry and the Government that things do not run into a panic situation,'' Mr. Engelmann said.
Officials suggested that the supply situation could remain satisfactory if other oil-producing nations, especially Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, increased their production. Many analysts expect Venezuela to raise its output to 2.4 million barrels a day from its current 1.9 million barrels.
At a British Petroleum news conference in London today, company officials said that even with a two-million-barrel-a-day drop in production caused by the Iraqi crisis, the world would have an adequate oil supply for a year if the coming winter was not severe. With a four-million barrel-a-day decline in output, however, a shortfall would be felt in October, they said.
British Petroleum's chairman, Robert Horton, estimated that the price of oil would average $22 a barrel over the next six months.
 
A Billion Barrels in Reserve
Helga Sleeg, the executive director of the International Energy Agency, said the West was in better position in this Middle Eastern crisis than it had been in previous crises because Government-controlled oil stocks were at an eight-year high. The billion barrels in emergency reserves in the industrialized world - including a 590-million-barrel reserve in the United States -are equivalent to 150 days of the industrial world's net oil imports.
Another positive factor is that many nations have reduced their dependence on oil. In France, for instance, oil has dropped to 40 percent of total energy consumption from 69 percent in 1973.
Mr. Engelmann said that by developing and tapping oil reserves and switching to other forms of energy, the industrial world stood a good chance of preventing a huge shortage.
Other Western officials are optimistic that the current crisis will be less damaging the world's economy than were the 1973 and 1979 oil shocks, which sent the West into recession.
The Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of industrialized nations, estimated that a $3-a-barrel increase in oil prices would increase inflation by five-tenths of 1 percent in the industrialized world in the first year and would reduce economic output by four-tenths of 1 percent in the first year.
But some economists said a $10-a-barrel increase - the amount that oil prices have risen over the last month - would triple those negative effects.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 728 words

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Iraq Puts Election Truisms To Test

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
All the uncertainty in the Persian Gulf has insured at least one thing at home: this fall's elections, which weeks ago seemed but a hodgepodge of races with little national focus, will now revolve heavily around the economy as it sags under the burden of rising oil prices.
On its face, that is bad news for President Bush and the Republicans. Few laws of politics have been proved more often than the one stated by Harold Wilson, the British Prime Minister, in 1968: ''All political history shows that the standing of a government and its ability to hold the confidence of the electorate at a general election depend on the success of its economic policy.''
Republican officials are in near panic over what may happen at the polls this fall as economic trouble stokes an already potent pox-on-politicians mood. ''I've been in politics for 30 years and this is the scariest political environment I've ever been in,'' said Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. 
But in this year's witch's brew of politics, maxims deserve a second look. The simple formula that bad economic news equals bad political news for the President's party may not capture the complexity of the modern economy or of politics.
Mr. Bush faces the most delicate political dilemma of his career. Nothing boosts the standing of a President and his party more than the firm handling of a foreign crisis. And there is nothing that hurts that standing more than a sliding economy. But the more firmly Mr. Bush stands up to the Iraqis, the more he insures higher oil prices, inflation and recession.
Assuming he handles the crisis well, which will dominate the campaigns: Foreign policy management or economic hardship? The conventional wisdom is that economics overrides almost all other issues, particularly in this post-cold-war world.
But there are dissenters. Some analysts in both parties say Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will not only boost President Bush's standing as a leader but also give him an explanation for a recession that was imminent anyway. Perhaps that will temper its political effect, since Americans, like most people, endure pain better when they are given a reason.
There is also the notion that recessions are different these days. Politicians fear them because they produce unemployed and angry voters. But what if this incipient recession does more damage, as some economists predict, to bankers and over-leveraged business executives than to working people? There will still be political fallout, but it could be quite different from the past.
To see the effect of the economy on the elections more clearly, it is necessary to ask how the economy affects voters. First, a truism must be dispensed with. Voters do not ''vote their pocketbook'' in the direct sense.
''Very few citizens are motivated to vote against the incumbent simply because they see their financial situation has deteriorated,'' said Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a professor of political science at the University of Iowa, who surveyed voters in the United States and five European countries to arrive at this conclusion.
In other words, higher gasoline prices will not, of themselves, lead to retaliation at the polls, particularly if the President explains them as a necessary price for a national goal.
What the voters respond to, says the professor, is their sense of where the economy is headed. Everything from the closing of a savings and loan to the announcement of higher unemployment can influence that. Indeed, 49 percent of Americans believe the country is in recession, according to a CBS News poll this week, and 29 percent more think it is near one.
What matters is the overall psychological effect. So it follows that factors other than hard data matter. Kirk O'Donnell, a Democratic analyst, says the 1986 and 1988 elections were influenced more by political talk about the economy than by real changes in the economy.
In 1986, he said, the Democrats persuaded voters that economic trouble was brewing and recaptured the Senate. In 1988, Republicans held onto the White House after calming economic fears, said Mr. O'Donnell, who watched from his perch as a campaign adviser to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.
So the political effect of the 1990 recession will depend a lot on whether voters think it is George Bush's recession or Saddam Hussein's.

PUB-DATE: August 10, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 942 words

HEADLINE: Birmingham Journal;
Bitter Memories of Bias Accompany City's Gains

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 8

 BODY:
From the days of Bull Connor's police dogs and fire hoses to the present, perhaps no American city has had to wrestle with the demons of race so conspicuously as Birmingham.
So as the P.G.A. golf championship gets under way here after a dispute over the efforts to integrate the Shoal Creek Country Club just outside this city, there is an odd mix of weariness, resignation, anger and even pride.
Despite the harsh memories and emotions engendered by the dispute at Shoal Creek and other incidents this summer, this is a city that has come to accept its status as a barometer of race relations in America. Almost three decades after the racial violence of the civil rights era that made it infamous, Birmingham has probably made as much progress in race relations as any city in the country. At the same time, it sums up as painfully just how far the nation has to go. 
''When people think of that era, they think of George Wallace and freedom riders and police dogs and fire hoses in Birmingham,'' said Dr. Russ Fine, a medical school professor at the University of Alabama who is the host of a radio call-in show here. ''And I don't know if that's an image that's ever going to be purged from the fabric of the American memory. We're a symbol, and we're held to a higher standard, but maybe that's not all bad. If you're held to a higher standard, then you have a higher standard to achieve.''
In many ways, the progress in Birmingham has been striking. Birmingham, where blacks now make up about 60 percent of the city's 275,000 residents, has a black Mayor, Richard Arrington Jr., and blacks are a majority on the City Council. It has an almost painfully earnest network of interracial commissions and study groups dedicated to fostering racial harmony and a series of intiatives aimed at voluntary efforts by businesses to provide economic and job opportunties for blacks.
Chris Boehm, head of the city's interracial Community Affairs Committee, said, ''The 60's damaged our city terribly and as a result of that, when it comes to race it's just not good enough for Birmingham to be equal to other cities; we have to be better.''
For blacks like the Rev. John T. Porter of Sixth Avenue Baptist Church, who recalls indignities like interminable waits in office lobbies for the one elevator out of eight reserved for blacks, or Louis J. Willie, who can remember a town with no black police officers or firefighters and only a handful of black professionals, Birmingham has undergone a revolutionary transformation.
''This is a totally different place,'' said Mr. Willie, head of the Booker T. Washington Insurance Company, who became the first black invited to join Shoal Creek. Last week the club accepted Mr. Willie as an honorary member and began procedures to accept its first regular black member.
''Anyone who thinks nothing much has changed in Birmingham has been like Rip Van Winkle, asleep for 30 years.''
Despite the progress, Birmingham is a place that has been buffeted by one racial dispute after another in the past year, including a furor over a white talk show host's one-day ban on black callers.
To many blacks, the progress masks the evolution of a new status quo that is almost as stifling as the old one in a city where housing and public schools remain almost completely segregated, despite the end of legal segregation. A survey of 48 American cities in 1987 ranked Birmingham last in the concentration of small black businesses. A study by The Birmingham News last year found banks and savings and loans were three times as likely to make loans in white middle-income areas as in black ones.
Donald Watkins, a local lawyer who is and special counsel to Mr. Arrington, said the departure of whites, discrimination in housing and employment and continuing economic inequality provide more subtle but just as insidious barriers to black advancement as were evident in the 60's.
''A lot of the problems are the same,'' he said. ''They're much harder to deal with though because the discrimination is more sophisticated and subtle.''
For many business people and white residents, the Shoal Creek dispute has been a nightmare - an dismal realization of their fears that the world still wants to see Birmingham as it was rather than as it is. For many blacks it has been a confirmation of the vestiges of the past that still linger in a changed city.
But many people, black and white, see a measure of hypocrisy in the degree to which Birmingham and the South remain a lightning rod for racial controversy in a nation bursting at the seams with it.
''If that Howard Beach thing had happened here, we would have been slaughtered,'' said Mr. Willie, referring to the incident in New York City where a black man, being chased by a gang of white youths, was struck and killed by a car.
And for some the furor has been a reminder of how much race in America is a captive of images - of Commissioner Eugene (Bull) Connor's police dogs - and how much easier it is to confront them than contemporary problems.
Jenell Smith, a 15-year-old high school student, has a summer job working at Phillips High School in a poor neighborhood. There is not much in his life that is further away than golf at Shoal Creek, but he sees in the dispute something he sees all around him -the degree to which for blacks and whites alike, past and present still intermingle in the doleful dance of race.
''Half the people if they didn't know about the past, they wouldn't have any racial tensions, but we can't seem to get away from it,'' he said. ''As it is, it goes up and down, up and down, over and over again. It never goes away.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
U.N. Council Declares Void Iraqi Annexation of Kuwait

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to declare Iraq's formal annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law.
The decision is legally binding on all members of the organization. But Iraq's United Nations representative defended his Government's action as ending an artificial division of the Arab world created in the last century by what he called the imperialist powers. The representatives of the United States and Kuwait's government-in-exile promptly pointed out that this argument could justify further annexations of Arab countries. 
The resolution, which was supported by all 15 Council members, said the annexation ''has no legal validity and is declared null and void.''
It tells all countries and international organizations they must not recognize the annexation or take any actions ''that might be interpreted as an indirect recognition of the annexation.'' And it ''demands that Iraq rescind its actions purporting to annex Kuwait.''
 
Unanimous Condemnation
This is the third time the Security Council has condemned Baghdad's takeover of Kuwait since the invasion last week, though it is the first time the Council has unanimously done so.
But while Yemen refused to participate in the first vote last Thursday condemning the invasion and Cuba and Yemen abstained in Monday's vote imposing economic sanctions, no member opposed any of these decisions.
After the Council had voted and most members made brief speeches denouncing President Saddam Hussein's aggression for the third time in a week, Iraq's Representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, told the Council that ''those who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.''
Iraq's annexation, he said, was an attempt to end the ''splintering of the region'' caused by the colonial powers that had ''transformed the Arab nation into 22 Arab states, redrawing the map of the region.'' It was part of the reunification of his country, he said.
The United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, and the Kuwaiti representative, Mohammed A. Abulhasan, immediately pointed out that this argument could be used to justify the takeover of other Arab countries.
 
Talk of a Second Resolution
''Where does it end?'' Ambassador Pickering said. ''Does it end in Kuwait? Does it move on to Saudi Arabia? Does it move on to Jordan?'' Council members are starting to talk informally about the possibility of a second resolution setting up a United Nations naval patrol to enforce the trade embargo against Iraq and occupied Kuwait under Article 42 of the Charter, which empowers the Council to take such military actions.
This follows announcements by the Soviet Union and France that they will not join a blockade of Iraq without United Nations authorization and a Soviet statement today that said Moscow wanted consultations in the Military Staff Committee on such a blockade.
The Military Staff Committee is a largely defunct organ comprising the Chiefs of Staff of the five permanent Security Council members. It is supposed to organize military enforcement of Council decisions, but has never been able to agree in the past.
Some Western countries say a new resolution setting up a United Nations blockade is not strictly necessary because the resolution imposing sanctions can be interpreted as giving their national navies the right to search ships suspected of infringements.
The Security Council today also set up a special committee to monitor compliance with the embargo and appointed Finland its president and Canada and Colombia its vice presidents.
Today Britain's representative, Sir Crispin Tickell, told the Council that the existing sanctions resolution justifies Britain's decision to use its warships in the gulf to ''monitor maritime traffic'' to insure compliance.
But others argued that a new resolution would establish this right more clearly and probably be a political necessity if the Soviet Union and Arab Governments were to join the effort to make the sanctions effective.
Last night Kuwait's government-in-exile convened an emergency session of the Council after Baghdad announced its annexation decision. Cuba immediately tried to give the proceedings an anti-American twist by proposing a resolution expressing concern at the buildup of foreign forces in the Gulf and calling for a halt.
But the Council's other third world members refused to support it and Cuba was forced to abandon its plan.
 
Soviet Urges 'Collective Effort'
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (Special to The New York Times) - Distancing itself from the United States' decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia, the Soviet Union today ruled out any military action in the Persian Gulf crisis except as part of a ''collective effort'' carried out under United Nations auspices.
''The Soviet Union stands for coordinated actions within the Security Council of the United Nations,'' the Government said in a statement issued today. ''If this organization takes a decision on the use of a multinational force, the Soviet Union on this basis, will elaborate its line of conduct.''
The Soviet Union called on the United Nations Security Council to devote its full-time attention to the crisis, and for immediate consultations with the Council's military staff committee.
But, the Soviet statement said, ''at this time there is no question of taking part in a multinational force or a sea blockade outside the confines of the United Nations Security Council.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
U.S. Says Turkey Plans To Cooperate on Iraq

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
In a crucial strategic development further isolating Iraq, the United States and Turkey laid the basis today for expanded military and intelligence cooperation to counter President Saddam Hussein, a Bush Administration official said.
The tacit understanding was reached today in five hours of talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, President Turgut Ozal of Turkey and other senior Turkish officials in Ankara. The Administration official declined to specify the exact form the expanded cooperation might take, but he hinted that it could almost certainly involve Turkey's granting the United States permission to use the fighter aircraft and bombers it has based in Turkey, ostensibly on NATO-related missions, for any potential war in the Persian Gulf.
The United States in recent weeks has been rotating 14-plane squadrons of F-111 fighter-bombers from bases in England to Incirlik air base in Turkey, where 5,000 American servicemen and dependents are stationed. Since the planes are supposedly on routine NATO missions, to use them against Iraqi targets, just as the United States used them to bomb Libya in 1986, would require Turkey's permission. 
''In the event that there were to be full-scale hostilities, I am quite confident that we could count upon our allies the Turks,'' the Administration official said after today's talks. ''I think it would be useful in judging Turkish moods and intentions to watch what happens with respect to what they may be doing in the next couple of weeks.''
 
Iraqi Pipeline Is Cut
Up to now the Turks have confined their response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to economic sanctions - cutting off the Iraqi oil pipeline that crosses Iraqi territory and abiding by the United Nations boycott. Antagonizing Iraq by raising their stake in the conflict to a military level is not something the Turks would do lightly.
Administration officials would only speak in terms of tacit understandings because the precise extent of expanded cooperation between the two nations will depend in part on the degree to which the NATO foreign ministers at their meeting in Brussels on Friday signal their willingness to stand by Turkey if Iraq attacks it. Mr. Baker flew here for that meeting from Ankara.
''The Turks,'' the Administration official said, ''because they are strategicaly located, are exposed in the event that there is any outbreak of hostilities, and they quite appropriately want to know that if they stand up in a forthright manner that their allies will be with them if there is trouble.''
The Administration official said Mr. Baker and Mr. Ozal had also discussed how their two nations could intensify intelligence cooperation to improve gathering of data about internal developments in the tightly sealed Iraqi state, Turkey's neighbor to the east. While the official did not say so, Iraq's long and porous border with Turkey could be useful in infiltrating men, money or materiel to destabilize the regime of President Hussein.
If Turkey does add its military weight to the tightening siege of Iraq, it would mean that in case of a war with Iraq, the United States would probably have access to American military installations, air bases, warehouses and intelligence-gathering units across Turkey.
It would also leave Iraq virtually surrounded by hostile neighbors - with American, British and Saudi troops to the south, American and Turkish forces to the north, Iranian troops to the east and Syrian troops to the west. The only safe border from Iraq's point of view is with Jordan. In return for Turkey's forthright military cooperation, the official indicated that the Administration is prepared to help ease the economic burden on Turkey of virtually cutting off its ties with Baghdad.
Turkish officials told Mr. Baker that they will have to forfeit $400 million in revenues that they derived from the Iraqi oil pipeline they just closed. They will probably have to forfeit $800 million from an outstanding loan to Baghdad, and they will probably end up losing another $1.5 billion a year in sales contracts with Iraq, investments and remittances from the estimated 3,000 Turkish workers in Iraq and Kuwait.
Mr. Baker, the official said, told Mr. Ozal that Washington had won a commitment from the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jabar al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to compensate the Turks with an undisclosed amount of money. In addition, the official said, the Administration will push Turkey's application for membership in the European Community, support Turkey's loan requests pending before various multilateral banking institutions, support Export-Import bank loan guarantees for sales of certain heavy equipment to Turkey and possibly also increase military aid to Ankara.
 
Turkey Reacts Cautiously
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9 (Special to The New York Times) - Turkey reacted cautiously to Mr. Baker's visit, saying without comment that the Secretary had ''emphasized the importance that the United States attaches to Turkey's security.''
An official statement also said President Ozal had ''expressed his content'' about President Bush's decision to send American forces ''for defensive purposes.''
In a televised address tonight, Mr. Ozal warned neighboring Iraq against even thinking of attacking Turkey.
There were reports of heavy military movement on the Iraqi side of the border, but officials in Ankara insisted that they had no firm information about unusual activity.
The Turkish Army increased its state of readiness, canceling all leaves and transfering F-16 and F-104 fighter jets to bases in southeastern Turkey that are closer to the Iraqi border. The United States has at least 14 F-111 bombers at the Incirlik air base in southern Turkey. American officials insist, however, that the planes are here for routine training and that they arrived before the gulf crisis erupted.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United States and Turkey reached an understanding on how to counter Iraq after talks yesterday in Ankara between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, left, and President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, center. At right was Ali Bozer, the Turkish Foreign Minister. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From King Fahd's Speech to Saudis

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a statement by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today, broadcast by Saudi television and translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation:
No doubt you realize through your following up of the course of the regrettable events at the level of the Arab Gulf region during the last few days, the gravity of the situation facing the Arab nation in the shadow of the current circumstances. And you undoubtedly know that the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia had exerted all that it could in effort and attempts with the Governments of the Iraqi Republic and the state of Kuwait, for the sake of containing the dispute that has risen between the two countries.
However, with great regret, matters developed in the opposite direction to what we were endeavoring; in fact, opposite to the aspirations of the peoples of the Islamic and Arab nations, and all the peace-loving countries of the world. Painful and regrettable events have been taking place since the dawn of last Thursday, corresponding to 2d August 1990, in a way that took the whole world by surprise, when the Iraqi forces stormed the brotherly state of Kuwait in the most vile aggression known to the Arab nation in its modern history which made the brotherly people of Kuwait homeless and caused them great suffering. 
While expressing its deep displeasure at the aggression to which the state of Kuwait, a sisterly neighbor was subjected, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia declares its categorical rejection of all the measures and declarations that followed that aggression, which were rejected by all the statements issued by Arab leaderships, the Arab League, the Islamic Conference organization and the Gulf Cooperation Council, as well as all Arab and international bodies and organizations.
 
Sheik's Return Demanded
The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia reaffirms its demand that the situation must be returned to what it was before the Iraqi storming, and the return of the ruling family led by Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of the state of Kuwait, and his Government. We are hoping that the emergency Arab summit which was called by the President Mohammad Hosni Mubarak of the sisterly Egypt Arab Republic would lead to results that would realize the Arab nation's hopes and bolster its march toward solidarity and unity of word.
Oh brothers, that regretful event came after Iraq's massing of huge forces on the borders of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. In front of these bitter realities and out of the eagerness of the kingdom for the safety of its territory and the protection of its vital and economic constituents, our wish to strengthen its defense potential and increase the level of training of its armed forces and out of the eagerness of the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to side with peace and non-recourse to force to solve disputes, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia expressed its wish for the participation of fraternal Arab forces and other friendly forces.
Thus the Government of the U.S.A. and the British Government took the initiative, on the basis of the relations of friendship which link the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and these states, to send air and land forces in order to back the Saudi armed forces in performing its duty to defend the homeland and the citizens against any aggression with the complete emphasis that this measure is not addressed to anybody but is only for a purely defensive aim imposed by the current circumstances faced by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
It is worth mentioning here that the forces which will participate in the joint training between them and the Saudi armed forces will be present temporarily in the Kingdom's territory and will leave it immediately when the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia wishes so.
