HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
As U.S. Forces Build, a Military Stalemate Shapes Up

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
As American forces pour into Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf, there are signs that a military stalemate between Iraq and the United States is rapidly developing.
Some American military planners are reported to have expressed concern that the Iraqis might attack in the next few weeks before the American force is fully deployed. But with each passing hour the danger that a shooting war will break out becomes less acute. Military experts with long experience in the Middle East believe that if President Saddam Hussein ever entertained hopes of attacking Saudi Arabia, as he did Kuwait, his chance is now lost. At the same time, the United States is constrained to adopt a defensive stance. 
Both sides have some high cards to play, but most entail risks that are probably unacceptable. Even Iraq's immense armored force of 5,500 tanks no longer seems capable of overwhelming Saudi Arabia in a quick sweep now that American air power can be brought to bear.
Hermann F. Eilts, who has served as United States Ambassador in both Saudi Arabia and Egypt and as a deputy commandant of the Army War College, believes that although the Iraqi armored forces are well trained and eager to fight, they would soon find themselves in trouble if they were to push across the Saudi frontier.
 
Two Options for Tanks
Any attack Iraq might mount would depend primarily on its armored forces, thrusting south from occupied Kuwait. The tanks, along with armored personnel carriers, self-propelled artillery and supporting vehicles, would have two options: they could sweep along the coast of the Persian Gulf toward Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, or they could head south across the desert to the Saudi capital of Riyadh.
Mr. Eilts said the coastal route is difficult for heavy vehicles. Much of the area is soft sand covered with ''sabkha'' - a brittle crust consisting mostly of salt. Even a jeep can break through this crust, he said, and getting a vehicle moving again takes time and effort.
An inland invasion route over packed desert sand would provide surer footing for a mechanized force, but a large column of armor would have no refuge or cover from American aircraft. Mr. Eilts, chairman of the department of international relations at Boston University, added that ''the Iraqis would put up a spirited and effective fight, but American aircraft would inflict very heavy casualties on them.''
President Hussein is certainly aware of this and in the view of many Western military analysts he is unlikely to risk destruction of his most potent land force. Restraints on the U.S. The blockade by American warships announced yesterday, coupled with international sanctions, must also influence President Hussein. Iraq's only access to the sea through the Persian Gulf is a 20-mile stretch of beach, and even when Kuwait's coast is included as Iraqi territory, the distance involved could be easily dominated by the American fleet.
But United States forces are also subject to important restraints.
Even the United States blockade of Iraqi oil exports is a double-edged sword. The measure is certain to hurt the Iraqi economy but it has already reduced global oil supplies and will probably weaken the American economy. Some experts believe that the United States has unnecessarily restricted the retaliatory arsenal it might have brought to bear on Iraq.
Frank Gaffney, a former Pentagon official now at the Washington-based Center for Security Policy, believes that the Bush Administration should not have barred production of a new ''binary'' chemical-warfare weapon, for example. A binary shell, bomb or rocket contains two ingredients that are relatively harmless when kept apart but when combined create a cloud of lethal nerve gas. The United States Navy does not permit chemical weapons aboard its aircraft carriers because of the hazard of accidental exposure of the crew. But the relative safety of binary chemical warheads would make them acceptable for use on carrier-borne aircraft.
 
A Powerful Deterrent
''Any aggressor aware that United States forces possessed a credible chemical-warfare arsenal, including binary warheads, would be powerfully deterred from using chemical weapons himself,'' Mr. Gaffney said.
But most military analysts believe that if the United States were even to threaten to use poison gas or nuclear weapons, world opinion, which now strongly supports Washington, would turn against this country. ''We might gain a military chip but lose the political war,'' a Western diplomat said.
By contrast, Iraq has already lost so much international sympathy that there is little more to be jeopardized, and Baghdad, in extreme circumstances, might be tempted to use poison gas or threaten foreign hostages.
Still, Western experts with experience in Iraq regard President Hussein as ruthless and calculating, but neither impulsive nor mad. In a purely military sense, he has achieved a resounding victory by annexing Kuwait, and few observers give the United States much chance of dislodging him. This may be enough for him, some suggest.

HEADLINE: Quayle Warns Haiti to Hold Fair Election

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle warned Haitian leaders today that the United States would cut off economic aid to this Caribbean nation if general elections scheduled for November are not free and fair.
''If you are going to have a country that is not democratic and not respectful of human rights, they are not going to be recipients of the American taxpayers' money,'' Mr. Quayle told reporters before he met today with Haiti's interim President, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot. ''I will be talking to them about that very clearly.'' 
The Vice President later spoke to a group of senior Haitian military officers and warned them bluntly of the consequences of military involvement in any effort to upset the elections.
Mr. Quayle told the officers, ''My message is: no coup, no murders, no threats, and instead, free and fair elections that will bring honor to the brave people of Haiti.'' He received only lukewarm applause.
 
In Power Since March
Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot came to power in March after Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the head of what had been Haiti's military Government, fled the country.
General Avril had come to power 18 months earlier in a coup. As interim President, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's chief responsibility is planning for this fall's election.
The United States will supply about $60 million in aid this year to Haiti, the poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere. Mr. Quayle said today that the United States was prepared to offer $3 million to Haiti's Electoral Council to help insure a fair election.
Last month, Haiti asked the United Nations to send nearly 300 civilian officials to supervise the balloting and about 40 military officers to insure that the country's poorly disciplined armed forces maintain law and order during the campaign. The United States and other Western nations have responded enthusiastically to the Haitian request.
 
Duvalier Supporters Feared
Haitian officials also want the election monitors to keep a close watch on the activities of groups still loyal to the nation's former dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier.
Port-au-Prince, the nation's capital, was rocked by strikes last month to protest the return from exile of two former Government officials who were linked with political violence and torture during the Duvalier regime.
Mr. Quayle is the highest-ranking American official to visit Haiti in more than 30 years, and American officials traveling with the Vice President said his presence here was intended to make clear the Bush Administration's concern for free elections.
''Haiti and Cuba are the last holdouts on democracy in this hemisphere,'' Mr. Quayle said at a news conference aboard a Government jet en route to Port-au-Prince. He said he would urge President Pascal-Trouillot to bring the independent election observers to Haiti as quickly as possible.
''One of the things that I'll be talking to President Trouillot about is trying to get observers in early,'' Mr. Quayle said. ''Time is of the essence.''

HEADLINE: Oil-Price Rise Poses a Threat For the Region

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
While the New York region is proportionally less dependent on energy than other parts of the country, the higher oil prices that have prevailed since Iraq invaded Kuwait endanger a local economy that is already among the frailest in the nation.
''No doubt about it, the New York City region is in recession right now, and this is coming at a very bad time,'' said Robert A. Dye, director of state forecasting for the WEFA group, a forecasting organization in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, said gasoline prices had already jumped about eight cents a gallon in the state. But this fall and winter, the cost of heating oil could be more worrisome, especially in New York State, where more than half the houses use it. Retail prices have also gone up about eight cents a gallon, and wholesale prices have soared to about 25 cents, Mr. Kessel said yesterday, shortly before several major oil companies agreed to decrease or freeze the prices that they charge retailers. 
No one predicts the kind of economic adversity produced in the region in 1973, when oil prices began a 10-fold rise and shortages resulted in sinews of cars at the pumps.
 
More Dependence on People
Then as now, the region's dense population and development patterns have led to more mass transit use than in other parts of the country. And over the last few decades many of the factories that would be hardest hit by oil prices have been closed - with a loss since the end of 1979 of 326,000 jobs -and been replaced by service industries that largely depend on people, not power.
There has also been a shift to more efficient cars and natural gas. Still, the oil-price surge comes as the region is suffering its first drop in jobs since 1982.
If oil prices remain in the range of $25 a barrel they would likely lead to a host of adversities, perhaps including a further drop in consumer spending that could drag the economy down even more, as well as higher transit and taxi fares and tolls. Utility bills might eventually rise $10 a month or more for a typical customer, according to one estimate.
The deepening weakness in the region was apparent in a report issued last week by the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, which found that New York and northeastern New Jersey lost 13,000 jobs in the first five months of this year.
 
Limit on Inflation
One of the few bright spots, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, were consumer prices, which had shot up in the first quarter of 1990 but moderated in the second. Should oil prices stay high, inflationary pressures would resume, although Mr. Ehrenhalt said the extent of those pressures would be limited by consumer resistance.
Consumer spending in the region was drooping even before the 1987 stock market plunge that serves as a watershed for the boom of the 1980's. Based on an analysis of what happened in 1973-74, Mr. Dye said he estimated that the nearly 50 percent increase in the price of oil that has already occurred could decrease spending on durable goods like cars and appliances by 10 percent, with spending on nondurable goods like clothing dropping less.
As a result, he said, people who depend on discretionary spending, like restaurant workers, ''would feel the pinch.''
Still, the region enjoys some insulation from an energy-price jolt. In a study in 1974, the Regional Plan Association concluded that the region had 9.7 percent of the nation's population but used 6.6 percent of the its energy. Since then, more factory jobs have been lost and mass transit riders gained, although motor vehicles registration has also risen sharply and the construction boom of the last decade has added energy-gulping skyscrapers in the city and sprawl in the suburbs.
 
Rise of Natural Gas
Current estimates of regional energy use are difficult to obtain, if they exist at all, but there appears to have been not only a rise in consumption but also a significant shift to natural gas, which is cheaper, at least so far, and largely produced domestically, although not in the region.
Daniel J. Walden, director of public informaton for Consolidated Edison in New York, said that in 1970, the utility derived 57 percent of its kilowatt hours from oil, 20 percent from coal, 19 percent from natural gas and 4 percent from nuclear reactors. Now, 50 percent is from natural gas, 33 percent from oil and 17 percent from nuclear reactors.
Also, the number of the utility's customers heating homes with gas rose from 129,000 in 1970 to 144,000 in 1980 to 180,000 in 1989.
''The gas companies, including us, have become more aggressive,'' Mr. Walden said.
It is far from clear whether oil prices will stay high or go higher, and in any case the impact of energy costs on the region is complicated and subject to much debate.
For example, it might seem that higher prices at gas pumps would lead to more people riding commuter trains, subways and buses. But Mortimer L. Downey, chief financial officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said any ridership gains would, at least in the short run, be more than offset by higher gas and electricity prices that the agency would have to absorb to run its vehicles.
 
Role in Boom
That might contribute to the need for a fare increase, which in turn might push ridership back down.
And while some experts emphasized the region's shift to a service economy, which typically uses less energy than an industrial one, Vincent Tese, the New York State Commissioner of Economic Development, noted that right now the state's service sector was ''under stress'' while manufacturing was ''holding its own.''
James W. Hughes, professor of urban planning and policy development at Rutgers, noted that the region's boom in the last decade had coincided with a drop in energy prices. And he said that was the only positive economic force left in the region - until now.
A danger of higher energy prices, he said, was that the region would send a lot of its capital to the oil-producing parts of the country and the world, as it did during the steeper price surges of the 1970's, Then again, Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, said that although higher energy costs would reinforce the local downturn, some capital might flow back if people in energy-rich areas choose to invest in the city.
Some economists also said the city might gain a competitive advantage, at least over its suburbs, if as in the 1970's higher gas prices help convince people to move closer to their downtown jobs.
But even if the city or the region somehow avoid most of the direct trauma of higher energy costs, they could still be dragged down if the national economy slides into recession because of them.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Seeking to Buy Aqueduct Track

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 9

 BODY:
New York State is exploring the sale of Aqueduct Race Track in Queens to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would close the track and use the land to expand Kennedy International Airport, state officials said today.
Negotiations between the New York Racing Association and the authority are preliminary, and the two sides are not close to agreeing on a price, the officials said.
One official, who asked not to be identified, said the prices discussed had ranged from $100 million to $200 million for the 203-acre site in Ozone Park, across the Belt Parkway from the airport. 
The racing association was said to be interested in selling Aqueduct and using the proceeds to upgrade Belmont Race Track in Elmont, L.I. The association now operates Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga, the three major thoroughbred race tracks in New York. Belmont would be renovated to accommodate year-round racing, which is now run only at Aqueduct, under the association's plan.
 
A 'Realistic Proposition'
The Port Authority has been looking for land to expand Kennedy, and Aqueduct would be a logical place, said Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development. The expansion might include new cargo services or warehouses, but would not involve lengthening runways, he said.
''It's a realistic proposition,'' he said. But, he added that while both sides were interested, they appeared far apart on price, partly because the Port Authority was assessing the site's potential as if it were vacant land.
''To N.Y.R.A., Aqueduct is an improved asset, while to the Port Authority it's a less than improved asset,'' Mr. Tese said.
A spokesman for the racing association, Steven Schwartz, said he would not comment on any Aqueduct negotiations, which were first reported today in The Daily News. Asked whether the association, a nonprofit corporation created by the state in 1959 to operate thoroughbred racing, would agree to sell if the Port Authority came up with a reasonable offer, he said, ''That's speculation, and we'd rather not respond to that.''
 
'Too Early to Tell'
Hugh O'Neill, the assistant executive director of the Port Authority, confirmed that his agency was interested in the site for possible expansion of cargo services and other airport operations, but he said it was ''too early to tell'' whether the site would actually be bought.
''It just hasn't gotten to the point where they have put out a firm asking price or we have put out an offer,'' Mr. O'Neill said.
Mr. Tese said a memorandum on the possible sale had been prepared for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whose backing would be essential to a deal. The Governor, speaking to reporters in Queens today, said he would not say what he thought about the idea until he saw some specifics.
''Did anybody say there were numbers?'' Mr. Cuomo asked. ''Didn't they say there were no numbers? How could I favor a deal without numbers?''
Aside from the tracks at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga, thoroughbred racing is also held at the Finger Lakes track in Canandaigua, and is to resume within a few years at Tioga Downs near Binghamton.

The Oil Jolt

Companies

HEADLINE: Oil Rise Helps Soviets, Hurts East Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The sharp rise in oil prices resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will give a windfall to the Soviet Union, the world's leading oil producer, but create havoc for the fragile economies of Eastern Europe, which depend heavily on imported oil.
If the prices stick, they will bring a much-needed increase in hard-currency earnings to the Soviet Union, and help Moscow's hard-pressed leaders provide more consumer goods to the restive Soviet public.
But for Hungary, Poland and other Eastern European countries, the spike in oil prices will make their road to a market economy more treacherous, aggravating their debt crises, feeding public discontent about price increases, and making times still harder for their obsolete, energy-guzzling industries.
 
'Don't Have the Money'
''An increase in oil prices could be salvation for the Soviet Union,'' said Jan Stankowsky, an expert on Eastern European trade at the Institute for Comparative Economic Studies in Vienna. ''On the other hand, the present situation could be a tragedy for the smaller Eastern European countries. They don't have the money to pay the present world market price for oil.'' 
The Soviet Union, which produces 12 million barrels of oil a day - twice as much as Saudi Arabia and a sixth of world output - exports 20 percent of it. Half goes to the West and the rest to Eastern Europe. Czechoslovakia gets 98 percent of its oil from the Soviet Union, and Poland 93 percent.
The Soviet Union earned about $20 billion in hard currency from oil exports last year - 40 percent of its hard-currency earnings.
It is not clear how large the boon to the Soviet Union will be. Kommersant, a Moscow-based business newspaper, estimated this week that the jump in oil prices from $16 a barrel before the Iraqi invasion to almost $26 a barrel could increase Soviet hard-currency revenues by $750 million by the end of the year.
But Gary N. Ross, president of consulting services at the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Associates, said the windfall for the Russians could be even greater. Since they export 1.3 million barrels a day to the West, the price rise could mean $13 million additional a day, or almost $400 million extra a month.
 
New System in the East
For Eastern European countries the story is different, because on Jan. 1 these former Soviet satellites are to begin paying for their Soviet oil in hard currency, and with the price pegged to world market rates. This will replace the system under which Moscow allowed Soviet bloc members to buy oil at below-market prices.
''The Soviet Union was going to gain something from this, and now they are going to gain even more,'' said Joseph P. Tragert, an economist with PlanEcon, a Washington-based consulting group.
Eastern European officials say they would have had trouble buying oil at $16 a barrel, let alone at $27. ''This will be our oil shock, and we will have to absorb it 100 percent,'' said Mr. Lang, the Hungarian economist who noted that the Communist world had sought, with some success, to insulate itself from the 1970's oil shocks.
Petroleum industry experts say that despite the higher prices, the Soviet Union will not be able to increase production quickly enough to help offset the worldwide shortages of four million barrels a day caused by the international boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Indeed, the Soviet Union has been struggling to prevent a further decline in production, down about 5 percent this year after dropping 3 percent last year.
 
'Seems to Be Some Unrest'
''Even if they wanted to increase production, they couldn't do so,'' said Coby van der Linde, an expert on Soviet oil at the Oxford Institute for Energy Research in Britain. ''There is a shortage of oilfield equipment. These seems to be some unrest in the oilfields. The fields are not well maintained and many are getting old.''
Oil analysts say the Soviet Union has reduced investment in the oil industry, which long absorbed 40 percent of the nation's industrial investment.
''They cannot change their investment policy within one or two weeks,'' said Ulrich Weissenburger, an expert on the Soviet economy at the German Institute for the Economy in West Berlin. ''Maybe if higher prices remain for a long period they will change their policy. But the priority of Soviet officials right now is to improve the situation in consumer goods.''
The key to future Soviet oil development, many industry officials say, is Western cooperation. Elf-Aquitaine, France's largest oil company, has agreed to explore for oil on a 13,500-square-mile site north of the Caspian Sea. Elf would obtain a percentage, now being negotiated, of any oil produced. The Chevron Corporation is talking with Soviet officials about developing a large field in western Kazakhstan.
 
Disputes Over Control
''The potential in the Soviet Union, especially in Russia, is huge,'' said Mari Buglass, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman in London. But she said that Western companies were hesitant to push ahead with cooperative deals there because so much was uncertain in that country. For example, Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Republic, says his republic controls its own oil resources, while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev likes to think they are controlled by the nation.
''Western oil companies want to know whether they will earn their money back and whom they will be dealing with,'' said Ms. Buglass. ''That's the only thing holding Western companies back.''
Because Soviet oil output is down and because the country is desperate for hard currency, Moscow last month suddenly cut back oil shipments to Hungary and Czechoskovakia by 13 percent. It diverted some of that oil to the West. This has forced these two countries to buy oil at world market prices, with Hungary agreeing to buy about two million barrels from Algeria and Libya, using a long-closed pipeline to the Adriatic. Poland agreed to buy seven million barrels from Iraq.
 
Rise in Inflation Feared
The Soviet cutback has caused Czechoslovakia to raise gasoline prices by 50 percent and has crippled the nation's chemical industry. Jan Klacek, an economist with the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, estimates that buying oil at world prices would increase inflation in his nation by more than 5 percent, and he said it could cause a decline in industrial production of up to 2 percent.
''This could knock the already-weak economies of Eastern Europe into a tailspin,'' said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs and a former Assistant Secretary of State. ''They are the biggest losers from this.''
The big question for cash-strapped Eastern European nations is where they will obtain the hard currency to buy the more expensive oil. Many economists say that because Poland and Hungary have the region's worst debt problems they will be hardest hit.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How Hussein Miscalculated

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
The crisis in the Persian Gulf struck at a time when demand for oil was weakening and prices sagging. In fact, Saddam Hussein's decision to gobble up Kuwait was driven by his need to shore up Iraq's failing economy, undermined by the long war with Iran. So he has put his unemployed, million-man army back to work, both to grab his neighbor's oilfields and refineries and also to panic the world oil market into a steep run-up in price. The rising inflow of foreign money, he calculated, would strengthen his bid for dominance of the Arab world.
But he miscalculated. The shock of his invasion of Kuwait did kick off panic buying that sent the price of crude soaring above $28 a barrel - but only days later that panic buying stopped and prices fell back. The price of North Sea oil for September delivery fell $1.75, to $24.75 a barrel, on Wednesday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange that day West Texas crude for delivery in September dropped $2.35, to $25.96 a barrel. 
One reason for the easing of panic buying is that when Iraq invaded Kuwait last week oil inventories were high. And unlike oil crises in 1973 and 1979, motorists have not rushed into lines to ''top out'' fuel tanks. Instead, they have complained about ''price gouging'' by the oil companies. The White House called on the companies for restraint, and they are indicating they will cooperate.
Another reason why panic buying quickly exhausted itself this time was the realization that there is plenty of spare oil-production capacity, in Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America, in Africa, the North Sea and in Saudi Arabia and the gulf.
The other oil producers, however, are not rushing to expand output. Venezuela, according to Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a leading authority on the world oil market, has spare capacity of 600,000 to 700,000 barrels a day; President Carlos Andres Perez said Venezuela could increase its output by up to 500,000 a day but wanted to do it in concert with other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Other members of OPEC could readily expand output to make up for all of the blocked Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Spare OPEC capacity is estimated at 3.3 million to 3.7 million barrels a day. But the Saudis and other OPEC members appear to prefer to raise output only enough to make up for part of the cut-off oil, to ''ratchet up'' oil prices to the mid $20's range. And in exchange for their cooperation, the Saudis and others are likely to seek benefits from the United States.
The United States could bring greater pressure on other oil producers by drawing down some of the 575,000 barrels in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but seems reluctant to do so. Some Administration officials have been talking of the importance of maintaining ''free markets'' and avoiding 1970's-style price controls.
To check Mr. Hussein's aggression, however, the Administration is leaning hard on its allies to cut off Iraq's oil shipments. Turkey, a NATO member, has shut the pipeline that carries oil from Iraq to the Mediterranean port of Yumurtalik. But Turkey wants to be paid $2 billion to make up for the losses it says are involved. Even without the closing of that pipeline or the one that runs through Saudi Arabia to Yanbu on the Red Sea, just a small number of United States naval vessels can seal off Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil shipments.
Indeed, Iraq's oil exports have effectively been shut off already. No tankers are loading at any of their three ports. And tanker rates have fallen sharply as owners have stopped sending ships to the gulf, following the United Nations resolution to impose sanctions against Iraq. Saddam Hussein miscalculated in underestimating the reaction against him in the U.N. and the solidifying effect of United States-Soviet cooperation with the end of the cold war. Japanese support for the oil embargo was another breakthrough.
But, except for Britain, the United States has thus far been left by its NATO allies to carry the military burden in Saudi Arabia, reducing the likelihood of a pull-back by Mr. Hussein. He has declared that Iraq cannot suffer the ''humiliation'' of a withdrawal. Nevertheless, if the Iraqi dictator cannot ship his oil out, his country's feeble economy will suffer a crushing blow and he could become a victim of his own army.
The oil shock of 1990 is shaping up as far less damaging to the West than the shocks of the 70's, and it will stay so if the United States gets the support it needs from its allies.
With the American economy growing sluggishly and world demand for oil soft, the inflationary impact is far less ominous than it was in the early or late 1970's. There is now no need for Federal Reserve monetary tightening - and good reason to avoid it, lest the economy be toppled into recession.
A deal with Congress to reduce the budget deficit, which President Bush still insists he wants, would enable the Fed to move interest rates down and keep the economy moving forward. This, as the President stresses, would also provide the United States with the additional resources it needs in this time of acute international tensions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Turnaround Manager To Head Jos. A. Bank

 BODY:
Timothy F. Finley, a turnaround manager, has been named president and chief executive of Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc., which operates 40 retail clothing stores throughout the United States and is known for its American-made men's suits.
Mr. Finley, 47, formed the Finley Group in 1985 to provide management to troubled companies. His main responsibilities at Jos. A. Bank will be to cut its debt from a leveraged buyout that was financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1988. The company, based in Baltimore, went private in the buyout. 
Jos. A. Bank, which he called a ''middle-priced Brooks Brothers,'' has a substantial mail-order catalogue sales operation. It plans to expand in the Northeast, where it has stores in Stamford, Conn., and Summit, N.J., but none in New York.
Mr. Finley described himself as ''a rather unstructured, fancy-free kind of guy who's not great at running a company in the long term.''
Eight associates share the management responsibilities of the Finley Group. Mr. Finley's average stay at a company is one to two years.
Mr. Finley has been president for two years of Baddour Inc., a 200-store chain in Memphis that operates under the name Freds Super Discount Store. It had $250 million in revenues last year.
He was chief operating officer of Castleberry Foods, a family-owned canned-meat company based in Augusta, Ga., from 1986 to 1988. Mr. Finley was an executive vice president of Cannon Mills, a leading towel maker based in Kannapolis, N.C., from 1981 to 1985. Before that, he was a partner at the Charlotte, N.C., office of the accounting firm Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, which has since merged with Touche Ross to form Deloitte & Touche.
''There is a general slowdown in the economy and the apparel industry that has contributed to the problems at Jos. A. Bank,'' Mr. Finley said.
Mr. Finley succeeds David R. Waters, 59, who resigned after two years to begin his own consulting business. Mr. Waters will continue on the company's board.
Jos. A. Bank had revenues last year of $150 million. The company, which has 1,700 employees, has corporate headquarters and three manufacturing centers in Baltimore.
Mr. Finley was graduated from Ohio University with a degree in commerce and now lives in Charlotte, N.C., with his wife, Dolly. They have a daughter.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Incentives On Ford Models

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said it would offer four-year loans at 4.8 percent on selected car lines and $1,000 cash rebates on others. The low financing and rebates end on Sept. 26, the date of the official introduction of Ford's 1991 models. The 1991 Escort and the Ford Explorer are in showrooms and are exempt.
Ford will offer the 48-month financing at a 4.8 percent interest rate through the Ford Motor Credit Company. Most other 48-month loans through Ford Credit have a 7.9 percent rate. Vehicles eligible for the cut rate are the Taurus and Thunderbird and the Lincoln-Mercury Sable and Cougar. Cash rebates on Ford and Lincoln-Mercury vehicles range from $600 on the Aerostar mini-van to $2,000 on the Lincoln Mark VII.

HEADLINE: Dow, Rising For 2d Day, Ends Up 24.01

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 24.01 points to 2,758.91. Favorable results of the Treasury's 30-year bond auction produced a late rally after stocks had drifted in light trading most of the day.
Investors remain cautious, and most refrained from making any sizable commitments. Uncertainty over developments in the bond market, concern over an already-weak economy and fear that news from the Middle East could again send oil prices up, cast a pall over the market most of the day. 
Late in the session prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly after the Government completed its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding with the successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds at an average yield of 8.87 percent, compared with 8.84 percent at the last refunding on May 11.
That provided the impetus for yesterday's rally in equities, sending the Dow up as much as 30 points late in the day. Having fallen 893.41 points yesterday, the Nikkei stock index in Tokyo continued to drop today, showing a decline of 286.18 points, or 1.04 percent, to 27,329.55, the lowest close of 1990. During today's session the index fell as low as 27,168.23, an intra-day low for the year, Volume Edges Up The ratio between advances and declines on the New York Stock Exchange was fairly close yesterday, with a slight edge to decliners. Volume for the day was 155.8 million. The S.& P. 500-stock index was up 1.59 points, to 339.94. The Nasdaq index of over-the-counter issues rose 5.25 points, to 412.98. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.46, to 341.49 Traders yesterday were not only focused on Middle Eastern developments, but were also awaiting results of the Treasury's refunding. The long bond is the measure by which most long-term interest rates are set. And with the poor auctions of three- and 10-year notes already behind, there was apprehension over the auction.
William M. LeFevre, senior vice president of market strategy for Advest Inc. of Hartford said the ability to sell the new 30-year Treasury bond yesterday after poor results from the notes' auctions stabilized the bond market and opened the road for the Federal Reserve Bank to ease short-term maturities.
According to Birinyi Associates Inc, which tracks program trading, there were only three buy progams yesterday. They occurred between 1 P.M. and 3:07 P.M. when the Dow rose 27.97 points. That was about the time results of the Treasury's bond auction were becoming known.
While few traders were willing to risk a run in the market yesterday after what has thus far been a volatile week, many stocks drew investor interest. The stock of Continenal Airlines Holdings rose by 1 3/4, to close at 6 1/4, on news that Frank Lorenzo was stepping down as chairman and that the Scandinavian Airlines Systems would be increasing its stake in Continental to 16.8 percent.
 
Disney Advances
The Walt Disney Company , rose 1 3/4, to 109 3/4. Disney stock, like other entertainment shares, was hurt by the recent rise in oil prices, which many thought would hurt attendance at leisure activities, but oil prices have since backed off. Disney's publishing divison is starting a new magazine for children in October. CBS Inc., another entertainment stock, rose 2 3/4, to 178 3/4.
Shares of MBIA Inc., an insurer of municipal bonds, rose 7/8, to 38 7/8 after reporting higher second-quarter and six-month earnings.
Sears, Roebuck & Company saw its stock rise 7/8, to 30 1/2, after its chairman, Edward A. Brennan, reasserted control over the merchandising group this week. Market speculation is that the move may be an admission by the company that its current approach to retailing is not working.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Securities Rebound

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly yesterday after the Government's successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds, the last of its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding sales this week.
The unexpectedly good reception accorded the new benchmark long bonds contrasted sharply with the lack of investor interest in the three- and 10-year notes auctioned on Tuesday and Wednesday. The bond auction was a success, dealers said, because the recent surge in oil prices caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait had sharply eroded the prices of longer-term securities, which are normally more vulnerable to inflation than shorter issues. The resultant rise in yield on the longer issues stimulated investor interest. 
But the successful distribution of the bonds to retail investors was not without cost to the Treasury. The average yield on the 8.75 percent bonds was 8.87 percent, compared with 8.84 percent at the last refunding on May 11. Still, interest rates were substantially higher a year ago, with the bonds auctioned on May 11, 1989, yielding 9.11 percent.
Given the higher yield and the 8.75 percent coupon, the new bonds in effect sold for $9,874.70 for each of the $10,000 units.
No sooner did the Treasury report the auction results at 2:30 P.M., Eastern daylight time, than prices of most Government securities moved up, led by the longer maturities. Similarly, the stock market, which had also been marking time awaiting the auction results, began to rise.
 
Late Surge in Prices
The outstanding long bonds, for example, were slightly higher in price before the auction results were announced and then began to rise sharply. Late in the session, the old benchmark long bonds, which also carry a 8.75 percent coupon, were being offered at 99 28/32, up 21/32 on the day, as the yield fell to 8.76 percent from 8.82 percent the day before.
Meanwhile, the $10.5 billion of new long notes that were auctioned Wednesday at an average yield of 8.77 percent were still trading on a when-issued basis but at a yield of 8.64 percent. The $11.5 billion in three-year notes sold Tuesday at an average yield of 8.10 percent were trading at a yield of 8.09 percent.
''The auction of the new long bonds was as good as the other two sales were terrible,'' said Ward McCarthy, partner in Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, Princeton, N. J. ''In part, the market's response to the auction was in effect a sigh of relief that the quarterly refunding sales were over, given the beating the long end of the market has taken since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait a week ago.''
A large amount of the three-year notes from Tuesday's auction and a smaller but still sizable amount of the 10-year notes sold Wednesday were still on the shelves yesterday of the dealers who absorbed the bulk of the sale.
The sales of shorter issues had been affected largely by the climate of fear caused by the Middle East crisis, dealers said, and while the climate has not changed significantly, although oil prices have eased somewhat, the higher yields on the long issue attracted buyers. Mr. McCarthy said domestic and foreign investors had placed sizable orders for the 30-year bonds.
''We can't at this time confirm the rumors about the strong Japanese interest in the long bonds,'' he continued, ''but with yields near the 9 percent level, it would not take much to attract buyers from whatever source.''
 
Lack of Retail Interest
Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, said that ''despite the lack of retail interest in the 10-year notes at the auction, once their prices fell and yields rose in the secondary market the buyers materialized.
''But, surprisingly,'' he said, ''the usually popular three-year notes remain somewhat of a sticky issue.''
One reason for the good reception for the new long bonds, Mr. Brusca said, was that the surge in oil prices set off by the Iraqi invasion caused investors to flee earlier this week from the longer Treasury maturities. But, he said, ''when the statistics of the auction, namely, the 'tail' was broadcast, the buyers came rushing back in.''
The auction tail, the spread between the low bid, 8.86 percent, and the average, 8.87 percent, was quite normal. By contrast, the tail on the sale of the 10-year notes was 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point and the widest since May 1980.
Another sign of the success of the sale was that the Treasury only had to accept 13 percent of the low bids. Still another was that almost $26 billion in bids were received for the $10.25 billion issue.
Also yesterday, the Treasury auctioned $10 billion of 36-day cash management bills sold in units of $1 million. The bills went at an average discount rate of 7.79 percent, a basis point between the highest and lowest bids. Roughly 21 percent of the low bids were accepted.
Discount rates on Treasury bills were narrowly mixed yesterday. The rate on the 90-day bills rose 3 basis points, at 7.29 percent, and the one-year bills slipped 2 basis points, to 7.19 percent.
The Federal Reserve once again added $2.5 billion of reserves to the banking system to meet seasonal and other technical needs. Dealers said the Fed's piecemeal additions of reserves this week was probably aimed at avoiding any misinterpretation that its actions represented an easing of credit or policy change. In any event, the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans was a bit tight at 8 1/16 percent before and after the Fed's midday intervention.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of new 30-year bonds:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed in the U.S., Lower Abroad; Gold Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance in United States trading yesterday after moving mostly lower in earlier dealings abroad. Gold prices gained. Interest in the dollar as a safe investment haven waned in the absence of fresh Middle East hostility, currency dealers said. 
Earlier this week, as outcry over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait intensified, investors scrambled to buy dollars. Investors typically turn to dollars in times of political and economic uncertainty.
 
Oil Prices Retreat
A retreat in oil prices from the lofty levels reached earlier this week also paved the way for an end to the dollar-buying binge. World oil transactions are conducted in dollars, and a rapid run-up in petroleum prices had increased demand for dollars. But on Thursday oil prices fell in the United States for a second straight session.
The dollar also was weighed down by concerns about the economy's health in the United States. There has been widespread speculation that the Federal Reserve will soon try to revive the faltering economy by pushing down interest rates. Lower rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to curb demand for dollars.
In Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar fell to 149.68 Japanese yen at the close, from 150.00 Wednesday. Later in London, it rose to 149.80. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 149.81, down from 149.90 late Wednesday.
The dollar strengthened against the British pound in New York trading after weakening in London. A pound fetched $1.8680 late in New York, compared with $1.86885 late Wednesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8720, from $1.8660 late Wednesday.
 
Other Late Rates in New York
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.5965 German marks, up from 1.5920; 1.3435 Swiss francs, down from 1.3380; 5.3510 French francs, down from 5.3365; 1,168.50 Italian lire, up from 1,165.00, and 1.14695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14785.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $385.80 an ounce, up $2.60 from Wednesday's settlement. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $385.60, $2.90 higher than Wednesday's late bid.
Gold rose in London to $385.25 an ounce, from $382.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the price rose to $385.00, up from $384.35 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.52 an ounce to $384.17.

HEADLINE: Net Up 24.6% At Wal-Mart

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BENTONVILLE, Ark., Aug. 9

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported today that it had a 24.6 percent gain in its second-quarter profit as revenue also increased by the same rate.
The fast-growing discounter, based in Bentonville, Ark., earned $272.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the three months ended July 31, compared with $219 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue grew to $7.6 billion from $6.1 billion in the period.
David Glass, the company's president and chief executive, credited the company's merchandising strategy for producing the profit improvement. But he said that forecasts for the second half of the year ''are characterized by anticipated economic uncertainty.''
Wal-Mart has bucked the slowing trend in the retail industry this year and has consistently outperformed its competitors. The discounter might pass Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation this year in annual sales volume, industry analysts say. Sears and K Mart are the nation's first- and second-ranking retailers, respectively.
Wal-Mart opened two new distribution centers and completed a third during the second quarter, resulting in an addition of more than three million square feet of distribution space. It also opened 18 Wal-Mart stores and 4 Sam's Wholesale Clubs.
Wal-Mart's stock rose 37.5 cents today, to $30.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF
ARAB VOTE TO SEND TROOPS TO HELP SAUDIS; BOYCOTT OF IRAQI OIL IS REPORTED NEAR 100%;
Baghdad Isolated

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Arab countries moved tonight to confront Iraq's thrust into Kuwait by voting to send troops to Saudi Arabia, with only Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization openly backing the isolated Iraqis in the crucial decision.
It was unclear tonight which Arab countries would actually send soldiers in response to a resolution pressed by Egypt and Saudi Arabia at the hastily called meeting. It calls for the Arab states to answer appeals by Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states for Arab soldiers to help defend against a possible invasion by Baghdad.
When the forces would be sent was also unclear, and no numbers on troops were offered, although it was expected that Egypt would take the leading role, probably supported by Morocco.
 
Only 12 of 21 in Favor
Twelve of the 21 members of the Arab League voted in support of the seven-point resolution. 
''We have decided to respond to the request by Saudi Arabia and other gulf states to deploy Arab forces to support the armed forces there to defend its lands and its regional security against any foreign attack,'' the resolution stated. It did not specify whether the Arab troops would officially join a multinational force or stand apart.
King Hussein of Jordan, perhaps under the greatest conflicting pressures, took an equivocal position, voting to approve the resolution ''with reservations.''
In apparent anticipation of the vote, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq broadcast his point of view on the airwaves this evening as the Arab League met in a tense, closed session. He issued an emotional call for the Arab masses to rise against foreign intervention and the ''humiliation'' of Muslim shrines in Saudi Arabia.
 
Calls for 'Holy War'
Urging a ''holy war,'' President Hussein said in the statement, ''Your brothers in Iraq are determined to continue jihad without any hesitation or retreat and without any fear from the foreigner's power.'' [Excerpts, page 4.] The Arab League vote was a victory for backstage American diplomacy, intensified by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's visits early this week with Arab leaders, to achieve what is called here an ''Arab face'' to lend legitimacy to the deployment of American troops in the Saudi kingdom.
There were large demonstrations in Jordan and Yemen today supporting Iraq and opposing the American presence. Mr. Hussein's efforts to set poor, frustrated Arabs against the rich, and invoke the specter of foreign and particularly American intervention, could have potent emotional appeal in squalid city slums and Palestinian refugee quarters.
Although Mr. Hussein's Baathist Party ideology is avowedly secular -its first Arab nationalist theorist was a Christian in Lebanon - his statement was a visceral appeal to Muslim feelings, invoking the specter of ''infidels'' defiling Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina, now under the control of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.
''O Arabs, O Muslims and faithful everywhere, this is your day to rise and defend Mecca, which is captured by the spears of the Americans and the Zionists,'' said the Iraqi President's statement, which was read by an announcer and heard on the radio throughout much of the Arab world. ''Revolt against oppression, corruption, treachery and back-stabbing.
''Keep the foreigner away from your holy shrines,'' the proclamation urged, ''so we will all stand as one to expel darkness and expose those rulers who know no sense of honor.''
''Tell the infidels there is no place for them in the lands of the Arabs after they squandered the people's rights and humiliated their dignity and honor,'' Mr. Hussein said. The wording of the Arab League resolution adopted tonight - to support Kuwait's ''efforts to liberate its land'' - raised the possibility of military action, possibly with the United States being drawn in, to reverse Iraq's takeover of its tiny, oil-rich neighbor and former ally. The measure did not make it clear whether or how the Arab force would coordinate action with the United States military.
 
Turning Point in Arab History
The emergency meeting's outcome was a kind of watershed in modern Arab history, ripping aside the slogans of Arab brotherhood that had served to veil differences. It took place in a closed session so emotionally charged that the Iraqis threw plates of food at the Kuwaitis at the official luncheon, and the Kuwaiti Foreign Minister fainted during the debate, according to reports that seeped out.
The vote essentially pitted pro-Western states, particularly those rich in oil, against the radicals. In favor were Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain, all oil states, along with Egypt, Morocco, Somalia, Lebanon, Djibouti and Iraq's longtime rival, Syria.
Sudan and Mauritania joined Jordan in voting to approve the resolution ''with reservations.'' Tunisia was the only country in the league that did not attend. Algeria and Yemen abstained, and Iraq, the P.L.O. and Libya voted against the measure.
The seven-point resolution was drawn up largely by Egypt but presented in the name of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which groups Saudi Arabia and five lesser oil states, including Kuwait. The measure repeatedly condemned Iraq for its Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait and for what it called ''threats to gulf states'' and ''massing troops'' on Saudi Arabia's borders.
The resolution also called for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops and the restoration of the Kuwaiti Government, and endorsed the United Nations economic boycott and embargo of Iraq.
Iraq's quick response was a statement by its press agency that the Arab meeting had ''implemented America's will.''
 
A Victory for Egypt
The outcome of the meeting was a triumph for President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who sought to rally consensus by warning that the Arabs must act together or face foreign intervention over which they had no influence. Most such Arab meetings in the past have ended in a stalemate.
In an opening speech, Mr. Mubarak said, ''The options before us are clear: an Arab action to protect the higher interest of the Arab nation, preserving Iraq and Kuwait, or foreign intervention that we will have no say or control over.''
As the meeting began, Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, called the proposals being circulated ''an American solution being given on Arab cover.''
Speaking for the grim-faced Iraqi delegation, Mr. Aziz told reporters: ''We're not coming here to discuss any Arab business under the threat of American forces and intimidation. If the Americans leave the region to its people, we are ready to discuss any questions.
''If you want to find an Arab solution to the problem, there should be an Arab atmosphere around you,'' he added in pointed reference to Mr. Mubarak's statements. ''No solution can be found with the Americans around you.''
 
GORBACHEV URGES SETTLEMENT
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (Special to the New York Times) In his first public statement since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today called on Arab leaders to ''begin active work to settle the conflict.''
''We are doing everything possible to reverse the course of events and put out the fire in the region, which is vital to many states,'' Mr. Gorbachev wrote in a letter to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, according to the Soviet press agency Tass.
''I believe that efforts by Arab countries could play a major role in this common cause. Perhaps it is the most preferable path to take.''
Mr. Gorbachev, who has been away from Moscow on vacation, warned that the crisis in the Persian Gulf was taking on ''an extremely dangerous and increasingly unpredictable character.'' He compared the growing momentum of the crisis to a ''stone, falling from a rocky cliff.''
The Soviet President defended Moscow's condemnation of Baghdad's actions. ''There is nothing anti-Iraqi in it,'' the letter said. ''On the contrary, we strived to help Iraq find a way out of the situation it found itself in with minimum losses.''

PUB-DATE: August 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 913 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF
ARABS VOTE TO SEND TROOPS TO HELP SAUDIS; BOYCOTT OF IRAQI OIL IS REPORTED NEAR 100%;
No Shipments Seen

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The international embargo of oil shipments from Iraq and Kuwait has choked off nearly all petroleum exports from those two countries, oil company executives and industry analysts said today.
The United Nations' economic sanctions, imposed on Baghdad on Monday for its invasion of Kuwait, have meant that no ships are showing up to be filled from the pipelines carrying crude oil from Iraq to Saudi Arabia and Turkey, oil executives in the Middle East and London said. One London oil official described the boycott as ''near 100 percent cutoff.''
 
'No Vessels' to Load
''It would appear no vessels are proceeding to ports'' in Kuwait and Iraq, said Norman Hooke, a shipping analyst at Lloyds Maritime Information Services, an arm of the Lloyds of London insurance market. 
With the embargo proving effective, other large oil exporters are rushing to increase their sales to the oil-consuming nations, especially Japan, that had been steady buyers of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil.
In New York today, the price of the benchmark American crude-oil grade, West Texas Intermediate, closed at $26.23 a barrel, up 56 cents for the day. The price has risen 30 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and 50 percent since mid-July.
 
Iran Moves First
Iran has been the first producer to make up for the shortfall created by the boycott of Iraq, selling millions of barrels of oil in the last few days from floating storage tankers at sea, oil industry officials said today in telephone interviews. Other leading exporters, notably Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, have notified their Western customers that they will be increasing production and selling far more oil.
The industry officials from several companies said Iran might have sold 10 million to 26 million barrels in the last five days to Japanese and other Asian customers. Those extraordinary sales from Iran's storage tanks, ranging from two million to more than five million barrels a day, represent a doubling or trebling of Teheran's typical sales in the world market.
The added Iranian sales counter a large part of the supplies lost because of the halt in oil shipments from Kuwait and Iraq. Those two nations had been selling about four million barrels a day in the world market.
''Iran is benefiting,'' said Peter Gign, manager of the international petroleum trading desk of Shearson Lehman Brothers in London. ''And the Iranian sales have comforted refiners for the moment, and thus consumers temporarily, in this time of crisis.'' Iran's sales help to explain, in part, the drop in oil prices on world markets on Wednesday and Thursday.
 
Wartime Storage
Iran has sold oil from the estimated 30 million to 40 million barrels of stocks it had stored in tankers as a security measure during its eight-year war with Iraq, which ended in 1988.
Iran cannot sustain such sales. Oil industry analysts estimate that Teheran can increase its output of three million barrels a day by a few hundred thousand.
Yet the Iranian move is bound to put pressure on other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that have additional production capacity, notably Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela, to produce more oil to satisfy world demand. Saudi Arabia can increase its current production by more than two million barrels a day, Venezuela by about 500,000 barrels a day, and the emirates by nearly 300,000.
American officials said that both Saudi Arabia and Venezuela had assured the United States that they would raise production to make up for the shortage. Oil industry sources said the Iranian move will insure that Middle East producers like Saudi Arabia and the emirates would want to make provisions to protect their market share in Asia and not let Iran take the whole share of Kuwait and Iraq in those markets for itself.
 
OPEC Accord Discarded
OPEC industry sources said the last agreement signed in Geneva by the cartel is no longer an obstacle, as most of its provisions had become, for all practical purposes, null and void.
Among other things, the July accord stipulated that the price of oil would be set at $21 a barrel. The actual price of OPEC oil now hovers closer to $24 a barrel, on average. The accord also said OPEC would limit its production to 22.5 million barrels a day. Without exports from Iraq and Kuwait, actual OPEC output stands at about 18 million barrels a day, far below what the world needs from OPEC.
Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have been pressuring Sadek Boussena, the president of OPEC and the oil minister of Algeria, to give them ''an OPEC umbrella,'' in the words of a senior official of the organization, that would allow them to raise their output without being criticized by members who favor higher oil prices.
Venezuela's energy ministry told the Associated Press today that it had not ordered the state-owned oil industry to raise its output, but that it could issue a new order later, ''depending on OPEC agreements.''
Yet even the added sales of Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members will not completely make up for the Kuwaiti and Iraqi production, most industry analysts said.
They expect Western countries will eventually have to tap their strategic reserves of petroleum.
Various oil experts also expect that the 21 members of the International Energy Agency based in Paris will move to use their strategic oil reserves as prices in the oil market approach the cost of pulling oil out of underground storage.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Says Its Troops in the Gulf Could Reach 100,000 in Months

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Pentagon officials said today that the American force mobilized to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack could reach 100,000 in a matter of months, and President Bush warned Baghdad not to try to ship oil through an undeclared allied naval blockade.
The White House hailed the decision of Arab nations to send troops to Saudi Arabia and to join in the worldwide economic quarantine of Iraq.
Two days ago, military officials suggested 50,000 as the upper limit for the ground force being assembled in Saudi Arabia unless fighting broke out.
With positions on both sides evidently hardening into long-term confrontation and hostility, Canada, France and Australia announced that they were sending ships to join American and British vessels in the waters of the Middle East.
Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One on his way to Maine, Mr. Bush avoided using the word ''blockade,'' apparently because questions of leadership need to be worked out, as well as legal problems. But he made it clear that any Iraqi ships trying to do business as usual would be challenged. 
 
A Test of Wills
Suggesting that the United States and its allies face not so much a test of arms with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as a test of wills, Mr. Bush said there was no sign that the Iraqis ''would be foolish enough to cross that border'' from Kuwait into Saudi Arabia. And Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq vowed that his country would stay in Kuwait despite the economic and military pressures the rest of the world could muster against it.
 
NATO Ground Forces Expected
An American official traveling from Brussels to Washington on the plane carrying Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said some members of the NATO alliance would also send ground forces to the Persian Gulf region, in addition to ships and planes. The broad international response to American pleas for help constituted a victory for the Administration, which had feared trouble if United States troops and ships seemed alone.
There was no progress, however, on efforts by American diplomats to win Baghdad's permission for 3,500 United States citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait to leave. Indeed, President Hussein responded defiantly to his increasing economic isolation and military vulnerability, calling on Arabs everywhere to rise up in a holy war, overthrow the Saudi royal family and drive Western powers out of the region. His bellicose words deepened fears in Washington that he plans to use the Americans and other foreigners, all de facto hostages for more than a week, as diplomatic pawns. A majority of the members of the Arab League voted at a conference in Cairo to send troops to Saudi Arabia and to support economic sanctions. It was not immediately clear which countries would do so, although Egypt, Morocco and Syria were widely mentioned, and it was not known whether they would form part of a multinational force or stand apart as a separate Arab contingent.
''I do not believe involvement in hostilities is imminent,'' Mr. Bush told Congress in a message this morning. But the seriousness with which the Administration regards the prospect of eventual combat in the Persian Gulf was underlined by its plans to send a pair of 1,000-bed hospital ships to the area in the next few days.
Mr. Baker said there were indications that Iraq was moving military units up to its border with Turkey and pouring more forces into occupied Kuwait, where there are already at least 138,000 Iraqi troops.
 
'Backed Into a Corner'
''He's backed into a corner,'' Mr. Bush said of President Hussein as he flew to his home in Kennebunkport, Me. ''He's been isolated by the rest of the world. Nobody supports him.''
He dismissed the Iraqi dictator's calls for a holy war as ''a rather frantic ploy'' that ''won't work.''
''I am pleased the way our allies are coming through,'' the President added. ''The troubling thing is that we're up against a man who is known for his brutality and irrationality and who has taken a step that, though widely condemned, has still not been reversed.''
Speaking after a closed-door session of NATO foreign ministers in Brussels where he appealed for help, Mr. Baker said: ''We all have an interest in thwarting Iraq's menacing and unlimited ambitions. If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.''
In addition to the difficulty of fulfulling his pledge to force the Iraqis out of Kuwait, Mr. Bush's most pressing concerns at the moment are the fate of the trapped Americans, including 38 held in a Baghdad hotel, and the potential for Iraqi terrorism, aides said. The State Department issued a bulletin warning against possible Iraqi terrorist attacks on American installations and individuals.
 
Blockade, but No Blockade
In what amounted to a full news conference on Air Force One, the President said that sanctions were already hurting Iraq but that they could ''be tightened even more.''
Then he in effect proclaimed a blockade while saying he was not doing so, with the words, ''I would advise Iraqi ships not to go out with oil.'' Mr. Bush declared that he would say no more ''because there are a lot of things going on right now that I don't feel like commenting on.''
In Brussels, Mr. Baker said that with ships of many nations taking part, someone would have to act as ''a traffic cop'' to avoid confusion. At the United Nations, there was disagreement as to whether a blockade had been authorized under Chapter 7 of the organization's Charter when the Security Council voted on Monday to impose economic sanctions, or whether a new vote was needed.
As for the President's plans, Mr. Bush said he would not be held hostage in the White House by the current crisis - an obvious allusion to Jimmy Carter's experience as President when Iran held American hostages for 444 days, releasing the final 52 only as Ronald Reagan was being inaugurated. Mr. Bush, defending his intention to take a 25-day vacation in Kennebunkport, said, ''I think the American people want to see life go on so long as they understand that their President and his top officials are on top of a troubled situation.''
 
'Peaceful Resolution' Seen
In his letter to Congressional leaders, sent in lieu of formal notification under the disputed Vietnam-era War Powers Act, Mr. Bush said: ''I do not believe involvement in hostilities is imminent; to the contrary, it is my belief that this deployment will facilitate a peaceful resolution of the crisis.''
He also pledged that ''our armed forces will remain so long as their presence is required to contribute to the security of the region'' - a period that some experts think could last for years.
The Administration continued to avoid using the word ''hostages'' to describe the Americans trapped in the Middle East. Mr. Baker explained the hesitancy by saying, ''Nothing has been asked or demanded for their freedom, so we are not calling them hostages.'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ''We are told they are being treated decently.''
Evaluating the prospects of winning freedom for the 3,500 Americans, Mr. Bush commented: ''We're not hopeless. But as we've seen with hostage situations - and I don't think this is one - sometimes it's very difficult.''
American troop strength in the region continued to increase today, with some units being transported to the peninsula in airliners chartered from Eastern Airlines and other carriers. Considerable numbers of airplanes, including C-130 transports from Pope Air Force Base, N. C., and F-16 jet fighters from Shaw Air Force Base, S. C., arrived in the last 24 hours.
Elements of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, based at Fort Stewart, Ga., moved by road today to the port of Savannah, the Army announced, to be loaded aboard a troopship, the Capella, for the trip to Saudi Arabia.
The Pentagon said the hospital ship Comfort, now berthed in Baltimore, and the hospital ship Mercy, docked in Oakland, Calif., were being prepared for active duty in the Persian Gulf. Both are relatively new and can accommodate battle-related surgery in air-conditioned operating theaters.
More than 35 major United States ships, including three aircraft carriers, are already in the Persian Gulf, the Indian Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea, or on the way. Britain, France and the Soviet Union already have ships there as well.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION THE GULF;
House of Saud: From Mud Fort to Oil Billions

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Once again, soldiers and weapons are astir on the enormous landscape of Saudi Arabia at the behest of a single family, the House of Saud.
It was in 1902 that a princeling of the clan, then in eclipse, led spear-carrying warriors in seizing a strategic mud fort at Riyadh.
He went on to gain sway over much of Arabia, to found the modern Saudi state with the House of Saud as its royal family.
That first ruler was known as King Ibn Saud. This week his 11th son, King Fahd, likewise head of the family and chief of the state, gave permission to President Bush to send American paratroops, armor and jets to the kingdom to protect it from Iraq. 
 
Male-Dominated and Secretive
Just how that epic decision was arrived at has not been disclosed by the family, which is as secretive as it is numerous and dominated by men: even some Western scholars, when estimating its numbers, give a figure just for the men in the family of more than 5,000.
Analysts say that giving the go-ahead to President Bush was a family decision by the House of Saud, where consultation among key members is the rule.
''They don't reveal the procedures of reaching agreement,'' said George Lenczowski, a political scientist whose latest book, ''American Presidents and the Middle East,'' came out this year (published by Duke University Press). ''They would rather present to the outside world a unified front of harmony and cooperation.''
After the King, the foremost family member is Crown Prince Abdullah, who is a half-brother of Fahd and also heads the National Guard. The third-ranking family figure is Prince Sultan, a full brother of Fahd who is Minister of Defense.
Two full brothers of the monarch, Prince Nayef and Prince Salman, are Minister of the Interior and Governor of Riyadh, respectively.
 
Family and State Interwoven
And so it goes. Professor Lenczowski, a Middle East scholar who has just retired from the University of California at Berkeley, said, ''You cannot distinguish between the House of Saud and the Saudi state; they are interwoven.''
Or, as it was once put by a Middle East analyst, William B. Quandt of the Brookings Institution, ''Saudi Arabia is a family-run business.''
Business has been good. The assets that the Saudi Government has outside Saudi Arabia - not to mention those inside its borders - are widely estimated as exceeding $100 billion.
In general, ''the boundary between the Saudi state treasury and the Saudi personal coffers is rather permeable,'' another Brookings Institute Middle East expert, Yahya Sadowski, observed yesterday.
 
Protector of the Faith
There are various reasons why the House of Saud has remained in power in Saudi Arabia, while ruling dynasties in such other Islamic lands like Libya and Iran have fallen in recent decades.
Analysts say the House of Saud dominates the Saudi armed forces and also controls the civilian government, where it relies largely on nonroyal Saudi technocrats educated in the West.
In addition, the House of Saud is seen as benefiting, in an era of resurgent and militant Islam, because it does much to promote and protect that faith. King Fahd said in 1986 that he wanted Saudis to address him not as ''Your Majesty,'' but as ''Custodian of the Two Holy Places,'' Mecca and Medina.
 
Education in Western Universities
Although it clings to tradition in many ways, and Islamic educations, entirely in Arabia, were given to many of Ibn Saud's sons, the next generation of the House of Saud has made Western education more common. Princeton is the alma mater of the Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, who was born in Riyadh 39 years after his grandfather, Ibn Saud, seized the mud fort.
Prof. Jon E. Mandaville, a historian at Portland State University in Oregon, observed that Emir Mubarak of Kuwait, a forebear of the exiled Kuwaiti ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, gave shelter to the future King Ibn Saud and his family for a time before Ibn Saud's raid on the Riyadh fort.
But in the 1920's, 30's and 40's there were repeated, though relatively minor, armed clashes between the two families and their subjects because of boundary disputes and various grudges and rivalries. ''Relations between the Saudi royal family and the ruling family in Kuwait,'' he said, ''have been reasonably cordial for the last 20 years or so.''
Saudi Arabia languished in the days before its oil became a major factor in the global economy. It had a moment in the limelight in early 1945, when Ibn Saud met with Franklin D. Roosevelt aboard a United States Navy cruiser in the Great Bitter Lake along the route of the Suez Canal. As a courtesy, the monarch had his retainers serve Arabian coffee.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION THE GULF;
A Few More Refugees Reach the Saudi Border

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Braving scorching August heat and other risks of the open desert in rugged all-terrain vehicles, a trickle of Americans and other foreign nationals continued yesterday to reach the relative calm of Saudi Arabia in a series of daring escapes from war-torn Kuwait.
To do so, the refugees had to leave paved roads for the trackless wastes of the Dibdibah desert, skirt border checkpoints where Iraqi troops were turning back travelers and cross hundreds of miles of rocky, barren terrain in temperatures that soared over 120 degrees.
''Three Americans arrived just 20 minutes ago,'' said Gene Heck, the commercial attache at the American Embassy in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, about 11 P.M. In a telephone interview, he called the Americans' 350-mile trip from Kuwait City ''an extraordinary effort.''
 
Driving in Desert
''They drove through the desert in an overland vehicle,'' Mr. Heck said. ''We haven't had a chance to debrief them, but I understand they work for private companies.'' He said the refugees carried food and water, but he knew nothing else about them or their crossing. 
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq closed that country's borders and those between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia on Thursday, leaving thousands of Americans and other foreigners trapped in the war zone. Western companies advised stranded employees not to risk a desert crossing, citing the risks of getting lost or caught by Iraqi troops.
It was unclear how many refugees had crossed into Saudi Arabia, although a Reuters dispatch from Dubai in the nearby United Arab Emirates quoted travelers as saying that as many as 800 private cars driven by Kuwaitis had reached al-Khafji, six miles inside Saudi Arabia.
Communication with the embattled region remained all but impossible yesterday. A few Western reporters in the area were unable to file dispatches, and only an occasional telephone call got through on clogged circuits. Some Western governments kept in touch with their embassies by radio.
 
Resistance Is Reported
Refugees reaching Saudi Arabia were quoted by Reuters as saying that gunfire could still be heard in Kuwait City, showing that pockets of resistance fighters were still harassing Iraqi occupation forces. Other refugees from Kuwait and Iraq spoke of rape, looting and violence by the invasion troops.
The Associated Press, in a dispatch from Bahrain, in the Persian Gulf, quoted travelers as saying that some Iraqi soldiers had looted banks, taken automobiles from showrooms, stolen furniture and jewelry from shops, beaten Kuwaitis and forced their way into homes to seize food and clothing.
Other travelers were quoted as saying that Iraqi soldiers were polite, even apologetic, in asking residents for food and water, and that an eerie quiet prevailed over the capital nine days after the invasion, with Iraqi troops squatting and sleeping on nearly deserted streets.
A few companies that reached their employees said Westerners in Kuwait did not appear to be in any immediate danger, although they were not being allowed to leave, and some companies were concerned about the long-term psychological effects on their employees.
 
Supplies Were Adequate
A spokesman at the British Embassy in Kuwait City said that food and water supplies were adequate and that electricity was functioning. The Baghdad radio said all Kuwaitis had been ordered to get back to work or they would lose their jobs, but travelers said that the order had been widely ignored and that many Kuwaitis were trying to flee the country.
Westerners in Iraq appeared to be safe, according to companies that were able to communicate with employees there. ''Life is quite normal in Baghdad,'' said Nils Ingvar Lundin, a spokeman for LM Ericsson, a Swedish maker of radio and telephone equipment.
Three company employees and their dependents were in the Iraqi capital, he said, and, like other Westerners, were moving about the city freely and receiving phone calls.
Westerners in Baghdad said that people anticipating shortages as a result of an international economic embargo rushed to stock up on rice, sugar, cooking oil and other foodstuffs.
In Saudi Arabia, more squadrons of United States fighter planes arrived to bolster the buildup of American combat troops, and a steady stream of chartered and commercial flights landed at Riyadh's airport, which was packed with people trying to leave the country.
But there was no sense of panic. Western companies generally asked their employees to stay on and continue working in Saudi Arabia, though most were urging that dependents be evacuated.
While American and Saudi forces were massing near the northern border with Kuwait, the streets of Riyadh were quiet yesterday, a holy day of rest in Muslim countries.
