HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION THE GULF;
A Million Strong? Some Experts Question Iraq's Military Strength

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
Iraq, with 17 million people, boasts of having a million-strong army, but some experts in the United States and abroad who have studied Iraqi demographics and intelligence reports estimated yesterday that the number of active forces may be half that amount.
''The figure of one million soldiers includes second-line soldiers, semimilitia units,'' said Mordechai M. Ababir, an Arab specialist at Hebrew University in Israel. ''Iraq's army is made up of 400,000 to 500,000 soldiers of first-line quality, and this is about the number of people you would expect to be under arms in a country of Iraq's size.''
 
Possibly Four Armies
''There are three, possibly four Iraqi armies,'' said Anthony H. Cordesman, an intelligence specialist on the Persian Gulf and an aide to Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. 
''There is the low-grade militia, that possibly exists only on paper,'' Mr. Cordesman said. ''There is the so-called popular army that has its origins in Saddam Hussein's ruling Baath Party. There is the regular Iraqi Army of perhaps 400,000, and the elite Republican Guards and other elite forces that number about 240,000.
''The Iraqis probably have a total of 600,000 to 700,000 active troops,'' he said.
While many analysts put asterisks next to the one million figure, it should be noted that every army has a large percentage of second-line troops. The one million figure is used by the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, an authority on the world's armies.
It is also worth recalling that in terms of percentage of total populace under arms, Iraq's mobilization was exceeded by all the primary combatants in World War II. The comparison is apt in view of that Iraq committed everything it had for the war against Iran, and did not significantly demobilize after the battle ended in 1988.
 
Scramble for Manpower Seen
Military analysts say that if war does break out, the Iraqis will have to scramble to find the manpower to fuel their economy and their armed forces, but they note that the Iraqis did so successfully during the eight-year war with Iran.
During the conflict with Iran, with 46 million people, the Iraqis relied on an estimated two million Egyptian guest workers - about half of whom have left since the end of the hostilities - a large infusion of women into the work force, and the conscription of boys as young as 16 and men as old as 43.
''Conscription began around 17 and often lasted to the age of 26 to 32,'' Mr. Cordesman said. ''There was no fixed term of duty. People would often be called back to the front for service.''
According to 1990 statistics, Iraq has 873,000 men between 18 and 22. Men between 23 and 32 in the country total 1,313,000. #30,000 Egyptians in Army Iraq also used some foreign mercenaries, including an estimated 30,000 Egyptians, in its army during the Iranian war. ''They had quite a number of both Sudanese and Egyptians who served in some capacity with the promise of substantial sums of money and citizenship, but we don't have an exact number on this,'' Mr. Cordesman said.
Stephen Pelletiere, a research analyst for the United States Army War College in Carlisle, Pa., said: ''In the last war, they did a phenomenal mobilization job. They mobilized some 50 divisions. When the crunch came, they got up the troops.''
Mr. Pelletiere, who just completed a study on the Iraqi military, added: ''We were impressed when we did our study that a lot of the talk we had heard about Iraqis not being loyal to the regime just didn't pan out. The last two years of the war, when you would have expected a falloff in support for the regime, it didn't work that way.''
But the heavy mobilization radically transformed Iraqi society. It gave women roles that were unheard of in other Arab countries and gave them educational opportunities that had been denied to women in the past.
 
Women Gain Education
''The war changed the whole demographics of Iraqi women,'' Mr. Cordesman said. ''Women who did not have children were usually given some work, and as the war progressed women became better educated.''
''They have an educated female population, and about 25 percent of the work force is now made up of women,'' said Phebe Marr, a senior fellow at the Institute for National Strategic Studies at the National Defense University in Washington.
An estimated 120,000 Iraqis were killed or were reported missing in action in the war with Iran, and another 230,000 Iraqis were wounded, according to statistics provided by Ms. Marr. ''This represents about 4 to 5 percent of Iraq's military-age population killed and 8 to 12 percent wounded,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Philippines Uses Foreign Assistance Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''In One Philippine Village, All the Forces That Rend'' (The Week in Review, July 15) states that foreign assistance to Manila is ''backlogged'' and ''unspent.'' As President Bush's special representative for the multilateral assistance initiative for the Philippines, I have given high priority to finding out how well the Philippines uses foreign assistance.
In the last month I have been in touch with the Japanese Government, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. They, with the United States, subscribed $3 billion of the $3.4 billion pledged for the first year of the initiative in Tokyo a year ago. The United States pledged $1 billion over five years. Congress has appropriated $160 million in this fiscal year, and the Administration has requested $200 million for fiscal year 1991. None of the major donors have serious problems with Philippine implementation of our assistance. 
The important project agreements negotiated by the principal donor countries with the Philippine Government in the last year have received little press attention. Leading examples are the World Bank's $390 million energy-sector loan, the Japan-World Bank-Asia Development Bank's $270 million water-supply project, the Asian Bank's $80 million fisheries-sector project and Japan's $65 million Pampanga Delta project.
On July 10 and 11, Ronald Roskens, administrator of the Agency for International Development, and I joined President Corazon C. Aquino and Jesus Estanislao, Philippine Secretary of Finance, in ceremonies to begin the South Cotabato special development project in Mindanao, to which the United States has committed $115 million. This year we are also funding feasibility studies for large development projects and private-sector investment, making grants to improve natural resources management, particularly the forests, and with the Export-Import Bank, helping to finance American exports for energy, telecommunications, transportation and construction projects.
The World Bank ranks the Philippines in the top quarter of countries that utilize their foreign assistance well.
 
ELLIOT L. RICHARDSON
 Washington, July 25, 1990

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION THE GULF;
Security Council's Rare Unity May Be Threatened Over U.S. Warships in the Gulf

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The United States appears to be heading for a disagreement with the other members of the United Nations Security Council over the use of naval forces to impose a blockade on Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
Diplomats say the potential split over timing and procedure threatens the unity the Council has displayed so far in its handling of the crisis, with the Soviet Union, China and most third-world members backing America's call for trade sanctions against Iraq.
In particular, it raises the danger that United States warships in the Persian Gulf could start stopping, searching and forcibly turning back tankers and other cargo vessels suspected of trading with these countries before the rest of the world community judges such military action necessary or justified. 
 
Baker Cites Resolution
The Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, said at a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels today that the Bush Administration believed the Security Council's resolution declaring a global boycott of Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait gave the United States the right to forcibly prevent other countries from trading with Iraq and Kuwait.
''It is the view of some of us,'' he said, ''that we have the legal authority necessary to institute such an embargo or blockade, provided that the request comes from the legitimate Government of Kuwait.''
Article 51 of the United Nations Charter gives all countries the right of ''individual or collective self-defense'' against an aggressor, and the Security Council affirmed Kuwait's right to invoke Article 51 in the resolution it passed last week.
But other Council members take the view that while the resolution forbids trade or other financial dealings with Iraq and Kuwait, it only allows countries to send naval vessels to the gulf to monitor ship movements and report suspected violations to the special Security Council committee on compliance.
Britain's United Nations representative, Sir Crispin Tickell, told the Council on Thursday that this is London's view, and diplomats say Canada, China, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire share Britain's basic approach.
Moscow's deputy representative, Valentin V. Lozinsky, said military measures should first be discussed by the Military Staff Committee, a moribund United Nations panel that plan enforcement of Council decisions.
The countries want the Council to adopt a new resolution calling for a naval blockade before any American, British, French or other warships patroling the waters around the Arabian Peninsula uses force to stop ships trading with these countries.
Most Council members say the time is not yet ripe for the Council to pass a resolution authorizing force in the gulf. They argue that the Council should first wait to see the results of Arab diplomacy and find out whether the embargo proves effective without such naval enforcement action.
International solidarity in adhering to the boycott is showing signs of strain. Sri Lanka has said it cannot afford to stop exporting to Iraq and Kuwait, and several countries are complaining that they cannot afford the higher oil prices the embargo is causing.

HEADLINE: Weicker Balks At Ruling Out An Income Tax

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Republican campaigning for governor as an independent, today released a detailed proposal for dealing with Connecticut's fiscal problems but continued to refuse to say whether he would seek a state income tax.
''I'll promise this state no new taxes, if this state promises me no new problems,'' Mr. Weicker said a news conference at the State Capitol.
The issue of a state income tax is probably the most fundamental question facing all four gubernatorial candidates. The Republican nominee, Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury, has pledged not to institute such a tax. 
The convention-endorsed Democrat, Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, has said he would call for one only if it were approved in an advisory state referendum. State Representative William J. Cibes Jr. of New London, who is challenging Mr. Morrison in a primary, favors an income tax.
 
No 'Pledges We Can't Keep'
Mr. Weicker, however, has said that he would not rule one out or call for one because, at this time, it is impossible to gauge the severity of the state's future fiscal problems. ''I'm not going to be so silly as to stand before this state and make pledges we can't keep,'' he said.
In his fiscal package, Mr. Weicker, a Greenwich resident who was defeated in 1988 in a bid for a fourth term in the Senate, said the projected $200 million deficit facing the state by the end of this fiscal year next June 30 could be eliminated through the attrition of state employees and through reducing consulting fees, computer purchases and other costs.
In addition, Mr. Weicker said that over the 1991-92 fiscal year, if the current gap between spending and revenue continued it would leave the state with an added deficit of $445 million. He proposed closing it by making further personnel cuts and other, unspecified, spending reductions. ''We will cross that bridge when we come to it,'' said Mr. Weicker's press secretary, Avice A. Meehan.
To help stimulate the economy, Mr. Weicker recommended repealing the 20 percent surcharge now levied on corporate tax returns, and the utility tax on non-manufacturing businesses. He also proposed a budget every two years instead of an annual one, an independent board of economic advisers, five-year economic forecasts and 10-year bonding packages.
 
Other Campaigns Criticize Plan
Reaction to Mr. Weicker's proposals from the other campaigns was hostile. Mr. Morrison said Mr. Weicker intended to propose a state income tax in the second year of his administration.
''He has basically said he will do it,'' said Mr. Morrison, who has proposed a freeze on state spending and hiring as well as a reorganization of state government.
Mr. Rowland has said he would reduce future budget shortfalls by making $360 million in spending reductions and reducing the number of state departments to 18 or 19 from the current 26. He would also ask state employees to contribute more to their health benefit plans and revise state workers compensation agreements.
His campaign manager, John A. Mastropietro, accused Mr. Weicker of being evasive on the income tax. ''This is the man who is allegedly not afraid to speak his mind,'' he said.
Although he would not commit himself, Mr. Weicker appeared to back away from an income tax in his proposal, which relied in some parts on the state's Commission to Study the Management of State Government, also known as the Thomas Commission.
''Connecticut is not in a recession because the state lacks an income tax, nor would the imposition of an income tax bring us out of a recession,'' the proposal states. ''The time for discussing an income tax was back five or six years ago when the state was enjoying annual budget surpluses. But in the current situation, imposing an income tax would be like pouring gasoline on a fire.''
 
'A Fuzzy Wuzzy Bear'
Apart from the income tax issue, the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, Robert G. Jaekle of Stratford, said Mr. Weicker's proposals were vague and in some cases, like employee attrition, relied on old statistical projections.
''We've finally gotten Lowell Weicker to come out of the cave,'' he said. ''But I think what we have is a fuzzy wuzzy bear.''
Mr. Cibes's campaign manager, Jonathan Pelto, said Mr. Weicker's projection for a budget shortfall for the 1991-92 fiscal year was at least $100 million too low. He also said some of Mr. Weicker's efficiencies, like reducing computer purchases, had already been adopted.
Mr. Cibes has proposed cutting the sales tax to 5 percent from the current 8 percent, with a constitutional cap; cutting the corporate tax rate to 10 percent from the current 13.5 percent; eliminating the dividends, interest and capital gains tax; repealing several smaller business services taxes, and imposing a 4 percent to 8 percent personal income tax with a $25,000 exemption for each family.
Mr. Pelto said, ''Nothing short of comprehensive tax reform will allow Connecticut's economy to rejuvenate.''
 
Weicker Leads in Poll
In the most recent poll by the University of Connecticut's Institute for Social Inquiry, Mr. Weicker led by 37 percent of those polled, with Mr. Rowland receiving 20 percent and Mr. Morrison receiving 13 percent. The poll of 500 randomly selected state residents, which was taken between July 23 and July 30, had a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
In a University of Connecticut poll of the same sized sample a month earlier, before the July party conventions, Mr. Weicker had the support of 41 percent of the respondents, compared with 11 percent for Mr. Rowland and 9 percent for Mr. Morrison.
Asked about a three-way race involving Mr. Cibes, who will face Mr. Morrison in a Democratic primary on Sept. 11, Mr. Weicker had 40 percent of those polled, Mr. Rowland 22 percent and Mr. Cibes 6 percent. In a race solely against Mr. Morrison, the party's nominee, Mr. Cibes received 9 percent of the Democratic respondents' support to Mr. Morrison's 57 percent.

HEADLINE: A Threadbare Men's Wear Industry

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Sales of men's clothing, which some economists view as an unorthodox indication of the nation's economic health, are in their longest and deepest slump in a decade.
Men's wear sales fell 8 percent in dollars and 6 percent in the number of sales transactions, or ''units,'' from January through May of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year, said MRCA Information Services, a research company in Stamford, Conn.
John Tugman, vice president of the information service, suggested several reasons. ''There's definitely concern about the economy,'' he said. ''There are perhaps more attractive alternatives for disposable income, such as entertainment, electronic goods, automobiles and travel. And what's missing is a fashion imperative - there's no new look that is so hot that the wardrobe has to be changed - so that purchases represent replacement business only.'' 
 
'A Sobering Attitude'
Dan Sweeney, president of Management Horizons, a management consulting firm based in Columbus, Ohio, said the downtrend ''stems from a sobering attitude created by the disasters on Wall Street, the savings and loan debacle, the leveraged buyouts that don't work and the white-collar indictments.''
The steepest buying decline is most evident among men under 35 and those over 55, according to MRCA's sampling of 11,500 American households.
The research company found that the biggest buying lag was among consumers in the next-to-lowest income category, those making $20,000 to $35,000 a year. They have spent 17 percent less on clothes so far this year than they did in the comparable period last year.
But all income categories, from those earning less than $20,000 to those making at least $50,000 a year, bought fewer clothes, measured in both dollars and units.
''It's a zero-sum game right now,'' said John Eyler, chairman and chief executive of specialty stores at the Hartmarx Corporation of Chicago, the country's largest manufacturer and retailer of men's apparel. ''It's the first serious lag in men's wear sales in a decade, and it's actually across the board in all price lines.''
Hartmarx recently reported a loss of $55 million for the second quarter of this year, with $51 million of that reflecting the cost of closing 65 of its 263 clothing stores that were unprofitable or marginal.
In the national survey, blazers and sports coats had the biggest drop, falling 36 percent in dollars and 38 percent in unit sales. Suits were down 5 percent in dollars, though they stayed even in units.
Jeans, which often led all apparel sales in the 1980's, fell 12 percent in dollar sales and 16 percent in units from January to May.
The 1990 sales decline follows erratic sales last year. For much of that year, relatively robust sales of men's clothing offset a long famine in women's apparel. Then men's wear sales suddenly weakened.
The prolonged decline in many segments of the industry and flat sales in others have prompted some economists to speculate that men generally believe that the nation will soon be in a deep recession.
Economists, merchants and demographers have long agreed that sales of men's clothing is directly affected by men's perceptions about their job security and the prospects for their companies. The experts also say that in times of uncertainty those men who are the sole breadwinners often cut back on their clothing purchases before asking other family members to do so.
In New York, Clifford Grodd, chairman of Paul Stuart, which sells expensive clothing aimed at executives, said he recently had lunch with a prominent men's clothing maker who told him, ''It's as if something turned off the faucet all around the country.''
From his own standpoint, Mr. Grodd added: ''I think that people have become overextended and very cautious about rising prices. Our own volume is running slightly ahead, but it's not an exciting business today. But with the economy in this area as choppy as it is, the last thing we need is consumer cynicism, which hurts everything.''
At Barney's New York, which has a total of eight stores in the metropolitan area and in a few other cities, Robert Pressman, executive vice president, said: ''Business is mixed. The fashion-oriented and European clothing is doing well, but traditional styles are weak. Totally, year to date, we are a little ahead.''
This year, said Fabian Linden, executive director of the consumer research center of the Conference Board, American consumers have shown less confidence in business prospects. ''In July 1989, 18.6 percent of our consumer respondents said they expected more jobs, while 13.2 percent said they expected less. This July, the ratio shifted - 14.2 percent foresaw more jobs, but 17.9 percent saw less.''
Some more-optimistic executives say the slump will reverse itself later this year or early in 1991. ''This fall should produce a better season because of stabilized fiber prices and new colorations and fabric treatment for men's suits,'' said Mr. Eyler of Hartmarx.
''Our manufacturing bookings for spring 1991 are up, too, and our Hart Schaffner & Marx suit, which averages over $500, has held up well in sales. So we see a bottoming out of this situation soon.''

GRAPHIC: Charts: clothing items worst hit by the slump in sales between the first five months of 1989 and 1990; decline in sales by household income, 1989 to 1990 (Source: MRCA Information Services)

HEADLINE: Gasoline Costs: A Psychological Toll

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Motorists - which is to say, almost everyone - are howling over the recent increases in gasoline prices. But with shifts in energy use in the time since the last oil shock, the public is focusing on what is most visible, but not most damaging.
The average increase in the pump price since Iraq invaded Kuwait, 16 cents, adds less than $7 a month to the cost of operating the average car, which uses about 500 gallons of gasoline a year. If the family members taking a 100-mile trip to the beach this weekend stop to calculate the additional cost for gas and oil that has resulted from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent reactions on world markets, they will find, on average, that it is less than the price of a bottle of suntan oil, or about $1.25. 
The effect is more modest now than in 1973, when gasoline prices first spiked, because average fuel economy has increased since then by 50 percent.
But economists say a 1 percent increase in the price of crude oil can cut the gross national product by a tenth of a percent or so. In recent weeks, the price of oil has risen by more than 40 percent, implying that if the increase sticks, the economy will move firmly into recession from its current level of modest growth.
This is not a new idea. In a 1983 article in the Journal of Political Economy, James D. Hamilton, an economist, wrote that oil price rises have preceded five of the six recessions since World War II.
Nevertheless, what catches the attention of America is the price of gasoline, which becomes a sort of popular version of the Dow Jones industrial average. It is a psychological landmark that is perhaps the single most important number that comes to mind when consumers think about what it costs them to live. The current furor, for example, is over an increase in costs equivalent to $6.75 on the monthly electric or phone bill.
But it is hard to imagine that meager an increase eliciting a Presidential attempt at ''jawboning'' oil companies to do their ''fair share'' in this crisis, or a request from a half-dozen state attorneys general for a Justice Department investigation into oil price increases. Yesterday, one state, Massachusetts, even promulgated emergency regulations to prevent ''gouging.''
But gasoline is different from a utility bill, or a bill at the supermarket. ''Utility bills, or bills for Brussels sprouts, are not posted on the highway, and you don't drive by them every day,'' said an executive of a large oil company yesterday, who insisted on anonymity. Every gas station posts a price and most drivers pass several of them a day.
Around the country, the public is angry, in part because of the speed with which the events were reflected at the pump. ''I can't believe Iraq invading Kuwait has anything to do with gas that's already in the tank,'' said Roger Spratt of Davenport, Iowa, who was visiting Six Flags Over Mid-America, an amusement park outside St. Louis, this week. Way 'to Hose the Consumer'
But Mr. Spratt, like many others, did not think the increase would have any impact on him. ''It's just another way to hose the consumer,'' he said.
At the Manchester Leasing Company, a car company in St. Louis, Jo Davies, the sales manager, said gas mileage was not an issue among customers. ''They don't even bring it up,'' she said. Ms. Davies added that she was filling out the paperwork on a new Saab Turbo convertible, and that gas prices were ''not even a consideration.''
In Brighton, Mass., a Boston suburb, Tolu Odebiyi went shopping at an Acura dealership yesterday. ''The oil prices will not make a difference on what kind of car I'm going to buy, but to wake up in the morning and see the prices have skyrocketed really caught me unaware,'' he said.
At times, the public seems to think of cheap gas as a constitutional right, a phenomenon long evident to officeholders who have contemplated proposing a substantial gasoline tax.
The lure of low-priced fuel was evident in Grandview, Mo., on Thursday when a service station that offered gas at 48.9 cents a gallon as part of a radio station promotion drew a line a mile long, which started forming an hour and a half before the sale started. Eleven police officers were sent to keep order.
''Americans are most attuned to what affects their driving,'' said Gerald M. Cheske, a spokesman for the American Automobile Association ''And the motorist, in many cases, is angry. They haven't had time to settle into any thinking of what it means to me, how it affects family income.''
 
Surprisingly Modest Effect
The effect is surprisingly modest, even this month, at the height of what is known as the ''summer driving season,'' a concept that is largely a holdover from the days when the car was a pleasure vehicle. A family of four taking a driving vacation will spend $173 a day for food and lodging, according to the automobile association; the gas and oil will cost $8.40 for each 100 miles. If the price of fuel rises 15 percent, it adds $1.26 to the trip. That would add $12 to a round-trip from New York to Bangor, Me.
But the oil increase, if it persists, will have a broader effect. If a price increase of $8 or $9 a barrel sticks, the national bill will be about $50 billion a year, close to 1 percent of the gross national product.
Half of the extra payment will be exported, because half of America's oil supply is bought from abroad, according to Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University, and ''not a lot of the other half will quickly get into spending,'' he predicted. The drain will be half met by reduced savings, and the rest by reduced purchasing.
''It's not excruciating, it's not a destroyer, but it's significant,'' he said. ''If someone put in a $50 billion tax bill, there would be screaming.''
 
Airline Tickets and Food
After gasoline, the effect will be felt first in services like airline tickets, then chemical products and petroleum-based substances like plastics, used for everything from Christmas toys to sandwich bags, Dr. Ratajczak said. And then there is food, for which 6 cents of every dollar pays for the energy used in processing and marketing, not counting what is spent for fertilizers and pesticides made from oil. An increase of 1 to 2 percent in food prices is possible, he added.
But a recession, not spiraling inflation, is the likely result this time, he said. ''Jobs are lost, on the one hand, and prices are going up on the other,'' he added. ''You are looking at the boss to see if he is going to fire you. It isn't the kind of economic climate where you go demanding wages to keep up with inflation.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Motorists formed long lines on Thursday at a service station sale in a suburb of Chicago to buy gasoline at 89 cents a gallon. 'Americans are most attuned to what affects their driving,' says Gerald M. Cheske, a spokesman for the American Automobile Association. 'And the motorist, in many cases, is angry.' HEADLINE: Dow Falls 42.33 Points, To 2,716.58

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks, still under pressure from Middle Eastern developments, ended sharply lower yesterday in moderately heavy trading as investors sold off ahead of the weekend, nearly erasing the gains of the last two days.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 42.33 points, or 1.53 percent, to 2,716.58. That brought its decline for the week to 93.07 points. Trading was moderate on a volume of 145.3 million shares. 
Feverish activity moved the Dow down across the 50-point level at 1:38 P.M. and to its low of 2,692.82, down 54 points, two minutes later. That brought the new ''circuit breaker'' rule on the New York Stock Exchange into play for the second time this week.
 
Program Trading Curbed
When the Dow falls more than 50 points, the rule restricts traders that use computer programs to initiate sell orders. Program traders are then not permitted to sell stock on a downtick, which is when a stock's last sale is lower than the one before.
Peter G. Grennan, a vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., noted an immediate calming effect once the circuit breaker was tripped.
Earlier in the day, news of a call by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, for an Arab uprising against foreign intervention in the Persian Gulf region sent jitters through investors and the markets. Oil prices were another reason for the sharp drop in the afternoon. The September spot price of West Texas Intermediate crude, traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rose 56 cents, to settle at $26.23 a barrel yesterday.
 
Little Effect on Market
For most of the morning stocks drifted lower as investors sold ahead of the weekend. A drop of a tenth of a percent in the July producer price index showed a weakening economy even before a coming oil-price shock. economists said, but it did little to sway the market. [Page 37.] Fears of higher oil prices, inflation, and concern over the weak American economy have not dissipated, but remain in the background, Mr. Grennan said.
The sharp selling spree, he suggested, was started by a downturn in the bond market - burdened with a large supply of paper, and traders who were hedging their investments by selling in the futures market. The bonds recovered after the futures market closed, and the stock slide ended.
''It was a Friday,'' Mr. Grennan said, ''and after the type of week we've had, I would have thought it unusual if the market had continued its rally.''
''It's very diffcult for any market to sustain any rally, if it is faced with uncertainty,'' he continued. ''Next week will be important as investors look for a trend to develop.''
Birinyi Associates Inc., which tracks program trading through certain flucuations in market activity, said there were nine program trades - eight sell and one buy, when the net decline on the Dow was 52.96 points. The eight sell programs happened between 10:05 A.M. and 1:44 P.M.
Markets do not deal well with uncertainty, even though they can accept most any economic situation from a depression to inflation, said one trader. Stock traders were not alone in selling off ahead of the weekend. Bond traders were doing the same thing, taking profits from the previous day's gains after a fairly successful auction of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
Losing stocks outnumbered gainers by 1,043 to 448. Anytime there are more than 1,000 stocks down, the losses are pretty well distributed across the board, a trader said. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.42 points, to 335.52, while the American Stock Exchange market-value index fell 2.17 points, or 0.64 percent, to 339.32, and the Nasdaq index fell 4.95 points, or 1.20 percent, to 408.03.
 
Increases for Gold Shares
The price of gold on the Commodity Exchange of New York jumped $11, to $397 an ounce, and with it gold stocks rose. ASA Ltd., a South African gold producer, was up 1 3/4, to 52 3/4, and Homestake Mining, a domestic gold mining company, gained 1 1/2, to 21 7/8.
Oil stocks made small gains but just about everything else was down.
The stock of American Express rose 7/8, to 27 1/2. The company said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. following shareholder approval.
Schering-Plough slipped by 1/2, to 46 1/2. The company announced after the market close on Thursday that it was discontinuing its worldwide marketing of Dilevalol, a drug used for hypertension, because of evidence in isolated cases of liver toxicity.
UAL, where an employee-led buyout group continues to have financing difficulties, fell by 6 1/4, to 107 1/2.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Bond Prices Off Sharply

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds were battered yesterday as traders and investment managers sought to hedge their portfolios for the weekend.
Many used the most common hedge against price declines, selling short an equivalent amount of bond futures in Chicago. Indeed, bond prices in the cash and futures markets moved even more in tandem than usual, over a broad range.
''Aside from wanting to square their books for the weekend because of nervousness over the Mideast situation, many in the fixed-income market were concerned about the large supply of refunding issues that are still in the hands of dealers,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. 
 
Japanese Absence a Factor
The absence of Japanese investors at this week's record refunding also created some unease, Mr. Ricchiuto said, ''but everybody's primary focus today seemed to be on getting their portfolios hedged for the weekend.''
Once the Chicago Board of Trade's bond futures market, the nation's largest such market, closed at 3 P.M., Eastern daylight time, the cash market in Treasury securities, which observes no fixed hours, meandered in light dealings.
Late in the session in New York, the outstanding benchmark Treasury long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in May 2020, were being offered at 99 18/32, off 12/32, while the yield rose to 8.79 percent, up from 8.76 percent the day before and 8.55 percent a week ago.
The Chicago bond futures market was just as volatile as the cash market, with the spot September futures contract in Chicago, which is the nearest delivery month, ranging between 91 23/32 and 90 8/32, before settling at 90 28/32, down 14/32 on the day.
 
New Long Bonds at 8.77%
The $10.25 billion of new 30-year long bonds, auctioned Thursday at an average yield of 8.87 percent, traded on a when-issued basis at 99 24/32, off 12/32 on the day, for a yield of 8.77 percent. Also in when-issued trading, the $10.5 billion of 10-year notes auctioned Wednesday at an average yield of 8.77 percent traded at 100 19/ 32, down 5/32, to yield 8.66 percent, while the $11.5 billion of three-year notes sold Tuesday at an average yield of 8.10 percent were unchanged at 99 24/32, for a yield of 8.09 percent.
When-issued trading ends, in effect, when the refunding notes and bonds are ''settled,'' or paid for, by the buyers. The record refunding auctions of this week will be settled on Aug. 15.
The shorter Treasury issues were essentially unchanged or posted minor losses, largely because this maturity sector would be the most immediately and beneficially affected by any lowering of interest rates by the Federal Reserve. Economists belief the Fed will soon have to cut interest rates to avoid a recession later this year.
 
Reserves Added to System
Thus, the shortest coupon issue, the 8 percent notes of 1992, were unchanged at 100 3/32, for a yield of 7.94 percent.
Similarly, discount rates on Treasury bills were basically unchanged, with the 90-day bills off a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point; the six-month bills were unchanged, at 7.29 percent, and the one-year bills slipped 4 basis points, to 7.15 percent.
As it has all week, the Fed added more reserves to the banking system. The latest intervention involved $1.5 billion of customer repurchase agreements. And once again the Fed's action was considered a technical response to seasonal needs rather than any policy move.
This supposition was supported by the steadiness in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans. The funds traded almost all day at 8 percent, before closing a touch easier at 7 15/16 percent.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Show Decline of 0.1% for July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level fell by a tenth of a percent in July, the Labor Department said today in a report that economists said showed a weakening economy even before the current oil-price shock.
Last month's decline was the first drop since April in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which foreshadows price trends at the retail level, but economists worried that it was a sign of falling demand for goods.
The department noted that the index measured producer prices before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which has sent oil prices soaring and provoked warnings that inflation would be fired up as increased energy costs rippled through the economy.
 
Uncertainty on Severity
''It's fair to say we're going to see some acceleration in energy prices, but the jury's still out on just how severe that's going to be,'' said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. 
The price of United States benchmark crude oil has gone to about $26 a barrel from $21.55 on Aug. 1, before the Mideast crisis. A barrel was at about $17 in early July.
July producer prices were more restrained than economists had expected. Their forecasts had been for a rise of two-tenths of a percent, which would have matched June's rise. But prices at the producer level are expected to soar in August and September as the impact of higher energy costs hits.
During the first seven months of the year, producer prices rose at a relatively modest annual rate of 3 percent, compared with a 4.8 percent rate of increase for all of 1989.
 
Decline in 'Core Rate'
Excluding the volatile food and energy components, producer prices still fell a tenth of a percent in July after a six-tenths rise in June. This is the ''core rate'' of inflation that is sometimes cited as a more reliable indicator of producer price trends.
It was the first decline in a year for the core rate, but that was not seen positively by some economists. Richard Rahn, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said it was ''a clear sign of weakening demand'' for goods. That impression is bolstered by lower factory orders, declining consumer demand, higher unemployment and more unsold goods, he added.
''The economy is virtually dead in its tracks,'' said Mr. Rahn, who expects a recession by the year's end.
After the release of the report, Government bonds rose moderately, but they later fell, and the stock market was sharply lower as the Dow Jones industrial average ended with a drop of 42.33 points, to 2,716.58. Traders said the markets were more affected, however, by Mideast uncertainty than by the price report, which has largely been superseded by recent oil price rises.
The price report showed that energy prices in July fell five-tenths of a percent after a nine-tenths drop in June. Gasoline prices were down 5.3 percent after a slight four-tenths rise in June. Crude petroleum prices fell 4 percent last month after an 11.9 percent June drop.
Crude oil prices were 23 percent lower in July than they were a year earlier, while gasoline prices at the producer level were 1.3 percent lower. Wholesalers pushed gasoline prices up strongly in the days after Iraq's invasion, and prices at the pump have risen more than 15 cents a gallon on average.
Consumer food prices were unchanged in July, after a drop of four-tenths of a percent in June. Tobacco and automobile prices fell, but prescription drugs cost more.
Speculation has grown that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, although a Fed governor, John P. LaWare, said on Thursday that it was too early to say how hard the economy would be hit by the higher energy costs.
Mitsubishi Bank economists estimate that each $1 rise in crude oil prices translates into a 4 percent increase in wholesale gasoline prices and a 2 percent rise in prices consumers pay at the pump. That, in turn, increases producer prices aboout two-tenths of a percent a month.
The various changes in producer prices put the July index for all finished goods, not seasonally adjusted, at 118, which means that a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $118 last month, up from $114.10 a year earlier.
In two companion reports covering earlier production stages, prices for intermediate goods were unchanged, while prices for crude goods rose six-tenths of a percent. Examples of the types of products in each of the three processing stages would be clothing for finished goods, cloth for intermediate and cotton for crude.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Highest Since March As Fears on Mideast Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures reached their highest levels in nearly five months yesterday as fiery rhetoric from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq reignited fears that a Middle East war would wreak economic havoc on the West.
In other markets, soybeans rallied strongly while wheat futures plunged.
Gold futures settled $11.10 to $12 higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for delivery in August at $396.90 an ounce, the highest spot-month settlement since March 19. 
Silver futures settled 11.1 cents to 12.7 cents higher, with August at $4.969 an ounce.
The gold market surged after President Hussein, in an outburst of fury against Western efforts to devastate his economy and hem in his army, called on Arabs everywhere to wage ''holy war'' against enemies of Islam.
Hours after the Hussein statement, a majority of the Arab League nations agreed to dispatch an Arab force to defend Saudi Arabia and approved economic sanctions against Iraq.
The developments set off a run-up in oil futures - West Texas Intermediate crude settled 56 cents higher, to $26.23 a barrel, for September delivery - and a decline of 42.33 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. Both moves supported the gold market, which tends to attract investors during times of inflation and economic and political uncertainty.
''Gold is getting helped twice, once by the political instability in the Middle East and once by the price of crude oil,'' said Jim Paul, chief commodities analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Gold has gained momentum since tumbling below $345 an ounce in June. Mr. Paul said the chart patterns, on which many large institutional investors and commodity funds make their trading decisions, indicate that the precious metals are likely to move higher.
But, he cautioned, ''We're not trading gold and silver; we're trading political events in the Middle East,and we don't know what's happening next.''
Soybean futures ended sharply higher, but below the day's highs, on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department issued a harvest estimate that was lower than expected. The market dropped from its highs on spillover selling from the grain pits, where a large sell order for wheat caused a plunge late in the session.
Analysts said the strength in soybeans was mainly a reaction to Thursday's Agriculture Department report. The Government projected a soybean harvest of 1.84 billion bushels, about 20 million less than expected. The estimate for the corn harvest - 7.85 billion bushels - was about 70 million less than expected.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Economy and Rates Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against most major currencies yesterday despite the possibility of an escalation of Middle East hostilities that could disrupt oil flows from that region and damage economies.
Analysts said weakness in the United States economy and the prospect of lower American interest rates weighed on the dollar. Trading was described as light. 
As Arab leaders gathered for a meeting yesterday in Cairo, the President of Iraq, Saddam Hussein, called on Arabs everywhere to attack Western forces in the region, overthrow the Saudi royal family and take back the Moslem holy sites in Saudi Arabia.
But a majority of the Arab League nations at the meeting later agreed to send troops to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq, approved economic sanctions against Baghdad and condemned the invasion of Kuwait.
In New York trading, the dollar fell against every major currency except the Japanese yen and the Canadian dollar after turning in a mixed performance on foreign exchange markets overseas.
''We saw dollar weakness at the close of the European session, and it carried over to New York,'' said Marc Chandler, a currency markets analyst at MMS International in Chicago. He added that the dollar was suffering because of the weakness in the United States economy, the likelihood of rising inflation and chances that American interest rates will fall while rates in Germany may rise.
He said the dollar would probably be even lower were it not for the Persian Gulf situation. Some investors turn to the dollar during strife on the theory that it offers more security than other currencies. ''The danger for the dollar now is for a protracted and costly United States involvement, he added.
The dollar rose to 150.40 yen in New York from 149.81 yen late Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar edged up 0.07 yen, to 149.75 yen. The dollar was quoted at 150.20 yen in London.
But the dollar fell against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8735 from $1.8680 late Thursday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8730 from $1.8720 late Thursday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.5895 marks, from 1.5965.
Dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.3375 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435; 1,165.00 Italian lire, down from 1,168.50; 5.3325 French francs, down from 5.3510, and 1.14705 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14695.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Environmental Doubts on 'Green' Ads

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
As big manufacturers start to pay environmental groups to help promote products like toilet paper and beer, the new marketing strategy is dividing environmental advocates.
Some groups say they have rejected lucrative offers and criticize others for lending their names to products that cannot be recycled or to alcoholic beverages. Other advocates say they fear that environmental endorsements may make consumers lose respect for the movement.
Sears and Coca-Cola are among the companies that pay a fee or a percentage of sales to environmental groups whose names they can then use in promotions and advertising. Among the products that have marketing arrangements with environmental groups are Minute Maid juices, Tanqueray gin and Canon copiers. 
''You hope the consumer takes away a little better feeling about your brand name and product,'' said Dan A. Schafer, a spokesman for Minute Maid, which is owned by Coca-Cola.
Coca-Cola is running a promotion with the National Parks and Conservation Association, a private group in Washington. In it, buyers of unrefrigerated Minute Maid juices can help pay for the planting of trees in Redwood National Park in California. The cost to the consumer for each tree is 75 cents, which the company matches; it has also paid $10,000 to the association, Mr. Schafer said.
The new marketing efforts probably will not raise product prices. But several environmental advocates said they may further antagonize consumers who feel they have been misled by false claims about product biodegradability.
''We'll lose our credibility if everything in the marketplace has the imprimatur of an environmental group,'' said John Bell, a spokesman for Friends of the Earth in Washington. Rosemary Carroll, the director of development for the Sierra Club in San Francisco, said: ''There is a lot of schlock out there right now. We've been approached by manufacturers of tampons, toilet paper and automotive parts, and we are not in the position to evaluate whether they are environmentally sensitive or not.''
Friends of the Earth recently passed up $25,000 from Marla Maples as part of a deal in which the group's name would be used in promoting No Excuses jeans, for which Ms. Maples serves as a spokeswoman. Michael Clark, the group's president, said the offer was not accepted because the group did not have enough time to assess the manufacturer's environmental record.
''We are getting at least one offer like this every week,'' he said. Ms. Maples's money is now expected to go to the Better World Society, a nonprofit group in Washington that produces and acquires documentary television programs on, among other things, environmental issues.
Previously, marketing that drew on environmental concerns was limited to companies closely identified with natural products or the outdoors: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., Patagonia Inc. and the Body Shop, to name a few. Typically, such companies donate part of their profits - from 1 to 10 percent of pretax profits - to environmental causes.
 
'Companies Can Help'
 But big consumer companies have entered the arena, driven by the so-called ''green'' marketing movement. ''We believe that consumers are becoming more sensitive to the fact companies can help the environment,'' said Richard Knudson, vice president of marketing for Moosehead Breweries of Canada.
The company has announced that, upon a consumer's request, it will give $1 to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation for every six-pack of its beer purchased. It has guaranteed the group at least $100,000. The foundation was set up by Congress in 1984 to funnel private donations to the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service. The Government will match the Moosehead donations.
Some groups, like the Sierra Club, are developing guidelines on the kinds of products they would promote. Others, like the Environmental Defense Fund in New York, have decided to steer clear of the arrangements. ''We have to be an independent force, free to criticize who we want,'' said Fred Krupp, the fund's executive director.
Many environmental leaders say they do not object to such marketing arrangements, because they can help raise money for, and awareness about, an important cause. But some said they were concerned that groups might sell their name too cheaply or to the wrong company.
''Most environmental groups don't have the resources to investigate whether the company they are endorsing has a track record they can be comfortable with,'' said Alice Tepper Marlin, the executive director of the Council on Economic Priorities. Her New York City group rates the environmental records of consumer product companies.
Some promotions are already under attack. Several environmental leaders criticized the arrangement between Minute Maid and the National Parks and Conservation Association because the juice packages cannot be recycled.
''Rather than addressing the waste they are creating, they are trying to put a good face on it by saying they are going to plant trees,'' said Ruth Caplan, who heads the Environmental Action Fund in Washington.
Mr. Schafer, the Minute Maid spokesman, responded that the packaging compared favorably with other containers. Elliot Gruber, the association's director of development, said, ''We have expressed our concern, but they won't change it.''
Promotion of alcoholic beverages is another sensitive issue for some environmental advocates. The National Parks and Conservation Association recently ran a promotion with Tanqueray gin, offering buyers of the gin a chance to win a trip to a national park. The company made a donation to the association, but Mr. Gruber would not say how much it was.
Spokesmen for several groups - including American Rivers, Friends of the Earth and the Environmental Action Fund - said they would not take part in promotions with companies that produced alcoholic beverages or tobacco.
But other groups said they saw nothing wrong with joining with alcohol producers. ''I don't think our promotion is going to make people who don't buy beer buy beer,'' said Charles Collins, executive director of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, which is involved in the Moosehead campaign. ''We feel the promotion is being done in a responsible manner, and it is giving us a chance to reach a broad audience that we have not reached before.''
Ultimately, however, environmentalists say their biggest fear is a loss of credibility. With many shoppers already confused by a recent wave of false or misleading environmental claims by manufacturers, the growing promotion of products by environmentalists may quickly come back to haunt them.
''A lot of companies are saying the environment is hot now and see it as a way of increasing their sales,'' Mr. Gruber said. ''Their concern is the bottom line, and it is up to us to somehow walk the fence and say we want to have more money and still retain our credibility.''

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;
Cancellation Canceled

 BODY:
Soviet hockey authorities, who were outraged when a top Soviet player, Sergei Fedorov, left their national team at the Goodwill Games in Seattle on July 21 to sign a contract with the Detroit Red Wings, have decided not to cancel a series of exhibition games with National Hockey League teams.
Officials of the Soviet Hockey Federation announced Sunday in Seattle that they would cancel two exhibition tours, one by the Montreal Canadiens and the Minnesota North Stars, who are scheduled to visit the Soviet Union next month, and one by three Soviet teams, which are scheduled to visit the 21 N.H.L. cities in December and January. The officials said the Red Wings' signing of Fedorov, 20 years old, violated the Soviet labor code and agreements between the Soviet Union and the N.H.L.
But as Tass, the Soviet press agency, made clear yesterday, the authorities simply had second thoughts about taking a punitive action against the N.H.L. that might punish the cash-starved Soviet economy. Some estimates suggest the economy could lose $1 million in hard currency if the tours were canceled.
Instead, the Soviet authorities have hit on a less disruptive way to protest the Red Wings' action: a lawsuit.
Tass said the Soviet federation was looking for ''experienced North American lawyers'' to assist in the litigation in an international or North American court. (AP)

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: Wooed, Wined and Overworked, Wall St. Lawyers Meet Pink Slips

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
They were the legal profession's gilded generation, an army of lawyers without limits. As law students, they were wined and dined and wooed by the most prestigious law firms in New York. Once hired, they began settling into a frantic but fantastically lucrative life. It was a life of glamour, prestige and, they assumed, stability.
Now, only a few years later, dozens of these lawyers have had a crash course in the realities of modern Wall Street practice. For the first time in their lives - lives of success atop success - they find themselves in an unusual position. They have been fired.
As the sour corporate climate reaches large law firms in New York and to a lesser degree cities like Los Angeles and Chicago, a bubble has burst. With business down, particularly in corporate work, real estate, and mergers and acquisitions, several of the most famous law firms have dismissed substantial numbers of lawyers, particularly those in the early years of their careers. 
The ax fell disproportionately on women - a reflection of their continuing marginal status at some firms, despite record raw numbers. In others, it fell on those brought in laterally from other firms rather than home-grown products. In still more, it fell more capriciously - on those who had the wrong mentor, an absentee mentor, or no mentor at all.
On the spectrum of hardship cases, the plight of 25-year-olds making $85,000 a year, most with skills more than sufficient to find work elsewhere, is admittedly not the saddest. There is no constitutional right to foreign cars or second mortgages. But many still carry large debts from law school. Moreover, there is the shock of dismissals in a world unfamiliar with them, as well as what the lawyers involved contend is the disingenuous way in which they were handled.
Elite law firms have always fancied themselves paternalistic places, where loyalty mattered more than the bottom line. While only a handful of associates were eventually promoted to partner, all but the most inept could remain, often for years, until something else came along. And when they left, they left quietly, with their reputations and their dignity intact.
Now, young lawyers are discovering that the marketplace works both ways.
''I never expected to stay forever, but I didn't expect to get booted out the door,'' said an associate formerly at Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, one of 24 dismissed earlier this year shortly before the firm's main client, Drexel Burnham Lambert, went bankrupt.
The firms involved do not deny that many of their lawyers have been asked to leave. But they have proven more willing to let go of lawyers than of the myth of gentility they have long cherished. Straining to preserve what remains of that image, they insist the dismissals are based on merit rather than on reduced earnings.
A representative comment came earlier this year from Roger Meltzer, a partner at Cahill Gordon and the firm's spokesman. ''The quote, layoffs, were not related to any financial problems at the firm; they were related strictly to the merits,'' he told Manhattan Lawyer magazine, a trade publication.
Mr. Meltzer declined to be interviewed for this article.
 
Feeling Blamed and Betrayed
The layoffs have left many of the young lawyers feeling betrayed by institutions which, they charge, courted them, exploited their loyalty, and worked them incessantly, only to dump them when times got tough and to blame them for poor performances. That, in turn, leaves some feeling chagrined over their own naivete.
''A lot of young people think they can go to a good law school and get a degree which will guarantee them stability and interesting work for the rest of their lives,'' said Lesley M. Friedman of Special Counsel Inc., a legal temporary service which has helped place some of the dismissed lawyers.
One of the more than 20 lawyers dismissed this year by Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson agreed. ''Maybe I was deceiving myself,'' he said. ''They'd always portrayed themselves as something other than the factory I guess they are.''
''I feel like an idiot, I really do,'' said another lawyer, one of 10 dismissed by Rosenman & Colin. ''When it comes down to money they'll just turn around and stab you in the back. Everyone is saying I'll get over it, but it's something I don't think I'll ever get over. I really felt that I was a good lawyer.''
Like almost all of those interviewed, these lawyers spoke on the condition that they not be identified. Those still working at their firms as they look for other jobs fear antagonizing the very people who have dismissed them, on whom they must still rely for references. Others, who have left, fear being branded second-rate.
''Egos have a lot to do with this industry,'' said one former associate at Rosenman & Colin. ''Even if the layoffs were economic, no one wants someone else's rejects.''
Given the secrecy surrounding the dismissals, no one knows the exact number of lawyers affected by the cutbacks. But industry experts agree that the numbers of those dismissed in the last six months far exceed normal attrition, and that at some firms most affected by the economic downturn a purge of sorts is under way. Other firms involved include Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy and Willkie, Farr & Gallagher, each of which has dismissed 22; and Shea & Gould, which has told at least 20 to leave.
The dismissals have created a climate of fear in large firms, a feeling not confined to those directly affected. It has spread to summer associates who expect to receive far fewer offers of permanent employment this year. It exists, too, among lawyers who survived the last round of dismissals but fear the next, which many expect to come sometime after Labor Day.
''Nobody feels secure,'' said an associate dismissed by Rosenman & Colin. ''Everyone's walking around on eggshells.''
But to the lawyers involved, what seems to matter more than the dismissals themselves is how they were done. Almost without exception, they said their firms initially assured them that they would ride out the tough times and not dismiss anyone.
Then, once the dismissals began, the firms chose to malign those they were jettisoning rather than acknowledge their own problems.
Merit was the only issue, contended Arthur Fleischer Jr. of Fried Frank.
''People who are not functioning as their peers are, are told that it doesn't make a lot of sense for them to stay here,'' he said. ''That goes back to time immemorial.'' He dismissed as nonsense the suggestion that anyone had been dismissed for economic reasons.
''I know most of the people who were let go, and most of them got great reviews,'' one recently dismissed Fried Frank lawyer countered. ''Don't give me this garbage that they were scum.''
''Even though they're fooling no one, it's easier to say 'These people weren't cutting the mustard' than to say 'We're not cutting the mustard,' '' an associate dismissed by Shea & Gould said.
That the partners at top firms continue to earn spectacular piles of money adds to the resentment. Last year, according to The American Lawyer, the average profit per partner at Cahill Gordon was $1.515 million - the highest of any law firm.
At other firms as well, the cutbacks are incongruously juxtaposed with signs of the record prosperity they recently enjoyed. Shea & Gould, for instance, just moved into lavish new offices in the Exxon building; partners there continue to enjoy catered lunches costing thousands of dollars a week.
 
Few Firms Admit Layoffs
Even so, the firm has just laid off its only black associate, a woman who had been elected by her colleagues only a few weeks earlier to a committee set up to discuss problems of younger lawyers. Others were dismissed within months of their arrival; one was told, ''You have about as much chance of making partner as you have of growing feathers.'' Still more have been dismissed in the last few weeks, when hiring everywhere is slow.
One Shea & Gould lawyer, Charles J. Spinelli, was let go while his wife was four months pregnant. ''I did not inform my wife for three months for fear that she would have a miscarriage; she had had one the year before,'' said Mr. Spinelli, who recently opened up his own office on Staten Island. ''It was agonizing.''
Leon Gold, a member of Shea & Gould's executive committee, did not return phone calls. Nor did partners at Milbank Tweed.
In any case, terms like dismissed and layoffs remain stricken from the lexicon at many of these law firms. Laura Colangelo, a legal recruiter in New York, explained why. ''Nobody is ever going to admit there've been any layoffs,'' she said. ''That means business is down.''
In fact, at least one managing partner, Robert Hodes of Willkie, Farr & Gallagher, acknowledged that some of those discharged at his firm were for economic reasons, and that they understood that this was so. ''There was no way not to be candid,'' he said. ''These are very smart people.''
Those dismissed include graduates of the top law schools, among them Harvard, Columbia, New York University, and the Universities of Michigan and Chicago. But more are from less prestigious law schools, including Fordham, New York Law School, Brooklyn and Cardozo, from which top firms first began hiring during the prosperous 1980's. That may signal a return to the elitism of an earlier age, and further complicates some job searches.
''I've never seen a marketplace this bad,'' said a former Fried Frank lawyer. ''A lot of firms say they're looking, but it's window dressing. What they're looking for are Harvard grads who walk on water. And if they have billable hours, that's nice, too.''

With him is his partner, Carmine DeSantis. (George McNish for The New York Times) (pg. 30)

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Mirage of Arab Unity

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The political map of the Arab world has been remade, or perhaps erased, overnight.
The vote of the Arab summit meeting on Friday night to send a symbolic force to join American troops deployed in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's takeover of Kuwait shattered the myth of Arab unity that has cloaked differences for decades. It is as if someone threw all the pieces of a game up in the air.
''This is the end of the Arab world as we and they have known it,'' said Judith Kipper, a Middle East analyst at the Brookings Institution. 
 
Arab World in Turmoil
''The Arabs basically are confronted with themselves,'' she said. ''Two myths went out the window: their capacity to protect themselves and pan-Arabism. It's a tremendous identity crisis.''
The swift unfolding of previously unthinkable events in the nine days since President Saddam Hussein of Iraq gobbled up his wealthy but weak neighbor and former ally have left the Arab world in turmoil.
Egypt, only recently emerging from a decade of isolation brought on by its peace treaty with Israel, has again become a center of the Arab world with President Hosni Mubarak's handling of the crisis. Iraq, the most powerful single player, supported for years by other Arabs as their protector from Iran, is suddenly a pariah, an isolated renegade.
 
Troops Leave for Saudi Arabia
The first several hundred Egyptian paratroopers and desert-trained commandos left here today for Saudi Arabia in a cosmetic, but politically important, deployment to put an Arab face on the American 82d Airborne Division's presence there. Arrangements were being made today for Moroccan and Syrian troops to join them.
But as a military and economic noose tightens around him, Mr. Hussein has launched an emotional appeal to frustrated, impoverished and discontented Arabs, invoking resentment not only of foreigners but of oil-rich hereditary rulers and the alleged ''defiling'' of Muslim shrines that could well threaten shaky Arab governments.
Elsewhere in the Arab world, Mr. Hussein found support in the streets. In Sana, the capital of Yemen, 10,000 demonstrators screaming, ''Fahd, atheist priest, Saddam lives and you must die!'' marched today on the Saudi and American Embassies. The crowd, which was protesting the Saudi King's invitation to American forces, threw rocks and worn-out shoes, an Arab insult.
Thousands rallied in support of Mr. Hussein in the biggest demonstration in Mauritania in years, and Palestinians demonstrated in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In Algeria, Tunisia and Jordan, support groups were raising volunteers to aid Iraq.
But in the first, morning-after sorting out, Mr. Mubarak appeared to be emerging as an immediate winner.
 
Historic Turning Point
''This will be one of those great markers in history, one of those events that indicates how disputes here will be resolved for the next 50 years,'' a senior Western diplomat said today. ''It puts the United States and this region in a new relationship that will be very important for its economic well-being for a long way down the road.
''This sequence of events has reminded the United States of the importance of the relationship with Egypt that it has nurtured now for 11 years,'' he added. ''It has really paid off in terms of American interest in the past few days.''
The senior diplomat went on to praise Mr. Mubarak's handling of the immediate situation and Egypt's return to influence in the Arab world, saying: ''This is long-term, a careful tending of garden. The Egyptians show a tremendous consistency. They move in a straight line.
 
Mobilizing Arab Countries
''He has moved with great, great care to mobilize the Arab countries, first with the Arab League resolution, then with the Arab summit. The Arab leaders are now traveling to Cairo, not to Baghdad.
''If all this plays out right, if gradually the noose tightens around Iraq and the goal of its withdrawal from Kuwait is achieved, if all that happens, Egypt is going to come out in a strong position,'' he continued. ''It will not be the strong postion of Egypt of 20 years ago based on military power, but based on conviction and persuasion.''
If Mr. Mubarak seemed an immediate winner, Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, appeared to be a first-round loser.
Frustrated with the lack of progress toward peace talks with Israel despite the pressure of more than two years of violent protests in the Israeli-occupied territories, Mr. Arafat had moved closer to Iraq in recent months believing the center of gravity in the Arab world was drifting toward Baghdad.
But by casting his lot with Iraq, Mr. Arafat has strained relations with Egypt, his main go-between with the United States in attempting to reach some kind of settlement with Israel. Perhaps even more important, he has alienated Saudi Arabia, his major bankroller.
Mr. Arafat's own Palestinian constituency is split, mirroring the dvisions between haves and have-nots in the Arab world. While frustrated Palestinians in the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and Jordan have been demonstrating in praise of Mr. Hussein, seeing him as a tough leader who threatens Israel, wealthy Palestinian expatriates in the gulf region, who regularly pay a six percent income tax to the P.L.O., have accused Mr. Hussein of destroyed their livelihoods.
 
Jordan's Difficult Position
King Hussein of Jordan is also in a difficult position. A longtime backer of Saddam Hussein, he wound up in an equivocal category at the summit, voting approval of the resolution ''with reservations.'' The King is caught among a number of pressures, not the least of which is a strong current of public opinion in Jordan supporting Iraq, much of it from Jordanians and Palestinians who worked in Kuwait and resent the way they were treated there.
President Saddam Hussein's portrayal of wealthy rulers as corrupt and subservient to the West could strike a responsive chord in Jordan, some analysts believe.
''To me, the gut issue is the regimes versus the people, because none of the Arab regimes represent their people, and this is why there is such cheering in the streets'' for President Hussein, Ms. Kipper, the Brookings expert, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Hussein has the wherewithal to foment protests through outposts of his own Baath Party and through payments to other political organizations that are emerging as the Arab world edges toward a more open politics, particularly in the North African countries, diplomats and other experts said.
But in view of Iraq's own human rights record, regarded by Amnesty International and other watchdog organizations as one of the world's worst, a number found Mr. Hussein's appeal ironic.
''It is Saddam as the avenger of past slights, appealing to everyone who was mistreated in Kuwait, everybody in the refugee camps,'' said Fouad Ajami, a Lebanese-born Middle East expert at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''They will be disabused of this. He is a man without scruples, a killer and a murderer on a vast scale. This is pan-Arabism with a bayonet, chemical weapons and a whip for all those who will not submit.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: A day after the Arab summit meeting, four participants met in Cairo. From left were President Chadli Bendjedid of Algeria, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. ''Frankly I tell you there is no hope'' for a peaceful solution to the crisis, said Mr. Mubarak, who orchestrated the Arab states' move to oppose Iraq. (Associated Press) (pg. 12)
