The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1475 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Gulf Policy: Vague 'Vital Interest'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
In his statement to the nation on Wednesday explaining the decision to send American troops to the Arabian Peninsula, President Bush said that the defense of Saudi Arabia was of ''vital interest'' to the United States. But Mr. Bush and his top aides have not clearly defined just how the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait touches the lives of Americans or affects their future.
For many Americans, the connection is not clear. Beyond the quick jump in gasoline prices, many people seem to share the view of Katie Safier of Miami, who mused in an interview: ''Why should we be involved? We could get oil from Mexico.''
One reason Bush Administration officials have not clearly articulated what is at stake is that the real political and economic interests involved are not quite so lofty as some of the broad principles used by the President to explain the operation. 
 
Freedom Is Not the Issue
The United States has not sent troops to the Saudi desert to preserve democratic principles. The Saudi monarchy is a feudal regime that does not even allow women to drive cars. Surely it is not American policy to make the world safe for feudalism. This is about money, about protecting governments loyal to America and punishing those that are not and about who will set the price of oil.
The failure to spell out the American stakes and justify them is also due to the inarticulate way the President and his advisers try to explain foreign policy to the American people.
In addition, President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other top officials live in a rarefied world of foreign policy discussions with a set of assumptions about the pivotal importance of the Persian Gulf - to such a degree that it does not always occur to officials to spell out what is at stake.
 
A Vital Interest Since 1949
As Mr. Baker told his NATO allies on Friday, without much elaboration: ''Since 1949, every American President has said that the gulf is a vital U.S. and Western interest.''
Why? To listen to American officials speaking privately, these interests can be divided into three broad categories, each of which is worthy of scrutiny.
One is the price of oil. Another is who controls the oil. The third is the need to uphold the integrity of national boundaries so that predatory regional powers will not simply begin devouring their neighbors.
The oil price argument goes as follows: If Iraq is able to get away with annexing Kuwait, it will control 20 percent of the world's oil reserves. If, in turn, it could also intimidate Saudi Arabia, the Iraqis would have influence over 45 percent of the world's oil reserves.
This would be bad for the United States, so the argument goes, because President Saddam Hussein would then be able to dominate pricing by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
 
In 1970's, No Reprisal for Saudis
But the United States did not threaten Saudi Arabia in the early 1970's when Riyadh totally dominated OPEC oil pricing and even used an oil boycott to try to force Washington to change its policies toward Israel.
Why is the United States' reaction different when Iraq is doing the dominating?
The answer, officials say, is that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq wants oil prices to rise more quickly than Saudi Arabia does.
At the OPEC meeting last month, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, President Hussein was pressing his OPEC colleagues to increase prices from around $15 a barrel to $25.
The other OPEC producers, including Saudi Arabia, shared his desire for a higher price, but they wanted a price of only $21 a barrel so as not to stimulate alternative energy production by the West. #5 Cents a Gallon More The difference for Americans between $21 a barrel and $25 a barrel is about 5 cents a gallon at the gasoline station pump.
In other words, by the price argument, one reason that the Bush Administration is sending 100,000 soldiers to Saudi Arabia is for the sake of 5 cents a gallon less. Some people say that in some ways it would actually be in the American interest to have higher oil prices, to rekindle research and development of alternative energy sources.
Such research was on its way to making the United States more independent of foreign oil before the Reagan and Bush Administrations abandoned support for the projects.
But officials argue that there is a lot more at stake than a 5 cent increase at the pump. President Hussein, they say, was only asking for $25 a barrel because he did not then dominate OPEC enough to seek more.
Oil is the single most important commodity in the industrial world, and its assured supply at reasonable prices is considered essential for economic growth - not just in the United States but also in Western Europe, Japan and the world at large.
If the Iraqi leader could, directly or indirectly, control 40 percent of the world's oil reserves, they go on, who knows what price he would demand -$40 a barrel? Maybe $50 a barrel?
Such an increase would almost surely tip all Western economies into recession. But it is not at all clear that Mr. Hussein would have any more interest in raising oil prices to $50 a barrel than Saudi Arabia did when it dominated OPEC.
The Iraqis understand the world oil market as well as the Saudis. That means understanding that if prices are pushed too high too fast, the West will find alternative energy sources, which will sooner or later drive the price of oil way down.
 
Saudis More Responsive
The second category is control of the oil. It is in the American interest, so the argument goes, that control of oil be divided among many states. But to the extent that it is not, Washington would like control to be in Saudi hands.
The reason is that, unlike Iraq, Saudi Arabia's leaders have historically been more responsive to American interests and staunchly anti-Soviet. President Bush cannot say that out loud, though, because it would embarrass the Saudi monarchy.
The United States is not sending troops to the gulf simply to help Saudi Arabia resist aggression. It is sending troops to support the OPEC country that is more likely to cater to Washington's interests.
In the past, when the United States was confronting the Soviet Union and competing for influence with Moscow in the Middle East, the stake in whose allies controlled what oil reserves had a military and strategic dimension. But today, with the Soviet Union cooperating in this crisis, that argument has lost much of its urgency.
The third and final vital interest at stake, Administration officials say, is the stability of the post-cold war world. If President Hussein gets away with taking over Kuwait by force, then other regional powers might be tempted to use similar means to advance their interests in their corners of the world.
That, officials say, means that is essential for future world stability that the United States and Soviet Union stand together and give a clear signal that such action will not be tolerated. The sovereignty of nations must be upheld.
As Secretary of State Baker said in a speech to NATO this week, ''If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.''
 
U.S. Violates the Credo
Yet, the Administration has not always acted on that credo in other areas of the world. During its first 18 months in office it supported a policy in Cambodia that would eventually have involved bringing the Khmer Rouge guerrillas back into the ruling coalition.
The Khmer Rouge are held responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians during their reign of terror in the 1970's. Although American policy has now been altered, might-makes-right was considered acceptable for Cambodia because it served the American strategic interest of countering the influence of the pro-Soviet Vietnamese Government.
In other words, both the might-makes-right arguments and those of national sovereignty are really, at best, more palatable ways of saying that the United States interest in preserving the status quo and stability in the Persian Gulf in primarily economic.
At root, then, the vital interests to which President Bush referred are both genuine and significant, given America's current dependence on foreign oil. Laid bare, American policy in the gulf comes down to this: troops have been sent to retain control of oil in the hands of a pro-American Saudi Arabia, so prices will remain low.
As an editorial cartoon in The Boston Globe on Thursday suggested, the interest at stake may be, in short, to make the world safe for gas guzzlers. The cartoon shows President Bush in the Oval Office addressing the American people. He says: ''Fellow Americans, I have sent our troops to the Middle East. . . . They are there to defend the security . . . the value . . . the principle we hold dear - 18 miles per gallon.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
ARAB TROOPS JOIN SAUDI FORCE; BUSH SAYS HE HOPES THE IRAQIS 'DO SOMETHING' ABOUT HUSSEIN

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
As Egyptian and Moroccan troops began landing in Saudi Arabia to guard against the threat of an Iraqi invasion, President Bush made it plain today that it would please him if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were to be overthrown.
Egypt and Morocco planned to send about 5,000 troops each to Saudi Arabia, probably with artillery and armored support, according to diplomats here.
Syrian officials said Damascus would also take part in the joint effort, which was approved on Friday at an Arab meeting in Cairo, possibly by sending troops to one of the tiny emirates at the mouth of the Persian Gulf that have been worried that they, too, might be invaded by Iraq.
 
Gunfire Reported on Saudi Soil
In the first word of gunfire on Saudi territory, diplomats in Riyadh reported that Saudi antiaircraft batteries had shot at two Iraqi reconnaissance planes near the Kuwaiti-Saudi border, The Associated Press said. An unidentified Saudi official quoted by the news agency disputed their accounts. The envoys said the Saudis fired about 10 rounds near but not at the planes, which then turned back without crossing the border. 
Answering reporters' questions at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., this afternoon, President Bush said the United States could not take any active part in ousting the Iraqi dictator. But he said, ''Whatever it takes to have our objectives met is what should take place.''
He said he expected President Hussein to respect the borders of Iraq's neighbors, adding: ''If that means Saddam Hussein changes his spots, so be it. If he doesn't, I hope the Iraqi people do something about it.'' [Excerpts from Mr. Bush's remarks, page 12.] Doubts on Peaceful Solution Mr. Bush also declared more bluntly than before that he and other leaders intended to use naval force to prevent Iraq from exporting oil.
''I think things are moving in the right direction,'' President Bush said as forces from a dozen countries converged on Saudi Arabia to join the multinational defense effort. But he suggested, without elaboration, that he thought that there was still room for a diplomatic solution to the crisis.
In Cairo, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt expressed a markedly different view. Asked about the chances of a peaceful solution, which he had spent the last week seeking, he replied, ''I want to tell you honestly, and note that I am always optimistic, there is no hope of that.'' #10-Year-Old Reaches Jordan More than 5,000 American troops are believed to be in Saudi Arabia, and the total is expected to reach 100,000 in the next month or two, although United States officials have refused to supply any official figures.
As the Arab troops arrived at Hafr al Baten, a Saudi air base near Dhahran, a group of 11 Americans, including Penelope Nabokov, a 10-year-old California girl trapped in Kuwait while traveling alone, reached Jordan after a grueling 660-mile bus journey across Iraq. The 10 other members of the party were diplomats and their families.
 
More Foreigners Escape
Five West Germans and 21 Britons also escaped from Iraq or Kuwait, whose borders were sealed for all but diplomats by Baghdad on Thursday. And an estimated 32 foreigners, mostly Americans and Britons, reportedly arrived in Bahrain today after escaping from Kuwait and traveling across the desert with the help of Bedouin guides.
But there was no success in persuading the Government of President Hussein to permit the departure of 3,500 other Americans still trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, which Iraq annexed this week.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the United States Embassy in Baghdad ''is in contact almost hourly'' with Iraqi officials to try to insure the Americans' safety.
''We're hopeful that we will be able to resolve the situation,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said. ''So far as we know, no American has been mistreated as yet.''
The American buildup in Saudi Arabia, also centered on Hafr al-Baten, continued with the arrival of more units of the 82d Airborne Division and more C-130 transport planes from Pope Air Force Base, N.C., and F-16 fighters from Shaw Air Froce Base, S.C., the Pentagon said.
Military officers said the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy would set sail from Norfolk, Va., for the Middle East next week. Its arrival there would give the United States four carriers in the region, unless one of them is sent back to its home port.
King Hussein of Jordan said today that he was not sending Jordanian forces to protect Saudi Arabia unless the United States and other non-Arab nations pulled out, Reuters reported.
In an interview with Cable News Network, the King said that Jordan had ''made it clear to Saudi Arabia'' that ''if they wanted our forces as part of a uniquely Arab force, we certainly would send all the units we could.''
Taking precautions against the possibility that Iraq might try to open a second front by attacking to the north, Turkey moved squadrons of F-4 and F-16 warplanes to several bases near the Iraqi border, newspaper reports in Ankara said. The Italian Defense Minister, Virginio Rognoni, reported Iraqi troop movements near the 200-mile frontier with Turkey.
 
Iraqi Oil Shipments Stifled
Tension between the two countries is high because Turkey, in adherence to United Nations sanctions, has in effect closed the pipelines running from Iraq across its territory to the Mediterranean port of Yumurtalik.
Mr. Rognoni also said Baghdad was massing chemical weapons near the Saudi border. Iraqi diplomats have said publicly in recent days that Iraq would use poison gas if it was attacked.
The White House confirmed that shipments of Iraqi oil through Saudi Arabia and Turkey had been completely cut off. And Mr. Fitzwater said the economic embargo, on which the President is counting to persuade Mr. Hussein to pull his forces out of Kuwait, ''appears to be having a considerable effect.''
Mr. Bush said only one small tanker had been loaded with Iraqi oil since shortly after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait before dawn on Aug. 2.
 
Searching Ships for Oil
Although he again avoided the word blockade, the President said the United States and its allies were prepared to stop and search tankers if necessary to insure that no Iraqi oil passed through the Strait of Hormuz, which is Iraq's only outlet to the sea.
Despite dispute on the point at the United Nations, he said the United States, in his view, already had authority from the international organization to halt Iraqi ships.
He said that while he had made ''a decision in principle that exports from Iraq will not get into the market,'' he did not want to use the word blockade because that might disturb other countries who were backing sanctions but whose view of what the United Nations Security Council had authorized might differ from that of the United States.
Intelligence officials said Iraq's economic plight has already reached the point that Baghdad sent Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, its Oil Minister, to Syria this week to try to persuade officials there to reopen a pipeline to the Syrian port of Banias that Syria closed during the Iran-Iraq war. Syria and Iraq have been bitter enemies for a number of years, and the mission reportedly failed.
There were indications that Baghdad was preparing for a long economic siege. The Government warned that selling food on the black market would be considered a criminal act of sabotage, punishable by death.
Mr. Bush met today with top foreign-policy aides, including Mr. Baker, the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Robert Gates, Mr. Scowcroft's deputy.
 
SYRIA TO SEND TROOPS TO GULF
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 11 (Special to The New York Times) - Syria, seeing an opportunity to topple President Hussein of Iraq, plans to send troops to the Persian Gulf as part of the force approved in Cairo by an Arab summit conference, people close to the Syrian Government said here today.
They also said that Damascus in addition served notice that it would not come to Iraq's assistance if it is attacked by Israel.
The Syrian military deployment, according to the report from people who did not want to be further identified, will probably be in the United Arab Emirates, one of the tiny states that overlook the gulf and that Baghdad had threatened.

HEADLINE: For Emigre Scientists, Job Hunting Is Difficult

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
While American universities and corporations worry about a future shortfall of research scientists and engineers, Victor Vigdorchik, a theoretical physicist and mathematician from the Ukraine, works as a home attendant in Brooklyn.
Joseph Pilmenstein, who was a senior research chemist in Moscow, spends his time in Jersey City scanning classified advertisements in newspapers and chemical magazines.
Mr. Vigdorchik has sent out 300 resumes in the last two years, to no avail. After 100 rejections, Mr. Pilmenstein is ready to settle for any kind of work. He has removed his Ph.D. in chemistry from his resume. 
Mr. Vigdorchik, Mr. Pilmenstein and thousands of other recent emigres from the Soviet Union who are trained in the sciences have found it impossible to find work in their fields. They are keeping books, driving taxis and working as doormen and guards. Some, like Mr. Pilmenstein, are living on welfare.
 
For the Stars, an Easier Time
Unlike these emigres, the stars of Soviet science are in great demand as visiting scholars at American universities. Some have recently accepted tenured positions: Nikolai Reshetikin, a mathematical physicist, is at Harvard University, and Aleksandr Migdal, a theoretical physicist, is at Princeton University.
''In general, the quality of Soviet work and education is highest in the theoretical area, including mathematics, and many of the stars are in those areas,'' Gerson Sher, director of the United States-Soviet department at the National Science Foundation, said. The Soviets ''are not likely to be so strong'' in fields relying on equipment or experimental research, he said.
The reasons given for the plight of the refugees are legion.
Soviet emigre scientists say the principal obstacles are lack of contacts and American job experience. Some add age or the language barrier, and many say they simply do not know where to look for jobs or how to present themselves at interviews.
 
It Helps to be Well Known
American corporate employers and academicians talk of other handicaps: overqualification or underqualification, unfamiliarity with American standards and the technological gap.
Many universities and corporations are restricting hiring because of the general economic downturn.
''Academic institutions are extremely loath to hire scientists who are not sufficiently famous or sufficiently young,'' said Joel Lebowitz, a professor of mathematics and physics at Rutgers University. He said this specifically affects Soviet scientists, who are generally between the ages of 40 and 65.
Gerald Lieberman, a research professor at Stanford University, said that Stanford and other leading research universities tend to hire well-known names or scientists younger than 35. Stanford has made offers to several distinguished Soviet physicists and mathematicians in the last year.
 
How to Market Themselves
Some leading corporations like Hewlett-Packard Company have imposed hiring controls in the last year and are not actively recruiting new people, said Michele Drake, manager of personnel communications at its Palo Alto, Calif., headquarters.
Arno Penzias, vice president of research at American Telephone and Telegraph Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., said that much of the thrust today is in modern technology, ''which is not widely shared by recent Soviet immigrants.''
No one can say how many Soviet refugees with Ph.D.-level degrees in science or engineering are unemployed. The New York Association for New Americans, a resettlement agency, estimates that the 40,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants who arrived last year included 400 Ph.D.-level scientists and 6,000 engineers. Most of them are still seeking jobs in their specialties.
Some experts said that more Soviet scientists would be able to find work if they knew how to market themselves.
 
Learning About Resumes
''They know their subject, but they don't know how to compete in the American system,'' said Rafael Rich, former head of research in a Moscow petrochemical refinery. He now heads the science division of Bnai Zion, a fraternal organization in New York City.
Many Soviet applicants are generalists rather than specialists, Dr. Rich said. Others push their own ideas or talk about family troubles and are not familiar with the needs of the company.
Dr. Rich, who came here in 1979 with a postdoctoral degree in mechanical engineering, passed the American professional engineering examination. He began as a designer at Dupont, rising to senior scientist at the American Standards Testing Bureau in New York.
Now he spends most of his time teaching newly arrived Soviet scientists about resumes, interviews and references. Job-seekers are urged to send reports on their work to recognized authorities so the results will be published and distributed to research and development companies, testing laboratories and universities.
 
Success Stories
Since January, Bnai Zion has helped find jobs for 30 Soviet scientists, but has files on another 350 looking for work. Success stories include: Mark V. Kigel, who was promoted to environmental program manager for Environics of Cranford, N.J.; Igor Klimov, whose patent for an apparatus for the treatment of limbs has interested a California manufacturer, and Sophia Gruzglina, who has obtained a $7,300 grant from the National Science Foundation for her project on compacting powdered materials.
But most of the Soviet newcomers have not found work in their specialties, like Mr. Vigdorchik and Mr. Pilmenstein. Both men are Jewish and left the Soviet Union so their children could live in a freer society.
When Mr. Pilmenstein arrived here a year ago, he said, he believed he would have no trouble finding a job as a chemist because his background, skills and English were good. He scratched his Ph.D. off his resume ''because they may think I'm asking for a high-level job.'' He said he has no regrets because his two children are happy and ''feel this is their country.''
Mr. Vigdorchik and his wife, Lyudmila, a high school mathematics teacher, received permission in 1988 to emigrate with their 19-year-old son, Lev.
 
Advertising for Taxi Drivers
Arriving in the United States, Mr. Vigdorchik found that almost all the job offers in the local Russian newspaper were for taxi drivers, home attendants or manicurists. He is taking a course in computer programming to update his skills. Meanwhile, he and his wife consider themselves lucky to have full-time jobs as home attendants.
''This means Lev can start premedical studies at New York University next year,'' he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although American universities have been worrying about a shortage of research scientists, Victor Vigdorchik, a theoretical physicist and mathematician, has not been able to find work in his field for two years. He and his wife, Lyudmila, a mathematics teacher, work as home attendants in Brooklyn. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Port Authority Plans Outlined

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The new director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last week that he would keep the Authority's $6-billion plans to renovate bridges, tunnels, airports, marine terminals and the PATH system moving forward.
In particular, he said that a people-mover system at Kennedy International Airport would be built.
But Stanley Brezenoff, the 52-year-old former First Deputy Mayor under the Koch administration, said the region's economic problems and competition from other cities posed hurdles for the agency he was named to head last Thursday, and he left open the possibility that the agency would again ask for increases in bridge and tunnel tolls. 
Mr. Brezenoff succeeds Stephen Berger in the $170,000-a-year job as head of a self-supporting public agency that administers the three New York area airports, six bridges and tunnels, the 14-mile PATH system, the World Trade Center, several industrial parks and ports in Newark, Elizabeth, N.J., and Brooklyn.
''Both sides of the Hudson are seeing declining business activity and employment, and there's strong competition from other Eastern seaboard ports,'' he said Friday at a news conference at the World Trade Center. ''A lot of other regions are making big investments in their ports and airports, and the Los Angeles area has moved ahead of New York as a port.'' These factors make it imperative that ''we advance the capital program so the region's competitiveness is enhanced,'' he added.
But because of uncertainties about revenues, he said, there might be a reduction in capital spending this year. The capital program includes $1 billion to renovate PATH stations and tracks and buy new rail cars and $500 million for repairs to the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the George Washington and Staten Island bridges.
Acknowledging that toll increases ''are never pleasant,'' Mr. Brezenoff said that they were only one of several ways to raise money.
Mr. Brezenoff said that traffic jams at Hudson River bridges and tunnels are ''not easy problems to deal with,'' and called for increased support for trans-Hudson mass transit. He also said that creating public-transportation links to the area's three airports was a priority.

HEADLINE: Arab Crisis, as Seen From Carolina

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, N.C., Aug. 10

 BODY:
As members of the Civitan Club bowed their heads in prayer, a minister reminded them of their good fortune ''in this time of crisis'' to have Representative Howard Coble as their luncheon speaker.
''We pray for him, his wisdom, his judgment and his honesty,'' the minister, Jim Hull declared. And after the invocation, it seemed only fitting that the members, many of them veterans of World War II, would spring from their seats and break into a chorus of ''America the Beautiful.''
The Sixth Congressional District, in the green and hilly midsection of North Carolina's textile country, is a world away from the Persian Gulf, where Iraq has invaded Kuwait and thousands of American troops stand poised. But the talk here is of war. So with their thoughts and their prayers, people turned to their closest link to Government, Congressman Coble. 
Mr. Coble, a backslapping, cigar-puffing conservative Republican who is running for a fourth term, responded with relish, seizing on the public ill will toward President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. ''I think he's meaner than a rattlesnake,'' the 59-year-old Congressman said. ''I think he's a congenital liar.''
 
His Best Source: 'Nightline'
Although members of the civic club prayed for Mr. Coble's wisdom in handling the crisis, the Congressman confessed that he had no role in planning military strategy. His best source of information was ''Nightline,'' he said, and his only briefing from the Administration came a day after the United States sent troops to Saudi Arabia.
''That was a secret meeting,'' he said, ''but most of what I learned at that meeting has since been disseminated and is known to probably all of you in this room.''
Kermit Stubbins, a club member who does accounting work for a car dealership, put it more bluntly. ''I don't think he can do anything,'' he said of the Congressman. ''I don't think he has any say-so.''
Mr. Coble, a lawyer by training, cultivates a country-bumpkin image. (That package of Beech-Nut chewing tobacco on his dashboard is ''for effect,'' an aide says.) So on a tour of the district on Friday, rather than talk about nuances of military and economic strategy, the Congressman confined himself to verbal fusillades at Mr. Hussein (''that S.O.B.'') and unscrupulous service-station operators (''price gougers'').
 
'Have to Play It Hourly'
With a large framed picture of a smiling George Bush as a backdrop, Mr. Coble leaned back at his desk in his Greensboro office and offered this assessment: ''Given the scenario and the cards that were laid on the table, I think the President did about everything he could do.''
As for how many troops the United States should commit to the gulf and whether they should engage in all-out combat, Mr. Coble called that a ''real difficult question.''
''I guess we're just going to have to play it hourly,'' he said.
Mr. Coble is no different from many colleagues returning home for their monthlong recess, who know little more than their constituents about the crisis in the Persian Gulf. While some Democrats say Mr. Bush should make his intentions clearer, no member wants to go on record opposing his initial response.
''I think the President has strong support now and I think that will continue,'' the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said in an interview. He added that opposition would mount only ''if Congress were to see a lack of support in other countries or a weakening of resolve.''
Helen Allegrone, a political novice who is Mr. Coble's Democratic challenger in the November election, has questioned sending troops to the gulf, but that position does not seem to play well here.
 
'A Mother's Tear'
As Mr. Coble walked up Market Street, the main drag in downtown Greensboro, no one had a bad word for the Administration's actions.
''I'm worried about what's going on across the water,'' said A. R. Wood, a Greensboro police officer making the rounds. ''We have no choice. We've got to do it.''
Fred H. Gregory was one of a handful of constituents who was moved to call Mr. Coble's office about the situation in the gulf. He said he told Mr. Coble's staff that Congress ''should not pussyfoot around'' and should declare war on Iraq. ''I'm not a jingoistic type,'' said Mr. Gregory, a retired Federal investigator. ''But let's go in there and take Hussein out. The world's going to be a lot better off.''
Mr. Coble said he offered ''some words of optimism and encouragement'' to a mother worried that her 23-year-old son would be sent to war. ''I can relate to that,'' he said he told her, ''because when I went to the military during the Korean conflict, I remember my most sad memory of my departure was seeing my mama cry at the bus station right across the street here. I'll never forget that. That was a mother's tear.''
Mr. Coble, who served in the Coast Guard, conceded that he ''never did dodge any Korean lead.'' But he added, ''The fact is, I was going off to war as far as my mama thought.''

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 13, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Sanctions on Iraq Appear Effective as Neighbors Block Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and Kuwait appears to be throttling shipments of food, military spare parts and other essential goods into the area.
All of Iraq's neighbors have largely closed their borders to trade, a State Department official who insisted that he not be identified said yesterday. But he added that it was unclear whether Jordan, on Iraq's western flank, would forbid food shipments on the truck route from Aqaba on the Red Sea through the Jordanian capital, Amman, to Baghdad. Reuters reported yesterday that trucks loaded with goods had left Amman on the road to Baghdad. 
Moves by United States and its allies to mount a naval blockade have prompted a reduction in Iraqi exports of crude oil to no more than a dribble, shipping and oil industry officials say. Oil exports are Baghdad's main source of money to buy food and weapons.
 
Dependent on Imported Food
Iraq, which has about 17 million people, relies on imports for three-quarters of its food, spending about $2 billion a year. While some rural areas are self-sufficient, the populations of Iraq's two major cities, Baghdad and Basra, depend almost entirely upon imported food.
The United Nations plans to let food shipments to Iraq and Kutwait continue at ''humanitarian'' levels to prevent famine.
Western diplomats said they did not intend to use what they call the ''food weapon'' to starve Iraq, but American officials want a reduction of food to minimum humanitarian levels. ''It can't be business as usual,'' a diplomat said.
Yahya Sadwowski, an expert on Iraq at the Brookings Institution in Washington, suggested that the embargo might stir up popular discontent in Iraq.
''Iraqis have got used to eating a lot of imported meat and rice in recent years,'' he said. ''The major suppliers could force them to switch back to traditional barley, which would be unpopular.''
The Baghdad Government said yesterday that it would sentence to death any ''profiteering merchants'' who hoarded food, Reuters reported. A communique read on Baghdad television said any act of hoarding or monopoly would be considered ''an act of sabotage affecting national security,'' the news agency said. The sentence for hoarding had been 10 to 15 years in prison.
 
Low Stockpiles
Iraq had low stores of food before its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and now has little oil money or access to international markets to replenish its supplies. As of July 25, the Iraqi Government held enough wheat for two months of normal consumption, enough rice for three months, enough beans and barley for a month and less than two weeks' worth of corn, said John P. Parker, an Agriculture Department economist who studies Middle Eastern food supplies.
 
Limited Warehouse Space
An American grain industry executive who asked not to be identified said Iraq's warehouse capacity appeared to be limited, noting that the country needed small, regular shipments of grain because it could not store larger quantities.
Mr. Sadwowski said Iraq had little chance of expanding its agricultural output significantly because of rising salt levels in fertile areas.
The critical economic issue is whether commercial Western oil supplies outlast Iraqi food supplies, said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an economist who studies energy issues at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The use of Western governments' strategic petroleum reserves, which the countries have resisted thus far, would extend the period in which they could do without Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, he said. Other oil-producing countries have signaled their willingness to increase output, although such increased production has not yet been seen. But even that extra flow of crude oil would be less than the production of Iraq and Kuwait it is intended to replace.
 
Imported Machinery Needed
''The pinch is going to come in three or four months,'' Mr. Verleger said. ''It looks like Saddam Hussein has decided to sit down for the long term.''
Despite efforts to make itself more self-sufficient, Iraq's industrial economy is also heavily dependent on imported machinery, and its war machine mainly relies on Soviet and French weaponry. Both the Soviet Union and France have pledged to cut off shipments to Iraq.
Jordan, which has been less critical of the occupation of Kuwait than three other neighbors of Iraq - Saudi Arabia, Syria and Turkey - has officially joined the embargo, completing the cordon. The Iraqi border with Iran remains tense and heavily militarized since an eight-year war between the two countries ended less than two years ago.
During the Iran-Iraq war, the 700-mile highway from Aqaba, Jordan, to Baghdad was improved, and convoys of trucks carried tons of needed supplies to Iraq, said Marvin Zonis, a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business who studies Middle Eastern politics and business. But even if each truck could carry 36 metric tons of food, which is roughly the weight limit on American interstate highways, supplying Iraq with wheat alone could require about 9,000 shipments a month.
 
'Logistical Nightmare'
Kuwait is even more dependent on imports, bringing in 96 percent of its food, and from Jordan it is 500 miles beyond Baghdad. ''It's a logistical nightmare,'' said Thomas J. Donohue, the president and chief executive of the American Trucking Associations, a trade group based in Alexandria, Va.
''Saddam Hussein undoubtedly believed that sanctions could not inflict substantial costs on him,'' said Kenneth A. Oye, an associate professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who studies international bargaining. ''I do believe these sanctions can inflict such costs.''
Syria has allowed no commerce across its border with Iraq since 1982, when it accused Iraq of having supplied weapons to an uprising in the city of Hama that left 6,000 people dead.
Turkey, the main supplier to Iraq of consumer products ranging from washing machines to tires and batteries, has stopped virtually all trade since Wednesday, said Daryal Batibay, the charge d'affaires of the Turkish Embassy in Washington. Food shipments have virtually stopped, although Turkey has claimed the right to resume them on a limited basis for humanitarian reasons, he said.
Turkey has reserved the right to send shipments of food for humanitarian reasons, in part because 30,000 Turkish construction workers are still in Iraq, he said, adding, ''It's a flexibility we wanted to keep.''
 
Food as a Weapon
The use of food as a weapon against Arab oil producers first received serious discussion in the United States in 1973, and prompted Saudi Arabia to subsidize its agriculture so heavily that it has even exported small quantities of wheat in recent years. But Iraq's agrarian investments were much more modest.
With the exception of a single highway in one low-lying area, the Turkish border with Iraq is a large mountainous region with peaks up to 11,000 feet high and virtually no roads. Smuggling has not been a serious problem along this frontier, Mr. Batibay said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Poll on Troop Move Shows Support (and Anxiety)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
Americans rallied around President Bush after he ordered military forces to the Persian Gulf, but the public's support is tempered by an undercurrent of anxiety and skepticism of the sort that has hampered American efforts to project power in the world since Vietnam, according to a poll by The New York Times.
Americans who expected a long war, for example, were far less likely to support sending troops than were those who thought a long war unlikely.
In general, the public was divided over whether the United States would end up fighting Iraq. Half expected a bloodless resolution to the confrontation, but a third said they expected fighting. The rest said they did not know what to expect. 
Showing the same support that the population typically has of presidents at the start of past foreign crises, 74 percent of Americans said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was dealing with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
 
Contrasting Historical Views
But reservations were close to the surface among the 670 people interviewed by telephone on Thursday and Friday. While 6 out of 10 accepted Mr. Bush's comparison of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to Hitler, 4 out of 10, in answering a separate question, said they agreed with a different historical parallel: that getting involved in the Middle East is a lot like getting involved in Vietnam in the 1960's.
Americans conceded in the Times poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points, that they had known little about Iraq and Kuwait just two weeks ago. Only a quarter of those surveyed correctly identified the government of Saudi Arabia as a monarchy.
Celinda Lake, a Democratic poll taker, said that as recently as last Monday people she interviewed were having trouble grasping that the confrontation was with Iraq, not Iran.
It has become axiomatic, particularly since America's failure in Vietnam, that the outcome military efforts is heavily dependent on the reaction of the public.
The movement of United States troops to Saudi Arabia, America's first important post-cold war military action outside the hemisphere, will be a test of President Bush's ability to hold the support of a public that has been turning increasingly homeward since the collapse of Communism. Indeed, before Iraqi tanks rolled into Kuwait 10 days ago, some political analysts had even begun using terms like ''neo isolationist'' to describe emerging American attitudes.
 
General Fear of Entanglements
Given the public's lack of knowledge about the details of the conflict, the poll's findings suggest that the uneasiness is more an expression of general fear of foreign entanglements than of opposition to the specific actions in the Persian Gulf.
Support for the American intervention was strongest among the best educated, those with the highest incomes and those who had been following the news from the area most closely. It was weakest among women, blacks, those with lower incomes and less education, and those paying least attention.
A similiar pattern has been noted by historians studying the early stages of the Vietnam War. The well-educated and well-informed tended to support President Lyndon B. Johnson's initial commitments, while the less-educated and less-informed, many more of whom were being called upon to fight, tended to be more opposed. It was only later, when opinion leaders became divided, that a sense of disunity enveloped the nation.
Politicians around the country last week were already noticing the double edge of public opinion about the Persian Gulf.
''It is not a clear message,'' said Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois. ''The majority say, 'Let's stand up to this guy,' '' referring to the Mr. Hussein.
Mr. Simon, who is campaigning for re-election, said he shares this view, but added: ''There is a second wave of public opinion which says, 'Don't let American troops get involved there.' There are two different threads of public opinion. Vietnam is still a part of our heritage. There are those who say, 'Let's not get involved.' ''
 
A Consistent Apprehension
Through a series of questions, a remarkably consistent 4 out of 10 Americans in the poll expressed reservations about the American intervention.
Even though President Bush emphasized that he had exhausted other options, 4 in 10 Americans said he was too quick to send troops.
Even though Mr. Bush addressed the nation and held a news conference on Wednesday, the day before the survey began, 4 in 10 also said he had not clearly explained why United States troops were sent.
And even though the President said the nation's vital interests were at stake, 4 in 10 again said that American intervention just helped to protect the profits of the big oil companies.
Different people expressed different reservations, so all told, two thirds of those surveyed agreed with at least one of those negative sentiments.
 
Support for the President
But Americans are not translating this undercurrent of concern into overall disapproval. Political scientists have long noted a ''rally-round-the-flag'' phenomenon, in which trouble overseas, from the Cuban missle crisis to the invasion of Panama, is followed by a temporary jump in a President's standing.
In keeping with that, President Bush's action in the Persian Gulf appears to have reversed a slide in his approval ratings that had been under way for a number of weeks and was being accelerated by increasing public awareness of economic deterioration.
In the latest poll, 72 percent said they approved of how Mr. Bush was handling his job and 19 percent said they disapproved.
Mr. Bush's approval rating was up from 60 percent in a Gallup Poll conducted July 19-22, after Mr. Bush abandoned his ''no new taxes'' pledge.
The jump in Mr. Bush's approval was measurable even in the course of the week. A poll by CBS News on Tuesday and Wednesday, just as he announced American military intervention, found 66 percent approved the way he was handling the Presidency and 22 percent disapproved.
 
Political Implications
The number of Americans who say they were paying close attention to the Persian Gulf situation has, not surprisingly, increased sharply in the past week, from 18 percent in a Gallup Poll last weekend, shortly after the Iraqi invasion, to 28 percent in the CBS News poll at midweek, to 37 percent by the end of the week in the New York Times Poll.
Since those who said they paid more attention tended to be the most supportive of American involvement, the increasing number of Amerians now following the developments will provide Mr. Bush with a chance to consolidate support in the days ahead.
On an issue related to the Persian Gulf crisis there was widespread agreement in the poll. Seven out of ten Americans said the upsurge in oil prices came because the oil companies were basically greedy.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Japanese Discord on Iraq Raises Doubts About Premier's Trip

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The crisis in the Persian Gulf has stirred unusual discord in Japan over how boldly to assert its leadership in denouncing Iraq and seeking oil supplies from other countries in the region, Government officials say.
The disagreements, which have leaked into the open in recent days, are raising doubts about whether Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will be able to leave on Wednesday for his long-scheduled tour of the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt.
The trip was planned months ago, and Mr. Kaifu and other officials said on Friday that he intends to go ahead. But officials also acknowledged that many colleagues, particularly in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, who fear the trip could turn into a debacle had pressed him to cancel it. 
The main concern is that by going to the region now, Mr. Kaifu might alienate Iraq and annoy other oil-producing countries by seeming to press them to pump more oil. Some aides were described as fearful that the Prime Minister would lose popularity at home by behaving like a supplicant.
 
Role in Guarding the Oil Flow
On the other hand, others say they fear that a last-minute cancellation would weaken Japan's image and undercut the arguments of officials that Tokyo was beginning to assert political leadership commensurate with its status as an economic superpower.
The Japanese position illustrates the special difficulties of the country that depends more than any other on oil from the Middle East, but which remains mired in longtime debates about whether it can afford to stir animosities by pursuing its economic interests boldly around the world.
Japan has traditionally acted cautiously in the Middle East, letting the United States and others take the lead in protecting the flow of oil. Its behavior has drawn criticism that Japan was getting a free ride while others were willing to take action.
After Iraq invaded Kuwait last week, Japan initially responded that it would boycott Iraqi oil after the United Nations Security Council acted. Then three days later, when it became apparent that the Security Council would act, Japan said it would indeed halt all purchases from Iraq and Kuwait.
The action cut off an eighth of Japan's oil supplies and sent the Tokyo stock market skidding.
 
'Weakest Link in the Chain'
''In terms of everyone's oil dependence, Japan is the weakest link in the chain,'' said Kazuo Nukuzawa, managing director of Keidanren, Japan's largest industrial trade association. ''So it cannot be helped that we took a long time to act. It looks like hesitation, but I would call it prudence.''
An American official said that Japan should not be criticized for its initial hesitation on sanctions against Iraq. ''We were impressed,'' he said. ''If you look at past crises, the Japanese response was really unprecedented in terms of comprehensiveness and speed.''
But there was another set of mixed signals on the question of the American decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia to protect against a further Iraqi incursion.
 
Discord Over Kaifu Trip
Initially, Japan declined to support the American action. On Wednesday, the Government's chief spokesman, Misoji Sakamoto, said of President Bush's action, ''The United States has made an independent decision and Japan cannot comment on that.''
But on Friday Foreign Ministry officials, when asked, said that Japan supported the American move wholeheartedly.
The initial wavering was explained as in line with Japan's resistance to endorsing the use of force. But critics say Japan is still trying to benefit from American actions but be free of the controversy surrounding them.
The disagreement over Mr. Kaifu's trip came into the open when Kabun Muto, the Minister for International Trade and Industry, said earlier this week that Prime Minister Kaifu would press Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing countries to make up for the losses of oil from Iraq.
 
Premier Seeks to Go Ahead
His comments were subsequently dismissed by Foreign Ministry officials, who said that Mr. Kaifu would not necessarily say any such thing, since such a move by the Saudis might provoke an Iraqi invasion.
Mr. Kaifu's trip is to begin on Aug. 15 and to take him to Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan and Egypt, the first visit by a Japanese leader to the Middle East in 12 years.
According to some news reports, Mr. Kaifu was the one person in the Government most insistent on going forward with the trip. He was said to be supported by the Foreign Ministry, which has long advocated a more bold approach by Japan in foreign policy.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Allies Reminded of Need for U.S. Shield

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Just as Washington was preparing to lower its profile in Europe in the new post-cold war era, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has abruptly reminded Western Europe that it still looks to the United States to defend its vital security interests.
Even though Western Europe has at least as much at stake in the Persian Gulf as the United States, it has waited for the Bush Administration to define the West's response to the crisis. It has then closed ranks behind Washington, albeit allowing the United States to assume the main risks and responsibilities.
As a result, the terms of the trans-Atlantic relationship, which had been slowly adjusting to the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, have once again changed. Experts now expect less questioning of Washington's leadership, a more cautious approach to future military cuts and new demands for the modernization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. 
''The Iraqi crisis has been a sobering experience,'' a European official at NATO said. ''It has demonstrated the limits of European power, and it has shown that only the United States can play the role of global policeman.''
 
NATO as Political Forum
In this case, the United States has taken the lead because NATO is prohibited by its charter from operating militarily outside Europe and North America. But Washington has pointedly emphasized NATO's continued relevance by using it as a forum for political consultations.
On Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went out of his way to brief NATO Foreign Ministers on the results of his trip to Turkey on Thursday and on United States plans for forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Much as it did routinely during the cold war, the alliance then pledged support for Washington's strategy.
In recent months, the premise of debate at the Brussels headquarters of NATO and the 12-nation European Community has been that as the demise of communism gives shape to a new Europe, the United States would inevitably play a less-dominant security role than it has here over the last 45 years.
Preparations were already under way for the withdrawal of some American troops from Germany, while the idea that Europe should assume greater responsibility for its own defense was gaining ground. At the same time, economic strength was feeding the European Community's confidence to act independently on the world stage.
 
A New Role Is Sought
Having lost its main reason for existence with the waning of the Soviet threat, NATO was also busily trying to define a new role for itself. Some nations, notably France, even favored switching the political focus away from the 16-nation NATO to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, where Washington's influence would be smaller.
But now, overnight, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has exposed Western Europe's inability or reluctance to project its power much beyond its own borders. And having long needed Washington to protect it from the Soviet Union, it now counts on the United States to tame a dictator who consolidated his power thanks in part to European armaments and credits.
''Only the Americans can mount a swift military response to a challenge of this sort outside the NATO area,'' The Independent, a British newspaper, said in an editorial Friday. ''Europe simply has to decide whether to tag along, although its interests are just as threatened as those of the United States. Its defense remains in American hands.''
One NATO member, Turkey, shares a border with Iraq, and if it is attacked, NATO is committed to coming to its defense.
 
Dependent on Oil Imports
With most Western European countries heavily dependent on oil imports from the Middle East, escalation of the crisis would cause havoc to their economies. Until last week, for instance, Denmark obtained 54 percent of its oil from Kuwait.
Washington has nonetheless seen its allies follow its lead. Britain has joined the United States-led multinational force protecting Saudi Arabia. France, stressing that it is acting independently and not as part of the multinational force, has sent an aircraft carrier and five warships to the Persian Gulf, while Canada and Australia have announced they too will send naval vessels to the zone. Spain, the Netherlands and Belgium are reportedly considering doing likewise.
Even with no end to the Iraqi crisis in sight, NATO and European Community officials said it had already provided several lessons, not least that regional conflicts may be more likely now that a Soviet Union bent on improving relations with the West has lost influence over such former clients as Iraq.
NATO officials also said Iraq's aggression was certain to affect the current debate about military cuts and the so-called ''peace dividend'' in Washington and many Western European capitals. ''A lot of people who were warning against rapid disarmament must be very happy this has happened,'' an official said.
 
New Doubts Are Raised
For the European Community, which was considering developing a ''security dimension'' outside NATO as part of its moves toward economic and political union, the crisis has raised fresh doubts about the viability of a new military organization that excludes the United States.
The Western European Union, a security body comprising nine European NATO members, has so far ignored the Iraqi conflict, although it is to meet in Paris later this month. In 1987, it coordinated warships from several European countries that were sent to protect oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.
But it is not viewed as an alternative to NATO. A European official said Europe would need ''time, hardware and organization'' to build a integrated military structure. ''This would affect the American stake in Europe,'' he said, ''and I don't think anyone wants to see the Americans leaving now.''
The United States, in contrast, makes no secret of its view that Europe should contribute more to its own defense. ''The irony is that we keep telling the Europeans that we don't want to act alone,'' an American official said. ''We'd be happy if they did more. We would prefer it to be done through NATO, but we're not holding them back.''
 
France Prefers to Act Alone
At the last NATO summit meeting, in London in June, the United States urged its allies to consider not only a new political role for the alliance, but also new rules to enable it to address ''out of area'' conflicts that affect the security of member states.
Already, the crisis has had telling effects on the trans-Atlantic relationship. France, for instance, has confirmed that it prefers to act alone rather than bow publicly to Washington's leadership. West Germany, the dominant European power, has also shown itself reluctant to become involved in extra-regional conflicts.
On the other hand, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has been visibly distressed to see Washington using Bonn as its main European interlocutor over the last year, has jumped at the chance of demonstrating that Britain remains the most steadfast ally of the United States.
By chance, she was in the United States at the time of the Iraqi invasion. Twice in four days, she could be seen ''co-managing'' the crisis with President Bush. And when she returned to London Tuesday, she immediately gave orders for Britain to join the United States in the multinational force defending Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: One Sign of Our Times: World's Refugee Flood

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA

 BODY:
Fifteen million men, women and children are biding their time outside their countries, often in great deprivation, internationally recognized as refugees.
Officials concerned with the problems of uprooted people believe these refugees to be only part of one of the overriding problems of this age.
Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, sees those who have been granted refugee status as the formally acknowledged segment of a worldwide mass movement of the deprived toward more prosperous regions.
Official and nonofficial specialists the world over share his perception.
 
Asylum Requests Grow Swiftly
Increasingly, such newcomers seek the protection of refugee status to legitimize their stay, despite efforts by governments to limit asylum requests. 
Applications to Europe, the United States and Canada, the traditional asylum-granting regions, have risen from 25,000 in 1973 to 600,000 this year, according to estimates. That does not include migrants living short of legality in parts of the world.
The situation now is similar in ways to the great refugee upheavals of World War II. John A. Scanlan, an Indiana University Law School professor who is an authority on the subject, said that a State Department report in June 1945 estimated the total of refugees at 33 million to 43 million. He said that by the end of 1948, the total had dropped more than half, to somewhere between 16 million and 18 million.
In recent years, countries have used various measures to thwart applications for asylum, like the United States policy of turning back Haitian boat people while they are still at sea.
Roger P. Winter, director of the United States Committee for Refugees, said in an interview in Washington that of 22,000 Haitians intercepted by the Coast Guard since 1981, only 6 had been allowed to proceed to port.
Officials of the High Commissioner's agency said that immigration officials in Western Europe often search airliners before allowing passengers to get off, and turn back potential asylum seekers before they can apply. Sometimes, the officials go to countries likely to produce refugees and sit next to airline employees at check-in counters to deny boarding passes to people suspected of wanting asylum. Who Is a True Refugee? The stream of migrants is blurring established definitions of who is a refugee and casts suspicion over the motives of those who claim asylum to escape violence or persecution in their own countries.
Mr. Stoltenberg said such suspiciousness was wrong because morally the motivation of people fleeing poverty was equally valid.
''The problem is poverty,'' said Mr. Stoltenberg, who is 59 years old and a former Minister of Defense and Foreign Affair in Norway as well as a longtime leader of the Labor Party. ''The majority of the world live in deep poverty.
''People will say: 'Why should this happen now? After all, we have had poverty since historic times.' They forget that we have had two revolutions.
''First, there is the information revolution. People now, even if they are very poor, know how people live in other parts of the world.
''The other is the transport revolution. It is much easier than before to be transported over long distances. We cannot hide away anymore. You can't hide away from the world.''
 
Boat People Symbolize Plight
Throughout a 90-minute interview at his agency's headquarters, the High Commissioner singled out the controversy over the plight of Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong as characterizing the complexities of the problem.
It encapsulates the grave questions posed by the mass movements, and illustrates the divisions provoked among those who receive appeals for asylum and the dilemma confronted by those who are entrusted with the care of the uprooted.
''The Hong Kong situation is a symbol of what might face us all over the world,'' Mr. Stoltenberg said.
About 55,000 Vietnamese are confined in camps intentionally kept at minimum survival level by the British colonial authorities to deter further arrivals. ''People are living on shelves,'' said the High Commissioner.
In a screening started by Britain in 1988, which broke its 13-year pattern of automatically granting refugee status to fleeing Vietnamese, most boat people have been labeled ''economic migrants,'' meaning they fled not persecution but poverty.
 
Forcible Repatriation
Under an agreement reached by all concerned countries under the High Commissioner's auspices last year, those ''screened out'' are to be returned to Vietnam.
That assent by the organization charged with being the advocate for refugees has provoked internal debate in the agency and nongovernmental refugee organizations. If voluntary returns do not resolve the problem, forcible repatriation, for which no date was set, was implictly agreed to.
About 4,000 Vietnamese have gone back of their free will and 51 were deported in November. Forced returns were then suspended because Vietnam and the United States, in rare agreement, raised strenuous objections.
The issue has led to intense controversy, as Britain and the Southeast Asian nations that are the refugee boats' first ports of call demand forced return.
Malaysia, Thailand and other countries of ''first asylum'' have pushed most new refugee boats back out to sea. They and Britain demand that the United States either accept for asylum all Vietnamese refugees or drop its opposition to forcible return.
 
Political Refugees Favored
''The usual principle is that those who are political refugees get asylum, those who are not have to go back,'' the High Commissioner said.
Outlining the controversy over whether that should apply in Hong Kong, he continued: ''I try to get consensus, because if I don't manage that, the alternative is rather gloomy. It will be breakdown of 'first asylum,' and it would mean drowning of tens, hundreds, maybe more people.''
The High Commissioner said that his organization was formally responsible only for those who are granted refugee status. ''But at the same time, I do fully respect those who flee their countries because of poverty, because it may be more dangerous to go back to poverty than to political persecution,'' he said.
Nonetheless, he said, to safeguard the possibility of finding asylum for refugees, repatriation is necessary. He said his office monitored the safety of those who had returned and provided economic assistance to the communities from which they had come to stimulate people not to leave.
 
'Psychologically Filled Up'
That is outside his agency's formal mandate, he said, but if there is no repatriation of migrants declared illegal, the world's readiness to grant asylum to recognized political refugees would break down. He said potential asylum countries were not necessarily ''physically filled up but psychologically filled up.''
Refugee officials and representatives of nongovernmental organizations devoted to the problem agree with the High Commissioner's view that the sense of being ''filled up'' has led to increasing restriction on the part of Western Governments. ''Most governments feel they are on the verge of losing control,'' Mr. Stoltenberg said. ''I definitely fear a Fortress Europe.'' Dennis McNamara, until recently deputy director of the High Commissioner's International Protection Division, wrote in an article soon to be published in Refugees, the agency's monthly, that in seeking to limit the flow of potential asylum-seekers, Governments have introduced measures that ''often ignore the crucial distinction between refugees or asylum-seekers and ordinary migrants'' and endanger the principle of refugee protection.
He listed strict advance visa requirements and heavy penalties for airlines that transport people without evidence of approved entry at their destinations. As an example, Mr. McNamara said such practices had greatly curtailed the movement to Europe of Tamils seeking refuge from the civil war in Sri Lanka.
 
Aftermath of World War II
Emphasizing that the number of present and potential uprooted people far exceeded the 15 million under his care, the High Commissioner said that even the 15 million for the most part no longer fit the definition on which his organization's mandate, dating to 1951 and expanded in 1967, is based.
It was intended to fit the refugees of the aftermath of World War II and the subsequent takeover of Eastern and Central Europe by the Soviet Union.
''In 1951, there was a limited group of people that needed to be helped, and they all came from the same environment,'' he said, noting their largely European background that fitted them readily into Western countries of asylum. ''It was relatively easy to be nice and kind. Today, it is a global issue.''
Much of the emphasis in the High Commissioner's tasks has shifted to assuring temporary asylum and feeding and housing vast groups more than protecting individual rights and helping refugees to find resettlement.
''There are millions outside their countries without prospect, hope or desire for a resettlement,'' said Court Robinson of the United States committee. ''They are offered no prospect of resettlement and none of going home.''
The biggest group, even allowing for what is believed to be inflated numbers, consists of 3.2 million Afghans in Pakistan and 2.3 million in Iran. #4.4 Million African Refugees Civil strife has produced 4.4 million refugees in Africa. The largest single group is 820,000 from Mozambique who have found asylum in Malawi, one of the world's poorest nations.
Mr. Stoltenberg said the Horn of Africa, which he considers the most intractable problem region, showed ''the trends of our time.'' He said, ''We don't have wars between states any longer, but we have 38 wars within states.''
As a result, 685,000 Ethiopians are reported to have taken refuge in Sudan, 384,000 Sudanese and 324,000 Somalians in Ethiopia, and 600,000 Ethiopians in Somalia. Most of those figures are widely held to be exaggerated.
About a million refugees have been resettled in the United States, 447,000 in Canada and 822,000 in Europe. Those statistics do not include people who have become citizens of their new countries or asylum-seekers. In Latin America, 1.2 million have been resettled.
''I am convinced that we will have a future with much more movement of people,'' the High Commissioner said. ''There is no doubt. That is a part of the future that we have shaped. My worry is that we will not be able to cope with those who flee from poverty.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Dartmouth;
Back to Class To Study Japan And Its Language

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H.

 BODY:
Although a Dartmouth College student might spend years preparing for a Wall Street career, a group of executives is reversing the process, going from the board room to the classroom.
Executives are trading their briefcases and suits for backpacks and T-shirts for what the college says is the only Japanese language and culture program in the United States.
From early morning until midnight in the new program, executives from I.B.M., Sears, Corning and other companies are split into small groups. There are nine instructors for the eight executives. 
In one room several executives learned to give directions by moving plastic people from the United States Embassy to the post office on a three-dimensional map of Tokyo. Then they sang the Japanese words for body parts, to the tunes of familiar songs. $5,600 for 12 Days Students in another room learned to tell time. When an executive mistook 1 o'clock for 2 o'clock, a colleague said, ''I made the meeting and you missed it!''
The 12-day program, which costs $5,600 a person, combines language skills with cultural and historical background. ''Words are only half the language,'' said John Rassias, director of Language Outreach here and creator of an instructional method that puts the student at center stage and requires the use of language in real-life scenarios.
To be successful overseas, people should be sensitive to cultural values, Mr. Rassias said, adding, ''The minute you understand the culture the language is no longer alien.''
Business deals can fall through because no one has made an effort to become familiar with customs and cultural values, he added. ''When you're in the board room,'' Mr. Rassias said, ''you have to play their game.''
An executive can add to his productivity by understanding the perspectives of others, said Dick Ver Eecke, an I.B.M. executive who lives in Tokyo. Mr. Ver Eecke said his Japanese counterparts would appreciate his efforts to learn their language.
The participants fall essentially into three levels of experience, according to Gary Garrabrant, a vice president of Bankers Trust Company. ''There are the people who already live in Japan, the people who are moving there and the commuters,'' he said, adding that he commutes there two to four times a year.
Extensive readings and lectures on interpersonal relations and advertising are included in the program.
The executive director of the Dartmouth Institute, Jan Bent, was a primary force behind the creation of the program, which the institute co-sponsors. She said the program is the only one of its kind in the nation.
The institute runs educational and cultural programs for alumni and business executives. This is the first time in its 19-year history that it has worked in conjunction with Mr. Rassias and his language outreach program.
Ms. Bent said she expected companies to realize that Dartmouth has ''something that will certainly benefit their bottom line.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Washington, St. Louis;
Black Students Learn How to Be Entrepreneurs

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Until this summer, said Kory T. Morrow, a 16-year-old high school student here, he never even considered opening his own business. But with the guidance of the Minority Youth Entrepreneurship Program at the John M. Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis, he and four other youths wrote detailed plans to open a mail-order software company.
Using skills learned in the eight-week program, Mr. Morrow's five-member team evaluated potential markets, calculated financial projections and laid plans for operations and management.
''The accounting was hard at first, but we finally got it,'' he said. 
The result is a business plan so solid that the program's judges gave it first place and, for the first time in the program's history, recommended that the students try to find financing and put it into operation.
 
Beat 7 Other Plans
The plan envisioned ways to sell software using basketball, wrestling and airplane-shooting games to teach mathematics that was written by Robert L. Hines, 17, one of the students in Mr. Morrow's group. It beat plans from seven other groups to develop an environmentally safe insect spray, publish a newspaper for blacks in St. Louis, form a custom-bathroom-building company, open an art gallery and start other companies.
Each member of the winning team received a four-year $500-a-year scholarship from the Urban League of St. Louis.
Maurice Wallace, the program's director, said some of the black entrepreneurs who made presentations during the program might be able to help raise capital for the students.
The Minority Youth Entrepreneurship Program was founded in 1987 after several black St. Louis businessmen discussed how limited opportunities were for blacks in the United States economy and how few black role models there were.
 
Black Entrepreneurs Speak
''These young African-American men and women don't have a real exposure to entrepreneurs in real life, so they don't have expectations to become an entrepreneur,'' said Ronald Thompson, the owner of St. Louis-based General Railroad Equipment and Service, one of the program's founders.
The program is free and is open to black students who have completed their junior years of high school. Forty participants are selected on the basis of essays, interviews and high school transcripts.
During the first half of the eight-week program, Olin professors teach a courses in accounting, management strategies and other topics, Mr. Thompson said.
The academic objective is ''to give them enough to think like successful entrepreneurs,'' said James Little, an associate professor of economics and finance.
The second month features talks by successful minority entrepreneurs from all over the nation. ''Most people seem to think 'Well, I'll go through college and then work for someone,' '' said Clarence Rogers, a student in last year's program. ''We see men like Ron Thompson succeed at what they do. It's very inspirational.''
 
Field Trips to Offices
''Most of all, I learned how the business world operates, how the real world is,'' said Mr. Morrow, who attends the Academy of Math and Science, a magnet high school here.
Mr. Thompson said students are also tutored in writing, oral presentation and study skills, and taught to run spreadsheets, word-processing software and data-base programs on computers. They also make field trips to offices and factories.
From the second week on, groups of five students work on plans for mock companies, preparing analyses of potential markets, financial projections, and operations and management plans.
''The academics really came to bear in the business plans,'' said Mr. Rogers, who will be a freshman at Washington University this fall.
Girard Hankins, president of Gateway National Bank and a speaker at this year's program, said: ''The future of the race in this country is if we can get a better understanding of what makes business tick.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Berkeley;
Improving Ties With the Nations Of the Pacific Rim

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
When Robert McCann, a graduate student, traveled to Thailand in June to begin studying that country's language, he joined a growing number of students from the University of California system. Their academic interests lie in helping California tighten its cultural and economic ties with Pacific Rim countries.
In the 1990-91 academic year, 458 students will study in 13 countries, according to the university's Education Abroad Program. That is more than five times as many students as in 1982-83, when a total of 86 participated in six countries. 
Increased trade and cultural integration between California and Pacific Rim countries led the State Legislature in the early 80's to direct the program to focus on the region, said Theony Condos, special assistant for international education in the office of David P. Gardner, president of the nine campuses of the University of California.
''If California is going to be competitive on the world market, we have to be graduating more and more students who are familiar with the languages and cultures of the Pacific region,'' Ms. Condos said.
 
More Nations
At the same time, the university recognizes the educational opportunities that the region has to offer. ''It's been neglected in terms of intellectual exchange,'' said John Marcum, director of the Education Abroad Program for the nine campuses.
''We have traditionally tended to go to Europe,'' Mr. Marcum said. ''We tend to go where it's easy to go - in terms of language, in terms of culture.''
Canada, Costa Rica, Indonesia, Korea, New Zealand, Taiwan and Thailand have all been added to the program since 1982. Increased numbers of students are studying in Australia, China, Japan, Mexico and Hong Kong.
Mr. McCann, a second-year graduate student in the teaching of English as a second language program at the University of California at Los Angeles, went to Thailand because he is considering working there after he graduates.
''It's going to be tied in with my career,'' said Mr. McCann, who is from Glastonbury, Conn. ''I need to learn Thai in a more intensive manner.''
 
'A Linguistic Barrier'
In an effort to increase students' interest in the Pacific Rim, the university offers scholarships of up to $1,500 a year - not based on financial need -to those bound for the region. The amount of each award is determined by the cost to study in the student's chosen country, university officials said. (Australia and New Zealand are excluded from scholarships because the demand to study in those countries is usually high without offering an incentive, Mr. Marcum said.) The program offers some opportunities for specialized study. In Japan, for example, students can take classes in economics and engineering. But most students studying in Pacific Rim countries focus on the basics - the country's language and culture, Mr. Marcum said.
''There's an enormous barrier - a linguistic barrier,'' Mr. Marcum said. ''As long as the pool of students with real language competency is small, we will have to focus a lot of the study on language.''
Although some Pacific Rim languages are more widely used than others, the program tries to provide a geographical and cultural range of countries for students to choose from, Mr. Marcum said.
Thailand is ''an up-and-coming country in terms of economics,'' Mr. Marcum said, with Mr. McCann in agreement. Since Mr. McCann exports cosmetics to Korea to put himself through school, he said that in addition to intensive language study, he wants to find a Thai business partner.
