HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
More Than Spotted Owls Is Endangered

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
''Ancient forests: Rage Over Trees,'' a National Audubon Society special, tonight at 8 on the Public Broadcasting Service, was shown on the Turner Broadcasting cable system last September - and therein lies a tale. About three weeks before the original presentation of the hourlong documentary on the controversy over logging in the Pacific Northwest, the Stroh Brewing Company, which had planned to give $600,000 toward the Audubon series, withdrew its support.
Environmentalists accused Stroh of backing off because of a threatened boycott of its beer by loggers who want to cut down some old-growth forests, home to 800-year-old trees as well as to the northern spotted owl and other wildlife. Officials of the Audubon Society, one group that wants the owl protected as an endangered species, said they had turned down changes requested by Stroh that would have made the documentary more favorable to the timber industry. Stroh officials said that their decision was a cost-cutting measure that had nothing to do with the talks the company had had with timber cutters. 
Tonight, by courtesy of General Electric, which is now supporting the Audubon series, viewers can see a slightly updated version of the program that caused the commotion. The environment is a favorite subject of public television, and in accord with prevailing sentiment, ''Ancient Forests'' comes down in favor of the big old trees and the creatures who make their homes among them. The annoyance of companies that are in the business of chopping down trees is unsurprising.
But unlike many television treatments of environmental issues that are too suffused in righteousness to attend to the other side, this documentary makes more than a gesture at giving the timber interests a hearing. Most astonishingly, the businessmen are just as clean-cut looking and plausible-sounding as the environmentalists. The difficulty is that after listening to both sides, particularly in an al fresco debate, the audience may be hard put to say whose case is closer to reality.
Industry spokesmen report that the United States has enough of the old trees to last forever. Environmentalists retort that at the present rate of cutting, they will be gone in a decade: ''The mill capacity outpaces the forest capacity,'' says one. ''They just chew it up as fast as they can.'' Industry spokesmen say that wildlife does not thrive in the old forests; environmentalists say it does. Industry spokesmen say that the spotted owl can survive in other habitats; environmentalists contend otherwise. The owner of a mill says that a halt to ''harvesting'' the old trees would eliminate 60,000 jobs, a death knell to many communities and to ''the soul of Oregon.'' Referring to the political power of the timber industry, an environmentalist says that America's future is being sold for today's dollar.
Two experts support the environmentalist case, but they do it in a somewhat lyrical fashion. What is wanting here are directly delivered facts and figures. Is there no relatively objective estimate on the extent and value of the old-growth forests? Can newly planted trees make up for those that are taken away? Isn't there an economist not employed by the timber industry who can estimate how many jobs would be lost if the cutting down of the old trees was stopped, and how some of the jobs might be replaced? Are there no uncommitted experts who can say whether the spotted owl and other species can get along elsewhere -and, if not, why it matters? (Rodent-rights activists may be upset by a scene in which owl-rights people use a mouse as bait.) Laying out the conflicting positions as this program does is assuredly useful, but more useful still would be an outside assessment of the claims and the charges. Unsurprisingly, both sides issue pronouncements to suit their predilections; the arguments are presented but they are not joined.
The producers make their case visually, with pictures from the air of sections near Opal Creek in the state of Washington that have been opened to loggers; they are not pretty. By contrast, the camera captures the cathedral-like peace of the yet-untouched trees; a lovely swimming hole; a heaven for backpackers, where, says Paul Newman, the narrator, ''solitude can be found.'' And it concludes with a camp-out and one of the environmentalists telling his children, by firelight, of the glories of the old forest. The background music gets inspirational whenever the camera catches a sun-dappled spot. The pictures are seductive; the issue becomes cast in esthetic terms.
At the start, Mr. Newman says that the dispute over the trees goes to ''the heart of society's values''; at the end, he urges viewers ''to let Congress know what you want done with them.'' An unexceptionable suggestion, which could be followed more responsibly if ''Ancient Forests'' - and television in general - reported on the issues with more facts and less atmosphere.
As for a company's withdrawing its support from a controversial program, that is a built-in hazard of the way public broadcasting is financed. Any company, be it Stroh Beer or General Electric, that attaches its name to a program or a series obviously does so with its own interests in mind, and controversy is rarely among them.
Whatever the shortcomings of ''Ancient Forests,'' its re-appearance is welcome, and General Electric's support for the Audubon series is all the more commendable given the circumstances. But to the extent that public television remains dependent on the kindness of corporations, controversy will continue to be an endangered species.

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
Putting Prokofiev and Mozart in the Same Basket

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
About all Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' and Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' have in common, it might be plausibly argued, is that both play in two long acts. Forget for the moment that Mozart sustains lengths more skillfully than anybody, let alone Prokofiev. Such gross differences are easy to point out. However, it is similarity that interests me today, not difference. While they may not jump out, some underlying resemblances can be discerned between the two operas. One close thematic relationship, which may be no news to you, struck me recently when I attended performances of these seemingly unrelated works within a few days of one another: ''War and Peace'' at the Seattle Opera and ''Cosi'' at the Santa Fe Opera.
''War and Peace'' is faithful, though certainly not entirely true, to the Tolstoy original in its willingness to sprawl almost out of control in hopes of achieving an effect of Homeric sweep and grandeur. The epic scale, after all, is what most of us think of first when ''War and Peace'' is mentioned. The opera follows the novel fairly closely in chronology and sketches the historical picture with economy and skill. Like Tolstoy, Prokofiev even gives one the impression that he is reluctant or unable to end the story, that sequels may be necessary. But he must have known that his work, no matter how cleverly constructed, would seem episodic and choppy in comparison with the revered original. 
The opera has its affecting scenes, but they are only half-realized tableaux, pictures that remind the listener of ''War and Peace'' but rarely more. Musically, interest tails off in the second half, not only because the confusions of young love are intrinsically more interesting than stage warfare. It is as if Prokofiev's concerns in Act II turned so sharply to the challenge of making Soviet propaganda that there was not much room for following Tolstoy's scheme of weaving together the stories of individuals struggling to survive as society disintegrated around them.
In any event, the 13 truncated scenes of his opera cannot and do not suggest the incredibly detailed fleshing out of even the most minor characters that is Tolstoy's constant compulsion. How could it? Although in the Seattle Opera's stirring production, 64 characters were named in the program, there was time during the nearly four-hour production to bring only a handful of them to anything like life. Even the principal characters had to make do with identity cards writen in shorthand, like the passing allusions to Prince Andrei's freemasonry or Napoleon's frontline gourmandizing.
Prokofiev's greatest impulse in this work seems to have been to dramatize, not so much Tolstoy's ''War and Peace,'' but the historic parallels between the Russian defeat of Napoleon in 1812 and the Soviet defense of Leningrad during World War II. That being so, it is ironic that he comes closest to writing great opera in the peaceful first act, when the webs of romantic love and lust in upper-class Russian society are being spun around Natasha and her admirers: Prince Andrei, Pierre and the ineffable thug Anatole. It is here, especially in the scenes seemingly modeled on Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin,'' that the opera most closely resembles not only Tolstoy but the Mozart who found so much hidden substance and humanity in the libretto that da Ponte furnished him.
It is easy to observe that the canvas Mozart chose to work on in ''Cosi'' is anything but epic in scope. In form, a simple-minded farce, it would be swallowed without leaving a trace in one of Tolstoy's chapters. But the affection and understanding that his music shows for the four lovers in his comedy are recognizably Tolstoyan. The cumulative power of the music - Fiordiligi's self-analyzing arias in particular - can be at least as psychologically complex in effect as the piling on of realistic details that brings Tolstoy's characters to life, great and small. When the deserter Platon Karatayev meets the half-starved Andrei on the battlefield he offers the prince a baked potato. ''Food'' or even ''potato'' are too abstract for Tolstoy; it must be a baked potato.
Although widely separated by time, space and artistic temperament, the creators of Fiordiligi and Natasha share a willingness to overlook human weakness. Everything is understood, therefore forgiven. Both composer and novelist have the gift of arousing our compassion for fallible man - but most particularly the fallible woman. Tolstoy and Mozart vibrate in sympathy with those poor outcasts, doomed by personality and circumstances to betray not only others but themselves. Tolstoy did not exhaust the theme of womanly moral crisis in ''War and Peace''; infidelity and betrayal loom even larger in ''Anna Karenina.'' Nor did the composer in ''Cosi.'' He obsessed on the subject in ''The Abduction From the Seraglio,'' ''The Marriage of Figaro'' and ''Don Giovanni.'' Tolstoy's sympathy for sexually and socially battered women amounts almost to a guiding principle.
Ponder all you wish on the grand political and social tapestry of ''War and Peace,'' what gives both the novel and the opera their flavor of truth are the smaller pictures. Think of a peace-loving Andrei cleaning his spectacles on the battlefield. Or the infatuated Natasha flirting with Anatole, unaware that he means to kidnap and rape her. Think what Mozart and da Ponte might make out of that latter misreading of the male animal. Come to think of it, they did deal with that tragicomedy of misunderstanding. They called it ''Don Giovanni.''

HEADLINE: World Markets

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer;
Iraq's Lunge, the Markets' Plunge

 BODY:
It was a rout.
Outside of precious metals, not a sector of stocks around the world dodged the fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the standoff between Saddam Hussein and most of the rest of the world.
And only one country's market, gold-rich South Africa's, managed to eke out a gain last week, albeit only four-tenths of 1 percent, according to the Financial Times World Indicies of 24 countries. Using local indexes, which include more stocks, even South Africa fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, despite a 9 percent rise in gold stocks. 
Even oil, once people began to take a closer look at the makeup of some of the oil companies, was weaker than might be expected. In the Financial Times Indicies, the oil sector declined four-tenths of 1 percent, after oil prices retreated and investors had second thoughts. ''Some people had jumped in willy-nilly,'' said David A. Robbins of UBS Securities in New York.
The performance of the oil sector didn't look so bad in comparison. According to the Financial Times Indicies, heavy engineering and shipbuilding fell 12.5 percent; autos dropped 10.7 percent; chemicals 10.0 percent; real estate 8.6 percent; media 7.7 percent, and beverages 5.6 percent. Precious metals, because of the flight of investors to gold, rose 1.24 percent. Many oil stocks surged on Aug. 2, the day of the invasion. France's Total jumped 2.4 percent; Elf Aquitane rose 3.3 percent; Belgium's Petrofina was up 3.6 percent.
But fairly quickly these stocks were dropped as it became clear that certain oil companies would be hurt as well as helped by the oil price rise. Some companies are not major producers and buy oil on the open market. Others derive a major portion of earnings from other lines of business. About a quarter of Elf's earnings are from chemicals, and about three-quarters of Total's are from oil-based products, like paint.
By week's end, Elf had dropped 2.7 percent from its invasion peak to 629 francs while Total fell 3.6 percent to 699 francs, wiping out, respectively, some or all of the gain since oil prices started rising before July's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Petrofina, which gets 19 percent of its earnings from chemicals and buys most of its crude oil on the open market, dropped 4.9 percent.
''They're not pure plays in the oil industry,'' said Didier P. Bodart, an analyst at Cresvale International.
The oil stocks that performed well, like British Petroleum, together with gold stocks, softened the Iraqi blow in a few markets. Australia's All Ordinaries index slipped just 1.1 percent, while Canada's Toronto Stock Exchange index lost just 2.9 percent.
The hardest-hit markets were Singapore, whose Strait Times Index fell 13.74 percent, Japan, where the Nikkei 225 dropped 11.38 percent, and Honk Kong, whose Heng Seng index fell 11.23 percent. Austria was down 10.3 percent and the declines in Spain, the Netherlands, France and Italy were in the 9 percent range.
While the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 182.68 points since Aug. 1, the day before the Iraqi invasion, it fared better than most world markets,based on local indexes. It fell 6.3 percent.
The markets can expect another difficult week, even if the gulf crisis doesn't escalate. Robin West, president of the Petroleum Finance Company, said in that case, the price of oil would fall further as the fundamentals took over. These include the promise of increased production from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other OPEC members to offset much of the the expected 4.5 miillion barrel-a-shortage from the embarago. ''There is a lot of crude in the world,'' said Mr. West, ''and this ought to supersede the psychology of the market.''
Even with stable oil prices - West Texas Intermediate closed at $26.23 Friday - or even lower prices, the fear of inflation and lower economic growth worldwide would cloud stock markets. And a standoff in the Middle East will leave many investors leery, even though the number of bargains out there should mushroom. Cash may be the way these days when one news bulletin can kill a ''sure thing.''

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3061 words

HEADLINE: Dancing Past the Recession

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
The nation, it seems fair to say, has never been in quite the same kind of economic bind it is in now.
With the winds of desert war threatening, with powerful forces of inflation set in motion, recession imminent or already here, with a savings and loan scandal and strains on the banking community, with a continuing decline in the industrial base and several consecutive years of Federal budget deficits far higher than ever before, negative factors seem to have converged in an extraordinary and ominous fashion.
So the good times are over. The economic life of the United States of American is terminally diseased. Let us now praise famous men, and throw in the towel. Right? Wrong. 
A close look at the forces behind these forces, and an extensive series of interviews with government and private economic experts, suggests other outcomes, other options, that are convincing and much less pessimistic. Serious problems lie ahead, yes. But the tools now exist - and more can be forged - to tackle them.
This is so largely because of the experience gained by government and new strategies adopted by business over the decade since the economic troubles of the 1970's and early 80's and the stock market collapse of Oct. 19, 1987, that make the economy less vulnerable to shock - from escalating oil prices, for example - than might be be expected.
This experience suggests that business would be well advised now to intensify its efforts at efficiency, to continue trimming, to cut plans that might seem extravagant or risky, to stay lean, poised and ready to pounce when the economy rebounds. And the Federal Government would be similarly instructed to continue its current deficit-cutting policy, with some careful modifications: warily ease interest rates downward to help the economy, but raise them again if inflation indeed becomes a serious problem. There are many new weapons in the nation's 1990 economic arsenal:
* American corporations have been making real efforts to diversify their sources of energy.
* Businesses have been pursuing cost-cutting strategies as well, making themselves leaner, reducing staff and inventories.
* Many corporations are much more global than they were in the 70's, enabling them to recoup domestic losses from stronger markets overseas.
* The Federal Government and business have learned valuable lessons in how to manage crises from their experience in the oil crises of the 70's, and from the collapse of the stock market in 1987.
* The United States is now in possession of a strategic oil reserve capable of offsetting disruptions in flow of oil from Iraq and Kuwait for at least 800 days.
* Other oil producers, like Venezuela, Mexico and Saudi Arabia, can bring on new production to offset losses from an embargo of Iraq.
* Inflation, though potentially strong, has not escaped Federal Reserve control.
* The Western industrialized nations are united in pursuit of a solution to the oil crisis.
* Higher oil prices are likely to spur efforts to develop synthetic fuels and to explore for oil domestically.
The economic news was gloomy enough even before Iraq seized Kuwait's oil fields and drove up prices on the spot market by 50 percent. (The sorting out of what the impact of the increase will be on various economic sectors has already begun. Page 4.) For the last six quarters, economic growth has limped along at less than 2 percent and falling, prompting several economists to say the country is now in a recession, though a recession is officially defined as two consecutive quarters of contraction, or below-zero growth. The June figures for unemployment showed a sharp jump from 5.2 percent to 5.5 percent, reflecting a loss of more than 430,000 jobs. Slowing economic activity also prompted Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, to revise upward his estimate of the size of the Federal budget deficit, from $100 billion to $161 billion. This revision came just as Congress and the Administration were locked in debate over how best to cut the deficit and bring it into compliance with the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets.
The fact that the nation is better equipped to meet crises than it once was does not mean that a big increase in oil prices over a sustained period would not hurt. It would. ''An $8 permanent increase in the price of oil, in year one, reduces economic growth by .2 to .3 percentage points,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. And spot-oil prices are now $10 higher than before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. With every dollar increase in the price of oil, $6 billion is taken from consumers.
And a rise in oil prices can, indeed, reverberate, because oil is such a pervasive part of the economy. The prices for oil-based chemicals and plastics rise in direct reaction, for instance, along with home heating fuel. ''For each 10 to 15 percent increase in the price of oil, consumer prices rise by a full percentage point.'' said Francis Schott, chief economist of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.
With the inflation rate before the Iraqi invasion hovering at 5 percent to 6 percent in July, the current 50 percent hike in the price of oil - if it were to remain - could bring inflation back to double-digit levels. An economy stagnant and beset by inflation would lay the foundation for a ''a replay of the 1974-79 period when we suffered with stagflation. This is deja vu,'' Mr. Schott said.
 
Stronger Strategies
It fact, these times are not really deja vu all over again, as Yogi Berra might put it. The American economy and American business have significantly changed. The strategies available for them to pull out of a slump, even at a time of climbing prices, are stronger and sharper.
Most experts agree that, for one thing, the nation's businesses, subjected to a decade and a half of intense competition from abroad and uncertain economic conditions at home, have become much more efficient.
Pat Choate, chief economist at TRW Inc., said American companies have become ''much leaner and much meaner than they were in the 1970's.'' Victor H. Palmieri, an expert in turning around troubled companies, agrees, and points to Kodak, Xerox, Control Data, Navistar, Midway Airlines in Chicago and Equitable as among the leaders in trimming their operations.
One key tactic for surviving economic peril is outsourcing, the practice of buying parts or materials from others when it is cheaper than producing them. There was a time when the quintessential American corporation thought it had to create every part of every product it sold. Now because of outsourcing, Mr. Choate said, company inventories are, in general, smaller than ever, and as a result, overhead is lower.
In manufacturing and retailing, just-in-time ordering - taking delivery on parts only when needed - is another strategy. Many of the nation's largest manufacturers and retailers, already anticipating a slow year before the Middle East oil crisis, have also kept stockroom supplies low. ''Our strategy has been to order less and reorder if we need to,'' said Ira Silver, chief economist at the J. C. Penney Company. ''We order closer to the season and are keeping less inventory; the industry as a whole is doing this. And our new stores are now more energy-efficient.'' Retailers are affected by the price of oil, ''because it takes money out of the consumer's pocket. But unless there's a real big oil shock and we go into a deep recession, we're in pretty good shape.''
In their efforts at greater efficiency, companies have jettisoned layers of middle management, reduced the number of production workers and cut down the time it takes to bring new products to market. As a result, they are better positioned to deal with the upsets of a recession and able to design new products more quickly to suit the times. ''It is the smaller companies, the ones that are holding all the big companies' inventories, that will be hurt,'' said Mr. Choate.
On the other hand, some small companies, too, are navigating better through rough economic waters, and have developed more flexibility. ''Our strategy began two years ago when we started to fire almost all of our 42 employees and make them outside contractors,'' said Stephen Meyers, a partner in American Communications Technology, a telephone installation and consulting firm in New York. ''By making them outside contractors we pay them more but only when we need them. We got rid of all our vehicles and pushed down our debt. Overhead is down.''
The corporations to be among the hardest hit in the event of a deep recession are those that have incurred large levels of indebtedness and that are short of cash. Overextension on ''junk bonds,'' for example, was another lesson for some in the 80's, if a late one. ''Companies that have gotten their debt down and still have the capacity to borrow - they'll do fine - companies like Ford, General Electric and American Express.'' said Mr. Choate.
And the major companies, remembering the seesawing of oil in the 70's and early 80's, now fully understand their need to keep their energy consumption as low as possible and diversify fuels. They are using a much wider range of fuels, like natural gas, coal and electricity than they did in the 70's. As a result, each unit of economic output now requires less oil input than it did.
 
Fuel Flexibility
John Deere Inc., the big maker of farm machinery and other heavy equipment in Peoria, Ill., has developed what it calls a ''fuel flexibility plan.'' Rather than relying exclusively on any one form of energy, it uses utility-provided electricity to power its machine tools, natural gas in its foundry and generates it some power of its own by burning coal. The Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor, Mich., a maker of washing machines and dishwashers, has also diversified; It has, for example, stopped making its washtubs out of porcelain-enamel, which must be baked, and has substituted plastics which, though made from oil, require less energy to produce.
Peter Schwartz, president of Global Business Network, a business strategy consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif., and formerly head of planning at Royal Dutch Shell in London, said that if the nation does see extended oil-price hikes, it will mean an even bigger trade deficit than the one it has now. That means the country will have try harder to export more. And companies with strong export strategies will benefit. Again, Deere, is one. Globally, ''it is very possible to experience a recession in the U.S. and still experience strong export demands,'' said Robert Combs, the company's spokesman.
Despite all these measures, times ahead will not be easy and companies will probably find their markets shrinking at least for the short term. ''For the next six months, customers will be in short supply and finding them will be expensive. The companies that will do the best will be those that are able to hold onto their customers by giving them high-quality service,'' Mr. Schwartz said. Can the Federal Government help? Even though burdened by a problem of its own that it did not have in the 70's and the recession of 1982 - that is, a $100 billion-plus annual budget deficit - the Government should not be regarded as powerless in this economy.
So far, there is no call for a major overhaul by the Administration, Congress or the Federal Reserve of the policies that had been put in place before the Iraqi invasion.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said the basic goal remains the same: cutting heavily into the Federal deficit over the next five years. ''We still believe that a growth-oriented, credible, enforcible, multiyear deficit reduction package is economically desirable. Our target hasn't changed. It's still around $500 billion over five years. Recent events underscore the importance of a growth-oriented deficit reduction package,'' Mr. Boskin said.
 
Finding the Right Mix
But there are calls for fine tuning. Lawrence Summers, an economist at Harvard University, said, ''The right mix of policies, before the oil shock, is still the right advice after.'' But he adds: ''Twist the mix toward less expansion on the fiscal side and more on the monetary side. If the energy prices stick, it means it's just not time for a big increase in energy taxes or imported oil fees.'' Lee H. Hamilton, a Democrat of Indiana and the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said the Government must keep trying to cut the deficit - but push some of those cuts into the future.
The Government has two basic methods for fighting a recession: fiscal measures - increasing spending, which directly stimulates demand to promote growth - or monetary measures - lowering interest rates, which increases investment and consumer spending.
Fiscal measures are inhibited by the Gramm-Rudman Act, which effectively limits increased spending by mandating cuts in budget deficits. But Gramm-Rudman has a built-in waiver. Norman Ornstein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, points out that ''if there are two quarters of less than 1 percent real growth, or if there is negative growth for a certain amount of time, the waiver goes into effect,'' giving Congress the power to spend more to stimulate the economy. President Bush offered to raise taxes recently, according to Mr. Ornstein, because he saw a recession coming: ''Bush took a real chance by reneging on his 'read my lips' pledge on taxes. He did it because there were enough signs in advance that we were nearing a recession, and he wanted to be ready.''
But the trouble with using government spending or high deficits to stay out of a recession, as Ronald Reagan did, is that the eventually the piper, or someone, somewhere, must be paid. Many argue that this, in part, is what is going on now.
The advantage of monetary policy is that it promotes investment, and growth, without adding to government spending. The disadvantage, is that, at least in the short run, it can breed the inflation the country is trying to avoid, depress the value of the dollar and discourage foreign investment.
Economists studying the results of previous efforts to shorten recessions tend to agree that lower interest rates, combined with a reduction in the size of the Federal budget, is the proper medicine for treating an economy suffering from both slow or negative growth and sharp inflation. And, they say, the current special conditions do not preclude these tools.
In the 70's, Federal spending was high but, at the same time, the Fed's policy was to keep money tight. Paul A. Samuelson, a Nobel laureate in economics who teaches at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology, said: ''We now know this was wrong. There was nothing sillier than President Ford wearing his WIN [whip inflation now] button at the economic summit just as the nation was entering a real tailspin of a recession.''
What seems needed is a judicious dose of the traditional medicine. The task of the Federal Reserve ''is to ease monetary policy warily,'' Mr. Samuelson said, ''ease interest rates, and then take in the slack later.'' The idea is that the lowered rates will stimulate the economy, but once inflation becomes a real problem, they can be raised again.
 
BREAKING THE ARAB OIL HABIT
If timing is everything, Saddam Hussein's decision to invade Kuwait and seize its oil fields couldn't have come at a worse moment - for him. ''Oil stocks, both private and public, are at all-time highs,'' said Philip K. Verleger, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. ''You invade when stocks are low, not when they are so high.''
Mr. Verleger said the world has ''99 days of supply on hand in tanks and in storage; 70 days of that are in private hands and 29 days are held by governments.
Three-quarters of public supplies are held by the United States in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve - 600 million barrels. ''We have an agreement to share that oil with the other industrialized nations if need be, except for France,'' said Mr. Verleger.
Total oil capacity produced by Iraq and Kuwait is 4.5 million barrels a day, about 20 percent of the world's supply - which, Dale Jorgenson, a Harvard University energy economist said, can be made up by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Indonesia, Nigeria, Mexico, Norway, Britain and the Soviet Union.
Prices went up after the invasion but, Mr. Jorgenson said, ''once the military situation stabilizes in a few days, the precautionary demand to increase inventories would be reversed and a lot of people, seeing high spot prices, will unload.'' The price outlook? ''Hard to predict, but I would say it would fall into a broad range somewhere between $14 and $24 a barrel - about where it was before the invasion.''
And the nation is less dependent to begin with than it was. As Michael J. Boskin, the President's economic adviser, pointed out: ''We use one-third less energy for every dollar'' of gross national product than in the 70's.
 
IN POSITION FOR THE CRISIS
Back in the dark days of the 1982 recession, with oil prices collapsing, John J. Murphy, the new president of Dresser Industries Inc., in Dallas, decided it was time to refocus on energy, even though there was no market for it at the time. ''We sold an insurance company, a fire hydrant company, a leasing company,'' said Mr. Murphy, now chief executive.
Since then, Dresser has concentrated on making products used in drilling, refining, transporting and mining as well as heavy equipment and industrial tools. ''Drilling activity in the U.S. dropped from 4,500 rigs in 1980 to a little over 1,000 at the beginning of 1990,'' Mr. Murphy said. Now, with oil prices rising after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait,there is likely to be an increase in exploration. Energy analysts say Mexico and Saudi Arabia, which have pledged to increase production, cannot sustain increases without substantial new investment.
The company seems to be in a position to benefit from the turbulence in the Middle East. While the phones are not yet ringing from companies that want to begin drilling or from countries wanting to invest in new pipelines, the company is cautiously putting a little more capital in place in the belief that they will.

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1439 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST
 
Prices at the Pump
 
Gas station owners seemed to react to the oil crisis with the quickened reflexes of commodities traders last week. Retail prices soared an average of 12 cents a gallon by Wednesday, with analysts blaming psychological factors, motorists blaming gas station owners, gas station owners blaming Arabs and oil companies. The oil companies fell all but mute. ''You don't see President Bush doing any talking either,'' said a Mobil Corporation representative at the beginning of last week. By Wednesday, the President was talking: ''I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share,'' he said. ''They should show restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices.'' Suddenly, oil company executives recovered their voices, as several announced price cuts and several others defended their increases.
 
Iran's Surplus Sales
 
Iran, of all nations, to the rescue? Iran is said to have sold millions of barrels of oil from its storage tankers last week. After a long, punishing war with Iraq, Iran is apparently eager to profit from an embargo against its enemy. But oil company executives say that the boycott of Iraqi supplies has been almost completely effective. Western nations, they say, will have to draw from their strategic reserves. 
 
A Cold Winter?
 
President Hussein might have picked the wrong season to start a fight. The world can more easily manage without his oil when it's warm. Oil finished on Friday at about $26.23, where some traders expect prices to settle. Analysts say that other producers can help compensate for a while for the cut-off in Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies. ''Right now you're in low-demand season,'' said Paul D. Mlotok, an energy analyst at Morgan Stanley. Getting along without Iraq's oil come winter is another matter. ''You're going to have to draw down inventory when people's tendency is to hoard it,'' he said. ''Prices could exceed $30.''
 
THE ECONOMY
 
An Architect to Remember
 
On Monday, at the age of 81, the architect who gave corporate America its modernist aspirations died. Beginning with Lever House - New York's first glass-walled office tower - in 1952, Gordon Bunshaft's example reverberated until all self-respecting corporations built with metal and glass instead of stone. His influence was amplified by his firm, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, whose huge New York office he headed.
Lever House itself was an act of corporate philanthropy. It sacrificed much of its permissible size to create a glade in Park Avenue's high-rise forest. Other architects perverted his principals to give developers the most rentable square feet for the money in boxy buildings that mar many an American downtown. And since Mr. Bunshaft retired a decade ago, architects have rediscovered materials and details that he had consigned to history. But his best buildings remain to embody a timelessness and vision that seem to have passed from the corporate scene.
 
Producer Prices Dip
 
Producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in July - before the Iraqis invaded Kuwait. Some on Wall Street saw the decline was evidence of an economic slowdown. Steven Axilrod, vice chairman of Nikko Securities International, said that higher oil costs will hurt corporate profits, since demand is too weak for them to raise their prices.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Dual-Currency Soviet Economy?
 
Attention Soviet shoppers: Reach into your mattresses, pull out your dollars and marks, and hurry over to the beriozka for all the goodies that hard currency can buy. The Soviet Union opened its hard-currency stores to its own citizens at the beginning of this month, without questioning how an estimated $2 billion in foreign money came into private hands. Most methods of obtaining it, like trading on the black market, remain illegal. A writer for the Soviet news agency, Tass, in an article headlined ''Epitaph for the Ruble?'', predicted the further emergence of a dual-currency economy, ''where a Soviet citizen will be asked to pay in hard currency not only for a packet of Marlboro cigarettes, but also for his airline ticket, a reservation in the restaurant and for mending his television set.'' Businesses, at least, might might soon find it much easier to acquire foreign currency. Moscow announced last week that it would open corporate money exchanges around the country next year. Only selected Soviet companies have been allowed to bid at the country's foreign-currency auctions so far.
 
Japan Applies Oil-Shock Lessons
 
The outlook for the Japanese economy is healthier than some fever charts indicate. Since the oil shocks of the 1970's - when idled taxi drivers, swept up in the panic, committed suicide - the Japanese have stockpiled oil, turned to nuclear power and made their cars and industries some of the most energy-efficient in the world. ''The Japanese have a great capacity to learn from trauma,'' said Susan J. Pharr, a Harvard professor of government. Japanese investors are not nearly so confident. The Nikkei stock average fell 7.4 percent for the week, to a low for the year.
 
COMPANIES
 
Lorenzo Bows Out
 
After two corporate bankruptcies, three acquisitions and a raging strike, Frank Lorenzo is quitting the airline business. He announced his resignation as chairman of Continental Airline Holdings Inc., formerly Texas Air, on Thursday. The Scandinavian Airline System made his on-time departure a condition of buying his Continental stock, increasing its stake to 16.8 percent. His replacement is Hollis L. Harris, 58, who worked his way up from gate agent to president of Delta Airlines in 36 years. Mr. Harris pledged to transform Continental's image and service and restore its profitability. Investors, who have suffered from Continental's decline, celebrated the news by bidding up its stock 39 percent in a day. With the company doubled over by debt, ''Mr. Harris should be able to open more doors in the financial community,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. The agreement with S.A.S. bars Mr. Lorenzo from the airline industry for seven years. Mr. Lorenzo has even more reason than shareholders to celebrate, as he leaves with $30.5 million from a comfortable severance package and a premium price for his stock.
 
Donaldson Heads Exchange
 
William H. Donaldson, one of the founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., was named to head the world's largest stock exchange last week. He will succeed John J. Phelan Jr. as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange in January. Mr. Donaldson, who is 59 years old, faces the tasks of defending the exchange against challenges from overseas markets, regional exchanges and other new ways of trading stocks and betting on the market.
 
The UAL Takeover Plan
 
The board of directors gave employees of UAL Inc. a break last week, but the economy didn't. The board decided on Wednesday to give the employee unions two more months to arrange financing for their $4.38 billion, $201-a-share bid. But with fuel prices rising and the economy lurching towards recession, airlines look like the last companies to invest in. The unions have had trouble finding equity partners, and several banks have defected. One hopeful sign: Northwest's corporate parent, NWA, the only major airline to be taken private so far, is successfully paying its debts.
 
Asbestos Cases Accelerated?
 
Ten Federal District Court judges reached an agreement on Friday to consolidate tens of thousands of asbestos cases. The judges said their unusual agreement can bring about a quicker, less costly way of compensating more than 100,000 victims. As many as half a million more cases could be filed over the next decade as more workers who have inhaled asbestos fibers develop cancer. Some of the judges have estimated that about legal expenses have absorbed about two-thirds of the payments that would otherwise go to asbestos victims. But some companies and lawyers for the victims are likely to challenge the new arrangements.
 
In Brief
 
A Broadway show with record advance sales of $25 million was canceled after Actors' Equity refused to let an English actor play a Eurasian lead role. ''Miss Saigon'' had been scheduled to open in March 1991 with members of minority groups in 34 of 50 roles.
 
The chairman of the world's largest accounting firm resigned after some of his partners objected to his choice of a vice chairman and possible successor. Larry D. Horner said on Wednesday that he will leave as chairman of KMPG Peat Marwick in October.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Riding Out the Mideast Storm

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
How can investors in mutual funds maneuver safely through the choppy waters of the current stock market?
Most important, don't panic. After that, market experts say, the course you chart depends on your tolerance for risk and your time horizon. For the adventurous, there are superb opportunities. For the nervous, there are ways to construct fund portfolios that smooth the market's ups and downs. 
So far, at least, most fund investors are heeding the experts' advice not to sell. While some fund executives reported slight outflows from stock funds last week, the wholesale dumping of stocks that immediately followed the October 1987 market crash was noticeably absent.
The lesson of 1987 for most investors - to sit tight in times of panic - is especially valuable today. The Lipper Growth Fund Index, a benchmark for funds similar to Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, has dropped close to 12 percent since mid-July. Unless you need the cash immediately, it does not make sense to bail out when prices are so low.
''If you're holding a good stock fund, keep holding on,'' said Gerald W. Perritt, editor of the Chicago-based Mutual Fund Letter. ''Prices will go up again.'' For long-term investors, ''looking too closely at the events of the past few weeks is a mistake,'' said John Markese, director of research for the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago.
Investors who dump their fund shares in the wake of bad news often overlook the tax implications of their hasty action, Mr. Markese said. And they also have to grapple with the problem of when to move their money back into the market.
Hanging on makes special sense for investors who have carefully crafted portfolios with 10-year horizons.
''What happens over the next few months isn't that critical to your overall return,'' said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants.
With prices down, should bargain hunters begin snooping around for good deals? Here the market pundits disagree.
Mr. Perritt, for one, doesn't see any buying opportunities yet. Hostilities in the Middle East pushed stock prices down, but other indicators, like a rising unemployment rate, also contributed to the decline, he noted. He predicts that further weakening in the economy will push stock prices down another 15 to 30 percent and concludes: ''It's premature to do any buying now.''
Other investment advisers advocate selective buying. They caution against jumping in immediately, because the markets traditionally overreact to bad news. As a result, they say, more sharp declines in the Dow Jones industrial average, like last Monday's 93-point fall, would not be very surprising. While part of the Dow's plunge was based on underlying fundamental changes, ''it's largely attributable to fear in the marketplace,'' said Craig A. Litman, a partner in Litman/Gregory, a San Francisco-based investment management firm that specializes in funds.
So these are good times for investors with strong stomachs who can handle the rough ride until events in the Mideast move forward and the markets settle down. Quick-footed investors can seize the moment to buy on weakness, picking up funds that they had long sought and are now at lower prices. ''Clearly, there are some opportunities out there,'' Mr. Litman said.
Of course, one way to hedge your bets is to buy funds that focus on oil or other energy stocks. Mr. Markese, for one, likes the T. Rowe Price New Era Fund, a no-load fund that invests mainly in companies that own or develop natural resources.
For his part, Mr. Phillips advises nimble investors to use the sharp market swings to ''pick up extra shares when prices are down, and sell when prices get ahead of themselves.'' But in fast-moving markets, Mr. Phillips said, it makes sense to stay with the familiar. Work with the funds that you have already researched or that you already own. ''This is not the time to be buying funds that you never heard of,'' he said.
On one thing, the pundits agree: the events of the past few weeks make a strong case for ''dollar-cost averaging.'' Investors using this method put money into the market on a regular basis, regardless of market levels. Accumulating shares over time at various prices works to smooth the volatility of the marketplace.
But buying small blocks of fund shares creates a problem for investors in load funds. In many funds, the upfront sales charge declines as the size of the purchase increases.
Investors who buy load funds can minimize the sales charge by signing a ''letter of intent'' which says that you plan to buy a certain number of shares in the fund over the next 13 months, says Dennis J. Kelly, vice president of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in New York. That way, you can qualify for the lowest sales charge on the total amount invested over that period, even though you are not buying the shares in a block.
 
PINPOINTING TAX-FREE PROFITS
Some tax-free funds are more equal than others. With some care, picking and choosing among them, you might find yourself pocketing some some extra profit.
The difference is that some funds hold ''private purpose'' municipal bonds, which are used to finance housing projects, student loans and recycling programs, among other things.
Private-purpose bonds offer higher yields than other tax-exempt issues because the interest they pay, although free from regular income taxes, may be subject to the alternative minimum tax.
That tax is designed to insure that wealthy taxpayers pay their fair share to the Government. It comes into play when an investor has a mix of certain types of deductions and tax-preferred income.
Investors who are not subject to the minimum tax can increase their returns by choosing funds that buy these bonds. To find out if a fund holds such bonds, call the fund's management.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Iraq Shatters Some Myths About Oil

BYLINE: By ARNOLD NADLER; Arnold Nadler is an energy consultant in Salem, Mass.

 BODY:
''We are frankly puzzled by claims that oil imports from OPEC countries constitute a threat . . . . References to OPEC as a ruthless cartel whose aim is to gain a stranglehold on economies of the West are completely false and misleading . . . . We must all endeavor to create a climate of mutual trust and respect . . . .'' - Dr. H. E. Subroto, Secretary General of OPEC, in the October 1989 OPEC Bulletin.
Like a thunderbolt, Saddam Hussein has shattered the benign illusion of peaceful, uninterrupted world trade in oil. We should be glad that the message has come now, not later. Better to have prices surge to $30 a barrel today, than to $60 under the same scenario in four or five years. 
Since the 1985 low point, world demand for oil produced by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has rebounded by seven million barrels a day. The rapid rise parallels the 1966-70 pattern, which was followed by the first oil price shock a few years later.
At about 23 million barrels a day, demand for OPEC oil is still moderate. However, if recent trends continue, by the mid- or late 1990's demand could be back to the daily peaks of 30 million barrels reached in 1973 and 1979. With market power clearly on OPEC's side, we would then be set up for a full-scale repeat of the price shocks of the 1970's. By breaking into the cycle early, Saddam Hussein has probably helped us avoid a more severe crunch down the road.
A useful assumption is that the Iraqi ruler will become the regional enforcer of the Middle East. He will make sure that the oil-producing states in the Persian Gulf and North Africa adhere to production quotas. What should we do?
First, of the 13 members of OPEC, five are outside the Middle East and North Africa. Venezuela, Nigeria, Indonesia, Ecuador and Gabon account for almost one-fourth of OPEC production. We should encourage them to move away from OPEC, something they may want to do anyway.
Second, we should try to brake the rise in world demand for OPEC oil. Since about half of the increase since 1985 is accounted for by soaring American imports, a sustained oil price surge could cost the country dearly geopolitically. Allies would quickly recognize that America's thirst for petroleum strengthened OPEC's hand. Though we are still the second-largest oil-producing nation in the world, our oil imports alone now exceed the petroleum consumed in France, Italy, Britain and West Germany combined.
Higher Federal gasoline taxes make sense. Each penny per gallon means about $1 billion a year in revenues. Both as a deficit-reducing measure, and to dampen consumption growth, a gradual increase of at least 25 cents per gallon would send the right message around the world.
There is a lot of oil in South America. Significant producers include not only Mexico and Venezuela, but Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and even Peru and Trinidad. Together, they pump more oil than Saudi Arabia (or Iraq and Kuwait combined). Political stability, sensible privatization and outside investment could lead to significantly increased output.
Domestically, we should accelerate the use of natural gas as automobile fuel, and be more realistic about drilling for oil offshore and in Alaska. Offshore drilling can be safer than importing oil by tanker. (British Petroleum is one of the largest oil producers in Alaska, and the Kuwait Investment Office owns 9.9 percent of it. Thus it is conceivable that Saddam Hussein's Iraq could become a significant minority shareholder in Alaska's oil fields.) Prior to the attack on Kuwait, mainstream forecasts pointed to continuing growth in America's thirst for Middle East oil. To make our future more secure, and the world less prone to crisis, we should move decisively to reverse that trend.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Yes, a Bright Side to the S.& L. Bailout

BYLINE: By HAROLD B. EHRLICH; Harold B. Ehrlich is a managing director of the Stamford Company, an investment bank in New York.

 BODY:
By common agreement, the savings and loan bailout is a major financial debacle for everyone except depositors, whose money is safe because of Government guarantees. The cost is borne ultimately by the American taxpayers.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has assessed the near-term direct cost of the bailout at a minimum of $89 billion and perhaps as much as $130 billion, up from the original estimate of $73 billion, which has already been set aside. The General Accounting Office has estimated the long-term overall cost of the bailout at $325 billion or more, including interest, with the total reaching as much as $500 billion. 
The costs in terms of additional unemployment, reduced personal incomes, depressed home prices and business losses probably will run even higher than the G.A.O.'s estimates. Developers and contractors are going bankrupt, people are losing jobs, and savings and loan shareholders are being wiped out. Still, this unmitigated mess has four favorable aspects, none of which has received much attention.
First, the low-quality debt of the troubled savings and loans is being upgraded to the world's highest-quality credit, that which is backed by the United States Government. This is happening by virtue of the Congressionally mandated liquidation of the savings and loan industry's holdings of ''junk bonds,'' plus the Federal Government's financing of the bailout. Specifically, the savings and loan units must sell holdings of low-grade bonds by 1994. Most have already begun doing this.
At the same time, to earn income, savings and loan institutions have been reinvesting the proceeds of these sales largely in higher-quality debt instruments, many issued by the Federal Government or its agencies. In addition, Federal credit is being used to support insolvent saving and loans whose own credit is now worthless. The combination of these activities greatly enhances the overall debt structure of America.
Second, this process has the effect of reducing the total amount of debt in our economy. Savings and loan institutions are selling junk bonds, often at far less than face value. Real estate mortgages and construction loans are being restructured, and many other loans are being called in or written off. The savings and loan institutions are also being forced to cut their own indebtedness, a good deal of which is not worth even close to face value. Additional public debt - mainly Government-backed debt - is being issued to pay for the savings and loan bailout, but much more private debt is being extinguished. The net effect is less total debt.
Third, this reduction of debt and the forced liquidation of assets -dumping junk bonds and real estate holdings - acts as a check on inflation. When the prices of homes are under pressure, businesses are failing, and unemployment is rising, people tend to curb spending. And when so many assets are up for sale, prices in general tend to be soft. However, if the liquidation proceeds too rapidly or goes on too long, these negative impacts, combined with further bankruptcies and unemployment, could do far more than just help restrain inflation; they could bring on deflation, which would hardly be desirable from almost any point of view.
Putting that grim possibility aside, a fourth favorable outcome of the bailout is likely to be generally lower interest rates, for several reasons. Since the overall level of interest rates is greatly influenced by the pace of inflation, slower inflation should help reduce rates. Consolidating and liquifying the savings and loan industry, as well as upgrading its debt quality, also augur for lower interest rates because less demand for credit should help reduce the cost of money.
Few would argue that these favorable aspects of the savings and loan mess - credit upgrading, reduced overall debt burden, slower inflation, or even lower interest rates - are worth the heavy cost in terms of business losses and human hardship. We would not be suffering this trauma if the senior officers of our financial institutions and Congress had acted responsibly.
Without a doubt, a great many people would be better off today if the excesses of the 1980's had not occurred. We can only hope that our economy is not overly damaged by the painful regimen that has been adopted to purge the past financial ills. My assessment, however, is that after the bailout our financial system will be more sound and interest rates will be lower.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Oil Crunch '90: The Game Has Changed

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
If oil prices stay up, how will the poorer countries - and companies - pay their energy bills?
That question may take on great importance in coming weeks, as the world watches to see what Iraq will do as an economic boycott takes hold.
One sure thing is that the patterns established in the two oil shocks of the 1970's will not hold. Then, the oil exporters, awash in cash, deposited the money in Western banks, which in turn lent it to the countries that needed the money to pay for oil. The banks called the process ''recycling,'' and no one spent much time worrying about how those countries would ever repay the loans. It turned out many of them couldn't. Bankers have not forgotten that lesson. 
This time around, the problem may be greater because Eastern Europe no longer can count on cheap Soviet oil.
It's not only the countries that have problems, of course. ''The combination of recession and oil price shock will create a new wave of bankruptcies,'' forecasts Richard Hoey, the chief American economist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''It's very clear that optimistic estimates of cash flow of a lot of borrowers will be disappointed.'' Mr. Hoey had been forecasting a mild recession before the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. Now he thinks it will be longer and deeper.
Two years ago, when Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was still in business and peddling junk bonds, those companies might have found a friendly lender to tide them over. Now the credit markets are in what Mr. Hoey, a veteran of Drexel, calls a ''risk crunch,'' in which would-be borrowers without excellent credit find money unavailable at any price, while blue chip companies can borrow all they want.
In the stock market, a free fall in prices early in the week was followed by a mild rally in mid-week and then a new decline on Friday, as Saddam Hussein called for a ''holy war'' against ''evil enemies'' that included the Saudi royal family. That helped send oil prices back up, with crude for delivery next month at $26.23 per barrel, and send the rate on 30-year Treasury bonds up to 8.79 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 93.07 points for the week, to 2,716.58, and is now 9.4 percent below the peak it reached less than a month ago.
Although it seems clear that Mideast news will dominate the markets for some time, and positive developments could start a rally, it is worth remembering that the current dip in prices started before the Iraqi invasion. ''Even if the Iraqi problem disappears,'' said Steven Einhorn, the chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, ''the market still has to confront the fundamentals of a weak economy and earnings disappointments.'' He says stocks remain overvalued.
If the Mideast standoff drags on, and oil prices stay high, the big division in financial markets is likely to be one of quality and safety. Companies with the financial flexibility to cope with higher oil prices and lower sales are likely to do much better than those that badly need to borrow when no one wants to lend.

HEADLINE: Very Often, Low-Tech Is Beautiful

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The report on stylus-based computers (''Liberating Machines from Keyboards,'' July 29) demonstrates a tendency to seek a complex, high-tech solution when a low-tech one would do. 
For instance, a problem with keyboards for those of us who type badly is that we hit the wrong key or two keys at the same time. A larger keyboard, either with bigger keys or with greater spacing between the keys, would solve that problem very well.
 
PROF. THOMAS MAYER
Department of Economics
University of California
Davis, Calif., July 29

HEADLINE: Chief Trumpet

 BODY:
Scholars like Clinton Rossiter describe the American President in terms that make him sound like a hat rack: Chief of State, Commander in Chief, Chief Diplomat, Chief Legislator, Chief Economic Strategist and, at least until the end of the cold war, Leader of the Western World.
Last week, a tired but tenacious George Bush demonstrated his appetite and aptitude for another role - leader of all countries, Western and Eastern, outraged by Saddam Hussein's naked aggression in Kuwait. Following his lead, the world rose up. 
At the same time, the President demonstrated a shortcoming that could undermine his orchestration of strength. ''Words at great moments of history are deeds,'' Attlee said of Churchill in 1945. Americans support their President when trouble strikes. But that support soon dissipates unless they understand the reasons to take risks. That's why Mr. Bush needs to fulfill another Presidential function as important as the rest: Chief Trumpet.
George Bush, foreign affairs expert, rarely shines as a strategist. He let a year pass before seizing the monumental openings offered by Mikhail Gorbachev. He aided and traded with Iraq for over a year. Even so, as Friday's remarkable news from Cairo attests, he is a superb crisis manager.
The decision by 12 countries to send an Arab force to Saudi Arabia gave him his third triumph of the crisis. It followed his success at persuading Moscow to join in condemning Iraq, and at mobilizing other countries to action.
President Bush's decision to send in troops was probably compelled by the danger that Iraqi armies would invade the Saudi oil wells. But it ran the risk that Arab attitudes would one day curdle, making American defenders look like infidel intruders. The Cairo decision could remove that curse.
As admirably as the President has performed as crisis manager, however, he faces another test of leadership. A President can call on patriotism for prompt support in a crisis. For it to last, he must engender understanding. To achieve that, the public needs answers to some uncomfortable questions.
Notably, why before the invasion did the Reagan and Bush Administrations so indulge Saddam Hussein? They granted him credits and technology transfers - all despite his hellish use of poison gas to attack Iranian troops and to slaughter 5,000 Kurds. Why did the U.S. stop at limp lamentation?
Since the invasion, Mr. Bush has been commendably clear in condemning Iraq. Still, his speech Wednesday was more notable for asserting the national interest than explaining it. A new New York Times Poll shows that while most Americans endorse the President's action, half do not comprehend the dangers.
Military necessity may have left no time to bargain with European allies over their troop contributions. But why must the U.S. again bear a disproportionate share of the burden of defending oil that they need even more than America does?
Sophisticated citizens know how much the world depends on Saudi oil. It's up to the occupant of the bully pulpit to educate ordinary citizens, including parents of those G.I.'s, to these harsh realities. Energy experts argue compellingly that it's time to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. But whose job is it to explain why America's conservation efforts have lapsed into indifference? The same Chief Trumpet.
No one expects eloquence from George Bush, who last week was at his plain-spoken best. But if he's to sustain the siege of Iraq, he'll have to see that words are deeds.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Soldiers In the Sands

BYLINE: By A.M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The alliance between the United States and Western Europe will face a clear but so far unspoken danger in the Middle East. It is important to face it in advance.
Unless allies of the United States are willing to commit ground troops - not just votes at the United Nations, not just planes and warships, but ground troops fighting in support of American soldiers and Marines -the alliance will become a mockery to millions of Americans.
If there is a desert battle in which American troops are the only Westerners to fight and die, American emotional withdrawal from the alliance will come quickly. 
A national surge for American political and military withdrawal will follow as the night the day. In the next election American candidates who still believe the alliance is worth American treasure or blood will be able to say so - and then retire to private life.
The only way to prevent all this is for Americans who believe in the worth of the alliance to speak up, frank and loud. This has not yet been done by American diplomacy or the American press.
So far everybody is pleased by the Western support President Bush has been promised at sea and in the air. That pleasure will last until the first ground battle.
The votes at the U.N. show that finally European governments understand that Saddam Hussein's dictatorship is not simply a ''regional'' threat.
Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the other oil states are feudal tyrannies, in themselves not worth jeopardizing the life of a single foreign soldier. If Saddam ever decides to let some of the Kuwaiti ruling family creep back into the country, they will eagerly follow his boots where he leads them, preferably into Israel - but with their money, of course, not their lives.
But because Saddam's lust for power has exceeded his wisdom, the West sees now what was always quite plain to see. Saddam Hussein intends to control the entire Middle East, as the instrument for dominating the Western economy.
The West deluded itself so long because it was wonderfully profitable to sell him weapons and death factories and to buy and resell his oil. American business lobbies told us what a good guy he was, remember?
Western Middle Eastern specialists sang us the lullaby about Arab brotherhood and how Brother Saddam would not attack Brother Emir or Brother King.
Brothers? Ask the Lebanese about shellfire from the occupation of Brother Syrians or the Kurds about the slaughter by Brother Iraqis.
European, African and American nations also know how to kill each other. But they spare the world the prattle about brotherhood while doing the killing.
Saddam ended the delusion by making his threat to his brothers and to the West at least temporarily inseparable. Our economy and their necks are bound together by his greed.
Fortunately President Bush sent ground troops before he had any guarantee that the Arabs or our allies would join us with the necessary strength.
If Mr. Bush had waited for advance guarantees, we would be waiting still. Saddam would be turning the oil spigot on and off at his pleasure while we gathered below, with money and weapons for him in our submissive hands.
It is not brotherhood that prevented the Arab states from uniting against Saddam before he sent his troops into Kuwait or why they kissed him for the cameras. This is the knowledge that eats at their leaders: They are too weak in the esteem of their people to take any risks with confidence.
Now Arab states say they will create an Arab force to help the U.S. save their oil and skins. That will be welcome, but perhaps it is better to wait to see how many Arab states actually put soldiers into the field.
Whatever the Arabs do, Americans will feel they have every moral right to expect the support of the allies where the U.S. gave it to them - on the battle ground.
The Western alliance cannot afford to wait long for Britain, France, Italy, Greece and other partners to commit themselves to join the American soldiers in the sand if the battle comes.
Mr. Bush did not say the U.S. would send ships and planes but no ground troops. It will come hard if that is the position of America's allies.
One day Saddam Hussein will go down, to Western power, to a coup or to an Arab terrorist, perhaps even his own working for a new Arab master.
But it will be a terrible sorrow if, before he goes, he is able to do what Hitler and Stalin, his role models, could never do: Turn Americans away from the Western alliance.

HEADLINE: Saddam Hussein, Mideast's Noriega, Has to Go

BYLINE: By Bernard E. Trainor; Bernard E. Trainor directs the national security program at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The issue underlying President Bush's moves in the Persian Gulf is not Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or even oil. It is Saddam Hussein, the Noriega of the Middle East. Like his Panamanian counterpart, he has to go. He ought to be disposed of now before his power and opportunity for doing greater damage grows.
Apparently, President Bush's first strategic goal has been achieved. It's too late for President Hussein to try to conquer Saudi Arabia without paying an unacceptable price at the hands of U.S. air power. 
Mr. Hussein's first option is to sit tight in Kuwait and try to outwait the U.S. while American troops sweat and swat flies in the desert. This option is based on the assumption that the U.S. troops and the Arab troops who will join them will all weary of their commitment as the gulf remains tranquil and the world turns its attention elsewhere.
It also assumes that avarice and greed will lead some to circumvent the international economic sanctions and clandestinely deal with Iraq. Although President Hussein has little cash, he has enough to prolong the siege, as well as Arab admirers willing to secretly help a brother survive.
In playing a waiting game, he holds one card he will likely use to advantage: hostages - thousands from many nations.
Saddam Hussein can also be expected to agitate an increasingly inflamed Arab world into viewing the industrial nations as infidels determined to humiliate the Arabs - a tactic probably accompanied by a renewed terrorism campaign.
Ascending the ladder of violence, Saddam Hussein's next option is to try to inflict a surprising defeat or unacceptable casualties on the U.S. forces and make a grab for Saudi Arabia. Xenophobic and isolated, he may believe that significant American bloodletting would undermine American resolve, as it did after did after the bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut that killed 241.
His tank divisions, well placed for a massive attack on Saudi Arabia with little warning, could succeed only if Iraq neutralized U.S. air power with chemical weapons. But the U.S. field commander, aware of this threat, surely would insist on a pre-emptive strike against Iraqi chemical-delivery capabilities. Even a partly successful strike by Iraqi missiles and aircraft armed with nerve gas against troops, airfields, ships, supply depots and the oil infrastructure could have a devastating psychological effect on Americans and Saudis alike.
It would also contaminate aircraft, making them temporarily unusable during a critical period and causing widespread casualties among servicemen and oil workers despite their protective clothing and antichemical devices.
U.S. troops are only marginally trained in chemical defense and have never faced such a prospect, as did their forebears in World War I. Besides, young soldiers won't want to wear clumsy protective overgarments, particularly in 120 degree heat, regardless of the lethal threat. Additionally, how well the suits will remain protective under rough use in the field is an unknown.
The third, most dramatic option available to Saddam Hussein, having declared an Arab holy war, is to attack Israel with chemical weapons, fulfilling his threat to scorch that country.
This might totally destabilize the Middle East and suck some of Saddam Hussein's Arab brothers into the conflict. At the least, it would generate further support from millions of disfranchised Arabs who lionize him and who could ignite civil disorder in the conservative and moderate Arab states. This turmoil would add a new dimension to the conflict and, in Saddam Hussein's eyes, create ripe opportunities to advance his ambitions.
If economic strangulation doesn't work, what are President Bush's options?
His greatest hope is to stimulate opposition in Iraq so that the Iraqis oust the man who is leading them to national suicide - not an easy task in the tightly controlled police state.
Though Americans are clumsy at fostering coups, it is not inconceivable that our agents might try to foment discontent, if not outright rebellion, among young army officers.
Another option is to wait patiently for a provocation that provides a credible justification for striking at Iraq's vitals: its industrial capacity, waterways, transportation and communications, depots and barracks, and, most of all, chemical and budding nuclear-production sites.
The odds are that in time Saddam Hussein will hand us the opportunity we seek; presumably we would then exploit our strong suit, air power, and avoid major ground combat.
Whatever we do, its goal should be to convince the Iraqi military to rid itself of its misguided commander. That may not be a possible or even realistic aim, but it is a worthy one in the service of Middle East peace.

HEADLINE: All for Oil, a Fuel That Fouls Air and Water

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The panic in the financial and oil markets and at the gas pumps in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is just another one of many chickens, like the savings and loan institutions fiasco, that have come home to roost after having flown the coop in the shortsighted 1980's.
Sure, it is a bad thing that Saddam Hussein marched into Kuwait and stole all that oil. But anyone with sense knew that, sooner or later, he or someone like him was going to do just that. Yet all through the 80's, the Reagan Administration, with almost everyone's wholehearted assent, systematically dismantled all research into alternative fuels and eliminated all encouragements toward conservation (remember ''Americans have a right to all the heat and air-conditioning they want''?), so that by the end of the decade we were importing much more oil than at the beginning. 
Can we really be as stupid as we appear to be? Think about what we are now fighting over: a fuel that is inherently dirty and dangerous at all stages of its production and use, and one that becomes more and more inefficient as it becomes scarcer. As we are reminded every day by spills in Alaska, Galveston, the Arthur Kill and the Cape of Good Hope, and noxious clouds over New York, Los Angeles, Athens and Istanbul, petroleum is a substance that has fouled the water and air of the planet ever since we started using it and one that will continue to do so until the last economically viable drop is found, processed and burned (assuming that it is not spilled beforehand).
Obviously, there are massive amounts of capital tied up in the production, refining and distribution of petroleum-based products. Just as obviously, we should not have kicked the fossil-fuel habit cold turkey. But we've known how scarce and dangerous this stuff is for at least 20 years, and we've known that any of a number of foreign potentates can grab control of a big chunk of it easily.
Thus, there was simply no justification for abandoning efforts begun during the first series of oil crises and continued throughout the Carter years to encourage conservation and to develop clean, domestic sources of energy that would prevent the sort of lunacy we are now seeing from occurring over and over again.
As long as we sit back and believe that we can rely on energy sources from countries that have neither the stability nor the inclination to supply us, we will be vulnerable to the sort of massive dislocations we are facing. And even if the supplies were ever to become reliable, do we really want this stuff? Instead of threatening sanctions and war over a finite and filthy resource like crude oil, let's deploy our energies toward finding a more practical and satisfying substitute. The world will be a safer, cleaner and more peaceful place as a result.
 
JONATHAN LANG
 New York, Aug. 7, 1990
