HEADLINE: The Paris Season For Gate-Crashers

BYLINE: By alice Furlaud; Alice Furlaud is a writer and broadcaster who lives in Paris.

 BODY:
The summer invasion so dreaded by American residents of Paris is in full spate. As the French Parisians flee their city, heading for the sewage-saturated seashore, on come wave upon wave of our fellow Americans, inundating Paris and our apartments: the friends, the friends of friends, the children of friends of friends, the friends of friends of the children of friends, the whole implacable pack of them determined to live it up in Paris for one-eighteenth of what it costs them to live very simply in, say, Fond du Lac, Wis.
''Hi! You don't know me, I'm at the Gare de Lyon,'' is the typical early-morning telephone call being received daily by one or another American expatriate this month. It's not as easy to Just Say No as you might think. The first time the doorbell woke me at 8 A.M. I assumed the two young thugs at the door had just escaped from prison.
After a few seconds I realized that no self-respecting prison would have allowed the wide streaks of magenta in the center of their convicts' haircuts. I also realized that one of them was the son of a dear American friend, so for her sake I let him and his companion sleep on my floor for three (for me) troubled nights. 
They were on their way from the rented Venice palazzo of one divorced parent to the rented Amsterdam houseboat of another. But in spite of their privileged backgrounds neither of them had - and this is practically always the case - more than 100 francs in his pocket.
A friend of mine living on the elegant Rue Bonaparte once had guests for 93 consecutive nights. Calm ensued. On the 96th day they started coming again, and she lost count.
Another woman I know endured 83 consecutive days of self-invited guests in her luxurious Luxembourg Gardens apartment. Then a call came from her ex-husband's ex-girlfriend's daughter, a person my friend had never set eyes on: ''I'm at the airport; could I stay with you for a few weeks?'' The worm made a U-turn: ''No!''
But for several days thereafter young men telephoned from the United States at hours like 4 A.M. asking for the girl. She'd given out my friend's number with that confident assumption, which amazes all of us who live here, that one of our functions as residents of Paris is to provide hotel, restaurant, consular, translating and travel agency services for any or all Americans who manage to get hold of our addresses.
On behalf of all my fellow-suffering Americans in Paris, I am posting the following notice at all American international airports and at the major railroad stations of Paris:
 
Rules for Would-Be Guests Of Americans Living in Paris
 
Planning the Visit
1. Never, ever arrive at someone's home unannounced, even if you have to spend two nights in the Tuileries Gardens.
2. Even if a Paris resident you met in America has actually invited you to stay with her - I mean ''him'' too; but the most vulnerable pads in Paris seem to belong to women - when telephoning to take her up on the offer, reverse field at once if there's the slightest nuance of a hesitation in her voice.
3. If the hosts you have targeted turn you down on the ground that their apartment is too small and there's only one bed, do not say ''I don't mind sleeping on the floor.'' They might mind. You hadn't thought of that, had you?
4. Never ask to stay with anyone you wouldn't naturally stay with in the United States. Noticing in the school alumni magazine that someone you knew in the second grade lives in Paris, should not encourage you to move into her apartment, even if only for a weekend.
5. If you're accepted, ask your hosts if there's anything they would like from their native land. They will probably choose some small item unobtainable in Paris like bobby pins or shredded wheat. But this should not count as your total thank-you present. Unless the hosts respond to your offer by ordering Word Perfect 5 for their computer, take them something fairly costly.
An Indian turquoise ring is packable; so is a box of wild rice or 10 beautiful linen handkerchiefs. Or buy them something in Paris. A case of Champagne for every week you stay with your friends will be much cheaper than a hotel and is the least you should provide.
 
Once Installed as a Guest
1. Even if your hosts are the age of your parents, don't treat them like your parents. Take them out to dinner once, and don't ask ''Do you know a cheap restaurant?'' Go to a cheap restaurant by yourself; but when entertaining your hosts - who will inevitably have to provide you with quite a few meals - do not skimp. Remarks like ''Is the Tour d'Argent still the best place?'' will go down well.
2. Be generous not only with your hosts but also with yourself in Paris. It's a peculiar fact that many Americans, young and old, choose the occasion of their first visit to begin a strict, miserly economy regime. They wander suspiciously around the grandest and most glorious city on earth, treating it like a clip joint.
A well-heeled couple from Minnesota once decided to spend their first visit to Paris on my living-room floor. They dined at only one restaurant - at my insistence. The rest of the time they bought food (the first few times I had to go with them to protect them from the dreadful non-English-speaking market men) and ate it cross-legged on my floor. They kept me at the telephone for hours comparison-shopping for a cheap trip to England, and when I found one that cost about the same as going Greyhound from Minneapolis to St. Paul, they gasped in horror at the price.
3. Even if you are urged to have breakfast with your hosts (better to stay in bed until they leave for work), keep the questions you are burning to ask (''How many francs are there to the dollar?'' ''How do you say chocolate chip cookies in French?'' ''Why do the windows open like that?'') until much later, say at the cocktail hour.
4. Limit the calls you make from your host's telephone to a very few local calls. Most French telephone bills are not itemized, and ''timing'' your long distance calls always works out to the host's disadvantage. Buy a telephone card and use phone booths. If you speak no French, limit the number of calls you ask your host to make for you to two the first day, one thereafter.
5. If blue jeans are absolutely the only thing you ever wear at home, go ahead and wear them in Paris - no one will be shocked. But if normally you dress in establishment or Vogue magazine perfection at your office in San Francisco or at dinner parties in Greenwich, your choice of jeans for Paris is insulting to this elegant city and to your hosts, even if your only baggage is a backpack. In my college days, after the war and before permanent press, we came over to Europe for the summer carrying only what would fit on a bicycle. We too wore shorts and jeans - but rolled up in our knapsacks were a sleeveless jersey dress and a pair of ballet slippers, in case of an evening out. A crushable cotton Indian skirt or a tie can be rolled up just as easily.
6. Don't expect your Paris friends to tour the city with you: You are on vacation: they're not.
P.S. There is nothing shameful about staying in a hotel.The little French hotel is a vital part of the Paris experience. (See Babar and Celeste having breakfast in bed in what appears to be the Hotel Lancaster, in Jean de Brunhoff's ''Voyage de Babar.'') But don't ask American friends to get you a hotel room. They'll have to put down a deposit or at least write a confirming letter to the hotel. Yours will be the 15th or 20th request of this kind they have had this summer.

HEADLINE: At the End of the Oregon Trail

BYLINE: By Suzie Boss; Suzie Boss is a journalist who lives in Portland, Ore.

 BODY:
It's hard to imagine an American beyond the age of 12 who doesn't know a thing or two about the Oregon Trail. Rugged pioneers and their prairie schooners rank up there with the people on the Mayflower as historical archetypes. But even those who can manage a glib discourse on Manifest Destiny or identify the year when the Great Migration began might have trouble pinpointing where the pioneers' journey ended.
Oregon City, the official end of the trail, is a quiet community of 16,000, a dozen miles up the Willamette River from Portland. Once the capital of a territory that sprawled from the Rockies to the Pacific, Oregon City probably claims more firsts than any other community this side of the Mississippi: first incorporated city, first newspaper, first Masonic lodge, first jail, first moonshine whisky still. Oregon City also holds the original plat of San Francisco, filed in 1850 at the only Federal courthouse for thousands of square miles. 
Yet during occasional visits since I migrated to Oregon in the mid-1970's, I've found Oregon City surprisingly bashful of boasting about the role it played in Western history. This is a working town, not a museum piece, and the paper mill and county courthouse on Main Street are the twin peaks of the local economy. It's also a bedroom community for Portland, with newer housing subdivisions pressing in against the older city core. And as the last major suburb to the south of Portland, Oregon City is also a transition point between city and country, with farmland lapping against the edges of town.
During a recent tour, however, I sensed a shift in mood. In 1987, residents lobbied the state legislature to declare Oregon City the ''true and correct end of the Oregon National Historic Trail.'' The bill seemed to spark Oregon City's pride and has coincided with several other efforts to lure history-minded visitors. Oregon City doesn't yet rival Colonial Williamsburg, but the lower-key approach may well be part of its charm.
Since 1987, Oregon City has been host to an annual summer pageant dedicated to pioneer days. Last summer, 5,000 visitors watched the dramatization of life along the Oregon Trail, circa 1851.
The city has also taken stock of its architectural heritage and published five walking-tour guides, highlighting homes dating from the 1840's and many Queen Anne Victorians from the turn of the century. Many of these are tucked into the same hillside in the heart of the city.
Other historic houses have opened as museums, and two are now bed and breakfast inns. A group known as the Old Home Forum has installed markers on notable homes, many of them listed on the National Register of Historic Places. With its pioneer pageant, two historic districts and a dedicated cadre of historians and preservationists polishing the city's heritage, Oregon City is once again starting to draw visitors.
One letter tacked to a museum wall offers proof. The traveler, a 72-year-old from Vermont, said his journey across the Oregon Trail - by bicycle - took him ''six weeks lacking a day,'' a far sight quicker than the six months it took pioneers to cover the 2,200 miles from Independence, Mo. Other Oregon Trail buffs frequently arrive in Oregon City in RV's and cars, lining up to have their pictures taken next to ''End of the Oregon Trail'' markers.
Even those who don't cover the entire Oregon Trail before arriving here can expect to stretch their legs to get to the local sights. Contemporary Oregon City is set on three basalt terraces, rising like broad stairsteps above the Willamette River. A free-standing municipal elevator - billed as ''the nation's only vertical street'' - connects the riverside level with the second tier, 100 feet above. The ride is free in both directions, but lifetime elevator passes are dispensed as keepsakes. The observatory at the top offers views of the river, the old downtown district and, on clear days, Portland and Mount St. Helens to the north. Those who want a real workout can take the stone stairs, built by W.P.A. crews in the 1930's.
The city began at the river's edge, just above the crashing waters of Willamette Falls. Here, the river spills 40 feet over a wide, horseshoe-shaped basaltic reef, creating a natural fish ladder that has made the site a fishing and trading place for 3,000 years. During spring salmon and steelhead runs, fishermen anchor their boats side by side to form a ''hog line'' just below the falls. Willamette Falls Locks, operating since 1873 on the west bank of the river and now a National Historic Site, moves river traffic around the falls.
It took Dr. John McLoughlin, chief factor of the Hudson's Bay Company at Fort Vancouver and the man that local schoolchildren know as the Father of Oregon, to think of harnessing the river's power for a sawmill and flour mill. Since the gristmill was opened in 1838, Oregon City has been a mill town. Main Street still ends at a paper mill, and a second mill operates across the river at West Linn.
Much of the lower level of Oregon City houses county government offices, but a few older buildings are used as retail shops, taverns and cafes. South of Main Street along State Route 99E lies the Canemah National Historic District, home to riverboat captains and boat builders during the 1860's. Many of their Gothic Revival homes remain, including the 1867 E. B. Fellows Residence, now painted bright peach and used as a bed and breakfast inn and restaurant.
Most of the self-guided tours, however, begin at the McLoughlin House, built in 1846 and now a National Historic Site. The boxy, two-story, white Georgian Revival home sits atop the cliff on the city's second level, the McLoughlin Historic District, where most of the city's museums and older homes are situated. A parklike promenade lines the cliff's edge.
The McLoughlin House is the city's oldest preservation success story. Originally built on the lower level of town, the house fell into disrepair and disreputable use after the death of the Canadian-born Dr. McLoughlin and his Swiss-Indian wife, Marguerite. In 1909, the house was winched up nearby Singer Hill, and restored by the McLoughlin Memorial Association. It has been operating continuosly as a museum since 1910.
About a third of the furnishings are original, including the blue floral china that Dr. McLoughlin had shipped from the Staffordshire district of England. The ornately set dining table, capable of seating 24, came from Fort Vancouver, where Dr. McLoughlin supervised beaver trading for the Hudson's Bay Company for nearly 20 years. Hudson's Bay officers lived like noblemen in the wilderness, typically sitting down to a five-course midday meal.
Although Dr. McLoughlin was considered a capable manager, his kindness to American pioneers eventually cost him favor with the British trading company, and he was forced to retire. He cut a handsome deal with the trading company, landing in Oregon City a wealthy man. His home, complete with glass windows, milled door frames and separate outbuildings for cooking and bathing, was a model of gracious living. Dr. McLoughlin lived here the last 11 years of his life and became a United States citizen in 1851. He and his wife are buried on the grounds of the McLoughlin House.
Furnishings include Dr. McLoughlin's intricately carved mahogany four-poster, surprisingly short for a man who stood 6 feet, 4 inches. The museum curator, Nancy Wilson, said that health practices of the day called for sleeping propped almost to a sitting position. The desk he used, also from Fort Vancouver, housed a subscription library for the Hudson's Bay Company. Seven volumes from the original Columbia Libary remain in the desk, along with a medical library dating from 1833. Oriental cabinets, beaver hats and pelts, Indian artifacts, pioneer-era spool beds and a 200-year-old quilt are among other exhibits that draw 12,000 visitors a year.
Next door sits the 1849 Barclay House, built by Dr. Forbes Barclay, physician at Fort Vancouver from 1840 to 1850. Once he moved to Oregon City, Dr. Barclay threw himself into civic affairs, serving as town doctor, coroner, mayor and school superintendent. This Colonial Revival house was also built beside the river, moved to its present site in 1937 and renovated by W.P.A. workers. The first floor is open as a visitor's center and gift shop. A small swatch of original wallpaper, the lining from tea boxes, remains.
Two other homes turned musuems are a short walk away, both near the 1913 Carnegie Library, which occupies a grassy square block. The Frances Ermatinger House, built in 1845, is the third oldest house in Oregon and the oldest in Oregon City. Built on the riverfront level, it has been moved twice, occupying the current McLoughlin level site since 1986. Ruth McBride Powers, a long-time preservation activist and Oregon City resident, bought the house, restored it and furnished it with period piecs from her extensive collection.
Mr. Ermatinger, another fur trader with strong ties to the Hudson's Bay Company and to Dr. McLoughlin, lived only four years in Oregon City. His home, however, will long be remembered as the site where Portland, Ore., won its name. The pioneers Asa Lovejoy, from Boston, and Francis Pettygrove, from Portland, Me., each wanted to give the name of his hometown to the new settlement they were plotting downriver. After dinner one night in 1845, in the study of the Ermatinger House, they flipped a liberty penny. Mr. Pettygrove won, and the new town that was then just a clearing on the riverbank would grow to overshadow Oregon City. Portland gained an early advantage due to its deeper natural harbor. Once the hub of trade moved a dozen miles downstream, other commerce and culture followed.
By the turn of the century Oregon City had lost much of its early thunder to Portland, but the older community was scarcely a backwater. In 1908, Harley Stevens, a station agent for the Oregon Pacific Railway, packed his new Georgian Revival home with enhancements. The museum has been known as the Mertie Stevens House, since the daughter who occupied it until age 96 willed it to the Clackamas County Historical Society in 1968.
The home contains many of the Stevens's original furnishings. The kitchen looks as though the cook had just stepped out, leaving pie crimpers, cream stealers and pot lifters on the counter. A large pot pantry, next to a wood range, is stocked with tinware, and a summer kitchen on the back porch is set up for canning. With separate rooms for sewing and linens, an open-air sleeping porch, a pass-through pantry opening onto the dining room and extensive built-in cabinetry, the house was a showpiece of modern ideas. The Stevens House contains a large collection of dolls, many of them Mertie's, Native American baskets and artifacts and an assortment of antique clocks.
This McLoughlin level is also home to the End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center. A slide show recounts the saga of the overland migration that brought 300,000 pioneers west. Exhibits describe what life was like along the way. Visitors learn that pioneer women wore split drawer undergarments to make campground hygiene easier and insisted on bonnets to protect their complexions from the prairie sun.
Diary entries tell of the hardships and small joys of the journey, and letters home at the trail's end recount the optimism that even six months of hard travel didn't erase. ''We could in five years all be wealthy farmers,'' wrote one early arrival to Oregon City. The promise of 640 acres of free, verdant land and a chance at a fresh start in life proved intoxicating enough to risk 1-in-10 odds of death.
From the End of the Trail Interpretive Center, it's a short drive or leisurely walk downhill to the real end of the trail, marked by a pavilion, monument and flagpoles. Pioneers called the meeting place Abernethy Green, but today it's better known as the Kelley Field baseball diamond. The national pastime seems a fitting use. Baseball was invented at about the same time that wagons began heading west over the Oregon Trail.
When wagon trains arrived at trail's end after a harrowing journey over the Barlow Pass summit of snow-covered Mount Hood, families would camp at Abernethy Green while scouting for land to homestead. They filed land claims in Oregon City, then scattered throughout the Willamette Valley to start life from scratch.
On a clear day, 11,000-foot Mount Hood looks almost close enough to touch from Kelley Field. With a little imagination, it's not hard to envision prairie schooners billowing down the last hillside and children in sunbonnets and worn breeches running ahead to frolic on the green at journey's end.
 
FOR A STAY IN OREGON CITY, ORE.
 
Getting There
Oregon City is about half an hour's drive south of Portland, by way of State Route 99E, State Route 43 or Interstate 205. The city covers three levels: Main Street and the old downtown district; the McLoughlin Historic District, also known as the second level, and the Hilltop District, with retail strip developments. The Canemah National Historic District is south of downtown on 99E. For walking and driving guides and other visitor information, get in touch with the Chamber of Commerce, 500 Abernethy Road, Oregon City, Ore. 97045 (503-656-1619).
 
What to See
Willamette Falls Locks can be viewed on the west bank of the Willamette River at West Linn. Follow the marked footpath through the James River Corporation paper mill. There are displays on the history and design of the locks.
Among other sights: Dr. John McLoughlin House (713 Center Street; 503-656-5146). Open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday 1 to 4 P.M. Sunday; closed Monday, holidays and the month of January. Entry fee: $2.50.
End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center (500 Washington Street; 503-657-9336). Open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday, noon to 4 P.M. Sunday; closed Monday. Entry fee: $2.
Mertie Stevens House (603 Sixth Street; 503-655-2866). Open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Wednedsay to Saturday, 1 to 4 P.M. Sunday; closed Monday and Tuesday. Entry fee: $1.50.
Francis Ermatinger House (Sixth and John Adams Streets). Open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Entry fee: $1.50. Rose Farm (536 Holmes Lane; 503-656-5146), site of the swearing in of the first governor of the Oregon Territory. Open Sundays only from 1 to 4 P.M. from March 1 to Dec. 15 or by appointment. Entry fee: $1.50. Oregon City Municipal Elevator, Seventh Street at the foot of the bluff. Operates from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. Monday to Saturday.
Clackamette Park, at the confluence of the Willamette and Clackamas Rivers south of downtown. Good for fishing, boating and picnicking.
John Inskeep Environmental Learning Center on the grounds of Clackamas Community College (19600 South Mollala Avenue; 503-657-8400) is an eight-acre park.
 
Where to Stay
Bed-and-breakfast accommodations: Fellows House (416 South McLoughlin Boulevard; 503-656-2089) is a restored river captain's 1867 Gothic Revival house in the Canemah National Historic District. Rates for two begin at $42.50 a night. The 1880 Jagger House (512 Sixth Street; 503-657-7820) is in the McLoughlin Historic District. Rates for two start at $55.
Among motels, Val-U-Inn (1900 Clackamette Drive; 503-655-7141) sits at the river's edge just off State Route 99E. Rates for two begin at $51.
 
Where to Eat
Small-town cafes dot the older downtown area, and franchised outlets are plentiful in the Hilltop district. Fellows House Inn and Restaurant (416 South McLoughlin Boulevard; 503-656-2089) is the best bet for lunch, with homemade soups, sandwiches and daily specials. Across the Willamette River in West Linn, Cherrio's (21980 Willamette Drive; 503-656-7606) offers fish and chips, sandwiches and specials for lunch, seafood and steaks for dinner. Papandrea's Pizza (1678 South Beavercreek Road; 503-655-6329) is a family-owned alternative to fast-food outlets.
 
Special Events
The Oregon Trail Pageant, a musical extravaganza set in 1851, is held annually in the 650-seat outdoor theater of Clackamas Community College. This year's event was concluded last Saturday. .B.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
The Twin Cities

BYLINE: By Suzanne Winckler; Suzanne Winckler is the author of Great Lakes and Plains States volumes of ''The Smithsonian Guide to Historic America'' (Stewart Tabori & Chang).

 BODY:
Minneapolis and St. Paul rise up on the plain like two glimmering mirages. They are known to outlanders as the Twin Cities, but since there's nothing for hundreds of miles across the farmscape that might invite comparison or confusion, most Minnesotans simply call them the Cities. They perch on tree-lined bluffs at the confluence of the Mississippi and the lesser-known but equally handsome Minnesota River.
Poised on these brinks, the cities somehow seem lofty, and from many vantage points a person has the giddy sensation of standing on a balcony or the prow of a boat. The Dakota Indians, from whom Zebulon Pike purchased the land in 1805 that inaugurated white settlement in these parts, called the area Mendota, or Meeting of the Waters.
As cities go, Minneapolis and St. Paul maintain a remarkable affiliation with nature. Excellent proof of this coalition are the four pairs of peregrine falcons that nested this year on the rooftops of high-rises in the metropolitan area. As August merges into September the air turns brisk, the trees start to gild, and people go out for a last-minute revel. 
There are a lot of places in the Cities for autumn basking. Perhaps the best-known natural attraction set aside for public use is the cluster of jewel-like lakes - Cedar Lake, Lake of the Isles, Lake Calhoun, Lake Harriet, Hiawatha Lake and Lake Nokomis - that lie in the heart of Minneapolis. But there are also many hiking and nature trails throughout the 7,000-acre Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge in the suburb of Bloomington (visitor's center, 3815 East 80th Street; 612-854-5900).
In St. Paul, Como Park (main entrance at Midway Parkway and Hamline Avenue, 612-488-7291) is a lovely 350-acre park, which was established in the 1880's. It features a free zoo (612-488-4041) and a beautiful Victorian conservatory.
 
Events
The annual event that caps summer in these parts is the Minnesota State Fair (main entrance at North Snelling and Midway Parkway, 612-642-2262 or 800-383-3247). This year the fair runs from Aug. 23 to Sept. 3. The many exhibit barns and show arenas remind Twin Citians of the agricultural base of their urban economy. Performers at the fair will include Bill Cosby, Bob Dylan, Bonnie Raitt, the Beach Boys and George Strait. Gate tickets are $4 for adults, $2.50 for children and senior citizens. General admission to the shows is $6.75 to $8.25; reserved seats are $11.75 to $13.25.
At the Walker Art Center (Vineland Place, 612-375-7577), a show on ''Russian Constructivism, Art Into Life 1914-1932,'' runs from Oct. 7 to Dec. 30. Open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 8, Sunday from 11 to 5. Admission is $3, $2 for children and senior citizens, except on Thursday, when admission is free.
At the Minneapolis Institute of Arts (2400 Third Avenue South, 612-870-3131), ''Mirrors of Empire: Dutch Marine Art of the 17th Century'' runs from Sept. 23 to Dec. 30. Open Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday from 10 to 5, Thursday from 10 to 9 and Sunday from noon to 5. Admission free.
The institute has also just completed restoration of the William Purcell House (2328 Lake Place), which was designed in 1913 by the architecture partners William Purcell and George Elmslie. This Prairie School masterpiece will be open to the public every weekend throughout September and the second Saturday of each month thereafter. Reservations are necessary. In St. Paul, the Science Museum (30 East 10th Street, 612-221-9488) dispels ursine myths with ''Bears: Imagination and Reality,'' which runs through Jan. 30. Shows at the museum's Omnitheater, noted for its large, wraparound screen, are ''Race the Wind,'' a movie on sailing that runs until Nov. 11, and ''The Great Barrier Reef,'' which opens Nov. 13 and runs to March 17. Open Monday to Saturday from 9:30 to 9, Sunday from 11 to 9. Admission $6 adults, $5 children and senior citizens, including the movie.
 
Great Vistas
The following spots reveal the blufftop character of the Twin Cities.
Fort Snelling (Routes 5 and 55 near Mendota Bridge, 612-726-1171) was a frontier outpost established in 1819 to regulate trade and traffic on the Mississippi River, which was then the main avenue of travel on the continent. Standing on sheer cliffs at the confluence of the two rivers, the diamond-shaped limestone compound commands a fine view. Open daily through Oct. 31 from 10 to 5; admission $2 adults, $1 children and senior citizens.
The James J. Hill House (240 Summit Avenue, 612-297-2555) sits on the edge of the bluff at the head of the most fashionable residential street in St. Paul. The 36,000-square-foot Richardsonian Romanesque mansion was the home of the 19th-century entrepreneur who built the Great Northern Railroad. Open Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday from 10 to 3:30; $2 adults, $1 children and senior citizens.
Windows on Minnesota (612-349-6250) is a restaurant on the 50th floor of Johnson and Burgee's well-known 20th-century architectural landmark, the IDS Center (717 Nicollet Mall), in downtown Minneapolis. While the tariff is steep (dinner for two will run around $90), this perch offers stunning views of the Mississippi River and the city of St. Paul to the east.
The Pillsbury A Mill (Main Street Southeast at Third Avenue Southeast) is a huge limestone structure built in 1881 to use waterpower from nearby St. Anthony Falls on the Mississippi. This cascade was the nucleus around which commercial-industrial Minneapolis grew. Call 612-296-8205 to get information on how to obtain Walking the Falls, a self-guided walking tour of the district.
 
Where to Stay
Hyatt Regency Minneapolis (1300 Nicollet Mall, 612-370-1234) is tucked into a surprisingly cozy corner on the south end of Nicollet Mall, nirvana for shoppers and window-shoppers. It is also an easy walk from the Walker Art Center and Sculpture Garden. Rates for two from $165 to $180 during the week; $99 to $110 weekends.
Normandy Inn Best Western (405 South Eighth Street, outside Minnesota 800-372-3131, in state 800-362-3131) is a short walk to Nicollet Mall and the Metrodome. Rates for double occupancy range from $56.50 to $72.50.
Budget choice (Minneapolis): Nan's Bed and Breakfast (2304 Fremont Avenue South, 612-377-5118) supplies a homelike atmosphere in a restored Victorian house. A room for two people, with shared bath, is $45.
The Radisson Hotel St. Paul (11 East Kellogg Boulevard, 612-292-1900) is in the downtown business district right next to the Mississippi River. A double is $99 during the week; $65 on weekends.
The Sheraton Midway in St. Paul (I-94 at Hamline Avenue, 612-642-1234) offers convenience for car travelers, since I-94 is the quickest route between the two cities. Weekday rates for a double are $79; weekend rates are $49.
Budget choice (St. Paul): The University Club (420 Summit Avenue, 612-222-1751), where F. Scott Fitzgerald used to meet friends for drinks, is now a tennis, athletic, eating and drinking spot for Summit Avenue neighbors. It also has two rooms for guests, which run $45 and $65 respectively for two people.
 
Where to Eat
Haute cuisine is not in overabundance in the Twin Cities and what survives there must pass the muster of a clientele that is by birthright thrifty and wary of affectation. Part of the fun of dining at a high-ticket establishment comes after the meal with the inspection of the check and discussion as to whether the occasion equaled the tab.
Under recent scrutiny was Azur (651 Nicollet Mall, 612-342-2500) in the Gaviidae Common shopping mall in downtown Minneapolis. Azur, with an icy underwaterlike interior of purple and black neon, has glass curtain walls overlooking a sleek urban landscape that includes a peek at the venerable Art Deco-style Foshay Tower. The artfully served Provence-inspired menu includes a scrumptious duck liver and rhubarb appetizer, tender medallions of lamb strewn with arugula, and numerous fresh fish and crustacean dishes adorned with seasonal vegetables. Dinner for two with a bottle of wine: $85, plus tip. Just down the street, in the Conservatory shopping mall, is Tejas (800 Nicollet Mall, 612-375-1132), a friendly, chic and breezy purveyor of neo-Mex, the lighter, more artful version of Tex-Mex. Dinner for two: about $65 with wine, plus tip.
The Loring Park Cafe (1624 Harmon Place, 612-332-1617), positioned conveniently between downtown Minneapolis and the Walker Art Center, is a crowded, sophisticated bistro. Dinner for two: $60 with wine, plus tip. After eating, take one of the greatest strolls in urban America: a walk to the Walker Art Center's Sculpture Garden across the beautiful blue and yellow bridge spanning Interstate 94.
Gelpe's Old World Bakery (2447 South Hennepin Avenue, 612-377-1870) sits amid the fun and funky shops that line a dozen or so blocks of Hennepin Avenue from Franklin Avenue south to Lake Street. The bakery makes Old World breads and a cosmopolitan array of cookies and sweets, from Viennese crescents to Ethiopian truffles and Java sticks.
On the culinary homefront, the Mississippi mud pie cupcake is a surpassing tribute to that local landmark.
A few pockets of 1960's counterculture can still be found in Minneapolis, the city that put Bob Dylan on the map. An inexpensive place to sit down to one of those cornucopian egg-potato-cheese-sprouts-avocado breakfasts of yore amid vintage 60's patrons is the Seward Community Cafe (2129 East Franklin Avenue, 612-332-1011). Try the earth breakfast ($3.20 to $7.70).
In St. Paul, not far from the baronial mansions on Summit Avenue, Cafe Latte (850 Grand Avenue, 612-224-5687) is a cafeteria-style eatery and bakery that serves fresh pasta salads, soups, sandwiches and some of the best desserts in the Twin Cities, including a chocolate-Kahlua cheesecake. Lunch for two: $14.
 
Shopping
In St. Paul, Grand Avenue between South Snelling Avenue and North Dale Street is lined with shops from the mainstream to the oddball in storefronts and old Victorian houses. Treadle Yard Goods (1338 Grand Avenue, 612-698-9690) carries an exceptional selection of natural fibers, including many hand-washed silks and pima cottons. Bijoux Bead (715 Grand Avenue, 612-221-9103) sells glass, metal, wood, plastic and ceramic beads, plus the paraphernalia for stringing the baubles into jewelry.
The West Bank is Bob Dylan territory. This mercantile zone lies along Cedar Avenue within sight of the Metrodome and the University of Minnesota campus, which has spilled over from the east bank of the Mississippi River. The West Bank's covey of shops and cafes is definitely more laid back than Nicollet Mall. Midwest Mountaineering (309 Cedar Avenue South, 612-339-3433) is a wilderness outfitter par excellence. Across the street, Tatters and Platters (316 Cedar Avenue South, 612-332-0071) is renowned for its hip recycled clothes and records.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Signs the Paychecks

BYLINE: By GUS TYLER; Gus Tyler, the assistant president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, is a visiting professor of labor studies at Queens College.

 BODY:

WORKING FOR THE JAPANESE
Inside Mazda's American Auto Plant.
By Joseph J. Fucini and Suzy Fucini.
258 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.
 
JUMP START
Japan Comes to the Heartland.
By David Gelsanliter.
262 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.
One out of every four passenger cars produced domestically is manufactured by a ''transplant,'' a foreign, generally Japanese factory sited in the United States. In the 10-day period ending May 20, 1990, vehicle sales of the Big Three - General Motors, Ford and Chrysler - fell by about 900 a day compared with the same period last year, while transplant sales rose by about 2,000 a day. Lee Iacocca wails: ''The transplants are murdering all of us.'' The British journal The Economist has suggested that Detroit's Big Three are as good as dead right now, and that the sooner they give up the ghost the better. 
Ironically, the transplants are here as a result of Detroit's desire to check Japanese competition. Fearful that quotas would shut them out of the American market, Japanese auto makers decided that if they could not export their product they would export their production.
In doing so, they were - once more - aping the United States. When Europe and Japan began to protect their postwar ''infant industries,'' American corporations hurdled the barriers by setting up transplants over there. Now the Japanese (and Europeans, too) are doing unto us as we did unto them.
That the Japanese are here, then, should come as no surprise. What is surprising is that they have been able to outplay the Big Three on the latter's home turf and that the Americans are falling ever further behind.
Two books - ''Working for the Japanese'' by a husband-wife team, Joseph J. Fucini and Suzy Fucini, on a Mazda transplant, and ''Jump Start'' by a Philadelphia journalist, David Gelsanliter, on Toyota, Nissan and Honda transplants - try to tell why the invaders seem about to dethrone the once impregnable Detroit dynasties. Neither book spends much time on design or quality, traits commonly perceived to be the Japanese forte. Instead, the authors concentrate on culture, the distinctive Japanese culture that makes it possible for a Mazda plant, for instance, to turn out as many cars as an American plant and to do so with a work force that is 15 to 20 percent smaller than those of its American rivals. Mr. Gelsanliter applauds such performances, and sees this as the wave of the future in auto production. The Fucinis abhor the process as inhumanly oppressive, and darkly hint at mini-revolts in the making. But both relate management methods to the culture of Japan.
Culturally, Japan is an extended family, ethnically homogeneous (a biogenetic entity), while the United States might be called an ''intended'' family, demographically heterogeneous (a geopolitical comity). The former is collectivist and hierarchical; the latter is individualist and egalitarian. Although neither is purely either, each is sufficiently different from the other to spawn its own managerial methodology.
In the factories, the contrary cultures express themselves as ''JIT'' and what I would call ''JIC'' - for the Japanese ''just in time'' and for the Americans ''just in case.'' Under JIT, there is no room for error and, the Fucinis would add, no time to breathe. Under JIC, allowance is made for human error and humane needs. When an American worker, undergoing training for JIT, asks about sick days, the answer is, ''You're not supposed to get sick here.'' And if he or she does, according to the Fucini account, the stricken one is treated like a healthy worker.
The average workweek in the Mazda plant is 60 hours; when workers enter the plant in the morning they do not know when they will be leaving in the evening. Should a worker come up with a time-saving device, as encouraged to do, an additional chore is given the eager beaver to fill the unused minutes. These and similar practices are characterized by Mr. Gelsanliter as Japan's attempt to reintroduce the Protestant work ethic to the United States. The Fucinis see it as a return to the days of production-line tyranny, where the worker is a Chaplinesque cog in a soulless machine.
Though none of the authors say so, the Japanese regimen is surely rooted in Japan's overcrowded society: 123 million people (half the population of the United States) crammed into an ungenerous land area the size of Montana. There is no room for error or internal bickering. If a leader makes an error, he commits the modern equivalent of hara-kiri by retiring in disgrace. Eleven-year-olds have been known to commit suicide for failing to earn the expected grade. By the same token, a Japanese worker in an auto plant, guaranteed lifetime employment, owes his or her life to the company and is expected, like an American athlete or ballerina, to go on with the show no matter the pain or the price.
In this spirit of so-called community, Japanese management preaches consensus, a word that means different, almost opposite, things to Americans and Japanese. Here, it means an agreement reached among peers, even if the boss is recognized as primus inter pares. In Japan, language and custom preclude any such egalitarianism. Every pronoun carries an explicit declaration of where the speaker stands on the social scale in relation to the person who is being addressed; every greeting is confirmed with bows whose depths indicate the rank of the parties. In the Japanese family called the company, the boss is Papa.
Although both books are in-depth examinations of Japanese transplants in the United States, they are not looking at the same phenomenon. Mr. Gelsanliter describes three transplants that were set up in carefully selected areas where, in the opinion of the Japanese companies, the culture was most compatible with that of Japan. They chose regions of high unemployment in Tennessee, Kentucky and southern Ohio, where they could find a heavy proportion of youngsters of Germanic stock who, after repeated and penetrating interviews, revealed an antiunion bias. When the United Automobile Workers union tried to organize Nissan's plant in Smyrna, Tenn., a year ago it was trounced.
The Fucinis, who have written two previous books, ''Experience, Inc.'' and ''Entrepreneurs,'' zero in on the Mazda plant in Michigan, a highly union-minded state. Mazda was organized top-down: Mazda allowed the union to organize the plant under pressure from Ford, which had agreed to distribute the Mazda-produced Probe models, and was under contract with the U.A.W. The kind of workers at Mazda were, of course, quite different from those in what Mr. Gelsanliter calls ''the heartland.'' In a later plant election, they opted for a different union leadership, one that was part of the more militant New Directions movement in the U.A.W.
Taken together, the two books pose an ancient question: Can a dominant or ''conquering'' nation impose its culture on those it dominates? Mr. Gelsanliter suggests yes, if the Japanese relocate outside Detroit. The Fucinis suggest no, although, they suggest, through the confrontation of attitudes there may emerge a third culture.
Both may be right: Mr. Gelsanliter in the short run and the Fucinis in the long run. Because of the contrapuntal dissonance between these books, the wealth of information and insights contained in each is more than doubled when the two are read in tandem.
 
WHERE'S YOUR BASEBALL CAP?
Japanese and Americans had very different ideas about the degree of loyalty and obedience a company should expect from its employees. . . . Mazda issued its American employees company baseball caps, with the understanding that the caps were a voluntary accessory to the mandatory blue-pants-khaki-shirt Mazda uniform. Taking the term voluntary to mean that they had a choice whether or not to wear the caps, many Americans elected to come to work bareheaded. This upset the Japanese, who regarded not wearing caps as a sign of disrespect toward the company. When the Japanese pressed the issue, the Americans countered that cap wearing was voluntary. True, the Japanese acknowledged, but if you really cared about the company you should want to wear your caps. The Americans, who could accept being told what they had to do by an employer, took offense at being told what they should ''want'' to do. As far as they were concerned, Mazda had overstepped its boundaries by trying to force them to do something that was supposed to be voluntary. Mandatory-voluntary was the term they began to use to describe the company's cap directives.
From ''Working for the Japanese.''

HEADLINE: Death Before Taxes

BYLINE: By KEVIN FLYNN; Kevin Flynn is the co-author, with Gary Gerhardt, of ''The Silent Brotherhood: Inside America's Racist Underground.''

 BODY:

BITTER HARVEST
Gordon Kahl and the Posse Comitatus: Murder in the Heartland.
By James Corcoran.
Illustrated. 274 pp. New York:
Viking. $18.95.
Of the tens of thousands of farmers, ranchers, small business people and rural laborers radicalized by the maelstrom of economic disaster in the 1980's, Gordon Kahl was simply one of a distressingly high number who went for their guns. Unlike most of those people, Kahl went on to kill. The most disturbing aspect of Kahl's one-man war on the United States Government is that he wasn't alone. 
But the death of the 63-year-old tax protester shed light on a rural subculture of extremism, growing like weeds in an already stunted garden. As a result, both the man's background and legacy following his violent explosion in 1983 make it imprudent to regard Gordon Kahl as a lone radical.
In ''Bitter Harvest,'' James Corcoran, a journalism teacher at Simmons College in Boston, provides mainstream America with the first honest appraisal of this heartland patriot-turned-terrorist and the cancer of the human spirit spread by the shadowy Posse Comitatus. Mr. Corcoran's novelistic narrative should frighten readers not because it shows what made Gordon Kahl different, but rather what made him so common.
In society's search for traits that set radicals apart, it overlooks the fact that such people are born and nurtured in our own neighborhoods, at our own dinner tables, often with the best intentions. They come not from aberrant gene pools or abused childhoods. They evolve ever so casually, one step at a time, from a growing sense of disenfranchisement and, ultimately, fear. Those who organize such extremists are often called hate groups. More aptly, they are fear groups.
Gordon Kahl became a man absolutely possessed by fear. A simple farmer and hard-working mechanic, he spent nearly all his life near his father's farm in central North Dakota, except for the meritorious duty he performed as a turret gunner during World War II.
But Kahl was on another journey, one he began during the cold war as an ardent anti-Communist. Fear of Communism fueled his trip through mainstream conservatism (represented by the Mormon Church and the John Birch Society) to a hard right turn onto the slippery slope of extremist religion and politics.
Kahl's last stop was a religion called Christian Identity and a political philosophy embodied in the Posse Comitatus. Christian Identity is an outgrowth of the anti-Semitic 19th-century religious cult called British Israelism, in which northern European Christians were ''identified'' as the literal descendants of the lost tribes of the kingdom of Israel. They were, they claimed, the true people of the covenant.
The Posse Comitatus combined their sense of being chosen with a virulent distrust of the Federal Government, income taxes and any abandonment of self-reliance beyond a dependence on the county sheriff. Its members, including many farmers, stockpiled sophisticated weapons and trained to use them against the Jewish-Masonic ''Synagogue of Satan.''
It was their belief that an enemy cabal actually controlled this chaotic, uncontrollable phenomenon called American society. Mr. Corcoran shows how even one of the ''good'' characters, the woman who fingers Kahl's last hideout, nearly backs out when she discovers to her horror that her F.B.I. contact is wearing a Masonic ring - proof, to her, of the international plot against white Christians.
Gordon Kahl finally was possessed by the most primal fear, that of losing his own life. He believed that the Government would kill him in prison if he surrendered to the ''New Sanhedrin.''
With the fanaticism of a true believer, Kahl was unbending. He stopped paying income taxes. He served a year at Fort Leavenworth and ostracized his wife when she paid off a tax lien behind his back. He refused to mail his probation reports after his release. And finally, he shot and killed two United States marshals who tried to serve him with a misdemeanor warrant for his probation violation.
Extremists like Gordon Kahl are not hooligans who simply latch onto a convenient ideology to justify their actions. They really do believe their lives are threatened, and are compelled to act out of those fears.
Mr. Corcoran analyzes the agrarian anarchy that gripped the Midwest in the last decade. His dispassionately reasoned presentation is nevertheless laced with the powerful emotions of those pulled into the whirlpool of failure. The author, whose roots are in North Dakota, refines the statistics, studies and excuses into portraits with personal impact.
The author shows the Federal Government in relentless pursuit of a tax resister who rarely made $10,000 a year - and only after he appeared on a television talk show to advocate tax resistance. As a result the radical right gained a martyr who has helped inspire others to violence. In 1984, Arthur Kirk, a Nebraska farmer whose land was in foreclosure, charged at a state patrol SWAT team with an assault rifle after threatening to shoot a warrant bearer; he was killed. That same year Robert Matthews formed a terrorist underground and carried out the assassination of the Jewish radio personality Alan Berg in Denver, before he too was killed.
There is a distressing lack of popular literature on radicalism of the right. The circumstances surrounding the principal event in ''Bitter Harvest'' show precisely the lack of understanding - on the part of both authorities and the public - of the causes, the effect and the dangerous potential of the farm crisis. For every Gordon Kahl, Arthur Kirk and Robert Matthews who picks up a gun, there are hundreds of other disenfranchised people in this loosely bound movement who probably never will. It should not fill us with relief, however, simply to stop frustrated people short of violence. Fighting an army of a thousand men is easier than fighting a thousand one-man wars.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1932 words

HEADLINE: And Now, Doctorates in Development

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Sarit Rozycki is one of a handful of young New York City developers who have been bidding up prices for prime midtown Manhattan real estate parcels recently. In her case the goal is to put up a 50-story office tower with retail space that she expects to become the first American home of Harrod's, London's swank department store.
Ms. Rozycki is not concerned that commercial development is soft in Manhattan, or that department stores have been struggling.
''That's all right,'' she said. ''They're going to do great. We're optimists.'' 
And why not? Her giant project lives only in a thick project book she is preparing as a final project for her master's degree in real estate development at New York University. Hence the flurry of similar big paper land purchases in the city, at the midblock of 47th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, where Tom Glasgow is building a 300,000-square-foot mixed-use tower, and on the east side of Union Square, right on top of the Amalgamated Bank building, where Gil Shalit wants to put a 25-story apartment house.
These young graduate students are part of a growing phenomenon in the country's evolving real estate business - the graduate student of real estate development. What used to be something young master-builders learned on the job from the Zeckendorfs or the Tishmans - a profession, in other words, that was half on-the-job training and half whom you know - now involves master's and even Ph.D. programs from New York to Berkeley, Calif., from the University of Wisconsin to Texas A. & M. Columbia University has two graduate real estate programs, in fact, one in its architecture school and the other in its business school.
Enrollments in these one- and two-year masters' degree programs have remained strong - 30 to 50 students, depending on the school - despite the downturn in development activity in many parts of the country. Or perhaps enrollments have held steady because of the downturn: with development jobs scarcer, students give up less income to drop out of the work force and put themselves back in school for a while.
''This is a good time to be out of the real estate business,'' said Lawrence S. Bacow, head of the M.I.T. Center for Real Estate Development.
These are not the ''How to Sell Real Estate'' courses that community colleges teach aspiring brokers and sales associates. The new graduate programs, most of them having assumed their current form in the last 5 to 10 years, seek to combine the disparate elements of real estate development, from design to real estate law, appraisal to site selection, that have traditionally been scattered among a number of different and often competing graduate programs.
''About 1982, we started thinking about this big sector of the economy that had been largely ignored by the academy, and it was called real estate,'' said Dr. Bacow.
''We recognized that M.I.T. was teaching people to deal with the separate properties of real estate, we were training architects to become the clients of developers, civil engineers to be construction managers, the planning department was training planners - we were working all around the edges but nobody was focusing directly on the center.'' At the same time, other graduate real estate professors noted, the real estate industry was passing from the private men's club it had so long been known as, and was becoming institutionalized in the widening ring of businesses that specialize in aspects of the trade.
Banks, pensions and insurance funds are adding real estate specialists to their stables of accountants and lawyers; real estate financing syndications now routinely cross borders, so that a failed shopping center in Austin, Tex., is probably crimping some investor's dividends in Basel, Switzerland.
Graduates of the real estate programs are therefore being hired by concerns that 10 or 20 years ago had little to do with the nuts and bolts of real estate development - pension funds, investment banks, insurers. Manufacturers and other corporations whose principal business may have nothing to do with real estate have in the past found that they were failing to take full advantage of assets they had accumulated in land and buildings.
Now there is a National Association of Corporate Real Estate Executives to testify to the number of men and women who have been hired just to handle those assets.
''The real estate business has become highly institutionalized,'' said Robert Zerbst, a Ph.D. graduate of Ohio State University's Center for Real Estate Education and Research, who has turned theory to profit as owner of Piedmont Realty Advisors, a San Francisco consulting firm.
M.I.T., among other schools, has made a minor specialty in its program of training future public officials to manage the public end of joint ventures between municipalities and private developers. Other schools emphasize the analytical over the speculative, the public benefit over private gain.
''A far smaller percentage of the real estate in the U.S. is now owned by single individuals than it was before, while a much higher percentage is owned by institutions,'' Mr. Zerbst said. ''And by the Federal Government, for better or worse.''
But underlying the new real estate curriculums run the old themes and dreams of real estate development as one way for a young person to make a lot of money in a hurry.
''Uh, Donald Trump,'' said Dan Brenna of the N.Y.U. program when asked his name.
But seriously: ''I know I don't want to work for someone else all my life, to be a wheel in a machine,'' said Mr. Brenna, a recent Rensellaer Polytechnic Institute engineering graduate. ''This way, I think I can get a job with a developer and after a while, start working for myself.'' ''Absolutely,'' Miss Rozycki agreed. Like many graduate real estate schools, N.Y.U. requires its master's students to have some experience in the world before they enroll, and of a group of students recently interviewed only Mr. Brenna had come straight from college, although he believes his engineering degree amounts to some pre-enrollment experience in a key aspect of real estate development.
For her part, Miss Rozycki is in fact a developer, having been in a partnership that renovates apartment buildings in Manhattan.
''But I want to go on to the next level,'' she said, ''and this program is going to make me more knowledgeable and more confident when I go to put together deals. I mean, one of the things we're working on is specifically, how to go to a bank and get the loan.''
That course, like all the others at N.Y.U. and at most real estate programs, is taught by adjunct professors with full-time construction, development, law and finance jobs.
Dr. Robert Bjorklund, an associate professor of real estate and director of academic affairs for the Master of Science in Real Estate program at N.Y.U.'s Real Estate Institute, has a brokerage and development partnership in New Jersey; he believes that teachers with real experience are far more valuable to young real estate tyros than the textbook approach to business analysis favored by traditional business schools.
''Anybody can crunch numbers and come up with an internal rate of return, but the M.B.A.'s never get to learn real market analysis, site selection and that kind of thing,'' he said. ''The course work was always, 'Let's assume 5 percent increase in rents and 3 percent increase in maintenance expenses . . . ' and it was all garbage in, garbage out. What investors and developers are really trying to figure out is, what are future costs going to be, and if you misforecast the numbers you have a very small chance of getting it right.''
The emphasis on upper level real estate development at first confuses some students, who come expecting to learn how to be better residential brokers.
''One of the problems with brokerages is that it's basically selling, and a great salesman doesn't need to come to my school to learn how to sell,'' said Norman Weinberg, associate dean of the School of Continuing Education and director of the Real Estate Institute at N.Y.U.
In other words, he said, the degree-granting real estate graduate schools are not going to add to the luster of the ordinary real estate brokers who have long wished that their business would be given the same professional respect and distinction as law and medicine.
Dean Weinberg noted that real estate education grew out of the land-use programs at western colleges - future developers still study high-rise projects next to agriculture students at Texas A. & M. - while in the East, the subject was considered a trade school subject at best. The change came when corporations began seeking graduates with real estate specialties, several program directors noted.
''If you're a corporation and you can choose between a person with a degree and someone without, you take the more highly qualified person,'' said Kenneth Rosen, chairman of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. ''So education in real estate is probably just at the beginning of its professionalization. It started in the last 5 or 10 years, as real estate became integrated into the overall capital markets, which meant that people in the stocks and bond business suddenly need to know about the real estate field.''
Dr. Rosen has no time for young real estate buccaneers on their way to retirement at 35. The emphasis at his school is on the analytical, not the speculative.
''If you're thinking of money, you had better go to Harvard or Wharton,'' he said, referring to the business school at the University of Pennsylvania. ''We don't train people to be C.E.O.'s, we train them to work with organizations.''
The pitfalls of real estate speculation are part of the course curriculum at Texas A. & M., said John Rodiek, a professor in the university's master's program in land development. The course is appropriate, he said, because the wreckage of the state's deflated real estate boom is all around.
''Speculation got this state's people in a lot of trouble,'' he said, ''so we are trying t0 teach our students the backgrounds to decision-making that are central to real estate management.''
As a project, some of the school's 50 degree candidates have begun preparing a thorough assessment of a 78-acre parcel of undeveloped land in San Antonio. The land is owned by the USAA Real Estate Company, a subsidiary of a big military life insurance company, which bought the land as speculation several years ago and is now casting around for something to do with it, Professor Rodiek said.
The students are swarming over the area, he said, studying vegetation, groundwater, city planning, local transportation and housing needs.
''The social values are important in a course like this,'' Professor Rodiek said. ''We want want to build housing on it, but we can't just address ourselves to what the yuppies will want. The Spanish population will increase sharply to 40, 45 percent in the next 15 to 30 years, and someone had better understand what that will mean for local housing.''
Still, he said, some of the students will want to hook their dreams to the next real estate boom to hit the Lone Star State.
''I think that some of them will want to have the same success that Donald Trump had,'' he said, ''but I think a lot of them have come to have a better understanding of what that means. Each student knows that they must take a much more realistic attitude about what it is going to take to be successful.''

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: X-Rated Tenants;
The Sun Is Setting on the Times Square Porn Palaces

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Twilight seems to be near for the gaudy, raunchy, blazingly public pornographic emporiums in and around Times Square, many of which - by a curious circumstance - are now tenants of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
Although there is still a large core of hard-core businesses on Eighth Avenue, their counterparts on Broadway and Seventh Avenue appear close to extinction. The Pussycat Cinema and Melody Burlesk, at Broadway and 49th Street, disappeared in 1986 to make way for the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza. By year's end, the Big Apple Theater, at Broadway and 43d Street, and the Circus Cinema and World Theater, at 49th Street, are all likely to be out of business.
And they may not reappear anywhere else, at least not in the form of large-scale theaters and sex supermarkets. 
''As they leave Times Square, they're really not going anywhere - they're just drying up,'' said Albert Bialek, of Albert Bialek Associates, a broker, real estate consultant and property manager. ''I don't see them spreading through the city at all. I think they're going out of business. I think they're losing their market. There's no clientele for that type of stuff today.''
William H. Daly, who has directed the city's Office of Midtown Enforcement since 1984, put it rhetorically: ''Would you, as a consumer, prefer to come to Times Square and watch a porno movie and worry about your safety, or would you rather rent one and watch in the comfort and security of your own home? That's had a lot to do with the decline of sex businesses.''
''As the city has closed the number of illegal sex-related businesses and as others have gone because of development or cable TV or home videocassettes,'' Mr. Daly said, ''we have not seen in another part of the city a concomitant rise or a displacement effect.''
Today, of the two dozen or so obvious sex-related businesses that remain in the Times Square area, about half are tenants of the state's development agency, which took the properties by condemnation in April to prepare for the redevelopment of 42d Street.
What makes the situation noteworthy is that these are exactly the kinds of businesses whose image was conjured by officials in the 1980's as they sought to build a consensus for the redevelopment effort.
''The project is expected to substantially eliminate the dangerous and threatening street conditions and the sex-related uses that now pervade the area,'' said the draft environmental impact statement in 1984.
One of the largest state tenants is the Big Apple, whose marquee recently advertised this quadruple bill: ''Sex Girls,'' ''Magic Shower,'' ''Virgin Heat'' and ''Love Shack.'' Another is Peepland, 228 West 42d Street, whose facade is distinguished by a two-story keyhole framing a giant neon eye. Among its many offerings, to gauge from the signs in the window, are ''Live Nude Girls.''
The state has at least nine other tenants that it describes as ''blight-related'': Adult Video World Bookstore, Blackjack Book Store, Forsythe Book Store, Le Sex Shoppe, Peep Show, Playland, Roxy Three Theater, X-Rated Video and XXX Video Store.
No one at the Urban Development Corporation knows how much rent these tenants owe because many of them are simply refusing to pay, according to Lawrence Josephs, director of public affairs for the agency. Eventually, he said, when the state figures out how much rent is due, that amount would be deducted from any condemnation awards.
The state has no plans to evict any of these tenants or otherwise move against them until the time comes for site preparation and demolition. The first phase, to clear the way for two of the four office skyscrapers planned by the developer George Klein and the Prudential Insurance Company, will close the Big Apple by Oct. 31. Other tenants, particularly in the mid-block properties along 42d Street, might remain until early 1991.
''This project has always made a big point that it is not antismut,'' Mr. Josephs said. ''That has to do with First Amendment considerations.''
''Yes, we have these sex uses,'' he said, ''but we don't consider them - from an operational point of view - to be separate. We consider all 11 tenants to be blighting uses but we don't really have a mechanism for treating anybody differently than anybody else.''
''They contribute to an overall feeling of lawlessness,'' Mr. Josephs said, ''to the feeling that maybe the rules don't apply in this area and that you can get away with whatever you want. But these particular establishments are not where crimes are occurring on a regular and ongoing basis.''
His assertion was borne out by Mr. Daly. ''We've never really seen any direct correlation between these businesses and crime,'' he said. ''The only aspect where the sex business created criminal conditions was about 10 years ago when you had street-level massage parlors along Eighth Avenue.''
Mr. Daly said the city was not out to close sex-related businesses except when they are clearly fronts for prostitution or drug dealing. Some arrests were made at Peepland in the past, he said, because the glass partitions had been removed in the viewing booths, allowing patrons to touch the women who were performing. But he said that the courts determined this did not amount to prostitution and had dismissed the cases.
The other remaining theaters on Broadway, the Circus Cinema (''The Best Porn in New York - A Triumph of Erotica'') and World Theater (''100% Porn Spectacular!''), which share a three-story structure at the corner of 49th Street, are to be gone by the end of the year.
They will be replaced by a 27-story, 324-room Hampton Inn hotel, developed by affiliates of the Spire Realty and Development Corporation of Melville, L.I., and McCann Project Management Services Corporation of Manhattan.
To keep land costs down, and thus preserve a $90-a-night room rate, the parcel is being leased for 99 years, rather than bought outright, said Edward Lapidus, president of Spira. The owner is Arthur Morowitz.
As for the changing use at that site, Mr. Lapidus said, ''As you stand on the corner of 49th, Seventh and Broadway, it's like watching the actual metamorphosis of the caterpillar into the butterfly.''
As recently as 1984, the draft environmental impact statement for the 42d Street project predicted that upper Times Square ''will be the preferred relocation area for the sex businesses,'' which ''could have a significant adverse impact.'' However, by the time the state finally took title to its land, the area to the north had already been redeveloped with office towers and hotels.
Instead of moving northward, the business has dispersed. ''Over the past six or eight months,'' Mr. Daly said, ''what has developed is a rash of openings of videocassette outlets where they sell primarily tapes for home use.'' Last year, stores opened on the Avenue of the Americas, in Chelsea and Greenwich Village, and along Canal Street. Vociferous protesters included a group called No Times Square in Greenwich Village.
Since then, one store in the Village has closed. Judith Joice, president of the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, said that the facade of a store at the Avenue of the Americas and Fourth Street had become ''somewhat more palatable,'' because ''instead of six-foot neon X's, they have a mural done by local artists which is very neutral.''
''I do believe we had some effect by having protests and getting petitions signed,'' she said. ''I'm not against pornography. It was the nature of the stores themselves. They were definitely 42d Street. It not only devalued property but made the neighborhood unsuitable for children to grow up in. I do think we stopped it by acting loudly and quickly. I'm not going to have my tongue cut out by the First Amendment that protects everyone except me.''

HEADLINE: Talking: Docks;
Ebb Tide In Market For Slips

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Dockominium sales lie dead in the water. Echoing the direction of the real estate market in general, demand has all but dried up for these slips, some of which had been selling as high as $2,000 a linear foot in the New York area only 18 months ago.
The Northeast - in particular the New Jersey shore - seems hardest hit, with slips of 35 feet and less suffering more than larger ones and marginal locations faring far worse than prime ones, according to professionals in the marina industry. Only the emerging markets of the Great Lakes and the inland waterways of the South, like those along the Tennessee River, appear to be holding their own, they report. 
A conceptual cousin to a residential condominium, a dockominium is a boat slip in a marina in which slips are individually purchased rather than rented from the marina operator. Ownership may take three forms - a deed, shares or a long-term lease. Monthly maintenance fees are charged to cover ongoing costs with day-to-day operations placed in the hands of a professional manager.
The phenomenon first emerged on the West Coast in the late 70's. It reached the East Coast in the early 80's in time to ride the crest of a boating boom that left aspiring yachtsmen frantic that they would no longer be able to afford to dock that boat if they failed to purchase rather than rent a slip.
Rental rates were rising by about 25 percent a year and waiting lists growing ever longer. Not surprisingly, early buyers doubled their money within three seasons while investors eagerly came aboard because even greater appreciation seemed as predictable as the next high tide.
But Donald Trump has not been the only one forced to cut back on sailing. A weakening economy plus rising costs has lowered the boom on a great many other people too. ''And one of the first things to go has been that boat,'' said Stephen Smith, an expert on waterfront development with Edward F. Heberger & Associates, real estate appraisers of Cheshire, Conn. The result is a cooling of the demand for slips.
The drop in demand, he said, came in tandem with the arrival of dozens of new dockominium projects. The combination has now ''blown the market apart,'' said Paul Dodson, executive vice president of the International Marina Institute, a research and educational center in Wickford, R.I.
Mr. Dodson gave as an example a 40-foot slip in Newport Harbor, R.I, that would have sold in 1988 for around $85,000, but would have barely fetched $50,000 at auction earlier this summer. Similarly, in Boston Harbor, he noted, the recent addition of 700 new slips has created a vacancy rate of 25 percent.
Artemas H. Crimmins Jr., manager and developer of Minneford Marina and Yacht Club on City Island in the Bronx, said he is selling his remaining 30 slips for around $1,500 a linear foot compared to $2,000 two years ago. And even these prices can be discounted, he said, if someone is willing to purchase a boat along with the slip. Prices are more difficult to establish on resales because ''nothing is trading,'' he confirmed.
If you own a slip, these experts say, do not try to unload it now out of a fear that the market will sink even lower. Rather, they say, it is wiser to find someone to rent the space temporarily to help cover carrying costs.
''You should hold on as long as you possibly can,'' said Mr. Smith, the appraiser.
Several underlying factors point to this strategy. Mr. Dodson noted that the market is so weak that hardly any new dockominium projects are being planned - at least in the Northeast, which is suffering the deepest dip in sales and values. Moreover, they say, lenders have grown reluctant to release construction financing for dockominiums. Thus, should the economy perk up, a shortage may quickly redevelop.
Dwight Merriam of Hartford, who is general counsel to the Connecticut Marine Trades Association, noted that the amount of shorefront that could support additional boat slips is rapidly diminishing.
With the growth in environmental awareness it will be far more difficult in the future, he predicts, to obtain the needed approvals to set aside many more.
''And you can't stack one dockominium on top of another like you can a condo,'' he said. ''It's a low-density project.'' Mr. Merriam is so sure of the inherent value of dockominiums that he is buying one for himself this summer on Long Island Sound. ''I have tremendous faith in the concept over the long run,'' he said.
But how to survive in the interim? To find a renter, Mr. Merriam recommends dropping the rent, since some income is better than none. Further, he suggested offering to rent by the month instead of for an entire season, as has been traditional.
His other suggestions include advertising a year-round rental or a winter rental if the marina has such a capability. It has become so costly and such a hassle to have a boat taken out of the water and put back again in the spring, he noted, that a year-round slip is sometimes preferred.
He also recommended offering a lease-purchase option which allows someone to put a part or all of the rental fee toward the purchase price at some future date. Mr. Crimmins is offering this deal, for example, at the Minneford Marina. Finally, as at Minneford, the boat and the slip could be structured as an all-in-one deal.
Those who do sell may find it necessary to offer help with financing. ''Everyone who is selling is taking back paper,'' said the owner of a 38-foot slip on City Island, who preferred anonymity. She said she sold her boat a month ago and is now trying to sell the slip. She will be satisfied, she said, if she gets back the $47,000 she originally invested.
If the intended buyer is a homeowner the most useful form of financing would be an equity loan. ''Quite a lot of our buyers are using them,'' said Philip Wallach, owner of the Guilford Yacht Club in Guilford, Conn. He is aggressively marketing his slips - 193 in all when constructed is completed, 80 of which have been sold - through direct mail campaigns, advertising and boat show appearances.
For the individual seeking a resale he recommends placing classified ads in area newspapers in addition to listing that slip with boat brokers, who normally charge 10 percent should they find the buyer. Those are the two places where anyone who is seriously interested will look, said Mr. Wallach.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Rental Co-op Up for Sale
 
Question: I rent a co-op apartment that the owner is about to sell. If the co-op board approves the new owner, it looks as if he will occupy the apartment. If this is the case, is there any way I can maintain our rental position past the term of the lease? . . . D. H., Manhattan
 
Answer: It would depend on the kind of lease you have. If you are a rent-regulated tenant whose lease predates the conversion of the building to a co-op, you would have the right to remain as long as you continue to qualify as a rent-regulated tenant. 
If, on the other hand, you rented after the conversion or from the owner then you probably would not be entitled to a renewal. According to David L. Smith, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, many leases for co-op and condominium apartments include clauses that give the owner the right to terminate the lease upon the sale of the apartment. If there is no such provision the new owner would have to honor the terms of the lease, but would probably not have to offer a new one.
 
Discontinued Intercom
 
Question: A few years ago the intercom buzzers were removed from the apartments in our building, which includes both rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments. In place of the old system, one outside bell was installed connected with the one elevator. There are three elevator operators, each of whom works an eight-hour shift. Sometimes these operators are not available, so visitors are kept waiting in the lobby. Do we have the right to request that the landlord put the intercom back in the apartments? . . . R. R., Kew Gardens, Queens
 
Answer: Probably. According to the rules governing rent-stabilized apartments, landlords cannot arbitrarily change building services.
It is probable that the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal would consider the removal of the intercom such a reduction.
If so, you and your fellow tenants are probably entitled to a rent reduction as compensation if the landlord does not agree to replace it.
However, Lee Hudson, the agency's spokeswoman, said the change in the system may have been done for a legitimate reason, such as improved security.
You should first try to negotiate a return of this service with your landlord. If that does not work, file a complaint with the housing agency. You would use form RA-84, which covers complaints about buildingwide services.
It would not be necessary for each tenant to file a complaint, but it must be signed by someone who wants to be eligible for a rent reduction if it is determined that one is due.
The forms are available in the rent office of each borough. The Queens office is at 92-31 Union Hall Steet, Jamaica.
 
Controlled Unit Sublets
 
Question: I am a statutory tenant in a rent-controlled apartment. I have been told that the rules have changed and that rent-controlled tenants may now sublease their apartments. Is this true? . . . R. M., Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Ms. Hudson, there are still no provisions pertaining to rent-controlled tenants that give them the automatic right to sublet for two years, a right that rent-stabilized tenants have.
There are exceptions, Ms. Hudson said, if the original lease permited subletting or if the landlord permitted subletting in the past, increased the rent as compensation for the sublet and then continued to collect the higher rent after the prime tenant resumed occupancy.
