HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: Providence, R.I.;
Macy's to Open At a New Mall

BYLINE: By Lisa Prevost

 BODY:
Macy's has announced it will open a store in downtown Providence, which has no major department store. It will be an anchor of Providence Place, a $300 million mall, office and hotel project to be built not far from the State House lawn.
R.H. Macy and Company decided to open in Providence because of the size of the potential market, which includes Worcester, Mass., as well as Providence, and the level of competition, said Maureen Burgess, a spokeswoman for Macy's. The Providence store is one of 10 new stores Macy's has planned for the next four years, she said. 
With 250,000 square feet on three levels, the store will be comparable in size to other Macy's stores, except for the huge flagship store in New York City. It will employ about 500 people.
The arrival of Macy's will have a ripple effect, said Lee Juskalian, a real estate broker who is a member of the design review committee of the Capital Center Commission. Providence Place is within a 67-acre downtown redevelopment district called Capital Center.
''People will say, 'If Macy's is looking at Providence, maybe we should look at Providence,' '' Mr. Juskalian said. Bonwit Teller also announced last spring that it would open a Providence Place store.
Providence Place has had something of a tumultuous history, as partners in the project have come and gone. The current joint venture partnership was formed by Conroy Development Company of White Plains and the Pyramid Companies of Boston. Pyramid is co-owner of the Emerald Square mall in North Attleboro, Mass., about 15 minutes outside of Providence. The developers have hired John Sasso, a business consultant and former aide to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, to get permits and approvals.
The architect for the project is Adrian Smith, a partner in the Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, who designed Boston's Rowes Wharf.
The 1.4 million-square-foot project will sit on a state-owned 14-acre site immediately off Interstate 95; a continuing education division of the University of Rhode Island will have to relocate to accommodate the project. In addition to the 900,000-square-foot retail mall, the project is expected to include a 275,000-square-foot office building and a 325-room luxury hotel. An enclosed parking garage will hold 5,500 cars.
Though the Rhode Island economy is in the grip of a regional downturn, Ms. Burgess said, Macy's is undaunted. ''That doesn't mean you stand still,'' she said. ''It means that you plan a little bit more conservatively.''

LENGTH: 1781 words

HEADLINE: Agencies and Colleges Showing Effects Of Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By Jay Romano

 BODY:
IN the state's public colleges, tuition will be higher. At Division of Motor Vehicles offices, lines will be longer. And on state highways, potholes will deepen before they are filled, more litter will accumulate before it is removed, and more time will pass before the deer accidentally killed by a truck or a car disappears from the side of the road.
These are a sampling of what state and local officials say will result from the budget cuts that accompanied Gov. Jim Florio's sales and income tax increase.
Officials of state agencies and administrators of public colleges and professional schools say the budget cuts will cause layoffs, tuition increases, deferred maintenance of buildings and equipment and curtailment or elimination of some services. 
Administration officials, who have termed the budget ''austere,'' say the reductions are necessary to minimize the tax increase needed to close the budget gap left over from the Kean administration. Though the effects may be harsh, they say, the long-term results will be a permanently balanced budget and a stronger state economy.
 
Critics' Opinions Vary
Critics have widely varying opinions. School officials and administrators of state agencies say that the budget reductions were large and that their effect will be both far reaching and long lasting. But some Republican legislators say that even more could have been trimmed from the $12.4 billion budget to avert the record tax increase.
Still other critics say that some of the cuts only shift financial responsibility from the state to the counties and municipalities and that in the long run taxpayers will pay more for some services than they do now.
The controversy, which has intensified as a result of a strong grass-roots antitax campaign, has become the focus of national attention as Democratic and Republican leaders wait to see whether Mr. Florio can weather the political storm that has resulted from his tax increase. Mr. Florio said last week that he would address residents on television on Wednesday at 8 P.M. to explain the effects and expected benefits of his tax program.
 
'All Across the Board'
''We are going to have a reduction in service all across the board,'' said H. Arthur Smith 3d, spokesman for the State Division of Motor Vehicles. The division's budget, he said, was cut by about $10 million, more than half of which was being used for overtime pay to maintain expanded hours at motor vehicle offices.
As a result, he said, the division has had to discontinue its policy of opening on Saturdays and staying open on weekdays until the last customer is served. And that, he said, will mean longer waits at motor vehicle offices across the state.
Gene L. Farrell, shop steward for the employees at the division's Regional Service Center in Wayne, said that when the center was open on Saturday, the average waiting time during the week was 20 minutes.
''Now we have two hours' worth of customers waiting outside before we even open the doors,'' he said.
Another hard-hit agency is the State Department of Transportation, which received $36 million less this year than last year. Barbara Richardson, a department spokeswoman, said that some services would have to be cut back and that a hiring freeze would be imposed on the department's 5,489-member work force.
''But the biggest impact will be on the road materials budget,'' Ms. Richardson said. That appropriation was cut by 20 percent, she said, and the effect will be noticeable in road repair, snow removal, line striping and sign replacement.
The Department of Transportation budget includes the state's appropriation for N. J. Transit, which carries some 300,000 bus and train riders daily.
Although the $218 million appropriation is the same as last year's, growing operating costs and falling fare receipts have left the agency with a $47.8 million shortfall. As a result, some train services have been cut and 200 jobs will be eliminated through retirement, attrition and perhaps layoffs.
In addition, said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for the agency, ''a lot of internal cuts that won't be readily apparent to the customer will be made.''
But one effect that is readily apparent is the 9 percent fare increase that went into effect with the new budget on July 1.
 
'We Really Had No Alternative'
''We really had no alternative,'' Mr. Lamm said. ''There are only three places we can turn to for funding: the Federal Government, the state government and the fare box.''
The state's higher education system will also have to charge more, experts say, because of a $107 million reduction in grants and state aid to colleges, universities and professional schools.
''For us, the cut was substantial,'' said Donald B. Edwards, vice president for public affairs and development at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. A decrease of $26 million in state aid together with unavoidable cost increases, he said, ''put us in a $35 million hole.''
As a result, Mr. Edwards said, university officials are deferring all but the most essential maintenance and repairs, have laid off several employees and have placed a job freeze on most open teaching positions. For those positions that must be filled, he said, part-time faculty members will be appointed instead of full-time assistant professors.
 
Tuition Up by $280
But even with such measures, he said, students will now pay $280 more for one year of full-time undergraduate study than the $2,576 they did last year, an increase of 10.8 percent.
''We will be able to get through this year by taking some steps that can't be repeated,'' Mr. Edwards said. ''We're trying to make sure that the folks in Trenton understand that.''
State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman said that officials in Trenton indeed understood the difficulties facing Rutgers and the other schools and agencies affected by the budget cuts.
''We had to hold the line,'' Mr. Berman said, ''and that is showing up in part as tuition increases.
''But every department took a 10 to 15 percent management cut except for Corrections and Human Services. We had to cut back on certain public health spending; we had to almost halve the state support for the arts; we've cut back on our ability to support tourism and our agriculture marketing program.''
 
Relief for Middle Class Seen
Yet along with those cuts, Mr. Berman said, the Florio administration is also creating a tax structure that will shift at least some of the rising costs of government away from the middle class.
''We are reducing the state's reliance on the property tax and increasing our reliance on a progressive income tax,'' he said. As a result, he said, there will be a shift in the tax burden from middle-income property-tax payers onto the state's most highly paid residents. But some say the shift may not turn out as expected. Teachers' union officials, for example, say the Governor's budget and school aid package will shift responsibility for some state expenditures on to property-tax payers rather than away from them.
Jerri Antunes, spokeswoman for the 130,000-member New Jersey Education Association, said that in the past, the state contributed approximately $900 million a year to the teachers' pension fund. But under Mr. Florio's school aid package, that contribution will be the responsibility of local school districts.
And though the state is reimbursing municipalities for the added responsibility by increasing state aid, education association officials say that eventually the pension costs will exceed the aid provided, placing a new burden on property-tax payers.
 
'It Will Get Worse and Worse'
''It may be one year, or three years or five years,'' Ms. Antunes said, ''but ultimately most districts will have to pay money. And from there it will get worse, and worse, and worse.''
But Mr. Berman said automatic ''inflator'' increases in the state aid to school districts would enable them to keep pace with the pension costs without increasing property taxes.
''The new school formula imposes spending discipline at the local level,'' Mr. Berman said. In the past, he said, state school aid was often based upon how much a school district spent. ''The more they spent, the more they got,'' he said. The new plan encourages local school boards to economize, he said.
And the budget reductions in other areas of state government, he said, impose that same discipline on department heads in state agencies.
''This budget is harsh,'' Mr. Berman said, ''but fiscal responsibility required some very tough choices.''
 
Budget Cuts Questioned
Some Republican lawmakers, however, say claims that the budget has been cut are inaccurate.
''This is typical, hypocritical, political nonsense,'' said State Senator Lee B. Laskin, Republican of Cherry Hill. ''When you cut through the maze of hogwash,'' he said, ''the budget is the same as last year except that we have more taxes.''
Cuts should have been deep enough to eliminate the need for a tax increase completely, he said.
''No matter who it hurts and no matter how hard it hurts,'' Mr. Laskin said, ''some cuts in services are necessary. The people in this state cannot afford to pay more taxes.''
Both critics and supporters of the budget agree that budget cuts are always difficult to make and that any reduction, large or small, has some impact.
 
Deer Recovery Program Eliminated
Many point to the elimination of the state's Deer Recovery Program as a striking example of how withdrawal of even a small amount of money can have an unexpected effect.
In past years, the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife assumed responsiblity for removing deer that had been accidentally killed on the roads. This year, the $145,000 previously appropriated for the program was eliminated.
''Last year the state picked up 1,320 deer on the roads in Hunterdon County,'' said John P. Glynn, the county's director of roads and bridges. ''They have advised us that they will no longer be doing that.''
As a result, Mr. Glynn said, the county obtained estimates from private contractors to remove and dispose of the deer. The estimates ranged from $50 to $75 an animal. The county, which had not anticipated such an expenditure in its current budget, chose another alternative. ''In most cases they haven't been picked up,'' Mr. Glynn said. County road crews move the dead animal off the roadway, he said, and leave it in the grass or brush on the side of the road. They then sprinkle lime on the carcass to prevent odor and to hasten decomposition.
''The Health Department has said that it's not a health hazard,'' Mr. Glynn said. ''I'd say it's more of a nuisance.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; People waiting, above, at the Motor Vehicles Division offices in Wayne. At Douglass College in New Brunswick, maintenance workers repaired dormitory roof. State officials say that because of budget cuts there will be longer lines at motor vehicle offices and maintenance of buildings will be deferred (Photographs by Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Living Cells Enter Commerce; Now, Who Has a Claim to Profits?

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
THE biotechnology industry welcomed the California Supreme Court ruling last month that a man was not entitled to share in the profits from a drug developed from tissues removed from his body. But the case raised questions about the property status of tissues, genes and other biological materials, issues that are not likely to go away.
Should people be paid for organs when they are used in transplants? Should women be paid for aborted fetal tissue, which might one day be used to cure Parkinson's disease and other ailments? Should a country be paid if a plant specimen taken from its jungle produces a cancer drug?
So far, the answers have largely been no. Organs, tissues and plants have mostly been used by researchers without obligation. The 1984 National Organ Transplant Act prohibits the sale of organs, and society has recoiled in distaste at the prospect of any commerce in aborted fetal tissues. People are sometimes paid for donating blood or semen, but the payment is described as being for providing a service rather than for the material itself. 
Yet tissues and genes represent the raw materials of the biotechnology industry. As medical and genetic advances improve the capability to make use of such matter, its value continues to rise.
''We have to change the way we think about genetic information,'' said Jack R. Kloppenburg Jr., assistant professor of rural sociology at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and author of ''First the Seed: The Political Economy of Plant Biotechnology'' (Cambridge University Press, 1988). ''It is in a sense like oil or like copper.''
The California case involved John Moore, whose spleen was removed as part of treatment for his leukemia. David W. Golde, his doctor at the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles, grew some cells in a culture from the spleen and found them rich in certain immune-system chemicals that were being studied for use as drugs.
U.C.L.A. patented the resulting cell line, a culture capable of reproducing indefinitely, and negotiated an agreement with Genetics Institute, a biotechnology company, to use the cells in developing a drug known as granulocyte macrophage colony stimulating factor. For $750, Genetics Institute, in Cambridge, Mass., provided Dr. Golde with stock that was eventually worth $3 million, according to the lawsuit. The company and Sandoz Pharmaceutical Company, which joined the venture, also gave U.C.L.A. about $440,000 in research grants.
Mr. Moore claimed that he was entitled to a share of the profits. While the court rejected the claim, it held that a patient must be fully informed of a doctor's economic interest in his tissues and that Mr. Moore can sue his doctor for failure to do so.
With regard to plants, the concept of property rights seems to be slowly gaining ground. For years, wild plants and seeds have been collected freely by researchers and crossbred with crops. A Turkish wheat variety helps give stripe-rust resistance to America's wheat crop at an estimated saving of $50 million yearly. An Ethiopian gene helps protect the barley crop from yellow dwarf disease, according to Mr. Kloppenburg, at a saving of $150 million a year.
Plant substances have also been the ingredients or inspiration for more than one-quarter of modern drugs, said Michael J. Balick, director of the Institute of Economic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden. The National Cancer Institute collects thousands of plant samples each year from Asia, Africa and Latin America in its search for new cancer drugs.
The countries from which such plants are obtained have rarely been compensated, since the specimens have been treated as the common heritage of mankind and have been exchanged without charge.
Some nations, however, are beginning to restrict access to wildlife samples or to demand compensation for their genetic resources as they do for mineral resources. Many of these nations, like Madagascar and Brazil, are in the tropics and are rich genetically but poor economically.
Some of the collectors are agreeing to provide compensation. The National Cancer Institute, for instance, is developing policies for paying royalties to countries where plant specimens have yielded valuable drugs. It has also brought scientists from those countries to the United States for visits or to collaborate.
Those advocating compensation say it is somewhat of a contradiction that companies can patent and sell the drugs, seeds and even genetically altered forms of life they make using the raw materials, and yet see no need to pay those who provide the ingredients. Why should Mr. Moore be barred from staking a claim to his cells when his doctor was free to do so?
But those opposing ownership rights argue that cells from Mr. Moore's spleen, transplantable organs, or even plant genes found in the wilds of third world countries have little value by themselves. ''Those folks who happen to live there didn't do anything to develop that material into something useful -it simply grows,'' said Richard D. Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, a trade group in Washington.
Technology offers the means of transforming the raw material into something useful, he said, so people who apply the technology should be awarded with property rights. Paying patients for their tissues would not do any public good and could have a chilling effect on research benefiting humanity, Mr. Godown said. ''The patient gives up something that is of no earthly value to him on the chance that something valuable for society will be produced,'' he said.
Yet paying sources could, in some cases, have some public benefit. If tropical countries received compensation they might do a better job of preserving their forests, said Dr. Balick of the New York Botanical Garden. Some people also argue that if people were paid for their organs, more organs would become available for transplant, alleviating a serious continuing shortage. Henry Hansmann, a professor at Yale Law School, has proposed a futures market in which people would be given a discount on their insurance if they agreed to turn their organs over to the insurer after death. While people can't sell organs, they do have some semblance of property rights, said James F. Blumstein, a professor at Vanderbilt Law School. The Uniform Anatomical Gift Act adopted by all states already gives patients the right to determine whether they will donate organs after they die and to specify the recipient -institution or person.
Last year, 13,384 organ transplants were performed. The creation of a market to supply this demand, however, raises other difficult questions. People worry that rich patients would outbid poor ones for organs or that poor people would be sources of spare body parts for the rich. Prohibiting the sale of the body or its parts is ''one of the ways you show special respect for the body,'' said Arthur L. Caplan, a bio-ethicist at the University of Minnesota.
Some people argue that the supply can best be increased by further limiting people's control over their organs. For the common good, organ donation could be made mandatory upon death, they say, or people could no longer be allowed to specify where their organs should go. Not surprisingly, these approaches raise even more ethical questions.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Hard Thing About Cutting Infant Mortality Is Educating Mothers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A PANEL of Bush Administration officials who investigated infant mortality recommended 18 steps to reduce infant deaths in the United States. Half the recommendations were marked ''high priority'' because they could have a ''direct and immediate effect.''
But the proposals, like the panel's draft report, have been in limbo for several months. The fate of the project is puzzling because its recommendations are relatively modest and seem well suited to an Administration that says it is eager to attack social problems but unable to finance big new programs. 
''Infant death and disability are not intractable problems,'' the report says, echoing studies by the National Academy of Sciences, in 1985, and the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, last February.
A central theme of the report, which was disclosed last week in The New York Times, is that the United States could substantially reduce infant deaths without redistributing income, eradicating poverty or spending billions of dollars. The techniques, by and large, are hardly revolutionary. But to be effective, they must be applied more widely, the White House Task Force on Infant Mortality said.
''If we just delivered routine clinical care and social services to pregnant women, we could prevent one-quarter to one-third of infant mortality,'' Dr. Ezra C. Davidson Jr., president of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, said in an interview. ''We have an extremely difficult, cumbersome, complex, uninviting system of providing health care to pregnant women. Patients have trouble getting into it, and doctors have trouble dealing with it. The frustrations are unbelievable.''
The White House study group noted that the infant mortality rate was higher here than in less affluent countries like Spain and Singapore, where the per capita output of goods and services is less than half that of the United States. It cited Japan as an example of how ''a national commitment and accessible health services'' can sharply reduce infant mortality.
But in their social and economic profiles, these nations differ from the United States. In the more diverse American population, some groups do very well and others very poorly. The mortality rate among babies born to college graduates, for example, is less than half the rate among those born to high-school dropouts. For blacks and whites alike, infant mortality has declined, but the rate for blacks has consistently been about twice that for whites.
By contrast, the infant mortality rate for Hispanic Americans is about the same as the rate for whites, even though poverty is much more common among Hispanic families. In New Mexico, the infant mortality rate is lower for Hispanic people than for non-Hispanic whites.
''Mexican immigrant women benefit from the culture and values and support of an extended family,'' said Antonia Hernandez, president of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. ''When they're pregnant, they receive a lot of nurturing. Pregnancy is seen as a wonderful event, even if it's out of wedlock.''
Government programs can reduce infant mortality, experts say, with just such a nurturing approach, through home visits by nurses, social workers and other counselors. A study last month by the United States General Accounting Office said that home visiting could reduce infant deaths by insuring that pregnant women received prenatal care.
Virginia and South Carolina have reduced infant mortality through use of ''resource mothers,'' who pay frequent visits to the homes of pregnant teen-agers.
Rae K. Grad, executive director of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, established by Congress in 1986, said that ''one out of every three pregnant women gets insufficient prenatal care, meaning that it either begins too late or includes too few visits.''
She cites the armed forces as a model in offering ''universal access to prenatal care.'' Infant mortality among military families is lower than the national average, with no disparity between blacks and whites, she said.
Obviously, it is difficult for government programs to curtail behavior like smoking, drinking and drug abuse, which increase the risk of low birthweight and infant mortality. Drug addicts are unlikely to seek help or to follow medical advice. Dr. Anthony Robbins, a former president of the American Public Health Association, said, ''You have to create a demand for services, for prenatal care, through education and marketing.''
The study group, headed by Dr. James O. Mason, Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, said many women could be reached by volunteers or health care workers paid modest salaries. It also recommended that more high schools offer instruction in ''pregnancy and parenting.''
Diane V. Downing, executive assistant to the New York City Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., said, ''Many women don't realize they need to get prenatal care early in pregnancy.''
Sara Rosenbaum, program director of the Children's Defense Fund, said: ''The great majority of poor women understand the need for prenatal care and actively seek it out, but often have to wait weeks or months to get a doctor's appointment. In some cities, a pregnant woman has to be heroic just to get an appointment at a public clinic.''
Budget cutbacks and the closing of municipal hospitals in some large cities have raised additional barriers to low-income women.
In New York City, Ms. Downing said, poor women may have to wait six weeks to obtain an appointment. In the suburbs of Washington, the wait is often six to 10 weeks. In 16 of Oklahoma's 77 counties, mainly in rural areas, there is no doctor to deliver babies. Nationally, there is a shortage of doctors practicing obstetrics. Several thousand say they have quit because of the cost of malpractice insurance. Some decline to take Medicaid patients, because they find the reimbursement too low or the paperwork and bureaucracy too burdensome.
In its report, drafted in response to a White House request for policy options, the task force recommended ''a nationwide public information campaign'' to combat infant mortality. But the Administration has no intention of disseminating its own findings. The Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services have withheld most of the document from Congress, saying they must ''preserve the confidentiality of the deliberative process'' in the executive branch of Government.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Cambodians Face Loss of Eastern Aid And Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
SOVIET retrenchment and the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, hailed in the West as the opening to a harmonious new post-cold-war world, promises yet another disaster for the people of Cambodia, who have already had their share of ravaging at the hands of external forces.
The Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, installed in 1979 after Vietnam invaded and ended the Khmer Rouge's brutal rule, has depended on aid from what was once a solid, Soviet-led bloc to finance its reconstruction of Cambodia and its intensifying war for survival against Khmer Rouge guerrillas. Cambodia is isolated by the West and still subject to an American-led embargo on investment and trade.
Even today, with socialist ideological solidarity in tatters, aid from the countries of Comecon, the Eastern-bloc trading association, represents an estimated 80 percent of Cambodia's annual budget. 
That is about to change dramatically, even as the Khmer Rouge presses its war of destabilization in the countryside and as Cambodians die in greater numbers. Comecon's five-year plan for aid, trade and investment expires at the end of this year. On Jan. 1, the fantastic world of soft credits, weird barters and transferable rubles will come to an end, and Eastern Europe's trade relationships will be based on market prices and hard currencies.
The Soviet Union and the Eastern European countries want relationships with all countries built on ''mutually beneficial grounds,'' Eastern European diplomats here keep saying. ''Translated,'' one said, ''that means dollar for dollar.''
Can one form such a relationship with Cambodia? ''Ah,'' the diplomat said. ''Of course you cannot.''
The coming aid reductions provide an incentive for Cambodia, and for Vietnam, too, to improve relations with the West. The desire for Western aid adds further pressure to both countries to seek a peaceful settlement to the Cambodian conflict, since the United States has made a settlement a prerequisite to improved relations. The aid factor is one reason Washington is hopeful for the success of its recent shift in Cambodia policy, which involves direct talks with Hanoi and probably Phnom Penh.
For Moscow especially, Cambodia's dependency creates a special responsibility. The Soviets provide the greatest share of Cambodian aid, followed by the East Germans and the Czechs. It financed the 11-year Vietnamese intervention in Cambodia and the client Government that emerged.
But the Soviet Union no longer has the money or, seemingly, the will to project an ideology onto developing countries anywhere. And Moscow is healing its split with China, chief backer of the Khmer Rouge.
''But it's true, there is a question of credibility involved,'' said a Soviet diplomat here. ''There is also a feeling of moral responsibility to help this Government defend itself from the Khmer Rouge.''
So the Soviet Union, he said, would continue to supply the Hun Sen Government with arms so long as other countries, in particular China, continue to supply the Khmer Rouge and the non-Communist factions allied to them. Moscow wants a moratorium on such aid, he said. Cambodian officials complain that the arms supply from Moscow has already been reduced.
Still, arms are almost the least of Cambodia's problems. The Soviet Union provides all of Cambodia's oil and gasoline, for instance, and nearly all of Cambodia's electricity comes from oil-burning generators. A halt in the flow of oil would be a disaster both economically and militarily. Yet it is clear, the Soviet diplomat admitted, that Cambodia cannot pay market prices in hard currency for its oil, let alone its fertilizer.
So what will happen? ''I think we must continue,'' the diplomat said. ''But an agreement has not yet been worked out.'' For the first time, he said, the Soviet Union has a sort of functioning Parliament, with real politics driven by domestic concerns, that will also have a say on foreign policy and aid.
An associated problem is the Soviet Union's request for assistance from the International Monetary Fund. The fund prohibits loan recipients from providing aid to any third country.
An American veto bars the fund itself from helping Cambodia, which will suddenly be faced with an enormous financial squeeze at a time when inflation is high and the economy shaken by war.
Such dire economic factors quite probably were a major topic in recent United States-Soviet discussions on bringing about a settlement in Cambodia. Last month, Washington announced that it was withdrawing diplomatic support from the Khmer Rouge-led opposition and allowing export licenses for humanitarian aid to Phnom Penh. The latter move was an indication that Washington intends to try to help Moscow keep Phnom Penh breathing until a settlement can be fashioned.
The coming unification of Germany poses another problem. Cambodia is one of the few countries where East Germany has an embassy and West Germany does not. The Hun Sen Government, desperate for a breakthrough to the West that might bring replacement aid, is hoping that a united Germany will maintain its embassy here.
But some East European diplomats said it is now almost certain that Germany, afraid of stepping out ahead of the rest of the West, would keep its economic commitments to Cambodia but downgrade its embassy here to a mission only.
Of course, recognition alone, even by hundreds of countries, won't save Mr. Hun Sen from the Khmer Rouge. But these are early days yet, and while the Khmer Rouge fighters are disrupting the countryside, they are not near the gates. A general economic collapse and associated popular panic, however, might bring them there soon enough.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The Big Voices;
A Debate About the Powers At the U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
AS the United Nations Security Council prepared sanctions against Iraq last weekend for invading Kuwait, the epicenter of the drama was not the Council Chamber with its horseshoe table, nor was it even the conference suite reserved for private consultations between the Council's 15 members. The most critical talks occurred in the office of France's avuncular United Nations Representative, Pierre-Louis Blanc, at his mission in 1 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, a five-minute walk away.
Mr. Blanc is currently ''coordinator,'' or chairman, of the five permanent Council members who hold vetoes on decisions. While the United States drafted the initial embargo plan, it needed a green light from the other four - Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union - before they took it to the other 10 members of the council. Those members' seats rotate, and they do not have a veto. 
For most of the last 45 years the Security Council was paralyzed by cold war tensions and most countries found it convenient to forget that the five leaders of the victorious World War II Allies still control this body. Now, as East-West tensions fade and the Council starts to carry out its mandate to preserve peace, many countries are questioning its composition and the way it works.
When its permanent members agree, the Security Council wields awesome powers, allowing it to intervene in a crisis, deploy peacekeeping forces, impose mandatory sanctions and even order armed forces into battle to enforce decisions. ''When it works, it's the only place to be at the United Nations,'' said a Western diplomat.
A permanent seat and a veto on decisions was the price sought by Stalin, Roosevelt and the other big powers for giving the Council such far-reaching authority. Without that veto Stalin would never have joined the United Nations and the United States Senate probably would have kept America out too.
Remembering the failure of the League of Nations and the horrors of the war that followed, the five major victors saw a powerful Security Council as the keystone, alongside the deliberative General Assembly, in a system of collective security that would make another such conflict impossible. Through the Council, they hoped, they could use their armed might to enforce peace and prevent a revival of militarism in Germany and Japan. The veto was invented because all five had to agree before using the big stick; none would tolerate its use against their own interests.
What is surprising, in retrospect, is that other countries also agreed to give such power to a Council on which, for most of the time, they would not even be represented. ''Only the idealism of the immediate post-war explains that,'' says Professor Richard N. Gardner of Columbia University, an authority on the United Nations.
The permanent members' privileges made clearer sense while Britain and France were imperial powers and when the five were the only nuclear powers. But the arrangements have come under question now - especially in the cases of Britain and France, which have lost their empires and have been outstripped by Germany and Japan in economic strength. Meanwhile, the end of colonialsm has created a third-world majority at the United Nations and turned nations like India and Brazil into regional superpowers.
Recasting the Council to better reflect current realities is difficult because the five must agree to changes in the Charter, and many fear that altering the Charter would open a Pandora's box of other demands.
Nevertheless, Japan, which has taken a back seat in world affairs for decades but now seems anxious to translate economic muscle into political influence, has informally proposed the creation of six new permanent Council seats that would not have a veto - for itself, a united Germany, India, Egypt, Nigeria and Brazil. Tokyo refrained from seeking veto powers for them because their claim to a greater voice is based on economic strength and population, not might.
There are, clearly, some stumbling blocks. For one, the plan would increase the already disproportionate representation of Europe. And would Pakistan accept a permanent Indian seat, or Argentina one for Brazil?
For now, in any case, the plan has been put on hold by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who fears that a German demand for a permanent Council seat at the moment of unification would send the wrong message to Europe. But few people at the United Nations doubt it will resurface.
Meanwhile, the five are consolidating their position, establishing themselves as effective mediators in conflicts. It was they who privately worked out the cease-fire agreement for the Iran-Iraq war, and now they are working on a peace plan for Cambodia.
Despite the jealousy their privileges arouse, the countries involved in these conflicts have accepted the five as impartial peacemakers. Like Winston Churchill's famous definition of democracy, the existing Security Council may turn out to be the worst possible mechanism for attempting to safeguard peace, except for all the others.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The Biggest Consumer;
America Is Still Demanding A Full Tank

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
THE threat by Iraq to the economy of the United States is once more demonstrating that the United States is an energy giant of the undesirable kind.
With 2 percent of the world's population and about 4 percent of its oil reserves, this country consumes a quarter of the world's oil. Since it produces only about one-seventh of the world supply, the United States is by far the largest oil importer.
Twice in the last 17 years, supply interruptions have made that fact painfully obvious; twice the Government pledged to trim energy use, but enthusiasm faded and the trend even reversed direction, with some sectors of the economy becoming less energy-efficient in recent years. 
In the Reagan Administration, which relied on the market to dictate changes in consumption, research and development spending was cut and auto efficiency standards reached a plateau. President Bush has taken a supply-side approach, seeking to protect the source of oil by military means.
The prospects for finding more oil here are poor. Richard Morrow, chairman of Amoco and president of the American Petroleum Institute, observed recently that of the roughly 600,000 producing wells in this country, average production is 14 barrels a day. At the current rate of pumping, the United States would be dry before 1998. In contrast, the Middle East's 3,000 producing wells average 3,900 barrels a day each, and the ratio of production to reserves gives some Persian Gulf countries more than a century of pumping at current rates.
All of this leads some to wonder if the United States can't cut demand.
That would certainly seem possible. Americans use nine times as much energy per person as the third world, a level hardly sustainable for the planet as a whole. Edward Renshaw, a researcher at the State University of New York at Albany, observed in a recent study that global oil reserves would last 47 to 88 years at current rates of consumption, but if all people used as much oil as Americans do, known reserves would be exhausted in 8 to 15 years.
The United States also stacks up badly against Japan and Western Europe, using roughly twice as much energy to produce each dollar's worth of goods and services.
The opportunity to conserve presents itself anew each time a new car is driven out of a showroom or a new water heater is installed. Between 1976 and 1986, improvements in water heaters, cars, industrial equipment and other energy-consuming devices cut the ratio of energy use to gross domestic product by 2.8 percent per year. But almost no progress was made in 1987 and 1988. Last year the improvement was about 1.5 percent.
Charles Komanoff, an energy analyst in New York, estimates that if the trend from 1976 to 1986 had persisted, and if half the additional energy thus saved had been oil, American consumption would now be lower by 1.6 million barrels a day - just a little more than Kuwait's OPEC quota.
Some improvement was more or less coincidental. The broadest measure of efficiency, the ratio of energy use to gross domestic product, hides what economists call a ''structural'' change. In the 1970's the United States exported much of its steel industry, which is energy intensive, and replaced it with service industries, which use relatively less energy. According to the Office of Technology Assessment, this switch accounts for one-third of the ''efficiency'' gain since the first oil shock in 1973.
Improvement also slowed because of market forces, according to experts; gasoline was as cheap last month as it was before the first oil shock, when inflation is taken into account, and because cars go 50 percent more miles on a gallon today than they did in 1973 the fuel cost to drive a mile is lower than ever.
One result of the decline in gas prices is that cars in the 1990 model year get mileage that is 4 percent worse than those in the 1988 model year.
Spending more to buy a more fuel efficient car is not a rational economic decision; nor is picking a place to live or work on the basis of how far away it is. ''I don't have any question that energy conservation is a very important thing for the country,'' said Constantine S. Nicandros, the chairman of Conoco, in an interview last week. ''But you can't have cheap prices for fuel and at the same time tell people, 'Don't drive so much.' '' He urges a ''hefty'' gasoline tax, at least 50 cents a gallon - an unusual position for an oil company executive. But he added, ''I don't think there are enough politicians with courage to impose a tax.''
Americans are not alone in their slippage. According to Lee Schipper, an energy expert at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, consumers in Europe and Japan as well as the United States are ''backsliding, using more heat, buying bigger cars and driving in more congested areas.''
Americans are worst, using about 350 gallons of gasoline a person; West Germans use about 150. Dr. Schipper found a variety of reasons: the West Germans not only have more efficient automobiles, but they drive fewer miles and have fewer cars per 1,000 people.
But the ratio of cars to people is rising all over the world, as is industrial demand for oil. According to Cambridge Energy Research Associates, at the turn of the century daily consumption of all commercial fuels, including coal, oil and other sources, was equal in energy value to 11 million barrels of oil. It was 31.5 million barrels in 1950, and in 1988, 162.1 million.
And if the rest of the world demanded energy the way that this country does, even the oil fields of the Persian Gulf would run dry before long.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Excerpts;
Fighting The War of Words Over Kuwait

 BODY:
''Since 1980 when we were at war, we faced circumstances which were as difficult as the war itself because they affected our economy and basic resource, namely, oil. There was confusion in the oil market. There was lack of abidance by OPEC decisions. . . . We say that war is fought with soldiers and harm is done by explosions, killing and coup attempts, but it is also done by economic means sometimes. . . . I say that those who do not mean to wage war on Iraq, that this is in fact a kind of war against Iraq.'' - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, addressing closed session of Arab summit meeting in Baghdad, May 30.
''Iraqis will not forget the saying that cutting necks is better than cutting means of living. . . . O God almighty, be witness that we have warned them. If words fail to protect Iraqis, something effective must be done to return things to their natural course and to return usurped rights to their owners.'' - President Hussein, threatening Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates over oil-production policies, July 17. 
''Your country is being subjected to a barbaric invasion. It is time to defend it.'' - Kuwaiti radio, Aug. 1.
''He won't stop.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to President Bush in Aspen, Colo., Aug. 2.

Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Moscow, Aug. 3.
''After coordination with the leadership of brotherly Iraq, we have agreed together that their brave forces, which came to help their people and brothers, will start withdrawing according to a timetable on Sunday, Aug. 5.'' - Statement attributed by Iraqi news agency to the Kuwaiti radio, Aug. 3.
''With respect to the majority of the Arab world, President Saddam is a patriotic man who believes in his nation and its future and in establishing ties with others based on mutual respect.'' - King Hussein of Jordan, Aug. 4.
''Iraq lied once again. They said they were going to start moving out today, and we have no evidence that they're moving out. . . . This will not stand. This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait.'' - President Bush, to reporters, Aug. 5.

No one, friend or foe, should doubt our desire for peace and no one should underestimate our determination to confront aggression.'' - President Bush, address to the nation after American forces began arriving in Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8.
''You said you would not strike and you struck. And now you are turning to Saudi Arabia and saying, 'I will not strike.' They will not believe you. Do you think they will wait until disaster strikes them, too? . . . You are not accepting the Arab umbrella. Well, you are getting the foreign umbrella. . . . You cannot put me in a bind like this. You cannot commit such a crime and then ask me for the impossible. Don't embarrass me. Just like you have interests, I have interests. I am trying as much as possible to protect Arab honor.'' - President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, address to his country, Aug. 8.

''The choice in front of us is clear - an Arab act that will preserve higher Arab interests and both Iraq and Kuwait, or a foreign intervention in which we will have no say or control.'' - President Mubarak, to a summit meeting of the Arab League, Aug. 10.

Your brothers in Iraq are determined on holy war without hesitation and without any slowing down, and without fear of the forces of the enemies.'' - Statement attributed to President Hussein, read on Iraqi radio, Aug. 10.

LENGTH: 1299 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Split Among Arabs Unleashes a People's Anger

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain

 BODY:
FOR Arabs everywhere, it was a momentous week, one in which long-suppressed antagonisms exploded into anger, military action and recriminations. For the Western powers, it was a week whose benefits and costs are only beginning to be counted.
''Whatever happens after this week - whether Saddam Hussein lives or dies, whether he keeps Kuwait or loses it, he will be remembered as an Arab who stood up to a formidable Western armada gathering to do battle with him,'' said Fawaz Jumayaan, a chemistry professor at the University of Jordan. ''After today nothing will ever be the same again in the Middle East.''
For the first time in contemporary Arab history, one Arab nation invaded another; for the first time since the cold war started in 1945, West and East joined in a gesture of geopolitical unity, opposing the annexation of Kuwait by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. 
Saudi Arabia, that most conservative of Arab nations, made a momentous leap, admitting to itself and the world that in times of real danger it cannot do without American protection. The decision to invite the American army to defend the House of Saud will be with the ruling family for a long time to come.
And the Arab League broke its perennial search for a vacuous consensus with half the 22 members voting, openly and unequivocally, to impose sanctions on Iraq and with some agreeing to send troops to stand with the Saudis against Saddam Hussein. The sum of all this is yet to be known, but that some of it will not be pleasing to the West is already evident.
In the Arab world the veneer of unity has worn even thinner, and deep demarcation lines have been drawn between nations. The oil-plenty countries of the Persian Gulf - the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, in addition to Saudi Arabia - already envied and criticized around the Middle East as selfish, idle and arrogant, have now added the stigma of being ''American puppets,'' in the words of many an Arab commentator.
President Hussein, shrewdly calculating his moves so far, took full advantage of these suppressed anti-gulf sentiments, calling in a Friday speech for the overthrow of all ''oil emirs,'' describing them as infidels who squandered their oil wealth and invited Americans to the gates of Mecca, where lies the holiest of the holy Islamic shrines. Mr. Hussein, who had put a wealth-distribution program into effect, interrupted it to wage the nine-year war on Iran, and now is badly in need of additional revenues to pay $80 billion in debt - $40 billion of it owed to other Arab nations.
The Middle East has now split into a clearly moderate pro-Western camp led by Egypt, with the perhaps temporary participation of Syria, and a fiercely nationalistic anti-Western constellation gathered around Iraq, including most Palestinians and hundreds of thousands of citizens in countries like Jordan, Yemen, Tunisia and Algeria. This radicalism will almost certainly surge anew as the Palestinians make common cause with radical Arab states, led by Iraq.
''The Americans never accepted our right to self-determination,'' said Radawan Abu Ayyash, the head of the Palestinian Writers Association in Jerusalem, explaining why Palestinians are taking a clearly pro-Iraqi position in this conflict, risking a loss of support from Egypt and Saudi Arabia. ''We have to look after our own interests.''
The widely circulated Tunisian daily Achourouk crystallized this growing pro-Iraqi stand among Arabs in poorer countries in a Thursday editorial that said, ''From the Atlantic to the gulf, the Arab man in the street is on the side of Iraq.''
Popular committees have sprung up in several countries, sometimes in defiance of their governments, to back Iraq's stand. Thousands of volunteers have signed up at Iraqi embassies in Tunis, Yemen, Jordan and Algeria to ''fight American imperialism,'' according to independent news reports from various Arab capitals.
In Yemen on Thursday 300 people stormed the offices of the official Saudi Press Agency shouting ''No to America!'' and ''American cowards!'' while other crowds attacked the Egyptian embassy in Sanaa, the capital, to protest Egypt's condemnation of Iraq.
Even among Muslim fundamentalist movements, which ordinarily would have been expected to oppose the secular Iraqi regime, there was enthusiastic support for Iraq and open condemnation of the Americans and of the Saudis, who have been great benefactors to all Islamic movements in the region.
One-third of the Jordanian deputies, representing the Muslim Front in Jordan's freely elected parliament, called upon all Arabs last week to unite against what they described as ''the new Christian-Zionist crusade against Arab and Islamic lands.''
''Where was this American enthusiasm when Palestinian lands were confiscated by Israel or when Israel occupied the parts of Egypt, Syria and Jordan in 1967?'' asked Sobhi Taha, chairman of the Writers' Association in Irbid, Jordan. ''Where was Saudi Arabia then?''
Egypt, which has taken a leading role in trying to find an Arab solution, also felt somewhat on the defensive, with some of its spokesmen looking for excuses to explain its anti-Iraqi stand even as it sought to rally the other nations around it. ''The fact is that if we allowed one Arab country to occupy other Arab countries, what excuse do we have with the Israelis to tell them they have to let go of the West Bank?'' said Tahsin Bashir, a former Arab League ambassador of Egypt and spokesman for the late president Anwar el-Sadat.
Yet even before this week was over, the harsh truth was that Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the other big oil producers of the gulf region had found a deep current of Arab dislike for them, and that wide segments of public opinion in the Arab world would hardly shed a tear if all the ruling families were overthrown as was the al-Sabah family of Kuwait.
These truths, long suppressed by the money doled by the rich Arabs to obtain support from their poorer brethren, are now coming out. As a result, many senior officials in the gulf region are saying they have washed their hands of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and of King Hussein of Jordan, men whose sympathy for Iraq was all too evident.
But with many Palestinian nationals running the economies of the oil states, there is a question of whether that distance can be maintained.
To be sure, there will be little enthusiasm now in the gulf countries and the United States for a resolution to the Palestinian-Israeli problem that may secure a homeland for Palestinians.
Within the gulf, it already appears that Iran, while taking full advantage of any setbacks for Iraq, has more in common with its powerful neighbor than with the Arabs of the gulf. Both countries would like to see higher oil prices and revenues. Both are anxious to see American and Western fleets depart from the Persian Gulf. And both agree that in the end they have to subdue the rich gulf Arabs and their regional influence to achieve these aims. But Iran has gingerly sided with the anti-Iraq camp, probably delaying any alliance.
At the moment, the West appears to take some comfort in Egypt's leadership in the crisis. After all, this most important summit meeting was held in Cairo on one day's notice, not in Riyadh, Baghdad or Amman.
But the Egypt that is claiming leadership of the Arabs today is not the nation of the late Gamal Abdel Nasser, whose charismatic Arab mantle Mr. Hussein is trying to assume. Egypt today is an impoverished, overpopulated country with $50 billion in debt, dependent on the $3 billion in American aid sent each year. Even with Egypt's new leadership role, this dependency on American aid is widely seen in the Arab world as dependency on American will - a position now shared by Saudi Arabia.

LENGTH: 1506 words

HEADLINE: NO QUARTER;
America Could Face a Long and Costly Commitment in the Mideast

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST as President Bush was beginning to trust in the stability of the emerging world order, the crisis most feared in the new era has exploded on the Arabian Peninsula. A war over oil is testing his ability to handle sudden adversity and holding out little hope for the kind of benign ending that followed the quiet revolutions of 1989.
Unlike in Europe, where just about everyone seemed to win at least a little, there will be losers in the Persian Gulf. It is difficult to imagine a resolution in which both George Bush and Saddam Hussein emerge unscathed, or even with equal damage. Indeed, what alarms the Bush Administration most is that it is easier to write scripts with no winners.
President Bush and the eclectic gathering of nations backing Washington say they had no choice but to enter this perilous position once Mr. Hussein invaded Kuwait, declared it part of Iraq and seemed to be eyeing Saudi Arabia. Now they are betting the ultimate stakes - war with a leader who has shown no qualms about prolonged bloodshed - that they can choke Mr. Hussein with economic sanctions until he surrenders Kuwait and, ultimately, some demand, his seat of power in Iraq. 
Mr. Bush seems to be enjoying popular and Congressional support for his military deployment, but Americans are not very good at waiting out wars, especially one that could involve 100,000 American soldiers and cost billions just when voters were waiting for the so-called peace dividend. How long, then, can the United States stand eyeball-to-eyeball with hostile Arab troops in a scorching desert where American soldiers seem certain to face cultural and political friction with their Saudi hosts? Is the United States embroiled in a politically volatile situation from which it may not be able to extricate itself easily? Will it find itself indefinitely protecting the gulf states?
Mr. Hussein has called for disenchanted Arabs to rise in a holy war against their oil-wealthy neighbors. This call seems to be falling on unsympathetic ears but even if Mr. Hussein is defeated, Middle East politics has been turned on its head, compelling the Arab world to rethink its alliances and potentially forcing some new balance between Arab oil and Western military and economic power. ''The legitimacy of the existing structure in the Middle East has not been this fundamentally challenged, even by Nasser,'' said Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State. The Bush Administration acknowledges that United States power is in the Persian Gulf to stay, one way or another, as long as the world economy must drink oil for survival. ''We're in for the long haul,'' a senior official said.
Oil is the political reality behind Mr. Bush's talk, however heartfelt, about national sovereignty, self-determination and the rule of law. Because oil is the lifeblood of the world economy, the Middle East, like no other region, has the potential to blow apart the fragile new comity between East and West. That, more than Kuwaiti independence, is what has drawn so many different interests together. Mr. Bush took advantage of the new East-West relations to rally an unprecedented coalition against Mr. Hussein, starting with a joint Soviet-American condemnation and culminating with swift passage of mandatory United Nations sanctions. With painstaking personal diplomacy, Mr. Bush has slowly enlisted European allies - and the Soviet Union - in sending warships to the Persian Gulf to enforce the embargo if necessary.
The Iraqi army, even if it has the million men President Hussein claims, seems a poor match for the American military with its overwhelming air power, and the American, Soviet, British, French, Canadian and German warships. But Iraq proved its endurance during the nine-year conflict with Iran and as tough as Mr. Bush may be prepared to be, Mr. Hussein can be meaner. This is a man who has used poison gas - and who has said he would not hesitate to use it again. Administration officials say there seems to be no solution acceptable to the West that includes Mr. Hussein's staying in Kuwait and, indeed, in Iraq. Representative Les Aspin, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was so alarmed that Mr. Bush had not made this point strongly enough that he wrote the President on Friday to ask him to ''make clearer to the American public and to the Arab public why we are there and the conditions under which we will leave.'' The White House, though, has tried to keep things as calm as possible under the circumstances by being circumspect in its talk about overthrowing Mr. Hussein.
It also shuns the word ''hostage'' to refer to the thousands of American citizens that Mr. Hussein won't let out of Kuwait or Iraq.
Washington is seeking a fine balance between a Western-imposed solution and an Arab solution. As the Arab countries tried to resolve the crisis within their own ranks, there was concern in Washington that they would buy off Mr. Hussein by erasing debts and permitting him some presence in Kuwait. Administration officials took heart from the vote at the Arab summit on Friday, in which only Iraq, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization opposed sending a common Arab force to Saudi Arabia. But Henry Schuler, director of energy-security programs for the Center for Strategic and International Studies, worried that ''the sine qua non of any Arab solution would be the withdrawal of American troops.'' The United States might want to resist if Mr. Hussein were still in a position of strength, but that would wreck any new Arab alliance.
The United States has been working to broaden Arab participation in the struggle against Mr. Hussein, arguing that otherwise, his portrayal of the fight as one between the Arab people and the American ''infidels,'' with the Saudi monarchy as their only ally, could be widely effective among Arabs disenchanted with the distribution of the oil wealth.
Mr. Bush sees a chance to improve relations with Syria and even perhaps with Iran. But there are risks associated with Arab military involvement. Mr. Schuler noted that the Egyptian army, for example, has a long history of fighting to overthrow monarchies, starting with the ouster of King Farouk in 1952. ''Now,'' he said, ''we expect this army to be reliable in propping up the House of Saud and putting the Emir of Kuwait back on his throne?'' In return for Arab assistance, Washington might find itself under increased pressure to push Israel toward a resolution of its disputes with the Palestinians.
In the cauldron of Middle East politics, Mr. Hussein's move has blown the already thin cover of the Saudi-American relationship. These relations have always had a fatal flaw: as soon as the Saudis acknowledged them - as they have by inviting American troops into their country - the rest of the Arab world could be at their throats. Mr. Hussein's efforts to exploit this have not worked so far since he can hardly assume the mantle of protector of the faith. But Administration officials and Middle East specialists worry that a prolonged presence of American forces in Saudia Arabia could rekindle religious resentment against the House of Saud. Then the Bush Administration, already talking about a long-term commitment to beefing up the Saudi military, could find itself having to prop up the Saudi Government.
The crisis has reinforced the idea of gulf dependence on American military power. ''We were living under a false sense of security,'' said Saud Nasir al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti Ambassador to Washington. Asked whether this means the United States must stay in the gulf as the protector of the states on its shores, Mr. Nasir was circumspect. ''We have to wait and see.'' This is not a new role. For two years, American war vessels protected Kuwaiti ships that were switched to the United States flag. Although the United States has no real logistical problem sustaining a major military force once it is in place in Saudi Arabia, there are important political ramifications at home. Just when many lawmakers were arguing for a cut in military spending, the gulf crisis has strengthened the hand of the strong-military lobby. At the same time, the prospect of paying for the costly Arab expedition is likely to strain American patience.
The Middle East operation has pointed up a flaw in American plans to meet a sudden crisis overseas: the shortage of ships and planes to carry armed forces to battle. ''We have a real airlift problem when it comes to moving anything heavy,'' said Richard H. Shultz, director of security studies programs at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. ''This sort of engagement shows we are cutting in all the wrong places when we start shrinking our overseas facilities.''
In the end, it might appear unseemly to restore a feudal Emir to his throne. But a West European diplomat said the United States and its allies will find a justification.
''We have never bothered about democracy in the gulf,'' he said. ''We have bothered about oil.''

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 16, Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: Secret Service Faces A Rise in Counterfeiting

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
INFLATION, and the drug trade, have aided counterfeiters in Connecticut, says Thomas W. Gardner of the United States Secret Service.
''Years ago, you'd go into a store with a $20 bill, and it was considered unusual,'' said Mr. Gardner, the agent in charge of counterfeiting cases at the Secret Service's Connecticut office, in New Haven. ''Today, the clerk sticks it in the cash drawer without even looking at it.''
And someone with $1,000 in genuine bills can exchange it for $10,000 in counterfeit ones, he said, then buy cocaine that can be peddled on the street for $30,000 - a 300 percent profit.
''Counterfeit money is very lucrative to the drug dealer,'' Mr. Gardner said. It can also be dangerous, he said, if the person who sold the drugs for counterfeit cash catches on. But most street dealers do not think ahead that far, he said. 
 
Larger Seizures
The amount of counterfeit cash seized in Connecticut rose to $117,000 in 1989, from $34,000 in 1985, he said, and is likely to go up again this year, with seizures averaging $3,000 a week.
The denomination of the average bogus bill is also increasing, Mr. Gardner said. In 1989, 4,200 bills were seized in the state, with an average face value of $28 each. In 1985, 1,300 bills were seized with an average value of about $26.
Despite the rise in counterfeiting, businesses that handle large amounts of cash said they have made few changes in their operations.
Robert Cunningham, president of the Salisbury Bank, in Lakeville, and chairman of the Connecticut Bankers Association, said he knows of no banks offering seminars to tellers on how to spot counterfeit notes.
At his bank, ''I can say while we pick up a few bills from time to time, we don't get a lot of it,'' he said.
The president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants, James Rogers said he was surprised to learn that counterfeiting had risen so sharply since the mid-1980's, because none of his members had mentioned any problems.
''I guess this is all part of a very tight economy,'' he said.
 
Big-City Operations
The Secret Service investigates all reports of counterfeit money.While it is better known for protecting the President and visiting heads of state, the Federal agency was created in 1865 to combat a counterfeiting problem so widespread that one-third of all paper money in the nation was believed to be counterfeit.
''You see more'' counterfeit money ''in Connecticut than you would, say, in the Midwest, because of its location'' between New York City and Boston, Mr. Gardner said. Counterfeiters typically operate out of big cities, he said.
A great many counterfeit coins, known as slugs, used to be made in Rhode Island, ''but inflation actually helped us there,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Now it costs more to make them than they're worth.''
He said most of the counterfeit cases in Connecticut originate in Fairfield County, for two reasons.
''The cost of living in southwestern Connecticut is higher, so you get a faster turnover of money, and more counterfeit gets into the system,'' Mr. Gardner said. In addition, he said, the county is only a couple of train stops from New York City, where many of the bogus bills probably originate.
''We believe that 50 percent of the counterfeit that turns up here, if not as much as 75 percent, is manufactured outside of Connecticut,'' Mr. Gardner said.
 
'People Don't Understand'
Many of the other bills turn up in large cities, such as Hartford, New Haven and Danbury, Mr. Gardner said, which is probably the result of the increased drug trafficking in those cities.
But fake money sometimes turns up in other locations, he said.A few years ago, a young man who lived in Franklin was caught passing counterfeit bills. He worked at the Electric Boat Company in Groton and had purchased the bogus bills from a co-worker in Rhode Island.
''A lot of people don't understand the seriousness of the crime,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Counterfeit is contraband, and having a counterfeit $1 bill is the same as having cocaine in your pocket.''
People also tend to think of counterfeiting as a victimless crime, until the first time they get caught with a bogus note. Even if criminal charges are not lodged, the store or bank that notices it must confiscate the bill and turn it over to the Secret Service.
''We get calls from people who want to know who's going to make up the $100 they lost because of a counterfeit bill,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''That's when they learn it's not a victimless crime. They're out that money, because they can't get it back.''
''People involved in counterfeiting are usually involved in other crimes,'' Mr. Gardner said. In about 50 percent of the arrests, a counterfeiter is carrying a weapon, he said.
 
Too Busy or Too Lazy
Making a bill look and feel genuine is very difficult, Mr. Gardner said, but many still pass undetected, because store clerks and bank tellers are often too busy or too lazy to look a bill over closely.
The Secret Service has only seven agents covering Connecticut, he said, and they are sometimes pulled out of the state for protection details, but they have the help of a sophisticated computer to track counterfeit money.
Each time a counterfeit bill turns up, a report is logged into the agency's computer, which looks for similarities to cases around the world that might lead back to the maker.
''We start at the bottom of the ladder and try to work our way up each rung,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Sometimes we're lucky.''
Each year, he said, 16 to 20 people are arrested on counterfeiting charges in the state. In the last five years, the Secret Service in Connecticut has had 10 ''plant suppressions,'' which means shutting down counterfeiting operations.
''The average seize is probably $1 million now, and that's still relatively small,'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Operations of $10 million, $15 million or $20 million are not unusual in Miami and New York.''
