HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Many Prominent Americans Support the President's Action in the Gulf . . .Resistance to Blatant Aggression, Defense of Allies and, Above All, Oil

 BODY:

Henry Kissinger
 
National security adviser to Richard M. Nixon, 1969-75; Secretary of State, 1973-77. Now chairman of a consulting firm, Kissinger Associates.
The fundamental problem, it seems to me, is that this is the most blatant case of 1930's-style aggression in the entire postwar period. In the middle of peace, without any particular provocation except the desire for more territory, Iraq has annexed Kuwait. If that is permitted to stand it will lead to a whole series of conflicts and revolutions in the region.
I referred to Germany in the 30's and not to Soviet expansionism in the 1950's because the Soviet Union did not actually annex those countries. Rather, it insisted on its right to impose puppet governments on unwilling populations. Saddam Hussein is actually abolishing a state and a dynasty that has ruled Kuwait for 250 years. 
If Saddam Hussein succeeds, in particular on the basis of the arguments he has used -that Iraq has an implicit right to supplant Arab states by military action - all the principalities in the gulf will be put at risk because virtually every country in the area, including Jordan, fits Hussein's criteria for justifying the overthrow of Kuwait, with the possible exception of Egypt.
If Hussein succeeds, a cycle of conflicts in the Middle East is absolutely inevitable, probably culminating in an Arab-Israeli war.
If Saddam Hussein can make his coup stick, in the face of unanimous opposition from the United Nations, a worldwide embargo and a U.S. military deployment, we will enter a period of growing chaos.
 
Edward W. Said
 
The Old Dominion Foundation Professor in the Humanities, Columbia University; a member of the Palestine National Council.
As an Arab and an American, the awful events unfolding in the gulf fill me with dread and sorrow. I have grown up with the spectacle of Arab and American interests in the Middle East for the most part in conflict. My assessment of American interests today as they have been acted apon and spoken about by President Bush now and in the past is that these interests are the unimpeded flow of relatively inexpensive and abundant Arab oil, the compliance of one or several Arab leaders with U.S. interests basically in protecting the flow of oil and not standing in the way of America's other major interest: Israel.
Beyond that, I have felt that the aspirations, the attempt to deal with a difficult historical legacy, the desire to achieve development and independence which have characterized the best of Arab nationalism - all these have never been considered to have entered the pursuit of American interests in the region. It is true that the Arab world today presents a sorry spectacle, with all sorts of inequities, tyrannies and mediocrities to make us all feel ashamed. Saddam is one of the results of the difficulties the Arab world faces - a tyrant and an aggressor, who seems nevertheless to speak to hidden emotions and frustrations in the collective Arab soul.
I am also angered as to why an illegal Iraqi occupation of Kuwait has aroused far more American force and passion than the brutalities and callousness of Israel's 23-year-old occupation of Arab land.
 
John C. West
 
Attorney and Distinguished Professor of Middle East Studies at the University of South Carolina; Governor of South Carolina, 1971-75; Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, 1977-81.
We do have a tremendous economic stake in the Mideast. We cannot afford to have Saddam Hussein or anyone else who is unfriendly to the United States control nearly half of the world's oil supplies. The fact is that we are far more dependent on imported Mideast oil than we want to admit. For example, in 1973, when we had the first oil embargo, we were importing less than 30 per cent of our oil. President Nixon declared Operation Independence, saying we would be free of imported oil in seven years. . . . The crisis ended, Mr. Nixon's plans were shelved, the next crisis came in '79, and at that time we were importing 40 percent of our oil.
In the late 70's, the Congress appropriated $88 billion for alternate energy sources and to meet the problem of dependence upon foreign oil. Again, the crisis ended, and there is at most only one small part of that program still alive.
Today . . . the person who controls half of the world's oil resources determines the world economic outlook, inflation, and whether we have a depression or whether we have prosperity.
The United States has some difficult times ahead. The history of boycotts' working is not good. But the hope must be maintained that the boycott of Iraq, including a shutting off of the oil supplies, will cause Saddam Hussein to retreat. If that does not work, we are faced with a long stalemate with our soldiers and airmen in a combat status in a hostile foreign environment, not unlike Vietnam.
 
Rep. Ted Weiss
 
Democrat of New York, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
For those of us who remember World War II, and know how it happened, what Saddam Hussein is doing bears a startling resemblance to how Hitler behaved. There were terrible consequences then, when the international community did not stand up - it just encouraged aggression.
I have had no reluctance whatsoever to speak out against American military action when it was illegal or improper, but I support U.S. policy when it stands up to illegal and improper behavior in other nations. . . . Secondarily, what is happening in the Middle East is important because of the oil - it is of terribly important concern to our economy. . . .
If you allow someone like Saddam Hussein to get a stranglehold on oil production, it gives him control of our economy. The price of oil operates on the basis of availability.
If you give that kind of control to a person such as Saddam Hussein, who is very, very ruthless, the consequences would be very, very dire.
I've been touting Saudi Arabia as a moderate force in the region, one we had the capacity to rely on, so it is nice to know that in fact, they are willing to let us help them defend themselves. . . .
Also, the crisis demonstrated that when Israel expresses its concern for its security, it is not being paranoid. There are nations surrounding her which are in fact very aggressive and very powerful. The safety and security of Israel has to be one of the top priorities for Israel and to her friends.
 
Rep. Patricia Schroeder
 
Democrat of Colorado and a member of the House Armed Services Committee.
Basically, our main interest in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait comes down to a three-letter word, oil. It is oil, oil and oil. Regrettably, we have diverted all our attention away from an energy program, and alternate sources of energy. We don't seem to have any capacity as a nation to think long-term: anyone who looked at the region could tell it has not gotten any more stable, and we certainly know the entire industrialized world relies heavily on oil. The world economy is quirky enough without a massive oil shock.
That's why we didn't have time to play around in dealing with this crisis. . . . Saddam Hussein had to be told that if he crossed the border into Saudi Arabia, he would be picking a fight with a force that is far bigger than just Saudi Arabia. We had to do that to convey our seriousness.
The thing I wish is that we had gone in under a United Nations flag. We did it the last time - reflagging the Kuwaiti tankers. We have become the 911 for the world. This time, we obviously had international support . . . and the Soviets also sided with us. As a military exercise, this is going to be very costly, and I wish we didn't have to bear all of the cost by ourselves.
The tragedy of this is that some will use the crisis to insist that we need an MX missile and a B-2 bomber and S.D.I. If we had spent the billions of dollars those weapons systems cost on building up our energy independence, we would have something to sell to the rest of the world, we would be like Saddam Hussein.
 
Jesse Jackson
 
Ran for the Democratic nomination for President in 1984 and 1988.
My position has been that we must defend our allies, protect our national interests, and contribute to world stability. . . .
Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are our allies and whenever the free passage of traffic in the gulf has been threatened, they have allied with us. In the cold war, they have been our trading partners, and have played a factor in the price stability of petroleum, which affects us and the Western world. They have done things to support us, when we needed it, and they had no place else to go.
Saudi Arabia is more of an asset to us than Grenada was a threat, Kuwait is more of an asset to us than Noriega was a threat. . . .
We went to Saudi Arabia with an invitation, so it was not an invasion as it was in Panama and Grenada. In Panama and Grenada, we violated international law and put in our own governments and the world scorned us for doing so. In this case Hussein broke international law. He said he would not invade, and he did. He said he would withdraw from Kuwait, and then he annexed. And then he began moving toward Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia asked for our help. It seems to me that we were obliged to respond.
Hopefully, our military presence there will serve as a deterrent to Hussein's expansion, and our diplomatic and economic initiatives will be a factor in getting him back to his borders and getting all parties around a table for a negotiated settlement. . . . Our military presence must be temporary, for the longer they are there, the more hostilities they will engender. And that's why we must put at least as much energy into helping the Arab nations' summit succeed, led by Mubarak, as any other tactic.
 
James R. Schlesinger
 
Richard M. Nixon's Secretary of Defense, 1973-1975 , and Jimmy Carter's Secretary of Energy, 1977-79. Now a counselor at the Center for Strategic and International Affairs in Washington.
Why is Saudi Arabia so important? Because it is the largest producer of oil, and the U.S. is becoming increasingly dependent on foreign sources of supply.
Could we survive without Saudi Arabia? Sure. We would find ourselves more subject to the whims of those who control the supply, but the U.S. is a large and powerful country.
Oil prices would be higher, and probably more erratic; there would be conservation, fuel-switching, and there would be a tendency to turn to other sources of supply for oil itself. Even if Venezuela and Mexico could meet the U.S.'s oil needs, they could not compensate for the oil dependence of Europe and Japan. But the U.S. would then lose its position as the leader of the world in the post-cold war atmosphere.
We were right to provide troops in Saudi Arabia as a deterrent to dissuade Iraq from attacking Saudi Arabia. We had a commitment, which has been stated and restated since the late 1970's. . . . For us to stand aside and watch Saudi Arabia be swept away would be the equivalent of standing by and watching Berlin be swept away in the 1940's.
I'm not sure Mr. Bush's political objectives of immediate and total and unequivocal withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and the restoration of its legitimate rulers, are achievable. We may have prematurely set our feet in concrete over this.
 
George W. Ball
 
Lawyer; Under Secretary of State, 1961-66; United States Representative to the United Nations, 1968; a senior partner, Lehman Brothers, 1969-1982.
President Bush basically had no serious option but the one he is pursuing. I think it is very important, however, that he not fall into the habit of talking about this as though this were an American operation. . . . The legitimacy of what the United States is doing depends now on the Security Council resolution. It's a United Nations action; he's got to keep that firmly in the forefront.
Even in the most moderate Arab countries, the Arabs privately have a considerable admiration for Saddam Hussein because they have such contempt for the Kuwaitis, who have been the beneficiaries of enormous wealth and . . . have behaved in an extremely self-indulgent way.
One of the major reasons that the Saudis are not better equipped than they were to resist this aggression is because the American Congress has bowed to the pressure of the Israeli lobby and denied the Saudis the military hardware that they have tried to buy.
While the United States a few years ago was the greatest creditor nation in the world, we are now the greatest debtor nation, and we are able to maintain ourselves in substantial part because of the flow of investment money from the oil-producing countries. . . . Should Saddam Hussein be permitted to roll over on the Saudis, then with his Iraqi-Kuwaiti-Saudi production, he would have a stranglehold on the world oil market - and he would be the last person who would be inclined to use his money to . . . mitigate our position as a debtor.
 
Richard Helms
 
Former Director of Central Intelligence and former Ambassador to Iran, now an international consultant in Washington.
The vital interest of the United States in Saudi Arabia is oil. With a capital O. Any interest that we have in Kuwait is the same: oil.
When I use the term ''oil,'' I am referring of course to crude oil production. It is the movement of this crude oil to refineries around the world which keeps the wheels of industry humming and the wheels of automobiles turning. Also oil, as the Shah used to say, is a precious commodity, because it provides the basis for a whole series of plastic byproducts as well as petrochemicals of different kinds.
The current crisis in the Middle East indicates once again how important it is for the United States to establish an energy policy. We have made various passes at this difficult activity, but each time whatever crisis has arisen, it has passed over, and the American public has forgotten the vital importance of crude oil to our economy, if not our very existence.
In recent years our import of crude oil has steadily risen until it is now almost 50 percent of our needs. This is a dramatic change from the days when Texas oil dominated the American domestic scene. It is incumbent upon the country - the President and the Congress - to wrestle with this difficult problem of an energy policy. Otherwise the United States, in fact the free world, will become increasingly hostage to unpredictable events in the Persian Gulf area.
 
Bernard Lewis
 
Cleveland E. Dodge Professor of Near Eastern Studies Emeritus at Princeton University.
I can understand the irritation of people who ask why on earth should we get involved with all these difficult and troublesome people in far places. . . . Nevertheless I feel that irritation is misplaced.
It seems to me that there are two major reasons why we should be concerned about the Middle East to the point of doing something about it - and even incurring some risks. The first point is oil, which is necessary not only for this country, which now imports almost half its oil, but also for the free world generally.
There is a real danger that one country, one government, you might almost say one man, would control so large a proportion of the world's oil that he would have power over not only pricing but also supply. He could allocate and price as he chose, and thereby exercise a degree of control which is more than unacceptable - which is positively dangerous.
Ultimately the only way to escape from this dilemma is to escape from oil, which pollutes the sea, the land, the air, politics, the economy, and much else besides.
The second point, which I think is even more important, is that if in this year 1990 a country may simply invade and annex a neighbor while the world merely says tut, tut and does nothing effective about it, then this is the first step to the breakdown of the international order. . . . If we let this pass, we shall be back in the international jungle of the 1930's, and we know where that led.
These comments were elicited in telephone interviews by Eric Pace and Alessandra Stanley.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Transcript of U.S. Statement About Measures Against Iraq

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 12

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the statement on measures to be taken against Iraq made today by President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
This morning, the President received a letter from His Highness, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait, requesting on behalf of the Government of Kuwait, and in accordance with Article 51 of the U.N. Charter and the right of individual and collective self-defense, that the United States Government take appropriate steps as necessary to ensure that the U.N.-mandated economic sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait are immediately and effectively implemented.
In view of the Emir's request, the President has decided that the United States will do whatever is necessary to see that relevant U.N. sanctions are enforced. The President stressed that these efforts will complement, not substitute, for individual and collective compliance that has been highly successful thus far. The United States will coordinate its efforts with the governments of other nations to whom the Kuwaiti Government has made similar requests.
Regarding Saddam Hussein's proposals announced today, the United States categorically rejects them. We join the rest of the U.N. Security Council in unanimously calling for the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, and the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate Government. These latest conditions and threats are another attempt at distracting from Iraq's isolation and at imposing a new status quo. Iraq continues to act in defiance of U.N. Resolutions 660, 661 and 662, the basis for resolving Iraq's occupation. The United States will continue to pursue the application of those resolutions in all their parts.

HEADLINE: G.M. Strike in Michigan Imperils Industry Talks With Union

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A four-day-old strike at a General Motors Corporation parts plant in Flint, Mich., is affecting other G.M. plants around the country and is influencing bargaining between the Big Three automakers and the United Automobile Workers union.
Leaders of the U.A.W. have insisted that the walkout by 2,800 assembly workers at the General Motors A.C. Rochester Division plant was undertaken purely over local issues that have been disputed for a year, including charges of unsafe conditions, work speedups and subcontracting of work to non-union companies.
The national contract that expires Sept. 14 allows strikes by individual plants only over such local issues, which are set out in the agreement.
But union leaders and G.M. negotiators are acutely aware that the strike has received the blessing of Stephen Yokich, the U.A.W.'s vice president in charge of relations with G.M., the nation's biggest automaker. The union leadership could presumably have withheld its approval until after a national contract was ratified, as has been the case in previous contract negotiations. 
 
'Sending a Signal to G.M.'
''There's little doubt that Steve is sending a signal to G.M.,'' said a union staff worker who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Yokich, who took over his post a year ago, is regarded as more confrontational with automotive management than his predecessor, Donald Ephlin. Mr. Yokich is a leading candidate to succeed Owen F. Bieber as U.A.W. president when Mr. Bieber retires some time in the next few years.
Harry C. Katz, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University, said the U.A.W. is trying to assert Mr. Yokich's tougher negotiating style as distinct from that of Mr. Ephlin.
''They want to show management they are not patsies,'' Mr. Katz said. ''It may be helpful in that this will allow the membership to let off a little steam.''
Many believe union members are frustrated with G.M. assurances over job security. The automaker in the past three years has closed several plants after the union thought it had received assurances that there would not be any further closings.
In the national contract talks, the union has earmarked job security as its No. 1 issue, ahead of wage and benefit increases. In recent years, the automakers have been willing to guarantee ''income security'' to laid-off workers, in essence acquiescing to an economic penalty for curtailing operations.
 
Unused Plant Capacity a Problem
G.M., which has much more unused plant capacity than other domestic automakers, has said it must close some plants to remain competitive. Moreover, company executives have recently said G.M. plants that make components, as opposed to those where vehicles are assembled, are a particular problem since many non-union manufacturers have wage scales far lower than G.M.'s.
The union cannot acknowledge that the strike in Flint is part of its national bargaining strategy. Doing so could provide ground for some states to deny employment benefits to workers who are idled as a result of the walkout at the Flint plant, which makes fuel tanks for more than half of the G.M. vehicles built in the United States, among other parts.
Already forced to close because of the Flint walkout are G.M. plants in Moraine, Ohio; Pontiac, Mich.; Shreveport, La., and a second plant in Flint employing 7,000 workers.
G.M. management is widely regarded by labor and automotive experts as having with the most troubled relations with union workers of any automaker. The problems are partly historic and partly a result of the excess capacity of its automaking and parts-making plants, which has caused frequent layoffs and shutdowns. G.M. executives have also aggravated ill will by awarding themselves lavish pay and benefit packages.
Disputes have been particularly bitter in Flint, about 60 miles north of Detroit, which is the birthplace of G.M. and of the U.A.W. Flint has lost about 30,000 of about 70,000 G.M. jobs since the mid-70's.
Part of the agenda of grievances at A.C. Rochester was the company's announcement six months ago that it plans to eliminate the jobs of 600 workers who make doors for various G.M. van models.

HEADLINE: Providence Journal;
World War Long Over, But Not The Battles

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 7

 BODY:
Behind a tiny American flag on his office desk, Cliff Wilson, the state commander of the American Legion, talks of Pentagon cutbacks, glasnost and the current Middle East crisis with cool detachment.
But mention Japanese pressure to change the name of a state holiday that will be celebrated Monday from Victory Day or V. J. Day to Peace Day, and the 62-year-old former Navy gunman begins his attack.
''If they were offended when we called it V. J. Day, we were pretty offended when they bombed Pearl Harbor,'' said Mr. Wilson, who is a veteran of World War II. ''Why should we have to pacify them?'' 
President Harry S. Truman proclaimed the holiday to mark Japan's surrender to the Allies on Aug. 15, 1945, and for years Victory Day was celebrated around the nation.
But now Rhode Island, the defiant colony that was the first to declare independence from England, is the only state still celebrating the Japanese surrender, although the state has changed to marking Victory Day on the second Monday in August.
While many Rhode Islanders consider Victory Day just another chance for sunbathing, members of the state's small but economically influential Japanese community say some residents use the holiday as an excuse to cause trouble. A name change, they say, is not just a matter of semantics, but also one of safety.
The Japan Society of Rhode Island says the name Victory Day promotes anti-Asian sentiments, slurs and racially motivated attacks. The cultural society has retained two lawyers to press for a change to a name like Remembrance Day or Peace Day.
''We are just concerned about increasing accounts of anti-Asian violence that have occurred on and around the holiday,'' said Jennifer Wood, a lawyer for the group, which has about 90 private and corporate members. ''Keep the holiday, just change the name.'' She said the society was considering filing a lawsuit against the state.
Hiroko Shikashio, a 47-year-old painter who was born in Japan, said she felt uncomfortable leaving her home in North Providence on Victory Day. ''Because I am Japanese, I have always felt uneasy about going outside on that day,'' she said. ''I think it is nice for people to have a holiday, but they should call it something else.''
Lawmakers here have found themselves straddling two forceful constituencies planted firmly at either end of the debate over a name change.
Rhode Island's 119,000 veterans, more than one-third of whom are World War II veterans, wield substantial influence over public policy decisions, state officials say. More than 100,000 soldiers, or 10 percent of Rhode Island's population, were swept into combat in World War II.
Now in their 60's and 70's, many of the World War II veterans, who have successfully opposed two legislative efforts to change the name of the holiday, contend that the issue is not one of civil rights but of foreign economic interests.
Last year, Japan was Rhode Island's third-largest trading partner, receiving almost $50 million in state exports, up from $34.5 million in 1987. At the same time, Japanese companies have invested about $500 million in Rhode Island, creating hundreds of jobs and helping to strengthen the state's sagging economy.
Kenneth J. Willette, director of the state's Department of Economic Development, insists that the name of the holiday is not the real problem. ''It is the perception that we are the only one that celebrates that raises questions,'' he said.
But local business leaders, many of whom are seeking Japanese investment, are still wary about the name.
''I have tried to get the players together to see if we could come up with a compromise, keeping the holiday without offending anyone,'' said Henry S. Woodbridge Jr., chairman of the Japan-America Society of Rhode Island, a business group that promotes relations between the state and Japan. In addition to sponsoring a summer festival that highlights Japanese culture, the society has suggested that Victory Day be changed to Rhode Island Veterans' Day.
But Mr. Wilson, the American Legion commander, says keeping the holiday name is a matter of principle. ''We can pacify them by calling it Victory Day instead of V. J. Day, he said. ''But we can't go any farther than that. They will have to win the title back.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 749 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush's Double Gamble

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
If President Bush loses the gamble he took in pledging that Iraq's conquest of Kuwait ''will not stand,'' he might turn out to be a loser in American politics too.
For the moment, polls and every other indication suggest that the Democratic Congress as well as the American people approve of Mr. Bush's determination to oppose Saddam Hussein, even to send troops to Saudi Arabia to guard a prime source of Western oil against any further Iraqi aggression.
Mr. Bush's well-received performance as Commander in Chief also may have allowed him to recover, at least for the time being, from reaction against his broken pledge not to raise taxes, and to rise above a surge of unwelcome economic news.
That's not surprising. Presidents who take military action abroad, particularly if they invoke rhetoric appealing to the overdeveloped American sense of self-regard, always benefit from a rally-round-the-flag effect. Mr. Bush spoke in ringing tones of turning back an aggressor and played on memories of the disastrous failure of other nations to stop Hitler's Germany at the outset. 
Prudently, the President did not picture his defense of Saudi Arabia for what it also is: protection of the oil supplies that fuel Western economies. Americans are not so ready to fight wars for such realistic but unidealistic reasons.
Nor has the word ''Panama'' passed Mr. Bush's lips in the Middle East crisis. But Panama is relevant, for at least two reasons. One is that not a few nations and at least a few Americans regard the U.S. conquest of that country as having been aggression masquerading as ''Operation Just Cause.'' George Bush thinks that's different; that was our aggression, not their aggression.
The second reason is that in Panama, U.S. forces were able to make the hit, quickly win a one-sided battle, and come home before the criticism began to build. So were the forces engaged in Ronald Reagan's glorious victory over Cuban construction workers in Grenada. In the age of television, such hit-and-run wars can be celebrated, since there's no need or time to watch on the home screen as a long parade of body bags comes sadly home.
The Bush Administration, perhaps at the behest of the feudalistic Saudi regime, did not permit a U.S. press pool to accompany the first troops sent to the desert - despite pledges, after Grenada and Panama, not to black out the U.S. public again. That may suggest White House hopes, however vain, for another quick, successful, vote-getting operation.
In the Middle East, that may not be in the cards. Indications are that Saddam Hussein will not invade Saudi Arabia and undertake the war with the U.S. that Mr. Bush's moves make a certain result. But nothing suggests, so far, that Mr. Hussein will pull out of Kuwait and restore the emirate, in effect surrendering to Mr. Bush's public demand.
If the President then tries to throw Iraq out of Kuwait by military force, it will not be a quick or bloodless operation, and it might not even be successful; and the alternative, as it now appears, would be stalemate in the desert - Iraq in Kuwait, the U.S. in Saudi Arabia. As became evident in Korea and Vietnam, however, the American public has little tolerance for long, limited, stalemated wars and the high casualty rate they bring.
If such a stalemate develops, which many military experts and authorities on the region believe likely, Mr. Bush might soon find himself under the severe public pressures to win or settle an unpopular, faraway conflict from which Presidents Truman, Johnson and Nixon suffered during Korea and Vietnam. Those Presidents had international military support; but Mr. Bush may not be able to persuade other nations - save Britain - to keep troops for long in a peacekeeping force in Saudi Arabia.
Meanwhile, tightening oil supplies and rising oil prices might bring both inflation and recession in the United States, a tough combination to overcome for a President seeking Congressional majorities and his own re-election. Thus, the long-term political outlook for Mr. Bush may not be as rosy as his present standing might indicate.
He and his political advisers are well able to make that calculation for themselves; apparently, they went ahead, anyway, with a policy they considered necessary, despite its political hazards. But beyond the line he's drawn in the sand, perhaps George Bush and the nation now can see that it would make more sense to regain independence from Middle East oil than to die for it.

HEADLINE: The Changing City; Woodside, Queens;
New Accents and Old Brogue Quietly Reshape Woodside

SERIES: A periodic look at New York's neighborhoods in transition.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
Madge O'Boyle stood in front of the apartment building in Woodside, Queens, where she has lived for three decades, since shortly after the Irish native arrived in the United States, and chatted with neighbors on the sun-baked steps.
Across 52d Street, Mike Lin, a native of Taiwan who came to Woodside five years ago, whacked a tennis ball on a handball court in Windmuller Park.
On nearby Roosevelt Avenue, Matilde Ramirez, once of Ecuador, prepared for the day's first patrons at the Colombian restaurant that she and her husband, a Colombian native, have operated for five years.
It was a typical summer day in the streets and parks and shops of Woodside, a largely working-class area of western Queens that has undergone sharp ethnic and cultural changes in recent years. And it has weathered the transformation, New York City officials and area residents say, with little of the trauma, tension or bias-based bellicosity that have too often accompanied such shifts in other areas of the city. 
Two miles long and about a mile and a half wide, Woodside extends from about 48th Street on the west to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and Conrail tracks on the east, and from about 30th Avenue on the north to a winding southern line formed by the Long Island Expressway and Maurice and Calamus Avenues. The woods and swamps that dotted the area in the 19th century gave it its name.
From a district once known as ''Irishtown,'' Woodside has evolved into a polyglot of tongues and traditions in which immigrants from Latin America and Asia are now estimated to make up nearly half of the 40,000 residents.
''It's one of the more integrated areas of the city, and in a really positive way,'' said Ted Finkelstein, director of the west-central Queens office of the city's Neighborhood Stabilization Program.
But despite the extensive changes, the Irish seem in no danger of disappearing from the blocks of well-kept private homes and solid apartment buildings that house mechanics, transit workers and office clerks, laboratory technicians, shopkeepers, accountants and lawyers. True, many Irish-Americans did move from Woodside as the newcomers flowed in over the last 15 years.
And, true, some of the Irish did vocally complain a dozen years ago about the many illegal aliens among the Hispanic newcomers - contending that the ''illegals'' were an unfair burden on the community's schools and hospitals, and being accused, in turn, of resenting people from a different culture.
But many other Irish, like 54-year-old Mrs. O'Boyle, saw no reason to pack up and leave.
''I love the neighborhood and I can find no problem with them,'' said Mrs. O'Boyle, the wife of an elevator mechanic.
Many of the newcomers are from Ireland, whose troubled economy has helped spur many young people to head for the cities of America. The result for Woodside has been several thousand ''new Irish'' who, longtime Woodsiders say, are different enough from the ''old Irish'' to add their own distinct flavoring to today's ethnic brew.
''You go into a diner and it doesn't take 10 seconds before you hear the brogue, which you wouldn't have heard around here 10 years ago except occasionally,'' said one of Woodside's old Irish, City Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey. The 41-year-old Democrat, whose parents arrived in the neighborhood in the 1930's, observed that most of the area's old Irish are at least second- or third-generation Americans.
Sean Benson, one of the new Irish, who came to Woodside from County Kildare five years ago, said the latest generation of his countrymen were contributing more than Hibernian tones. With their youth and vigor, he said, they are bringing ''a new freshness, a dynamism, into the neighborhood - into the pubs, the restaurants, opening new businesses themselves.''
For the most part, though, ''the guys work in construction, the women as waitresses or nannies,'' he said. The 29-year-old Mr. Benson, who heads an advice center for Irish newcomers maintained by the Irish Immigration Reform Movement on Roosevelt Avenue, said most of the new Irish are in this country illegally, often having entered on limited tourist visas and staying on when they expired.
 
Paradox Over New 'Illegals'
There is more than a little paradox in this, some Woodsiders acknowledge, considering the resentment by some local Irish in the 70's, when ''illegals'' were all from south of the border.
But paradoxes and legalities apart, Woodside has come through its transmutation pretty smoothly, officials say.
Yet there have been rough moments. In what the police termed a bias-related incident in 1988, a group of Hispanic men, some wielding baseball bats and iron rods, beat several worshipers outside an Islamic mosque, which was then at Queens Boulevard and 50th Street. Congregants said there had been months of harassment.
Last year, two Korean men were assaulted by whites voicing racial slurs in a doughnut shop on Roosevelt Avenue, the area's main commercial strip, said Capt. Ryan Thomas, commander of the 108th Precinct, which covers most of Woodside.
 
'People Are Mostly Friendly'
But such incidents are exceptions, he said. Mostly, Woodside is a solid area of people who ''go to work and come home and seem to have their own place in the community,'' he said.
Residents of various backgrounds agreed.
Pausing from her summer job at a summer school for Korean children, near her 51st Street home, Jung Yoon Choi, 18, who came from South Korea with her family eight years ago, said: ''Sometimes when I'm passing in the street a person might yell out, 'Chink!' But, really, hardly ever. The people are mostly friendly. Those who do it may not even live here.''
The Rev. Sang Il Park, a Woodsider who is pastor of the Korean Presbyterian Church of Southern New York, said that Woodside has ''not at all'' been like the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, where some blacks have been waging a long and venomous boycott against two Korean-owned groceries.
''There will never be an A plus neighborhood, but I give Woodside an A minus,'' he said.
Woodside is ''definitely not a high-crime area,'' Captain Thomas, the precinct commander, said. He acknowledged, however, that many of its residents, like people all over the city, are increasingly concerned with crime.
One anonymous group of citizens, disturbed by prostitution along stretches of Queens Boulevard, recently put up signs on utility poles warning that the license-plate numbers of the prostitutes' customers would be recorded and their families notified.
A major reason for its generally peaceful transformation in recent years, said Mr. Finkelstein, the Neighborhood Stabilization official, is that local leaders and institutions have developed ''programs that service all the groups.'' Residents say two groups have been especially important: Woodside on the Move, which dates from the 1970's and sponsors job-placement, business-aid and youth programs, and St. Sebastian's Roman Catholic Church, which runs English-language classes and conducts one of its Sunday Masses, celebrated by more than 1,600 people, in Spanish.
Despite this, many Hispanic people in Woodside ''don't feel welcome'' at St. Sebastian's, said Jorge Aleman, a Woodsider of Honduran origin who works with a Hispanic-aid group called Hispanos Unidos. ''At the end of Mass, Spanish people like to stay around at their church and get to talk to the priest,'' he said.
The Rev. James Frost, the church's parochial vicar, said that a tight schedule of crowded Masses and limited space restricted such socializing.
For his part, Mr. Aleman was quick to say that that was his only complaint about life in Woodside. ''Otherwise,'' he said, ''it's a beautiful neighborhood.''

HEADLINE: In New York's Parks, More Litter and Less Money

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Newspapers blow across the dusty, threadbare Great Lawn of Central Park. Abandoned cars block a running path in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. Citywide, trees that were once regularly pruned and meadows that were once regularly sodded now receive infrequent care.
After a decade of dramatic improvement on the coattails of the mid-80's economic boom, New York City's parks are a testament to a leaner, meaner era of municipal finance.
Maintenance has been cut, land acquisitions have been put on hold, the number of employees has fallen 12 percent since 1986 and tens of millions of dollars in capital projects have been delayed. And while police statistics do not show an increase in crime, many people say the parks seem more dangerous, or at least less inviting. 
The new Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gotbaum, acknowledges that basic maintenance has suffered. ''We've had to reduce the number of people who clean and plant, as well as playground attendants,'' she said. ''And our tree-pruning has been cut incredibly.''
Linda Davidoff, executive director of the Parks Council, a private advocacy group, said, ''The parks are shabbier, dirtier and less usable.''
 
'Hardest Times' in 10 Years
The cuts, which Parks and Recreation Department officials and park users say pose a threat to one of the city's most valuable and fragile resources, began in the late 80's, when the New York economy started to falter. But they have become more severe with this year's city budget-cutting.
''These are the hardest times we've seen in 10 years,'' said Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, the Central Park administrator. ''A lot of things break my heart. The Great Lawn is a dust bowl and the pond is almost completely silted up. They were due for a major restoration, but now I don't know when we'll get the money. And there's a terrible problem with homeless people living in the park.''
While Mrs. Gotbaum is attempting to cope with the cuts by increasing private fund raising, worker productivity and volunteerism, she has also shifted the department's priorities from ecology and public events, like having gondoliers in the lake at Central Park, to improving recreational services.
Many employees say that the new Parks Commissioner - a venture capitalist and avid tennis player who was a leading campaign fund raiser for Mayor Dinkins - has worked tirelessly to maintain services and boost morale. They say she is more open to employees and less media oriented than her predecessor, Henry J. Stern, but also less politically connected and less vocal about environmental issues.
The Parks Department's 26,000 acres include scores of parks and a network of natural, historic and recreational areas. The department oversees 7,200 acres of woodlands, marshes and other natural areas; 2.7 million trees; 15 miles of beaches; 862 playgrounds; more than 500 tennis courts; 27 recreation centers; 37 swimming pools; 40 preschools; 13 golf courses; six ice-skating rinks; 15 historic houses, and 1,500 monuments, statues and other artworks. The department sponsors more than 500 concerts, 900 nature walks, 1,000 family workshops and 200 school programs a year.
 
More Trims Are Sought
''My immediate goals are to energize field workers and get this agency running better,'' Mrs. Gotbaum said. ''I also think we can get more help from the private sector and work more closely with communities and other city agencies.''
The department's budget was reduced from $195 million, or 0.73 percent of the city's budget, in fiscal 1990 to $185 million, or 0.68 percent of the budget, in the 1991 fiscal year that began July 1. The staff has been cut by 135 positions, to about 4,340; five years ago, the payroll included 4,950 people. Last week, Mayor Dinkins called for more trims in the Parks Department budget as part of a package of cuts to pay for hiring more police officers.
In Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, the clean-up staff has been cut 30 percent in the last two years, said Paul C. Berizzi, the park's administrator. ''There's a lot of litter and illegal dumping of cars, and we just can't keep up anymore,'' he said.
The capital budget for building and restoration, which is financed separately by city bond issues, was also cut this year from $146 million to $135 million. ''A lot of high-priority projects got knocked out or delayed, and it looks bleak for the coming years,'' said Diana Chapin, the department's deputy commissioner for planning. Projects in poorer areas, like ones in Thomas Jefferson Park in East Harlem and Belmont Playground in the Bronx, have been especially hard hit, she said.
 
'The Fear Is There'
Crimes like the rape of a jogger in Central Park last year have also increased fear among park users. There are no citywide statistics on crimes in parks, and the number of major crimes in the Central Park precinct declined slightly last year, according to the Police Department. But parks like Tompkins Square, Washington Square and Marcus Garvey Park are notorious sites for drug-related crimes. A recent count found 1,600 homeless people live in Manhattan parks.
''The fear is there,'' said Debbie King of the New York Road Runners Club. ''People are running more together, but if you can't go into our parks except in groups during the day, what's the point of having parks?'' She said that the number of attacks that are reported to her group, like the rape of a woman a week ago last Sunday morning in Inwood Hill Park in upper Manhattan, has increased in the last year.
But the most significant effect of the department's financial problems may be that the city will be unable to acquire new park lands before sites are lost to private development.
Community advocates and environmentalists have particularly urged that former commercial waterfront in Brooklyn and on the West Side of Manhattan be converted to parks. One of the sites of much contention has been the 76-acre Penn Central Railroad yards between West 59th and West 72d Streets owned by Donald Trump. ''I'd like to acquire it,'' Mrs. Gotbaum said, ''but the site belongs to Trump, and the city doesn't have the money.''
 
Needs of Brooklyn and Queens
Although nearly one-fourth of the Bronx is park land, the borough's big parks like Pelham Bay and Van Cortlandt are in the middle-class north, with few open spaces in the South Bronx. In Brooklyn and Queens, the two boroughs with the lowest percentage of city park land, the central section of the former and the northwest part of the latter ''urgently need new parks,'' Ms. Davidoff of the Parks Council said. While the National Park Service operates Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge at the south edge of the two boroughs, other natural areas like Udalls Cove in northeast Queens and Spring Creek in Brooklyn are unprotected.
The creation of Staten Island's 1,780-acre Greenbelt was one of the Parks Department's major accomplishments of the early 1980's. But environmentalists say the city must act quickly to save the borough's other natural lands.
Mrs. Gotbaum acknowledged that if areas are not acquired, ''they'll go to ruin.'' But unless a state environmental bond issue passes this fall, she said, the city cannot afford to acquire much land and if it could, it would have trouble paying to maintain new parks.
In an effort to alleviate the department's financial problems, Mrs. Gotbaum has expanded the year-old City Parks Foundation and embarked on an aggressive private fund-raising drive. She has raised about $350,000 during her first seven months, and has convinced corporations to ''adopt'' parks for contributions of $5,000 to $250,000.
 
Working With Schools
Fees have also been imposed this year for previously free services like summer day camp and preschool, and the department may increase what it charges the 350 park concessions, which provide about $18 million a year.
Although there have been volunteer planting and clean-up campaigns like the annual You Gotta Have Park festivals for several years, Mrs. Gotbaum has enlisted 35 volunteer Urban Park Rangers to supplement the 184-person paid force. Last month, she initiated an antilitter drive in which park visitors seen picking up litter are given tickets to Mets games or other prizes.
The Commissioner is also forging closer ties with other agencies, like the Board of Education and Departments of Environmental Protection and Cultural Affairs, whose purviews overlap that of the Parks Department.
Representing her emphasis on recreation, which Mrs. Gotbaum calls her No. 1 goal, several schools will begin this fall to use city centers for sports instruction, said William T. Castro, the assistant commissioner for recreation.
''We're not just throwing up our hands and saying, 'We have less resources, so we're going to do less,' '' said Robert L. Garafola, the department's deputy commissioner for management. ''We're going to make every effort to equal what we did in the past. But it's going to be difficult.''

THE OIL JOLT
 
President Bush ordered the Navy to intercept Iraqi oil shipments and all but limited humanitarian imports of food and other supplies, carrying out his threat to blockade Iraqi commerce. [Page A1.] The world economy is in better shape to withstand higher oil prices and a drop in supplies than it was during the 1973 and 1979 oil shocks, economists and energy experts say. [A9.] 
 
Western Europe's buoyant economy will be slowed but not stopped by higher oil prices, economists say. Plans for a single market by the end of 1992, German reunification and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe are strong positive forces. [D1.]
 
Oil company officials do not expect new exploration and drilling to follow the sudden jump in crude oil prices. Their companies, they say, have not yet been persuaded that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will have a long-term effect on prices. [D1.]
 
The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait cut overseas stock prices, exaggerating existing problems like inflation, high interest rates and slowing growth in several industrial countries, including the United States. [D3.] In Japan today, concerns about the Middle East and widespread selling of cash-index positions caused the Nikkei stock average to plunge more than 5 percent, falling below the 27,000 level for the first time in more than two years. [D2.]
 
The freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets will not hurt banks in the U.S., according to Government data and industry estimates, although bankers complain of administrative headaches. [D3.]

A four-day-old strike at a General Motors parts plant in Flint, Mich., is affecting other G.M. plants and is becoming a factor influencing national contract talks between the Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union. [A12.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Americans Turn the Tables And Buy a British Agency

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
During the last decade, acquisitive British advertising agencies snapped up some of Madison Avenue's most famous names - Ogilvy & Mather; Ted Bates; Compton; Backer & Spielvogel and J. Walter Thompson.
Now, the tables have been turned. On Friday, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles bought Yellowhammer, one of London's largest and most well-respected agencies.
The Yellowhammer deal is likely to be but the first in a series of acquisitions by large American agencies that have already begun shopping in London's Soho district, where many British agencies have their offices, some industry analysts and British advertising executives said. McCann-Erickson has reportedly been looking over London agencies and Grey Advertising unsuccessfully tried to buy Yellowhammer. 
Charles Channon, a spokesman for the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, a trade group for British agencies, said there appeared to be a number of agencies for sale. Already, a handful are looking for buyers.
Would-be buyers may well be compiling shopping lists, and it would be no surprise if the lists included some of British advertising's most well-known names, like Collett Dickenson Pearce & Partners, Bartle Bogle Hegarty and Cowan Kemsley Taylor, which was started earlier this year by a group of executives from Saatchi & Saatchi's London office.
British agencies are attractive to their American counterparts for several reasons. London is an ideal base for American agencies that want to increase their presence in Europe and take advantage of the boom in advertising that is expected to follow the lifting of trade barriers in the European Community at the end of 1992.
Some analysts predict that advertising spending in continental Europe will rise by at least 10 percent annually for the next few years. In comparison, spending in the United States is expected to rise at about half that rate.
Roy Bostock, the chairman and chief executive of D.M.B.& B., said Yellowhammer's reputation for innovative work for Barclays Bank, Fiat and the British Government would give D.M.B.&B. additional clout when it competed for European accounts.
D.M.B.&B., like other large American agencies, already has a well-established office in London, from which it controls its European operations. An easy way for American agencies to pick up new European clients, analysts said, is to buy British agencies.
Mr. Bostock said his agency was also interested in Yellowhammer because the agencies shared an important client, Fiat. Yellowhammer handles the Italian auto maker's advertising in Britain; D.M.B.&B. has the account in Spain, Italy and Greece. ''We want to build our Fiat business in Europe, and the addition of Yellowhammer is going to help,'' he said.
British agencies can now be bought at bargain rates because many are financially vulnerable, analysts said. High inflation and a depressed British economy have slowed advertising spending in Britain, and ad expenditures are expected to decline at least 1 percent this year, compared with a 12 percent rise in 1988 and a 3 percent increase in 1989.
''A lot of agencies are in trouble,'' said Chris Akers, an analyst with Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers in London. ''A few big agencies may see business grow by 5 percent or more, but many are going to see their business decline by 10 percent to 15 percent.''
Prices are also expected to be low because, by Madison Avenue standards, British agencies are small. A mid-sized agency in London has billings of about $150 million. In New York, middle-ranked agencies are at least twice that size, with billings of $300 million to $500 million.
Yellowhammer is a good example of how some British agencies have become vulnerable. The publicly owned agency, which has billings of about $120 million, had expanded aggressively into continental Europe in the last few years and had started a number of advertising and marketing subsidiaries at home.
When the British ad industry took a nosedive last fall, Yellowhammer found it increasingly difficult to service its debt and the agency went into receivership last week, said Jon Summerill, the agency's chairman.
D.M.B.&B. had been eyeing Yellowhammer for some time, said Graham Hinton, the co-chairman of D.M.B.&B.'s London office. Mr. Hinton moved quickly, completing the complicated deal in just five days. And while he would not disclose the terms of the agreement, Mr. Graham said he acquired Yellowhammer at a ''very good price.''
Mr. Summerill said some Yellowhammer's subsidiaries like Generator, a small agency, would probably be sold in management buyouts.
Yellowhammer will remain a separate operation, Mr. Hinton said. But, he said, Johan Fourie, a D.M.B.&B. executive, has been named Yellowhammer's managing director to give the agency some ''of our discipline and grit.''
And, while Yellowhammer's house is being put in order, Mr. Hinton said, he is keeping an eye open for another acquisition. ''When the right agency comes along at the right price,'' he said, ''I'll buy it.''

LENGTH: 1328 words

HEADLINE: Europe's Quick Pace May Slow a Bit

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The higher oil prices that are likely to be the legacy of Iraq's military moves in the Middle East will slow but not stop the buoyant economy of Western Europe, economists say.
Before the current crisis, Western Europe seemed to have everything going for it. The 12-nation European Community's program to turn itself into a single market of 325 million consumers by the end of 1992 had started an investment boom. Higher spending generated by German reunification and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe promised to keep Western Europe's economy growing.
The expectation among economists and oil companies is that the price of oil will stabilize at $23 to $25 a barrel - provided President Saddam Hussein of Iraq decides not to challenge the American-led forces in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. 
While those prices are about one-third more than those of a few weeks ago, ''oil prices would have to be a lot higher to put Europe into a recession,'' said Peter Gutmann, an economist at the National Westminster Bank, one of Britain's largest banks. Only a major disruption that sent prices beyond $40 a barrel could bring European expansion to a standstill, he said.
But that analysis by no means suggests that Europe will feel no pain. Oil at $23 to $25 a barrel will reduce economic growth in Western Europe by as much as one-half percentage point over a year and will increase inflation by one-half to 1 percentage point, most economists agree. The effects of such changes would quickly become apparent.
Economists now expect the average inflation rate for Western Europe to edge up to 5.5 or 6 percent by year-end, from about 5 percent now. Economic growth is expected to be about 2.5 percent in 1991, compared with the previously expected growth of about 3 percent. Last year, Western Europe's economy grew 3.5 percent.
There are a number of reasons why the oil crisis will not be felt as severely as the oil shocks of the 1970's.
For one thing, this increase is not nearly as great as those in the past. In 1973, prices quadrupled when Arab members of OPEC embargoed oil shipments to the United States and some of its allies. In 1979, after the fall of the Shah of Iran, prices doubled.
In addition, in inflation-adjusted dollars, the price of oil has fallen dramatically since the early 1980's, when it peaked at about $60 a barrel in today's dollars.
Western Europe has also become much more energy efficient. ''Oil consumption relative to economic growth is much less than it was,'' said William P. Ledward, an economist at Nomura Research Institute Ltd., the London-based research arm of the Japanese securities firm. That dependency has dropped by about 30 percent since 1980, he estimates.
 
Strong Forces Behind Growth
Economists also think Western Europe is in better shape to weather higher oil prices because strong forces are behind its growth. These include the 1992 program and German reunification.
What happens to West Germany, whose gross national product accounts for 25 percent of the European Community's, matters a great deal to Western Europe. West Germany's growth is expected to slow to 3 percent to 3.5 percent in 1991 from 4 percent this year. But economists say they are not worried.
With German reunification, ''the strongest impetus for growth in Europe is the acceleration of domestic demand in Germany,'' said John Lipsky, director of international research at Salomon Brothers in London.
A growing number of economists expect the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, to lead an interest rate increase on the continent to make sure that the higher oil prices and heavy public spending related to German reunification do not ignite inflation, now 2.4 percent.
They say the Bundesbank could raise rates by a half to three-quarters of a percentage point within three to six months, which would increase short-term German rates to as much as 9 percent. That means the dollar, which has recently been weakening, could fall during the next six months to perhaps as low as 1.50 marks, from near 1.60 marks now.
Economists in Western Europe are also confident that the higher oil price will not mean a return to the days of raging inflation. One reason, they say, is that central bankers will act more decisively this time to make sure inflation does not take hold.
In addition, labor markets are not as tight as they were in 1973 and 1979 in many countries, making it less likely that higher oil prices will set off a wage-price spiral as they did in the past. Although the level of wage increases has been rising in Britain in particular, and to a lesser extent in West Germany and Italy, economists had already been expecting a moderation next year.
While Britain's unemployment is now a low 5.7 percent, it is beginning to rise. And reunification with East Germany will ease some labor shortages in West Germany, where unemployment is 7.1 percent. In addition, unions are much weaker in countries like Britain and France than they were in the 1970's.
''I don't think the rise in inflation is going to be a self-generating problem,'' said George A. Magnus, chief international economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in London.
 
Impact Will Vary
While Western Europe as a whole is in good shape to weather the higher oil prices, the effect will vary from country to country.
The impact will be somewhat less in France, for example, which gets a relatively large portion of its electricity from nuclear power plants. Italy is more vulnerable because its power plants burn more oil. Energy-producing countries like Norway, Denmark and the Netherlands will be even better off, said Mr. Ledward of Nomura.
Britain, with its North Sea oil fields, is a small net exporter of oil. That means the higher oil prices should have a positive, if minor, effect on its trade balance, which has been deeply in the red.
On the other hand, Britain's economy is currently the weakest of any major country in Western Europe, and its inflation, at 9.8 percent, the highest. A base interest rate of 15 percent has already caused a recession in the commercial and residential real estate markets, and the Confederation of British Industry had warned that the manufacturing sector was on the verge of a recession even before Iraq invaded Kuwait.
 
European Monetary System
Because they expect Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government to ease interest rates, many economists expect Britain to avoid a recession. As a matter of fact, they think the higher oil prices will cause the Government to lower interest rates sooner rather than later and to join the European Monetary System, which would tie the pound to the mark.
The Conservative Government has to hold an election by July 1992, and probably would like to hold one next year if possible. That means getting the economy moving again. And if the Bundesbank raises interest rates, economists reason, Mrs. Thatcher will have to join the European Monetary System so she can lower British rates without causing the value of the pound to plummet.
 
British Credibility
Although lowering rates is often inflationary, tying the pound to the mark would give Britain credibility in the financial markets in connection with its willingness to fight inflation.
Mrs. Thatcher has promised to join the system, whose member currencies are managed so their value relative to one another does not radically change. So far Mrs. Thatcher has had to be dragged, kicking and screaming, to join the system. She has no desire to see the European Commmunity become a United States of Europe and she fears that proposals to create a single European currency and a central bank will be a big step toward just that.
During the summer, John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, made comments that have led analysts to believe that Britain would join the system in the fall. The higher oil prices, said Christopher Dillow, a Nomura economist, ''mean we're still on course.''

HEADLINE: Crisis at Top Loan Insurer: A $1.5 Billion 'F'

SERIES: Students in Default: A troubled Agency - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The nation's largest guarantor of student loans is facing a financial crisis because its borrowers defaulted on $1.5 billion in obligations in the last two years. And on Capitol Hill, some legislators are saying that the $2 billion the Treasury spends each year on student loan defaults is a sign that the Government's policies toward such loans are lax.
Education experts say the troubles at the largest guarantor, the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, might be the blow that forces changes in how student financial aid is administered.
Students are currently eligible for federally insured loans regardless of their credit histories and earning potential. Because banks know they are likely to be reimbursed 100 percent for any losses on student loans, they typically exercise little or no credit judgment in making them. That policy, enacted by Congress during the Administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, may be cast aside if the foundation's problems turn out to be more than an isolated case. 
The Higher Education Assistance Foundation backs $9.6 billion in loans made by banks, savings and loan associations, credit unions and other financial institutions to students for college and vocational study. In turn, at least 80 percent of its commitments are backed by the Government.
The foundation recently told the Government it was having trouble covering the loans it had guaranteed, because of a sharp increase in defaults, particularly among vocational-school students like those studying to be truck drivers, hairdressers and court stenographers. The roughly $1 billion in defaults forced the foundation to make such large payouts that a cash squeeze is threatening its survival. Government officials say the agency's troubles will not affect the availability of new student financial aid, although some banks are backing away from the foundation's program.
 
Effort to Avoid Federal Bailout
Education Department officials say they are working on ways to avoid using public money to resolve the foundation's problems.
The foundation has already been lent money by the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, a federally chartered but shareholder-owned corporation, and earlier this month Sallie Mae said it would provide up to $200 million more in emergency financing to keep the organization afloat.
But tax dollars may have to be used to meet the foundation's obligations if a private-sector rescue cannot be arranged. Coming at a time when billions of Federal tax dollars are already being used to rescue hundreds of savings and loan associations, the mere chance of a Federal bailout of the foundation is sounding alarms on Capitol Hill.
Some legislators worry that a bailout of the troubled agency could cost hundreds of millions of dollars.
''It is the question of whether or not there has been diligence in seeking strong, stern measures to control defaults and to stop those who would abuse the system,'' said Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.
Ted Sanders, the Under Secretary of Education, has said six other federally backed guarantee agencies are also having financial difficulties. $14 Billion in Loans Guaranteed The Higher Education Assistance Foundation is a private, nonprofit company based in Overland Park, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City. A subsidiary of the HEAF Group, the foundation is one of the oldest of 58 agencies, some privately owned, others state controlled, that were established by the Government in the mid-1970's to relieve it of the administrative burden of guaranteeing payment on student-loan defaults.
Since it was started in 1977, the foundation has guaranteed more than $14 billion in student loans. Last year alone, it guaranteed $1.79 billion in new loans, 14.6 percent of all such loans made in 1989.
Under pressure in recent years as loan losses mounted, the Government put some restrictions on its repayment rates to agencies like the foundation that have a high default rate. If any of the 58 agencies have 9 percent or more of their loans go bad, the Government limits reimbursement to 80 percent on any further defaults.
 
More Pressure on Banks Likely
Even if a liberal lending policy is retained, financial experts say the system needs to be refined. The Government is likely, these people say, to force banks to be more discerning by limiting reimbursements.
''It seems to fly in the face of all sound principles of lending money and issuing insurance,'' said Thomas Wheeler, the president of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.
The Higher Education Assistance Foundation was incurring sizable losses well before it got into its current pinch, but when the Education Department announced that the foundation was experiencing ''serious financial problems,'' a slow, steady decline turned into a free fall. A number of lenders indicated that they would never again do business with the foundation; other lenders said they would seek to have their student loans insured elsewhere until they could be confident that the foundation was solid.
 
Range of Agency's Default Rates
''The 'Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval' was removed by the Department of Education,'' said David Westbrook, a spokesman for the foundation. ''We now need to put it back on.''
Mr. Westbrook said the overall default rate on loans in the foundation's portfolio ranged from 4 percent to 17 percent, depending on the state. He added that those default rates were roughly twice as high as those for healthier guarantee agencies. The foundation's average default rate is 35 percent on loans to students who attended trade schools. At some trade schools, the rate is as high as 68 percent.
Some people involved in the rescue efforts say that the foundation may be beyond repair and that a takeover of the troubled agency may be necessary.
One possibility is that the foundation's loan guarantees would be assumed by Sallie Mae. Sallie Mae buys student loans from banks, credit unions and other educational lenders, and adding a guarantee business like the foundation's might be a logical extension. Another possibility is that the foundation would be carved up and its obligations assumed by other federally insured agencies.
 
Possibility of Fraud
Some experts suggest the foundation's difficulties may stem more from fraud among vocational schools than from deficiencies in the foundation's management.
''There are a number of unscrupulous trade-school operators who have made a handsome living at the expense of the student-loan program and of American taxpayers,'' said David S. Hochstim, a financial institutions analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''They bilk the system by luring students in, obtaining the proceeds of their student loans and not providing a valuable education. The students then typically default, often not even aware that they obtained loans for which they now have obligations to repay.''
In recent years, trade-school loans have shown a default rate four times that of conventional student loans. Yet the foundation managed to become the nation's leading backer of these shaky borrowings, at one point devoting 65 percent of its guarantees to them.
 
Students' Problems Cited
The foundation is required by various state and Federal laws to take on this risky business, but one question that will undoubtedly arise in upcoming Congressional hearings is whether the foundation's management actively pursued the bad business.
For their part, representatives of trade schools say the problem is not with trade-school curriculums but rather with the financial condition of many trade-school students.
''The problem is that we have made poor people borrow too heavily to finance their education,'' said Steven Blair, president of the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools. ''If you took our students and placed them in a two-year college or a four-year university, their rate of default would be the same.''
The toughest questions are likely to be directed at Richard C. Hawk, the foundation's chairman and chief executive. A former assistant dean at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Education, Mr. Hawk is a founder of the foundation. Mr. Hawk, who declined to be interviewed, helped build the foundation into a nationwide operation with 800 employees.

D8)

HEADLINE: New Boom In U.S. Oil Is Doubted

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Executives of American oil companies say they do not expect the sudden jump in crude oil prices to stimulate exploration and drilling because they have not yet been convinced that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will have a long-term effect on prices.
In addition, industry experts say, the drilling industry withered during the 1980's and does not have the capacity to sustain a sharp increase in activity now. And even if there were the ability, the multinational oil companies have concluded that geologic prospects are better abroad than in the United States, so most new investment would be overseas.
The companies say their profits from drilling done in previous years will rise this year because the oil now being pumped is suddenly worth more. But money spent now to look for a new oilfield might not result in oil being brought to market before the invasion is just a memory. 
 
Riding Out Price Fluctuations
''The lead times are so long, you'd just be nuts to change your basic investment strategy on the basis of price changes in one week,'' said John Lord, a spokesman for the Mobil Corporation. ''You're talking about investments that won't come on stream for 5 years, if you're lucky, or maybe 10 years.''
Mobil bases its investments in exploration and production on an internal estimate of oil prices three years into the future, and has not changed its current estimate for the next three years, Mr. Lord said.
At the Exxon Corporation, the largest American oil company, which will spend $7.5 billion to $8 billion this year looking for oil, William Smith, a spokesman, said: ''Exploration and production budgets are based on long-term considerations. It would seem premature to base E. and P. plans on recent events.''
 
Long-Term Strategy
Shell said in a statement: ''Shell Oil's exploration and production program is based on long-term strategy rather than short-term reactions to market swings or other economic factors. We have not made any changes to our E. and P. programs based upon the Iraq-Kuwait situation.''
At Conoco Inc., which will spend about $2 billion this year and probably the same next year on exploration and production, Constantine Nicandros, the chairman, said that higher prices would have to persist for a year before planners believed that they were here to stay.
Ten years ago, when the Iranian revolution made prices triple and economists were predicting that oil prices could only rise from there, Mr. Nicandros said his company, a subsidiary of the Du Pont Company, and many others had drilled wells that would be profitable at $30 or $40 a barrel, only to see the prices fall to less than $10. ''The cemeteries are full of people like that,'' he said.
At another big oil company, an executive who agreed to speak only if he was not identified said of the recent surge in prices, ''even if it stays up for a year, that isn't very important to drilling plans.''
''The important thing is what will the price be in six years,'' he said.
The companies will continue to seek permission to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska and in offshore areas where they have been barred. And they will argue that the turbulence in the Middle East shows the significance of the United States' dependence on imports, which is now near 50 percent.
 
Drilling Abroad
But even if the companies decide to drill more, a larger volume of drilling would follow the same pattern as current drilling: mostly abroad. Because the United States has been so thoroughly drilled compared with the rest of the world, industry officials do not believe that the decline in American production would stop even if oil stayed at $25 a barrel for the next few years. But some experts add that production of gas, which substitutes for oil in many industries, could grow if the increase in oil prices helps pull the price of gas out of its current slump.
But the state of the drilling industry complicates that prospect.
''The only way to drill more is to have more rigs running, and there are not that many rigs that are available to go to work anymore,'' said James M. Nicklos, an oil driller and the former president of the Houston chapter of the International Association of Drilling Contractors.
At the peak of the oil boom, in the early 80's, more than 5,000 rigs were running; about 1,000 are operating now. Mr. Nicklos once ran 15; now he has 2, and is building a third.
''Nobody really knows how many more rigs there are available to go to work,'' said Mr. Nicklos, who estimated there were 1,500. ''We've been in the process of buying rigs recently, and the equipment's dried up. There's not much out there.''
''You can't just go to a supply company and say 'I want a rig,' '' he said. ''They're not even set up to build them.''
