HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Airlines in Pull Of Global Magnet

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE changes wrought by airline deregulation since 1978 go on and on. Many fares were cut drastically. Routes within the nation were revamped. The industry became concentrated in the hands of nine major carriers. And now globalization is bringing a new upheaval.
Globalization means, in effect, that simply being a domestic airline is no longer enough. The new view is that long-term survival also requires a network of flights between the United States and numerous foreign cities. Some carriers, particularly American Airlines, believe in globalization more enthusiastically than others, like USAir. But willingly or not, all the big carriers are being drawn into overseas expansion. 
''If you are going to take full advantage of your domestic market, then international growth is almost unavoidable,'' said Donald J. Carty, an executive vice president at American Airlines.
The reasons are plain enough. One is that passenger traffic between the United States and other countries has been growing at more than 15 percent a year since 1987, while passenger traffic on domestic flights has hardly increased at all. Secondly, the fares are not subject to the discounting that cuts into profits on domestic flights, because international fares are mostly regulated through bilateral agreements. And finally the new hub-and-spoke route structure in the United States almost requires the airlines to expand overseas.
The hub airports developed by the top airlines in recent years are usually in large cities and are fed by numerous ''spoke'' flights from smaller cities. Thus, Delta Air Lines channels passengers into its Atlanta hub for Delta flights to London, Paris and Frankfurt. USAir feeds into Pittsburgh for a recently inaugurated daily flight to Frankfurt. For example, five people bound for Frankfurt, fly in to Pittsburgh from Louisville, Ky., five more from Akron, Ohio, and so on. Without USAir's Pittsburgh-Frankfurt flight, each of these feeder trips might carry five fewer passengers, depriving USAir of the extra domestic revenue. The same Louisville passengers, wanting to get to Frankfurt, might instead travel via Delta to Atlanta.
''If the airlines don't have international operations, they are depriving themselves of the opportunity to carry those passengers over their domestic legs,'' said William Boyd, an analyst at the Transportation Department.
Such economics explains why the nation's carriers are scrambling for overseas routes. American, for example, recently bought Eastern's Latin American routes and is acquiring flights as rapidly as it can to Europe and East Asia. It is bidding, in one case, against United, Delta and Contintental for a soon-to-be-awarded Tokyo-Chicago route.
Dozens of alliances and joint ventures are also being struck with foreign carriers, the latest being the announcement last week that the Scandinavian Airlines System had agreed to increase its ownership stake in Continental Airlines. Whether an equity stake or a marketing agreement, the goal of these arrangements is to serve routes that airlines do not yet want to fly themselves. Thus, American Airlines feeds passengers into a Cathay Pacific flight from Los Angeles to Hong Kong, and USAir, through a deal with Alitalia, allows a passenger in Rome to check his bag through to Akron as if he were making the entire trip on a single airline.
USAir is also seeking authorization to fly its own planes between Philadelphia and Paris and between Pittsburgh and Manchester, England. But USAir's specialty is serving small American cities, and it lacks the wide-bodied jets usually used in international service. ''We will take advantage of market opportunities, but we won't expand on a global basis in a big way,'' said John Bronson, a USAir spokesman.
That decision might someday cost USAir its place among this country's Big Nine, those carriers with more than $1 billion in annual revenue. Today, American, Delta, United and Northwest are thriving as domestic and international carriers. Continental is just behind them in size. Trans World Airlines and Pan Am are fading, in part because they lack extensive domestic routes to feed international flights. USAir and America West Airlines, while strong at home, are fledglings abroad.
Fledglings are exposed to two dangers. One is that the Federal Government might award new overseas routes to the four or five carriers with the strongest international operations. The other is that the Government might someday permit Lufthansa or KLM or Alitalia or some other foreign carrier to operate flights within the United States, in exchange for that same right for American carriers in Europe.
No United States carrier officially favors this much deregulation. Even Alfred E. Kahn, the architect of deregulation in the Carter Administration, acknowledges that a USAir, lacking an extensive overseas operation, might not win out in competition on its home turf against a KLM or a Lufthansa. And the Big Nine might become the Big Six or the Big Five.
